webTitle: Champagne breakfasts and batting collapses that blazed a trail for England cricket tours

fields.headline: Champagne breakfasts and batting collapses that blazed a trail for England cricket tours
fields.trailText: It had been, said England's cricket captain Nasser Hussain last week, "a wickedly hard and arduous tour and the guys can't wait to get home and rest up". Fair enough - and British Airways club class awaits them at Harare next week, once all their golf clubs are safely stored in the hold.
fields.body:
It had been, said England's cricket captain Nasser Hussain last week, "a wickedly hard and arduous tour and the guys can't wait to get home and rest up". Fair enough - and British Airways club class awaits them at Harare next week, once all their golf clubs are safely stored in the hold.

Might any of Hussain's weary men give a thought this morning for the primitive founders of their feasts? On February 13 1862 was begun what is acknowledged to be the first ever "Test" match, between an All-England XI and XXII of New South Wales & Victoria Combined at the Outer Domain, Sydney. Crowds of 10,000 watched. The contest continued through February 14 and 15.

Prophetically enough, having won the toss, the English innings collapsed twice for totals of 60 and 75 and the 22 locals won by 12 wickets. In David Frith's new and unputdownable history of that seminal trip (The Trailblazers, Boundary Books, £14.99), one could mischievously change the names of the tourists' openers, from Bennett and Iddison to Butcher and Atherton, and the report could have been filed from Africa all of 138 northern winters later.

"Bands played and drums banged and scorecard vendors shouted. There was a sense of occasion as 'the test of the tour' commenced just after 12.30 with the entry of the umpires. Bennett took strike for All-England, facing George Gilbert, with George Moore bowling from the other end. All went according to expectation, with Bennett and Iddison both missed in the deep, before the first wicket went down at 21. From that point on thrills rippled round the ground as England lost all 10 wickets for a further 39 runs."

A team of English cricket professionals had crossed to north America and played eight matches in 1859. That inspired two Australian catering entrepreneurs, Christopher Pond and Felix Spiers (who owned Melbourne's Piazza Hotel, the Theatre Royal restaurant and the Café de Paris), to consider a cricket tour as an alternative to their originally proposed lecture tour by the novelist Charles Dickens, who had twice turned down their huge £10,000 offer (the great man, alas, was never to visit Australia).

With shades of Kerry Packer and Ali Bacher recruiting Englishmen more than a century later, Spiers and Pond dispatched their agent, Barlow Mallam, to England with instructions to offer the 12 best cricketers £150 a head (about £7,000 today) and all expenses paid for a tour of some dozen matches in the new colony that winter.

George Parr of Nottinghamshire was reckoned to be England's "Prime Minister" of cricket and, on behalf of his men, he stood out for more money. But Surrey's Heathfield Stephenson (a famed name in Victorian cricket who had been vice-captain to Parr on the American trip) persuaded half a dozen of his Oval confreres to make up the body of the team, which left Liverpool on October 20 aboard Brunel's great, and also aptly pioneering, SS Great Britain. Just 12 cricketers - and, note, no sign of a manager, scorer, physiotherapist, bowling coach, batting coach, fitness coach, psychologist, press officer, baggage-exec. . .

The voyage took more than two months and there were more than 10,000 "animated locals shouting at the arrival of cricketers from 'home'" when Stephenson led his men ashore at Melbourne's Sandridge Railway Pier on December 23.

They had arrived to cheer up a sad young colony. In the first week of December the skeletons of the two intrepid explorers, Burke and Wills, had been discovered in the outback. On December 14 Prince Albert had died at Windsor. Faraway Australia had been ordered to grieve and was dutifully doing so.

Melbourne's population was 120,000 (nearly 70% British-born), and that of Australia, still in gold rush mode, was now more than a million. Not only did English cricketers auspiciously arrive in Melbourne in 1861 but so did a mewling babe named Helen Mitchell (later Diva Dame Nellie Melba). That November also saw the first running of the horse race for the Melbourne Cup (Archer at 6-1, Johnnie Cutts up).

The England cricketers won four and drew two of their opening matches in front of thrilled crowds. There were banquets and festivities to mark every stop. To Sydney and the "Test" - and suddenly two batting collapses and ignominious defeat. Over February 13, 14, and 15 the scores were: England XI 60 and 75; Combined XXII 101 and 35 for nine.

Only Surrey's leftie George Griffith (11 and 38) made a double-figure score in either innings. To no avail in the Combined second innings did the Surrey bowlers "Terrible Billy" Caffyn and Tom Sewell take respectively six for 16 and three for 14.

"Immediately the theorising began," writes Frith. "Was all the travelling weakening the Englishmen? Not only were there suggestions in some quarters that the match might have been 'thrown': they were over-indulging off the field of play."

The latter was possibly so. Years later in his biography 71 Years Not Out, Caffyn recalled "scarce a day passed without our being entertained to champagne breakfasts, luncheons and dinners."

On February 16 1862 the Sydney Morning Herald presciently and solemnly announced: "A new cricketing era has doubtless commenced . . . from this date cricket becomes the leading national pastime of Australia."

Stephenson's pioneers drew their 14th and last match at Melbourne on March 22 and arrived home, via RMS Northam on May 12 after 206 days away.

webTitle: Camara snapshot puts Reds in picture

fields.headline: Camara snapshot puts Reds in picture
fields.trailText: Liverpool may no longer be in a league of their own but they continue to pursue a Champions League place with an awesome sense of purpose. Yesterday's narrow victory over Arsenal was achieved through a nice piece of larceny by Titi Camara accompanied by dedicated, disciplined defending that recalled the era of Bill Shankly when nothing, absolutely nothing, was given away.
fields.body:
Liverpool may no longer be in a league of their own but they continue to pursue a Champions League place with an awesome sense of purpose. Yesterday's narrow victory over Arsenal was achieved through a nice piece of larceny by Titi Camara accompanied by dedicated, disciplined defending that recalled the era of Bill Shankly when nothing, absolutely nothing, was given away.

Gérard Houllier's European mix frustrated Arsenal's attempt to spring back after their unexpected defeat at Bradford City the previous weekend. Dennis Bergkamp began his first match since late November and Patrick Vieira was also back after injury but neither was able to inspire Arsène Wenger's team sufficiently to find a way through a thicket of forest-green shirts.

Liverpool have now won 10 games out of 14 and taken 32 points out of a possible 42, rising from 12th to third in the process. When it comes to talking titles, however, Houllier, like David O'Leary at Leeds, is a reluctant optimist.

"The team is making progress," said Houllier. "We are mentally tougher than we were a year ago and more composed. But as for winning things, well there are a lot of games to go."

Nevertheless, having defeated Leeds and Arsenal on successive weekends, Liverpool's manager may permit himself a few silent cheers. Both victories have been achieved without the match-winning capabilities of Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler, whose injuries appeared to leave Houllier with a minimal choice up front.

If ever there was a time for Arsenal to end a run of 13 unsuccessful encounters with Liverpool this seemed to be it. The reality, however, was that once the opposition had taken the lead just past the quarter-hour Arsenal appeared less and less likely to break Wenger's duck against the one Premiership side he has yet to beat.

"It was a frustrating game for us," Arsenal's manager admitted. "We had the ball but they had the chances."

Arsenal's cause was not helped by the kick on the knee that forced Emmanuel Petit off at half-time. Yet by then Liverpool had already had to adjust to the loss of Steven Gerrard, with a recurrence of a groin injury, just past the half-hour and the way they coped encapsulated the spirit and discipline of their performance.

With Vegard Heggem, the substitute, at right-back and Jamie Carragher moving from back four to midfield, Liverpool continued containing the runs of Vieira while denying Bergkamp and Thierry Henry their normal attacking channels. Time and time again, just when Arsenal thought they had created space for a scoring chance, a Liverpool player would intercept a pass or make a covering tackle.

Thus after a crisp, confident opening Arsenal's football steadily congealed. Had Bergkamp been fully match fit he might have produced the moment of genius needed to outwit Houllier's centre-backs. As it was, Sami Hyypia commanded the Liverpool penalty area from start to finish.

In the 18th minute, as Arsenal's defenders pushed forward in a ragged line, Gerrard's quick through ball sent Camara clear with Lee Dixon keeping the Guinean onside. Camara slipped the ball past the advancing David Seaman and Liverpool knew they had a lot of defending to do.

They went about the business with such aplomb that few shots came through to Sander Westerveld. And when Westerveld did miss a centre from Oleg Luzhny, who had just come on for Fredrik Ljungberg, in the 78th minute Dominic Matteo made an excellent interception to stop the ball reaching Silvinho at the far post.

However, Liverpool enjoyed one piece of luck. Near the end a corner from Davor Suker, Bergkamp's replacement on the hour, evaded Westerveld and fell to Vieira, who from a narrow angle produced a shot that glanced off the bar.

But by then Liverpool should have put the game beyond reach. At the end of the first half Erik Meijer, sent clear by Camara, saw his shot blocked by Seaman and in the 70th minute Danny Murphy, having come on for Meijer, failed to exploit a similar opportunity after a Martin Keown mistake.

Vladimir Smicer, a feathery presence in this sort of game, wasted an opportunity to complete Liverpool's victory in added time after Carragher's horizontal header had sent him through.

 Arsène Wenger risked a row with Kevin Keegan when he ruled Tony Adams out of the England squad. The Arsenal manager insisted there was "no chance" of his defender playing against Argentina a week on Wednesday. Adams has been out for a month with a foot injury but Wenger said: "It's not that he's not fit, it's just not acceptable that he could play for England without having played for Arsenal. So there is no chance of him joining up if he is picked - especially for a friendly."

webTitle: Kennedy ensures blue moon follows red sunset

fields.headline: Kennedy ensures blue moon follows red sunset
fields.trailText: Among the numerous songs Manchester City supporters sing about their unspeakable red-shirted rivals, just about the only one which is printable is the quaint little ditty: "Never felt more like singing the Blues when City win and United lose."
fields.body:
Among the numerous songs Manchester City supporters sing about their unspeakable red-shirted rivals, just about the only one which is printable is the quaint little ditty: "Never felt more like singing the Blues when City win and United lose."

The only problem is that the opportunity to sing it arises once in a blue moon. It was understandable, therefore, that two middle-aged chaps were belting out the song with considerable gusto in the streets of Moss Side a good two hours after the final whistle on Saturday.

At the end of a week that has seen a Manchester bookmaker pay out three months early on bets that United would retain the Premiership title, this was as good as it gets.

Joe Royle's team will in all probability be promoted back to the Premiership in the coming months but United, despite their capitulation on Tyneside, are still on course to dwarf any achievement their neighbours might manage.

City supporters have seen enough false dawns in their time to know that being in the top two in mid-February is no guarantee that the season will not end in tears.

Yet the manager, Joe Royle, seems to have rid them of the sado-masochistic streak that has defined the troubled recent past.

"There has been a change of feeling at this club. This used to be the sort of game where the fans would be on the edge of their seats fearing that the opposition would score," he said. "We got there in the end. My feeling was that it was going to be one of those frustrating games where we draw or lose to a breakaway. But we are made of sterner stuff these days."

The home side played well only for two 10-minute spells at either end of the game, but it was enough to claim three precious points to keep them in touch with the leaders, Charlton, who also won.

Mark Kennedy, the Republic of Ireland winger, having created Shaun Goater's opener, hit two late goals to subdue Norwich, who had looked good value for a draw after Iwan Roberts headed a first-half equaliser from Chris Llewellyn's well-placed corner.

Royle praised Kennedy as his side's "match-winner" and added: "It's a confidence thing with him, and in the last two games he has looked to be back to his best.

"We started like a house on fire. But their equaliser rocked us, and they made it very difficult with bodies behind the ball. But Kennedy changed all that. He's capable of getting 15 goals a season, and I hope that will encourage him."

Norwich's manager Bruce Rioch must have had mixed feelings at seeing someone he had signed as a 16-year-old when he was at Millwall deny his side a point.

"We deserved to get something out of the game," Rioch said and then, referring to Kennedy, added: "We go back a long way, and I know he has a lot more to offer. He has a great talent, a great left foot; he can cross and shoot. But he has got to keep driving himself forward."

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText: Merry Millers
fields.body:
Merry Millers

Terry Dolan's first game in charge of York ended in disappointment when Rotherham opened a three-point gap at the top of the table with an injury-time goal from Gary Branston securing a 2-1 win. Barry Conlon had earlier cancelled out a seventh-minute opener from Leo Fortune-West.

 Swansea were yesterday forced to battle for a 0-0 draw at improving Cheltenham and the point that keeps the Welsh club firmly in second place. Controversy reigned early in the second half when Swansea's goalkeeper Roger Freestone handled outside his area. But he escaped with a booking and the free-kick came to nothing.

 Macclesfield kept their first clean sheet in seven games to seal a 2-0 victory over Barnet, the one-time runaway leaders.

 Marco Gabbiadini scored his 19th goal of the season as Darlington closed on the top three with a 4-1 win at Exeter.

Hartlepool's play-off hopes suffered a set-back with a 2-1 defeat to Southend at Roots Hall. Martin Carruthers took his tally for the season to 14 with a goal two minutes before the break and another two minutes after.

 Shrewsbury ended a run of seven games without a win with a 1-0 victory over Leyton Orient, beaten for the first time in nine games.

 The bottom club Chester earned a goalless draw with Hull, the first time in 13 games Chester have not conceded a goal.

fields.headline: Nationwide First Division
fields.trailText: Fulham fired
fields.body:
Fulham fired

Fulham remain in contention for the play-offs after ending Portsmouth's mini-revival with a 1-0 win at Fratton Park. Tony Pulis's side had won their previous two games but Bjarne Goldbaek's 72nd-minute goal moved the visitors into eighth place.

 Stockport's manager Andy Kilner was furious after the referee disallowed a last-minute effort by James Gannon against Queens Park Rangers. Chris Kiwomya scored in the 78th minute to give Rangers a 1-1 draw.

 Clinton Morrison earned Crystal Palace a point with a late goal against Sheffield United. Marcus Bent's seventh goal in seven games had given United the lead.

 West Brom won for the first time in 15 games with a 1-0 victory over Crewe.

 Swindon kept a clean sheet for the first time in 14 games in a 0-0 draw at Blackburn.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText: Gregan's glee
fields.body:
Gregan's glee

Preston were the only one of the top three to win, Sean Gregan's 25-yard drive at Chesterfield moving them two points clear at the top. The hosts remain one place off the bottom.

 Wigan were booed off after what was only their second defeat in29 league games, a 1-0 reverse at home to lowly Colchester, for whom Steve McGavin's header did the trick.

 Bristol Rovers had to make do with a point against Scunthorpe, who had their manager Brian Laws ordered from the dugout in the first half. Mark Walters put the hosts in front but Chris Hope deservedly levelled it.

 Reading's 2-0 win against high-flying Millwall made it four games without defeat . Phil Parkinson and Nicky Forster did the trick, and the Lions slipped to fifth.

 Burnley moved up to fourth after a 1-0 win at Bournemouth, where Ian Cox was given a standing ovation a week after his recent move to Turf Moor. Andy Payton got the winner with his head.

 "This result has come at the right moment," said Peter Taylor, the Gillingham manager, after their 3-1 win at Oldham, a first on their travels since November and a timely boost for Sunday's trip to Chelsea.

Andy Payton got the winner with his head.  "This result has come at the right moment," said Peter Taylor, the Gillingham manager, after their 3-1 win at Oldham, a first on their travels since November and a timely boost for Sunday's trip to Chelsea.

fields.headline: Venezia player 'attacked'
fields.trailText: Three Cagliari players were yesterday accused of attacking a Venezia rival in the dressing room after losing their Serie A relegation battle 3-0.
fields.body:
Three Cagliari players were yesterday accused of attacking a Venezia rival in the dressing room after losing their Serie A relegation battle 3-0.

Maurizio Ganz, who scored two of Venezia's goals, claimed that Cagliari's goalkeeper Alessio Scarpi, the Uruguayan defender Diego Lopez and midfielder Daniele Berretta carried out the attack on Fabian Valtolina, a 28-year-old midfielder who was taken to hospital by ambulance.

Fabio Capello was almost as enraged after his Roma side were held 2-2 at Perugia and proceeded to accuse the officials of treating his team like naughty schoolchildren.

The Roma coach had been ordered to leave the dug-out with eight minutes to go after he had disputed a corner from which Perugia equalised.

Francesco Totti was sent off in the first half for a push on the referee after he had just booked Roma's captain for dissent at a free-kick.

"Referees treat us like children," Capello said. "I don't understand why every Sunday we have to hold out our hands to be caned."

Uefa has declared that it is unhappy with the idea of European clubs taking part in Fifa's World Club Championship. Gerhard Aigner, chief executive of European football's governing body, said: "Uefa is not convinced about the viability of sending representatives to the second edition - if there is one."

fields.headline: Stewart answers Ipswich's prayers
fields.trailText: Evolutionists in Ipswich finally have something to smile about. After three years of fruitless searching, it seems the missing link has been found.
fields.body:
Evolutionists in Ipswich finally have something to smile about. After three years of fruitless searching, it seems the missing link has been found.

Not that Charles Darwin need turn in his grave. Having fallen agonisingly short of promotion to the Premiership with three successive play-off semi-final defeats, George Burley may have found the key to realising his side's ambition - a ruthless goalscorer.

Marcus Stewart inevitably scored the winner on Saturday in his home debut against Huddersfield Town, the club he left for £2.5m two weeks ago, and his partnership with David Johnson could steer Ipswich into one of the two automatic promotion spots. Heaven help the Portman Road faithful if it must be the play-offs once more.

Ipswich are unbeaten in their last 16 league games and with the youthful talents of Jamie Clapham, James Scowcroft, Matt Holland and Richard Wright they have a side capable of prospering in the top flight. Should they fail this season, the promising group could be torn apart.

Stewart, having just arrived, is determined to see the squad remain intact. "We've got just as good a chance of going up as in the last three years," he said. "But in the past the luck hasn't gone with Ipswich. Hopefully I can bring the extra bit of luck and we can go up automatically. I've scored two goals in two games and I'm delighted to have scored the winner against a club I love."

Refreshingly, the away fans reciprocated his feelings and chose not to harangue their former hero. Stewart responded by missing when unmarked after 70 minutes with his first clear chance.

But he made amends with his next touch. Fed by Clapham, he turned and planted his shot precisely into the far corner from the edge of the area. It was no more than Ipswich deserved, despite wasting a dominant opening to the second half in which Johnson had a penalty saved, only for Huddersfield to equalise through Dean Gorre after 56 minutes. Scowcroft had given Ipswich the lead with a tap-in from six yards after Holland's header hit the post.

For Steve Bruce's side, who led the division at Christmas, the play-offs are now the only realistic target. The sale of Stewart could hit them harder than they expected.

fields.headline: Dispute clouds Cameroon win
fields.trailText: Cameroon became the champions of Africa for the third time yesterday with a dramatic penalty shoot-out victory over the hosts Nigeria.
fields.body:
Cameroon became the champions of Africa for the third time yesterday with a dramatic penalty shoot-out victory over the hosts Nigeria.

The 4-3 win, after the match had finished 2-2 following extra-time, was steeped in controversy after Victor Ikpeba's fourth penalty for Nigeria was not awarded by the Tunisian referee Mourad Daami despite appearing to cross the line after hitting the underside of the crossbar.

Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu had earlier seen his penalty, Nigeria's third, saved by Boukar Alioum.

After Marc-Vivien Foé of West Ham had spurned the first chance to win the game for Cameroon, placing his penalty wide of the post, Liverpool's Rigobert Song held his nerve to seal victory.

Nigeria had recovered from two goals down to force the game into extra-time. Samuel Oto'o silenced the 40,000 fans at the Surulere Stadium with a superbly taken goal in the 27th minute. The Real Madrid teenager controlled a quick free-kick before turning past Furo Iyenemi and firing a shot into the far corner.

Cameroon quickly doubled the lead when Nigeria's goalkeeper Ike Sharunmu let a shot from Patrick Mboma squirm through his legs.

Twice Cameroon spurned chances to put the result beyond doubt. Oto'o hit a shot at the legs of a defender after Sharunmu stumbled outside his penalty area, before Mboma's 41st-minute header struck a post.

The hosts scored a desperately needed goal just before half-time when Chukwu Ndukwe made the most of poor Cameroon marking to finish from close range. Then Jay-Jay Okocha marked his return to the team after a one-match suspension with a stunning 25-yard shot to make it 2-2 within 90 seconds of the restart.

Cameroon had beaten Nigeria in the African Nations Cup finals of 1984 and 1988 but they squandered several more chances to seal a comfortable victory this time, with Eto'o especially unlucky to see a 51st-minute shot bounce back off the post.

"All credit to the players because they could have easily lost faith after Nigeria made it 2-2," said Cameroon's coach Pierre Lechantre. "But they came out fighting and showed how determined they were to win this cup."

Nigeria, unbeaten at home for 19 years and defending an 11-match unbeaten run in the tournament, took the game to Cameroon in extra-time, Babangida and Ikpeba both coming close to scoring as penalties loomed. But they could not put an end to Cameroon's jinx over Nigeria.

Meanwhile South Africa's Mark Fish announced his retirement from international football after South Africa's 2-1 victory over Tunisia in the third-place play-off, citing distaste for the South African federation as the reason for his decision. The Bolton defender, who has 58 caps, said he was unhappy with the treatment of the coaching staff and the way football is run in South Africa.

Nigeria (4-4-2): Shorunmu; Okpara, Iyenemi, West, Babayaro; Oliseh, Adepoju (Ikpeba, 96min), Okocha, George (Babangida, 70); Kanu, Chukwu (Aghahowa, h-t).

Cameroon (3-5-2): Alioum; Song, Kalla (Mettomo, 93), Njanka; Foé, Wome, Njitap, Mayer, Olembe; Mboma, Eto'o (Job, 72).

Referee: M Daami (Tunisia).

webTitle: Platt breathes easy after remembering his lines

fields.headline: Platt breathes easy after remembering his lines
fields.trailText: David Platt's theme after this match was the thin line between success and failure, and he should know better than most. Platt saw his own playing career rocket following one second of magic 10 years ago when he volleyed England into the World Cup quarter-finals.
fields.byline: Neil Moxley at the Bescot Stadium
fields.body:
David Platt's theme after this match was the thin line between success and failure, and he should know better than most. Platt saw his own playing career rocket following one second of magic 10 years ago when he volleyed England into the World Cup quarter-finals.

This win, Forest's first away league success since October, may prove equally important in terms of his managerial career. Defeat would have left Forest one point above the relegation zone. Instead, with three of their next four games at home, survival now seems a far safer bet.

Platt made five changes after last week's 3-1 defeat by Manchester City, bringing the loan signing Tony Vaughan in to shore up the defence and dispensing with anyone resembling a winger. It took a bizarre goal from an Alan Rogers free-kick to set Forest on their way, the ball evading a cluster of heads and bouncing in past an unsighted James Walker.

Gabor Bukran then rattled the crossbar for Walsall with a drive, mirroring Mark Robins's first-half effort that also bounced off the woodwork. These were the two examples seized upon by Platt afterwards to illustrate the margin between glory and failure.

"I might try and retain the pressure on us for next week's game against Crystal Palace," Platt said. "We responded well to that today."

Putting pressure on players instead of the manager; there's a novelty. Platt had better hope his theory does not backfire, lest the thin line between success and failure rear its ugly head again.

fields.headline: Odds stackup againstWilson
fields.trailText: Danny Wilson's season is fast approaching the point of no return but he remains willing to put his money where his mouth is. After yet another afternoon of despondency the Sheffield Wednesday manager, perhaps from a sense of duty more than anything else, was still bullish enough to accept a £10 wager that his team will not be relegated.
fields.body:
Danny Wilson's season is fast approaching the point of no return but he remains willing to put his money where his mouth is. After yet another afternoon of despondency the Sheffield Wednesday manager, perhaps from a sense of duty more than anything else, was still bullish enough to accept a £10 wager that his team will not be relegated.

If this tepid display is the sum of his side's resistance, Wilson will be paying out sooner rather than later.

Wednesday's season reached its crossroads a long time ago and several wrong turns later they now find themselves heading into a cul-de-sac.

If 40 points is the benchmark for survival, Wednesday must conjure up 23 from their remaining 13 games to harbour any real ambition of clambering to safety. To date they have amassed 17 from 25. With those statistics, it is no wonder Wednesday's brass band have suddenly lost their oomph.

Blaming Wilson remains an unpopular pastime, usually indulged in only by busybody parliamentarians. He clearly has a lot of neutral friends left over from Barnsley's brief flirtation with the big time but he has inherited a poor side and contrived to make it even worse.

Why he was named manager of the month for January remains a mystery, although the joke among the Sheffield United supporters is that the presentation was made by the reigning boxer of the month, Julius Francis.

Instead most of the bile was directed towards the club's chairman Dave Richards. His loyalty to Wilson remains undiminished but his perceived lack of foresight has prompted the Wednesday Independent Supporters' Association to petition for his removal from office. Whether it will have the desired effect is doubtful.

There was no such doom and gloom for Southampton. Their feats of escapology have become almost legendary in recent years and the signs point to an unusually premature happy ending to their perennial struggles.

This was their fourth win in five games and their second in succession since Glenn Hoddle ended his sabbatical and breezed into The Dell. "That's six points out of six and I'm delighted," said football's most famous side-parting.

It was not pretty, far from it. But Southampton's optimism was understandable after Jo Tessem had advanced from his wing-back role and stuck out one of his long legs to turn in Matt Oakley's cross in the 26th minute.

The advantage was defended with a dogged determination although it was almost forfeited within three minutes when the Saints keeper Paul Jones rugby-tackled Gilles de Bilde, only to redeem himself with an outstanding save from the resulting penalty, which De Bilde took.

"On another day it could have been a red card," said a less than happy Wilson, adding: "But we probably needed seven of them sent off to do us any good."

De Bilde's faux pas was a prelude to Wednesday hoisting the white flag and the home side failed to muster a single effort on goal during the second 45 minutes. When the inevitable happens, it is unlikely the man who takes Wilson's money will put it towards a copy of the club's end-of-season video.

webTitle: Francis has need of a fitting finisher

fields.headline: Francis has need of a fitting finisher
fields.trailText: It was in this corresponding fixture almost 29 years ago to the day that the world beyond Birmingham became aware of Trevor Francis when he scored all his side's goals in a 4-0 win. The feat prompted Bolton's record scorer Nat Lofthouse to describe the 16-year-old as "the next Jimmy Greaves".
fields.body:
It was in this corresponding fixture almost 29 years ago to the day that the world beyond Birmingham became aware of Trevor Francis when he scored all his side's goals in a 4-0 win. The feat prompted Bolton's record scorer Nat Lofthouse to describe the 16-year-old as "the next Jimmy Greaves".

How a Francis would have thrived on Saturday given the incisive approach play by City that ensured the visitors' rearguard afforded their goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen about as much protection as a knotted hankie in a tempest.

Yet perversely, despite having Francis as their manager, City's finishing is invariably more miss than hit. Ask Allan Johnston. Earlier this season the Scottish winger spent some time at St Andrews on-loan from Sunderland; now he is at Bolton and he needed just 20 minutes on Saturday to do what he had failed to do in 10 appearances for City - score.

Not only was his lob over the stranded Ian Bennett well executed, it was also against the run of play. By then City, who had spurned a catalogue of chances and continued to do so, should have been beyond recall.

As they surely would be at the top of the First Division if Francis was in his pomp on the pitch rather than forced to mastermind matters from the touchline.

Instead, their victory, courtesy of Isaiah Rankin and Dele Adebola finally coming good with second-half goals, has returned City to the play-off zone and done Bolton's top-six hopes no favours.

Francis, though, was more effusive about his strike pair than his side's rise up the table. "The league position does not concern me at the moment," he said. "But Adebola and Rankin are developing into a good striking pair and took their goals well."

He was not impressed by Eidur Gudjohnsen's last-minute challenge that left Martin Grainger in a heap and cost the Icelandic international a red card for violent conduct.

Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce felt his striker had been harshly treated. "The mayhem that followed probably made up the referee's mind to send him off," he said. "It was a poor decision." Francis was not so sure. "It was a striker's challenge," he said. Not one of his strikers, surely - more often than not on Saturday they would have failed to make contact.

webTitle: They woke up and it was all a dream

fields.headline: They woke up and it was all a dream
fields.trailText: Crisis? What crisis? Kenny Dalglish hardly looked like a man who had spent a few sleepless nights, his Celtic footballers looked as if they could play the game and their travelling supporters clearly were not the same people who had been trying to turn scarf throwing into an Olympic event. At Dens Park, there were actually smiles on faces.
fields.body:
Crisis? What crisis? Kenny Dalglish hardly looked like a man who had spent a few sleepless nights, his Celtic footballers looked as if they could play the game and their travelling supporters clearly were not the same people who had been trying to turn scarf throwing into an Olympic event. At Dens Park, there were actually smiles on faces.

Nor did the ghost of John Barnes hover over the match, the "head coach" being last seen with a burger and fries outside his house before leaving for Liverpool to resume private life. It was rather as if the past seven months simply had not happened.

Indeed, the atmosphere was improved enough for Dalglish to wax almost lyrical. Of course, three goals poured on old wounds is strong medicine.

But there were still things that jarred on a bitter day. Mark Viduka and Ian Wright made a big play of kissing their shirt badge, which was rather overdoing it. They are paid for their services and are not required to fall in love with the hand that signs the cheques. But at least everyone wanted to talk rather than sulk.

The Australian, whose dressing-room antics at half-time on Tuesday against Inverness Caledonian Thistle represented the first bit of the roof falling in, was positively chirpy. "My conscience is clear. Nobody got hit, as has been suggested. It was just an argument, nothing more. They happen in every dressing room and I think that the most disappointing thing is that it leaked out."

Dalglish significantly threw an olive branch to his fans by relegating the Israeli Eyal Berkovic to the bench. This was surely a signal that the caretaker manager believes, like themselves, that a player's shorts should get dirty while playing in a Scottish winter.

Olivier Tebily also started on the bench but came on to play surprisingly well as a wide midfielder. "I thought we had another Jimmy Johnstone out there," said Dalglish with only the slightest touch of irony. Jonathan Gould was left out, presumably as a scapegoat.

The Monday-morning question, though, is whether the director of football wants to stay in the dug-out. He keeps insisting he does not but softened his stance slightly on Saturday evening. "At the moment it feels good," he said, "but right now I don't think it will be me who is the next manager." Tommy Burns remains favourite.

Wednesday's CIS Insurance Cup semi-final against Kilmarnock will tell us more about the club's state of health.

Against a useful Dundee, every single player felt he had to tear into every tackle by way of atonement. That eventually set up three second-half goals for Johan Mjallby, Viduka and Colin Healy, but the sight of Alan Stubbs playing in midfield was a reminder of how slender Celtic's resources are with Paul Lambert out.

But that hardly mattered to the fans, who saw Rangers' lead cut to seven points. Within days they will have branded Dalglish as some kind of miracle worker and the soap opera - nobody say crisis - will go on its merry way.

 The Celtic-slayers of Inverness were brought down to earth at Love Street where St Mirren extended their lead at the top of the First Division with a 2-0 win. Caley enjoyed the grateful support of a coachload of Rangers fans, whose team were not playing on Saturday.

Of course, three goals poured on old wounds is strong medicine. But there were still things that jarred on a bitter day. Mark Viduka and Ian Wright made a big play of kissing their shirt badge, which was rather overdoing it. They are paid for their services and are not required to fall in love with the hand that signs the cheques. But at least everyone wanted to talk rather than sulk. The Australian, whose dressing-room antics at half-time on Tuesday against Inverness Caledonian Thistle represented the first bit of the roof falling in, was positively chirpy. "My conscience is clear. Nobody got hit, as has been suggested. It was just an argument, nothing more. They happen in every dressing room and I think that the most disappointing thing is that it leaked out." Dalglish significantly threw an olive branch to his fans by relegating the Israeli Eyal Berkovic to the bench. This was surely a signal that the caretaker manager believes, like themselves, that a player's shorts should get dirty while playing in a Scottish winter. Olivier Tebily also started on the bench but came on to play surprisingly well as a wide midfielder. "I thought we had another Jimmy Johnstone out there," said Dalglish with only the slightest touch of irony. Jonathan Gould was left out, presumably as a scapegoat. The Monday-morning question, though, is whether the director of football wants to stay in the dug-out. He keeps insisting he does not but softened his stance slightly on Saturday evening. "At the moment it feels good," he said, "but right now I don't think it will be me who is the next manager." Tommy Burns remains favourite. Wednesday's CIS Insurance Cup semi-final against Kilmarnock will tell us more about the club's state of health. Against a useful Dundee, every single player felt he had to tear into every tackle by way of atonement. That eventually set up three second-half goals for Johan Mjallby, Viduka and Colin Healy, but the sight of Alan Stubbs playing in midfield was a reminder of how slender Celtic's resources are with Paul Lambert out. But that hardly mattered to the fans, who saw Rangers' lead cut to seven points. Within days they will have branded Dalglish as some kind of miracle worker and the soap opera - nobody say crisis - will go on its merry way.  The Celtic-slayers of Inverness were brought down to earth at Love Street where St Mirren extended their lead at the top of the First Division with a 2-0 win. Caley enjoyed the grateful support of a coachload of Rangers fans, whose team were not playing on Saturday.

fields.headline: Dons dismay Sturrock
fields.trailText: Aberdeen, such a joke at the start of the season, had the last laugh yesterday when they gained a place in the final at the expense of Dundee United thanks to a late goal from Arild Stavrum.
fields.body:
Aberdeen, such a joke at the start of the season, had the last laugh yesterday when they gained a place in the final at the expense of Dundee United thanks to a late goal from Arild Stavrum.

The defeat certainly did not amuse the Dundee United manager Paul Sturrock, who immediately threatened to quit after heavy criticism from a supporters' group "United for Change". "Following this I will have to review my situation," said Sturrock. "I don't think players or myself should be treated in that way."

In truth, Aberdeen were just about the better of two very ordinary sides. Ebbe Skovdahl, the Dons manager, had kept very calm as weeks went by with his side unable to win a league match, and was entitled to a small grin at the end of a fiercely contested if hardly skilful semi-final, although Aberdeen's 78th-minute winner was finely fashioned.

The instigator was the Moroccan Hicham Zerouali, an unlikely recruit to the ranks of those who ply their trade at the wrong end of the Premier League, but who has become a cult figure in the Granite City.

Zerouali came deep to pick up the ball, looked forward and found that his only option was a pass to Andy Dow. Making up a lot of ground quickly, he received a return pass and fired in a shot across the face of the goal, and Stavrum simply diverted it into the net.

"It was good for us because the supporters have stayed with us even when things were difficult," said Skovdahl. "It was difficult to play on such a soft surface. Players were fighting for the ball because it was a cup tie and so it became hard to keep it on the grass."

Sturrock's mood was not helped as Craig Easton and Steven Thompson were shown the red card after the final whistle following a bust-up with the Dons' Rachid Belabed.

webTitle: Charlton's bandwagon leaves Wolves limping behind

fields.headline: Charlton's bandwagon leaves Wolves limping behind
fields.trailText: Ten out of 10 for Charlton. If they can make it 11 wins in a row at home to Fulham tomorrow, they will be seven points clear at the top and in possession of a club-record nine successive league wins. And if they can make it 12 out of 12 at Bolton on Saturday, they will also be in the semi-finals of the FA Cup.
fields.body:
Ten out of 10 for Charlton. If they can make it 11 wins in a row at home to Fulham tomorrow, they will be seven points clear at the top and in possession of a club-record nine successive league wins. And if they can make it 12 out of 12 at Bolton on Saturday, they will also be in the semi-finals of the FA Cup.

They may not be quite unstoppable, but on Saturday they were altogether too much for a Wolves team that began with restricted ambitions and a makeshift midfield and then lost two key players through injury.

"It was a solid performance," said the Charlton manager Alan Curbishley. "Even the bar at the end there done its job."

What distinguishes them is their speed and movement. They work the length of the field and they break out en masse. Even without Mark Kinsella, their captain and heartbeat, they were much too lively for a Wolves team that is a little sluggish around the edges.

Keith Curle may be almost as quick as ever, even at 36, but it is asking a lot of Neil Emblen and Steve Sedgley, who have done their share of defending, to keep up with the likes of Graham Stuart or Shaun Newton.

Neither of the goals were scored by strikers, which is some indication of where Wolves were having difficulty. The strikers, indeed, had a fairly undistinguished time of it. Martin Pringle, who had hardly trained after turning an ankle last week, took time to find any touch and never looked confident, but ran around to good enough effect to earn a standing ovation. And Andy Hunt, after hat-tricks in his past two games, made himself enough opportunities for another - he had five shots on target, as many as Wolves had in total - without causing the splendid Michael Oakes any distress.

Hunt did have the ball in the net just before half-time with a header from a set-piece after running his marker into a wall of players, but the referee raised some trivial objection.

Stuart made the breakthrough soon after, arriving late but with unshakable conviction on the end of a Pringle cross. Then Steve Brown, a central defender without any reputation as a goalscorer, struck an immaculate half-volley for the second.

It was Wolves' first defeat in six games and it cost them Andy Sinton, their most effective midfielder, who may have done ligament damage in a tackle that earned Stuart a yellow card.

This is what Wolves have come to expect: confirmation of their fears. They are the longest serving and suffering team in the division and are going to stay that way for at least another season.

fields.headline: Strachan fearful of falling cautions
fields.trailText: Peter Reid's rage was understandable but it was curious to hear Gordon Strachan also fearing for the future after a pulsating game won by a Coventry side embossing their increasing reputation for entertainment.
fields.body:
Peter Reid's rage was understandable but it was curious to hear Gordon Strachan also fearing for the future after a pulsating game won by a Coventry side embossing their increasing reputation for entertainment.

Strachan claimed his side had just given "the best attacking display I have ever seen at this ground", built on three goals in the first 18 minutes. Yet, on the evidence of this highly physical game, Coventry's manager fears that his work will be harmed if the recent softly, softly approach to issuing cards continues.

Strachan wondered why only four cautions were dispensed by Paul Alcock in a game replete with rash challenges, the tone being set by a high lunge from Nicky Summerbee on Stephen Froggatt that saw Coventry's left-back hobble off after 10 minutes with an ankle injury. Alcock ran out of patience in the 37th minute, booking Chris Makin for a relatively innocuous foul.

The caution count was 3-1 to Sunderland, yet Strachan accused neither them nor Alcock, preferring to blame policy.

"We've got to watch that we don't get back to the dark days of the 80s when you could intimidate," he said. "It's gone from nine bookings a game to next to nothing. If that was played a month ago, I don't think you'd have seen that many players left on the pitch."

Reid has other worries. "I'd like to apologise to our fans for the first 45 minutes. The first half was totally unacceptable. I haven't got words to describe it," Reid said of that period, but of course he had. "It was like Billy Smart's circus. But it will change, I can assure you."

Robbie Keane and Mustapha Hadji scored Coventry's openers but it was the third that illustrated their defensive incompetence as Hadji had time and space to usher in Cedric Roussel to fire home.

Kevin Phillips struck just before the hour, a supremely confident volley which sent out a message to Coventry - and to England. He then combined with Niall Quinn for Alex Rae's fly-kick two minutes from time. Fortunately for Strachan the woodwork denied Kevin Kilbane in the dying seconds. "Had it been 3-3," Strachan said, "I'd have been scratching my head for the rest of my life."

webTitle: The Smiths are still miserable now

fields.headline: The Smiths are still miserable now
fields.trailText: The Everton performance? Wonderful. And Joe-Max Moore? Awfully good. Not to mention Richard Gough. Love him. With the theatre luvvies poised to secure their takeover at Goodison - gosh, what a thrill - a whole new era is seemingly opening up for the tinseltown Toffees. Trust a dour Scotsman to bring matters down to earth.
fields.body:
The Everton performance? Wonderful. And Joe-Max Moore? Awfully good. Not to mention Richard Gough. Love him. With the theatre luvvies poised to secure their takeover at Goodison - gosh, what a thrill - a whole new era is seemingly opening up for the tinseltown Toffees. Trust a dour Scotsman to bring matters down to earth.

Like that Scottish play, better not to mention his name. And better not quote him directly, because he didn't want that. Suffice to say that the Everton manager, who ended this match in a high state of agitation, thought that his side should have nailed down the lid well before Avi Nimni's goal revitalised Derby, and reckons that his squad is not good enough. "Last year Derby were challenging for a place in Europe. Now, with virtually the same team, they are struggling to stay up," said Walter Smith, for it was he.

Understandably he did not want to single out the deficiencies in his team, but it is pretty obvious that unless the board stumps up big bucks Smith believes that Everton will remain at best an entertaining fringe production.

Much had been expected of Derby this season but the protracted and ultimately negative wrangle over the passport renegade Esteban Fuertes appeared to drain the club of dynamism.

Here, though, their plethora of possession was always on the point of being undone by dreadful defending. And then there was Uriah Rennie.

Rennie's refereeing moves in mysterious ways, its blunders to perform. Spencer Prior's challenge on Gough barely warranted a penalty, while the same player's trip on Nick Barmby certainly did. Rennie saw it the other way, and the timing of Michael Ball's penalty was crucial, Moore having scored from their only other attack.

"I don't know how they sleep at night. At worst it was obstruction but never a penalty," said Jim Smith, the Derby manager. But there was perhaps enough in this performance to persuade him that the relegation corner is being turned, albeit on wobbly wheels.

webTitle: Referees still 'trying to punish Di Canio'

fields.headline: Referees still 'trying to punish Di Canio'
fields.trailText: Whether Igor Stimac believes MI5 killed Princess Diana is unclear but he certainly sees a conspiracy against Paolo di Canio. When push comes to shove, the defender said, West Ham are paying for the Paul Alcock affair 17 months on.
fields.body:
Whether Igor Stimac believes MI5 killed Princess Diana is unclear but he certainly sees a conspiracy against Paolo di Canio. When push comes to shove, the defender said, West Ham are paying for the Paul Alcock affair 17 months on.

Twice Di Canio was fouled in the box, Stimac claimed, and twice Neal Barry played on. There could be only one explanation. "This referee wanted Bradford to win the game," the Croatian said. "His decisions were amazing.

"I think they are trying to punish Paolo di Canio for what he did more than a year ago. He's been punished by the FA, so referees should stop doing that. He had two clear penalties... What's the point of the rules? What's the point of referees?"

The defender's words amount to an accusation of professional misconduct, which might interest Lancaster Gate. At least Di Canio did not give the crowd a chance to see whether the soles of Barry's boots are sponsored. To suggest he was angry is an understatement.

Inside half an hour the Italian felt he should have had two penalties, although the first looked a dive. Stimac said: "At half-time he was very disturbed. He was out of control and we had to calm him down. He didn't want to come out for the second half. That's how frustrated he was. But I understand it because he cares."

Di Canio has a will to win which knows no bounds. It pains him, says his manager Harry Redknapp, to lose a five-a-side. Any perceived injustice turns a calm family man into a timebomb. So was Redknapp not tempted to substitute him at the interval? "Harry trusts Paolo," Stimac said. "He knows how far he can go."

Yet even Redknapp might have been surprised by Di Canio's antics when a third penalty claim was waved away in the 54th minute. Convinced he was fouled by Gunnar Halle - and replays suggested he had a point - the striker decided enough was enough.

Taking his shirt from his shorts, he ran to the bench, gesticulating wildly to be taken off before crouching on the halfway line. Thankfully for West Ham, who were 4-2 down, the manager ignored him. "He's my man to get us back in the game," Redknapp explained. How right he was.

From the start Di Canio behaved like an Italian told he did not know his tagliatelle from his tortelloni. He once indulged in a playground wrestling match with Frank Lampard for the right to take a spot-kick. Not surprisingly he won and scored.

The worry for Stimac is that Di Canio could turn his back on England. "They're pushing him too far," he said, "and it's sad because he's a great talent. Joey Cole says that every day he learns something from Paolo."

Di Canio, of course, can be partial to a bit of pushing himself. His behaviour was fitting on a bizarre afternoon which started with West Ham losing their goalkeeper Shaka Hislop for the season with a broken leg, saw his debutant replacement Stephen Bywater, nicknamed Boy Wonder, perform more like Boy George and ended with an astonishing West Ham comeback.

After going ahead through Dean Windass, Bradford fell behind to Trevor Sinclair and John Moncur. They seemed destined to win when Peter Beagrie equalised from the spot and Jamie Lawrence capitalised on two Bywater errors.

But Di Canio scored his penalty and Cole his first Premiership goal before the Italian set up Lampard's winner. "I could play a match in my back garden," said West Ham's captain Steve Lomas, "and it wouldn't be as mad as that."

webTitle: FA steps in over tunnel brawl

fields.headline: FA steps in over tunnel brawl
fields.trailText: The Football Association looks certain to impose severe punishments on Chelsea and Wimbledon following a mass brawl after the final whistle in the players' tunnel, during which the Dons' manager Egil Olsen was allegedly pinned against a wall.
fields.body:
The Football Association looks certain to impose severe punishments on Chelsea and Wimbledon following a mass brawl after the final whistle in the players' tunnel, during which the Dons' manager Egil Olsen was allegedly pinned against a wall.

The exact details of what occurred as the Chelsea and Wimbledon players walked off the pitch are hazy, because immediately after the incident the referee Peter Jones declared the tunnel a no-go area. Club officials then went to great lengths to play down the events with a childish misinformation.

It appears that between 16 and 22 players, plus Wimbledon's coach Mick Harford, were involved in the ugly scrap, which was sparked when Kenny Cunningham, who minutes earlier had been rowing head to head with Chelsea's Dennis Wise on the pitch, was doused with Lucozade.

With punches being thrown for several minutes, police were called. But they will not be taking any action, said a police spokesman, as the FA is dealing with it "in-house". The brawl took place right in front of the referee and he is bound to include details in his match report to the FA, with charges almost certain to follow.

"I don't know who started it," said Olsen later, "I'll have to find out." One of his players, Jason Euell, said: "It wasn't a bloodbath. I didn't see any punches thrown but there was a lot of pushing. It was obvious that no one wanted to back down. It was hard to see exactly who was involved but Mick Harford was trying to sort the situation out."

The brawl overshadowed a tough but ultimately thrilling game. OK, relegation-threatened Wimbledon had overdosed on frustration after seeing a 1-0 lead crumble to a 3-1 defeat in 17 minutes. Yes, Chelsea had overcome the jinx of taking only three wins from Wimbledon's previous 12 visits. But this was road-rage violence perpetrated by players prizing petty revenge over self-discipline.

What people should have been talking about was Chelsea's comeback within a comeback. After a stuttering start to their league season Gianluca Vialli's team have lifted themselves to fifth and sniffing distance of Europe after a ninth league game unbeaten.

Vialli credits the team's impressive run with playing only one match a week, with limited travelling involved. Ominously, though, in a fortnight Chelsea resume their twice-a-week schedule for a month, thanks to the Champions League and FA Cup.

Here they certainly made hard work of breaking down Wimbledon. It was only after the visitors took the lead on 73 minutes with a debut goal from the £2.5m striker Andreas Lund following a Wise error, that Chelsea sprang to life.

This was largely due to the introduction of Jody Morris and Gianfranco Zola, who cast off any thoughts of disgruntlement at his substitute's role to create openings.

Once Gustavo Poyet's audacious 20-yard volley had brought Chelsea level, Zola produced a trademark jink to feed Morris, whose cross was headed home by George Weah. Morris added a smart finish from the edge of the area. But then football gave way to all-in wrestling.

What people should have been talking about was Chelsea's comeback within a comeback. After a stuttering start to their league season Gianluca Vialli's team have lifted themselves to fifth and sniffing distance of Europe after a ninth league game unbeaten. Vialli credits the team's impressive run with playing only one match a week, with limited travelling involved. Ominously, though, in a fortnight Chelsea resume their twice-a-week schedule for a month, thanks to the Champions League and FA Cup. Here they certainly made hard work of breaking down Wimbledon. It was only after the visitors took the lead on 73 minutes with a debut goal from the £2.5m striker Andreas Lund following a Wise error, that Chelsea sprang to life. This was largely due to the introduction of Jody Morris and Gianfranco Zola, who cast off any thoughts of disgruntlement at his substitute's role to create openings. Once Gustavo Poyet's audacious 20-yard volley had brought Chelsea level, Zola produced a trademark jink to feed Morris, whose cross was headed home by George Weah. Morris added a smart finish from the edge of the area. But then football gave way to all-in wrestling.

webTitle: United living on a knife edge

fields.headline: United living on a knife edge
fields.trailText: A point has been reached that whenever Manchester United suffer a rare defeat one half- expects the odd curtain to be rent in twain. This was once the case with Liverpool but Anfield has not seen a league title for nine seasons. Nothing in football lasts for ever.
fields.byline: David Lacey at St James' Park
fields.body:
A point has been reached that whenever Manchester United suffer a rare defeat one half- expects the odd curtain to be rent in twain. This was once the case with Liverpool but Anfield has not seen a league title for nine seasons. Nothing in football lasts for ever.

Not that the champions' defeat on Saturday has dwelt a mortal blow to their chances of winning the Premiership for the sixth time in eight years. Nevertheless the result has made United catchable again and Leeds can draw level on points by beating them at Elland Road next Sunday morning, when the referee will need to combine the wisdom of Solomon with the vision of Superman.

For Newcastle the main significance of only their second victory over Sir Alex Ferguson's team in eight home games was that it confirmed Bobby Robson as a messiah with method. For once the Newcastle board got it right when they appointed Robson to clear up the debris left by Ruud Gullit; now they can go for the double by giving him a decent contract.

Robson is clearly loving every minute of it. "I like working at the wrong end of the table for a change,"he said after this win. "It's something I haven't experienced for something like 28 years, since my early days at Ipswich.

"Since then I've been England manager and worked with top clubs like PSV Eindhoven and Barcelona, where it's all about trying to win things. Now I've had to turn a poor side into a winning team. I took over a ship that was leaking."

Here Robson's ship came home amid wild rejoicing. Newcastle's victory was born of the striking partnership between Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson so long delayed by the latter's misfortune with injuries, and Ferguson left this match half-an-hour early with a strain.

Robson had been thinking about employing an extra defender to contain United but instead played Kieron Dyer and Kevin Gallacher either side of his midfield pair, Rob Lee and Gary Speed. In fact Gallacher, roaming free, was largely responsible for ending the early dominance of Roy Keane and Paul Scholes which at one stage promised United victory.

Ultimately, however, they contributed in no small part to their defeat, Keane's dismissal by Steve Lodge just past the hour virtually ending their chances of taking something from the game. Keane went for the sixth time in his career after a second booking for catching Lee with a late tackle from behind, but the United captain had set himself up for a red card with a crass piece of dissent directed at a linesman shortly before half-time.

A fortnight earlier pictures of Keane apparently leading a lynch mob towards Andy d'Urso in protest at a penalty decision against Middlesbrough persuaded Ferguson to admit that such behaviour was out of order. Yet here, after Keane had been sent off, Andy Cole argued himself into the book and later Jaap Stam was cautioned for haranguing a linesman. Three bookings for dissent did not suggest that the players had got the message.

"We were suffering from the Middlesbrough carry-on," Ferguson said. "That's what happens in football and we have to accept it. But it's important there's not a vendetta against us. The referee seemed keen to to get the boy off."

In fact Lodge had tolerated an earlier foul by Keane on Dyer and just before dismissing him had given United's captain the benefit of the doubt following a rash lunge, studs up, towards Newcastle's goalkeeper Steve Harper.

At the time United were smouldering with a sense of injustice, Cole's clever flick over Harper appearing to cross the line before the keeper grabbed the ball back. Yet it took an oblique television camera angle to reveal the truth of a matter hidden from the officials by Harper's bulk.

The fact that the case for leaving goalline judgments to an electric eye had been strengthened hardly helped Manchester United. At the time Newcastle were in danger of losing the lead they had taken after 26 minutes when Ferguson met a nod-down from Shearer with a sharp turn and a glorious left-foot volley inside the near post.

A man short, the other Ferguson bravely replaced Denis Irwin with Nicky Butt and played three at the back. But Newcastle gratefully plundered the extra space and Shearer beat Mark Bosnich from long and short range to cheer up the watching Kevin Keegan.

webTitle: Collymore heads for cracking his own conundrum

fields.headline: Collymore heads for cracking his own conundrum
fields.trailText: "Oh yes," said Martin O'Neill, responding to a change of questioning tack. "The match. Sometimes it almost seems a sideshow these days." Thank heavens, though, for Stan Collymore. As the main attraction the game could have driven strong men into clinics.
fields.body:
"Oh yes," said Martin O'Neill, responding to a change of questioning tack. "The match. Sometimes it almost seems a sideshow these days." Thank heavens, though, for Stan Collymore. As the main attraction the game could have driven strong men into clinics.

Everyone knows the man's qualities: pace, power, skill, strength in the air. Emile Heskey showed them in abundance, an indication to Collymore how far he has to go.

Of course the wayward one was out of touch, smudging lines that can be sharpened only by match practice. But after 11 months out of the Premiership, four since his last loan match with Fulham and weeks of false rumours and headlines he was back where he wanted to be.

O'Neill, expected to give him a late run, started him instead. At first he bumbled his control. Then he shot with absurd speculation, wanting too much too soon. But, as he picked up the pace, he became increasingly integrated in a three-man front line. "When we thought he might be getting tired, he got stronger," said O'Neill. Collymore was ever perverse. In truth he had not done enough to get tired. That was part of the problem at Aston Villa; he seldom did.

O'Neill, running with his psychological wheeze, kept him on to the end. He said beforehand: "Anything he does on the field is a bonus", as if he had signed him primarily for dressing-room harmony.

There was no sign of bonus until the last half-hour when two headers showed Collymore's talent and avowed hunger. Chris Day tipped the second away. For the first Collymore outjumped him and saw his soaring header come back off the bar. Far from cursing his luck he was up for the sequel, the natural reaction of one for whom team matters more than self.

Endorsing the impression of a changed man, he admitted to being nervous. "It's hard to describe what it's like to be back. It's like a dream." And until late on he played like a sleep-walker unaware of his stage. He thanked Leicester for making "him feel really welcome". The wages of thanks is effort.

Collymore, the gifted charmer who can strike with either foot and both personalities, continues to court goodwill before losing it. Graham Taylor, generous, civilising and so much an admirer that he owned up to having nearly picked him for England as a Southend player, popped in to wish him well. But for the time being Collymore remains a conundrum wrapped in contradiction and stuffed with scrambled ego.

Oh yes, the match. Nordin Wooter's deflected header matched Matt Elliott's cock-eyed opener. Was this the top level Collymore craved? Not for long in Watford's case, it appears. Or was it just a dream, the same old dream, soon to be fouled up once more?

fields.headline: Banks thrash out merger details
fields.trailText: High-level talks between NatWest and Royal Bank of Scotland will begin today, as the Scottish bank is expected to reveal it has won the backing of the majority of NatWest's shareholders for its £21bn takeover.
fields.body:
High-level talks between NatWest and Royal Bank of Scotland will begin today, as the Scottish bank is expected to reveal it has won the backing of the majority of NatWest's shareholders for its £21bn takeover.

The two sides - which failed to decide the terms of an "agreed" takeover despite months of behind-the-scenes attempts - will discuss integrating the two businesses in a process expected to involve cutting at least 18,000 jobs.

Shareholders in NatWest have until lunchtime to support Royal Bank's bid, which will create the eighth largest bank in Europe. But the official outcome, to be published at 5pm, is considered a foregone conclusion since NatWest last week gave up its four-month battle against the competing bids of Royal Bank and Bank of Scotland.

As the discussions between senior executives at the banks get under way, Royal Bank will be hoping its shares will recover stability. On the stock market, it has yet to be decided what the new combined entity will be called, although the NatWest name will remain on the high street.

Neither Sir David Rowland, NatWest's chairman and chief executive, nor Ron Sandler, the chief operating officer - who can both expect a £1m payoff for four months' work - want jobs in the combined organisation.

It is not clear whether other members of the senior executive team will stay on. They include finance director Richard Delbridge and Gordon Pell, lured from Lloyds TSB to run NatWest's UK operation only 14 days ago.

webTitle: FA charge four clubs after weekend of misconduct

fields.headline: FA charge four clubs after weekend of misconduct
fields.trailText: Leeds, Tottenham, Chelsea and Wimbledon were today charged with misconduct as the Football Association reacted to a weekend of disturbances in the Premiership. The four clubs have been charged with failing to control their players during the respective encounters at Elland Road and Stamford Bridge.
fields.body:
Leeds, Tottenham, Chelsea and Wimbledon were today charged with misconduct as the Football Association reacted to a weekend of disturbances in the Premiership. The four clubs have been charged with failing to control their players during the respective encounters at Elland Road and Stamford Bridge.

Individual misconduct charges have also been brought against Chelsea captain Dennis Wise, Wimbledon right-back Kenny Cunningham and coach Mick Harford, following a confrontation in the players' tunnel after the match. Leeds left-back Ian Harte has also been given a separate misconduct charge after his alleged stamping on Spurs' Chris Perry.

The FA have also written to clubs today to warn that they will be held responsible for players showing collective dissent towards match officials. The move comes after Manchester United were twice involved in such incidents in the last 16 days, against Middlesbrough and Newcastle.

fields.headline: The best host scene
fields.standfirst: House on Haunted Hill
fields.trailText: In the onetime Vannacutt Asylum - allegedly possessed by the ghosts of its inmates - entrepreneur and party-giver Stephen B Price (Geoffrey Rush) wanders among his guests. The house's owner, Watson Pritchett (Chris Kattan) approaches him.
fields.body:
In the onetime Vannacutt Asylum - allegedly possessed by the ghosts of its inmates - entrepreneur and party-giver Stephen B Price (Geoffrey Rush) wanders among his guests. The house's owner, Watson Pritchett (Chris Kattan) approaches him.

"Mr Price, I think I've done a great job of getting your guests here, and I think I deserve my money. Now."

"Right here, Mr Pritchett..."

Price waves a cheque in Pritchett's face, then snatches it away again, placing it in a box to his left.

"...As well as five other bona fide bank drafts for $1 million each. Made out to cash."

One of the guests, Eddie Baker (Taye Diggs) steps forward.

"And when do we get paid this money, sir?"

"The second the sun hits tomorrow morning. Assuming you have stayed the entire night."

He pauses.

"And that you're still alive, of course."

Sarah Wolfe (Ali Carter) turns to Price.

"What are you talking about?"

"Oh, sorry. A detail I guess I forgot to mention. You die - you lose. Your cheque gets divvied up by those still among the living."

The guests shuffle awkwardly.

"But look on the bright side! If there's only one of you still upright at dawn you'll be leaving here with $5 million in your pocket!"

See also: The Masque Of The Red Death, Performance, The Cable Guy

Don't see also: Stag Party

Pointless trivia: Geoffrey Rush's next two movie roles are the Marquis de Sade (in the forthcoming Quills) and - in vocal form - Bunyip Bluegum in the cartoon The Magic Pudding.

webTitle: Public inquiry announced into Marchioness disaster

fields.headline: Public inquiry announced into Marchioness disaster
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: The government is to set up a full public inquiry into the Marchioness   riverboat disaster, it was confirmed today.     Mr Prescott announced in the Commons that he had ordered a judicial inquiry   into the collision and the rescue operation that followed on the Thames in central London in 1989.
fields.body:
The government is to set up a full public inquiry into the Marchioness riverboat disaster, it was confirmed today. Mr Prescott announced in the Commons that he had ordered a judicial inquiry into the collision and the rescue operation that followed on the Thames in central London in 1989.

The pleasure craft Marchioness sank after a collision with the 1,475-tonne dredger Bowbelle on the Thames in London in the early hours of August 20, 1989.

51 people on the 90-tonne Marchioness died celebrating the birthday of London financier Antonio de Vasconcellos. Many survivors said that the resuce operation had been ineffective.

Mr Prescott said that the inquiry would have the power to obtain documents, issue summons and summon the attendance of witnesses.

There has never been a public inquiry despite a coroner's court ruling that the young people on board were unlawfully killed.

The Bowbelle captain, Douglas Henderson, was tried in 1991 on a charge of failing to keep a proper look-out. The jury failed to reach a verdict, as did another jury at a second trial, and Capt Henderson was formally acquitted.

One of the representatives of the victims' families who today met Mr Prescott, Shirley Bennett, said she was thrilled by the government's decision.

"I'm over the moon, although it is not before time, it's been 10 years. This inquiry will allow us to know what happened on that night," she said.

Another of those at the meeting, Malcolm Williams, who survived the disaster, added: "The inquiry will heal a lot of pain, a lot of hurt and anger. I have waited 10 years to find out why I was left struggling for my life in the water."
