webTitle: Prescott: 'a legacy of misery and grief'

fields.headline: Prescott: 'a legacy of misery and grief'
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: A little over 10 years ago on 20th August 1989 on a fine warm summer evening, 132 people were enjoying a riverboat party on the Thames.
fields.body:
A little over 10 years ago on 20th August 1989 on a fine warm summer evening, 132 people were enjoying a riverboat party on the Thames.

Within minutes their boat - the Marchioness - would be sunk, struck by a dredger, the Bowbelle. 51 young people would lose their lives and many more would be injured.

Many questions have remained unanswered about the cause of the collision, the reason why so many died, and the handling of the whole affair following the incident.

The search for the truth was not helped by the failure of the then Government to institute a full public inquiry.

On 18th August last year, I announced a wide-ranging Public Inquiry into safety on the River Thames and the circumstances surrounding the Marchioness disaster.

It was chaired by a senior judge, Lord Justice Clarke.

It was an open public inquiry. Its scope was broad and its examination detailed, including written and oral evidence.

For the first time all the relevant documentation was gathered together in one place and it allowed everyone concerned to make their case.

The inquiry reviewed current safety standards on the river and Lord Justice Clarke's report was published quickly, as requested on 2 December 1999.

Lord Justice Clarke was also asked to advise "Whether there is a case for a further investigation or inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the Marchioness disaster and its causes."

His second report, dealing with this issue, is being published today. Copies of both reports are in the library of the House.

I am greatly indebted to Lord Justice Clarke and his team for producing such thorough, well-considered and impressive reports so quickly.

Lord Justice Clarke recognises that the regulation of safety on the Thames is much improved since 1989.

This is due, in no small part, to the effort of the survivors of the Marchioness tragedy and the relatives of those who died.

The Government accepts all 44 of Lord Justice Clarke's recommendations. Ten have already been implemented on the Thames, and action is well advanced on implementing the rest.

I have today placed in the Libraries of both Houses an action plan on river safety. This explains how my Department, working with the Maritime and Coastguard Agency and the Port of London Authority, intends to implement the recommendations.

These include:  a consultation on the consumption of alcohol by people in charge of vessels;  funding a Formal Safety Assessment on "Search and Rescue" facilities on the Thames; and  funding the provision of experimental life saving equipment at locations along the Thames.

Although the inquiry's recommendations are confined to the Thames, our approach will be to pursue the recommendations on an UK-wide basis.

Safety is as important on other rivers as it is on the Thames.

Turning to Lord Justice Clarke's second report, he considers the case for a further investigation or inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the Marchioness disaster and its causes. Lord Justice Clarke concludes, and I quote, "I have no doubt in my mind that if such a tragedy happened today, there would be a widespread public demand for an inquiry. In my opinion such a demand would be entirely justified."

He goes on to say that the tragedy, "cried out for public scrutiny in order to discover how it was that such a terrible event could occur."

To put matters right, I can announce today that I have ordered a Judicial Inquiry under section 268 of the Merchant Shipping Act 1995 into the collision between the Marchioness and the Bowbelle and the search and rescue operation that followed the collision.

My Right Honourable and Noble Friend, the Lord Chancellor, has agreed to appoint Lord Justice Clarke to conduct the Inquiry which will have the power to obtain documents, to issue summons for the attendance of witnesses, to take evidence on oath and to order cross-examination.

Lord Justice Clarke considers that the scope of this Inquiry will be sufficient and that the public interest does not require a further inquiry into the Police investigation, the two inquests or the failure to secure criminal convictions.

The Government accepts his recommendations on these matters.

I commend Members of the House to read Lord Justice Clarke's searching and thorough review.

Lord Justice Clarke also addressed the question of the relationship between inquiries, inquests and criminal and civil proceedings.

This can be a cause of great frustration and is an issue which concerns me greatly.

This can sometimes lead to delays in inquiries, or in the publication of reports. These problems can extend far beyond transport.

We therefore need to consider his proposals carefully, across Government. The Government will report to Parliament when we are in a position to do so. However, on one issue, I intend to go beyond what Lord Justice Clarke recommends.

The bereaved families have expressed forcefully their great distress at the removal of the hands from the victims for fingerprint identification purposes, without advising the next of kin.

Lord Justice Clarke looked at this in detail but did not recommend that this be covered by the Inquiry.

However, in consideration of the anguish this incident caused I have set up a non-statutory public inquiry into this specific matter under Lord Justice Clarke to run side by side with the Judicial Inquiry.

The full terms of reference will be published today and have been placed in the library.

On the matter of the costs, I will look favourably on applications made by the relatives of the victims and the survivors for reasonable legal costs to be met from public funds.

Such funds need to be used efficiently so that work is not duplicated and that the Inquiry's timetable is adhered to. Lord Justice Clarke will ultimately decide on the award of costs at the Inquiry.

The Marchioness disaster was the last and worst of a series of collisions on the Thames.

It raised concerns about boat design, numbers of crew, the readiness of emergency services and the way people were treated after an incident.

The Marchioness families, and many others over the last 10 years have made representations to this Government and the last Government. They have felt strongly that no full public inquiry took place and they had limited opportunity to express their concerns.

In 1992, I myself condemned the "legal fancy dancing" which caused confusion and stood in the way of a full public inquiry.

The Marchioness families have lived with grief for 10 years.

A new public inquiry cannot bring their loved ones back. But it can, I hope, bring some peace of mind to know that their case can be told and lessons can be learned for the future.

fields.bodyText: A little over 10 years ago on 20th August 1989 on a fine warm summer evening, 132 people were enjoying a riverboat party on the Thames. Within minutes their boat - the Marchioness - would be sunk, struck by a dredger, the Bowbelle. 51 young people would lose their lives and many more would be injured. Many questions have remained unanswered about the cause of the collision, the reason why so many died, and the handling of the whole affair following the incident. The search for the truth was not helped by the failure of the then Government to institute a full public inquiry. On 18th August last year, I announced a wide-ranging Public Inquiry into safety on the River Thames and the circumstances surrounding the Marchioness disaster. It was chaired by a senior judge, Lord Justice Clarke. It was an open public inquiry. Its scope was broad and its examination detailed, including written and oral evidence. For the first time all the relevant documentation was gathered together in one place and it allowed everyone concerned to make their case. The inquiry reviewed current safety standards on the river and Lord Justice Clarke's report was published quickly, as requested on 2 December 1999. Lord Justice Clarke was also asked to advise "Whether there is a case for a further investigation or inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the Marchioness disaster and its causes." His second report, dealing with this issue, is being published today. Copies of both reports are in the library of the House. I am greatly indebted to Lord Justice Clarke and his team for producing such thorough, well-considered and impressive reports so quickly. Lord Justice Clarke recognises that the regulation of safety on the Thames is much improved since 1989. This is due, in no small part, to the effort of the survivors of the Marchioness tragedy and the relatives of those who died. The Government accepts all 44 of Lord Justice Clarke's recommendations. Ten have already been implemented on the Thames, and action is well advanced on implementing the rest. I have today placed in the Libraries of both Houses an action plan on river safety. This explains how my Department, working with the Maritime and Coastguard Agency and the Port of London Authority, intends to implement the recommendations. These include:  a consultation on the consumption of alcohol by people in charge of vessels;  funding a Formal Safety Assessment on "Search and Rescue" facilities on the Thames; and  funding the provision of experimental life saving equipment at locations along the Thames. Safety is as important on other rivers as it is on the Thames. Lord Justice Clarke concludes, and I quote, "I have no doubt in my mind that if such a tragedy happened today, there would be a widespread public demand for an inquiry. In my opinion such a demand would be entirely justified." He goes on to say that the tragedy, "cried out for public scrutiny in order to discover how it was that such a terrible event could occur." fields.headline: 17 for 5 and they still won
fields.trailText: In 1561 one-day internationals to date (Feb 14) the only time a team has been 21-5 (as South Africa were in the final of the triangular tournament against England) or worse yet went on to win was in the 1983 World Cup, when India were 17-5 v Zimbabwe at Tunbridge Wells but still won, mostly thanks to Kapil Dev's 175*. There have been 1345 ODIs since then.

webTitle: Tunnels, T-shirts and This day in history

fields.headline: Tunnels, T-shirts and This day in history
fields.trailText: WISE AFTER THE EVENT
fields.body:
WISE AFTER THE EVENT

Dennis Wise has been sitting nervously all day waiting for the phone to ring or the post box to bulge - but to no avail. It's Valentine's Day, for crying out loud! Don't the FA care at all?!? If David Davies and his lean disciplinary body really cared they surely would have sent a card. Or at least charged Dennis with misconduct after a initiating a mysterious mass brawl in the Stamford Bridge tunnel on Saturday.

Nobody seems to know exactly what happened at the end of Saturday's match between Chelsea and Wimbledon. But some of the reported highlights include: Egil Olsen getting pinned against a wall; an unknown player 'falling' down the stairs; Gianluca Vialli landing on the end of a headbutt; and big Mick Harford getting involved, with John Hartson and Vinnie Jones as backup. Robbie Earle claims "there was more action in tunnel than in the Tyson fight", while Hermann Hreidarsson reckons "it was not a big deal. This sort of thing happens in football because of people's emotions."

Or a person's emotions. Whatever else is said about the fight, everyone seems to agree that Dennis Wise started it. It was he who goaded Kenny Cunningham at the end of the game, and he who sprayed the Wimbledon defender with Lucozade as they departed down the tunnel. He also used his column in the Chelsea programme to offer the entire Wimbledon team out at paintball. Dennis already has the worst disciplinary record in the Premiership, and his continued antics puzzle the bejeasus out of most people. But perhaps he's just looking for a little love. Are you listening, David?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WACKY, ZANY, MAD, BONKERS, TIRESOME

Mike Reed, the Premiership's most controversial - yawn - and colourful - snooze - referee, certainly is a crazy kinda guy! Last week, he was reprimanded by the FA and taken off a televised match as punishment for celebrating along with Liverpool when they scored during a game he was officiating. But has that punishment quashed his sense of fun? Not a bonkers bit of it!

"I enjoy football and like to have a laugh and joke with players," Reed explained to the North Staffs Referee Club in Shelton (he gets all the big gigs). "We don't want to be like robots. Why shouldn't we smile and enjoy the game?'' To this end, Reed has lined up a zany jape for the last ever Premiership match he'll take charge of. What a character.

"I have a T-shirt made and will show it when a goal is scored in my last game!" tittered the cheeky ref. Mike, you crazy loon! "But knowing my luck it will be a 0-0!" We hope not. After all, the Fiver doesn't pay good money to see the players in action. No, we prefer to watch the man in the middle attempt to grab all the attention with a series of melodramatic flourishes and self-promoting gestures. We'll miss you when you go, Mike.

* Next month: experienced official Kevin Lynch. Anyone is welcome to attend the meeting at the Rectory Club, Rectory Road, Shelton, on Thursday March 9, starting at 7.30pm. If you decide to go, any minutes of the meeting will be gratefully received by the.boss@theguardian.com .

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It won't be special going back there one bit. I'm pretty upset with the way I was treated when I left. I helped them get promoted and they also reached a Coca Cola Cup Final. Then they made a £2m profit on me, and I'm the villain!" Paul Merson practices diplomacy ahead of his return to the Riverside.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HAPPY KOOGANDAY!

Kelvin Koogan is 49 years old today. He doesn't look it at all, does he readers? No, he looks like he's 85 and ought to be retired on grounds of being too old to do anything useful. But sadly, that's unlikely to happen (unless somebody is prepared to forge his birth certificate - which might be worth a pop). But what lessons can Koogan take from this celebration as he prepares to announce his squad to face Argentina?

Well, on this day in history Sir Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin (reports the Fiver's history expert Dr Franz Fiver). He observed in 1929 that after leaving a plate of staphylococcus bacteria uncovered overnight, a layer of mould had formed, similar to that which appears on bread, and killed much of the bacteria. Perhaps Kelvin Koogan should consider leaving a plate of bacteria out overnight, and see what happens. He may discover a new antibiotic. If that fails, he could always play the mould on the left wing.

Also on this day in 1779, Captain Cook was murdered by the natives of Hawaii. Cook, who had 'discovered' Hawaii only a few years earlier, was killed by the locals after he and his crew were adjudged to have overstayed their welcome. There are, of course, no lessons to be learned here for Mr Koogan, who remains a very popular England manager. But he may wish to tip the staff at Burnham Beeches a little extra next week just in case.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal are on the verge of signing Ronald De Boer. The Dutch international is tipped to leave Barcelona for Highbury, initially on loan. A permanent deal may be struck in the summer with Marc Overmars heading in the other direction.

Derby, West Ham, Sheffield Wednesday, Coventry, Southampton and Watford are all attempting to sign Rangers defender Colin Hendry on loan.

Everton will accept £500,000 for John Collins. According to the Sun, the Scottish international's former club Monaco are interested.

Preston and Huddersfield will bid for Manchester City winger Terry Cooke. Maine Road boss Joe Royle has accepted the 23-year-old player's transfer request.

Ruud Gullit has been lined up to replace Trott Moloto as coach of South Africa.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Clubs should be deducted points if their players continue to misbehave on the pitch, Professional Footballers' Association chief executive Gordon Taylor has claimed. "We don't want referees intimidated and we feel this is a matter of collective responsibility for players and also clubs. We feel clubs with bad records should be warned. If they don't listen to warnings, there's a view we could consider the deduction of points," he told Sky Sports News.

Muzzy Izzet has pledged his international future to Turkey. "I obviously had to sit down and do some hard thinking because I was born in England and was thinking I might have a chance of being called up by them," explained the Leicester midfielder. "But I have decided to take up Turkey's offer to play for them and I know that one person who is delighted for me is my father." Izzet hopes to break into the squad for Euro 2000.

Aston Villa striker Benito Carbone has denied reports that he has had talks with Fiorentina and has hinted that he wants to stay at the Midlands club. Carbone insisted: "There are four teams interested in me in Italy - but I haven't spoken to anybody. I would like to stay at Villa. I love this club and want to remain here."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm)
Informed debate instigated by Eammon Holmes. No, really.

Football Extra (12.35am)
All the action from the Deva Stadium. You don't need goals to enjoy a good match.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.15am)
Low-quality kick-and-rush rubbish from a historically poor league.

Sky Sports 1: Monday Night Football (7pm, 12.15am)
Andy Gray moves some magnetic things around a shiny green table, and then Middlesbrough play Aston Villa.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.45pm, 2.15am)
If McCaff isn't good enough for Lionel Bienvenu, he isn't good enough for the Fiver.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 11pm)
Frank Finlay's 1965 portrayal of Iago in Olivier's Othello will never be bettered, argues Dean Holdsworth.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm)
Archie MacPherson takes us on a tour of Dartmoor, Wandsworth and Wormwood Scrubs. No, hold on, that's Eurogaols.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
A man sits in a stand. He is cold.

webTitle: Carve-up for the online cash cow

fields.headline: Carve-up for the online cash cow
fields.trailText: 10 reasons why you won't become an internet millionaire . . .
fields.body:
10 reasons why you won't become an internet millionaire . . .

Admit it. You've got a great idea for an internet business. You're fed up of reading, and possibly writing, about other journalists becoming millionaires and you just know that it's your turn now. Well, I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but there's a pretty good chance that it's not going to happen. Why? Well, here are 10 reasons for a start . . .

1. Someone else has already had the idea

A great stumbling block for journalists, who are often so wrapped up in their world that they fail to notice what's going on around them. I haven't yet had someone say: "Here's a great idea. Let's sell books over the internet", but I've had plenty of similar ones. The simple rule is if you've had the idea, then at least five other people have as well. If someone else is already doing it, then at least 10 other people are planning to do the same. And, if you find yourself saying "Yes, they've done it, but we're going to do it better" then stop immediately. Best is not as important as biggest or first.

2. You haven't got a domain name

The system for registering domain names is rather silly and frustrating, but it's the only one there is. Journalists may be skilled at snappy headlines or choosing a title for a section or magazine, but this is in a different league. Rather than coming up with an idea and then spending six months trying to find a domain name that fits, it is almost better heading to www.register.com to see if you can find a good, available name and then finding an idea that will work with it.

3. You don't care about technology

Big mistake. Your biggest problems will be with technology. You will spend more time screaming at computers of all kinds than you ever deemed possible. The technology behind a big website is now scary, and there is no simple out-of-the-box solution that will let you build a serious site in the same way you can, say, buy Quark and start producing a magazine. And no matter how much you outsource, you should know now - it will never just sort itself out.

4. You forgot about marketing

Unless you've got something so special that the world is automatically going to rush to your doorstep - and although I don't know you, I'll take a bet that you haven't - marketing should be your biggest single expense. It's not a whizzy bolt-on - it should actually drive what you do. Oh, and chucking £10m at an advertising agency and telling them to get on with it is not the same as sorting out your marketing.

5. No one wants your lovely writing

This isn't quite true, but very nearly. Most journalists plan ideas which are effectively magazines with a bit of e-commerce attached; the most successful sites are the opposite - brutally efficient e-commerce with at most a bit of a magazine attached. People want function, involvement and entertainment. There's nothing wrong with elegant, incisive prose, but it's just not what people flock to websites for.

6. The competition is brutal

You thought that newspapers were tough? Wait till you're slugging it out in a market against a couple of ex-traders with MBAs, a teenage genius with a rich father and a former timeshare salesman desperate for an early retirement. Everyone is currently out there with you trying to make a million, and you might be surprised to find that some people are really rather sharp, despite the fact that they've never written a witty intro in their lives.

7. You forgot about project management

The dull truth is that net businesses are 80% organisation, 20% inspiration. Inspired, visionary leaders and teams of bright young things brainstorming and working all night is all well and good, but without the much more mundane skills of project management you will find yourself wasting endless time and money. You will also find that people with money like to see that you're organised. If you're not, they'll find someone who will do it for you, whether you like it or not.

8. The web isn't like print

Journalists moving from print to online often find it damnably frustrating. The two things you need to know immediately are: you can't just move things around a page as you can in print, and everything, but everything, will take much longer than you think.

9. The advertisers won't buy it

That old print model of creating a product, getting a niche demographic audience and selling it on to advertisers is not going to be enough to make you money. The vast majority of online advertising goes to a small number of huge sites, rates are falling and, as a result, few venture capitalists will now fund a project which relies entirely on advertising.

10. You've just let all the above reasons put you off

Get a grip. If you give up that easily, you'll never get anywhere.

Simon Waldman is the head of Guardian Unlimited

Wait till you're slugging it out in a market against a couple of ex-traders with MBAs, a teenage genius with a rich father and a former timeshare salesman desperate for an early retirement. Everyone is currently out there with you trying to make a million, and you might be surprised to find that some people are really rather sharp, despite the fact that they've never written a witty intro in their lives. 7. You forgot about project management The dull truth is that net businesses are 80% organisation, 20% inspiration. Inspired, visionary leaders and teams of bright young things brainstorming and working all night is all well and good, but without the much more mundane skills of project management you will find yourself wasting endless time and money. You will also find that people with money like to see that you're organised. If you're not, they'll find someone who will do it for you, whether you like it or not. 8. The web isn't like print Journalists moving from print to online often find it damnably frustrating. The two things you need to know immediately are: you can't just move things around a page as you can in print, and everything, but everything, will take much longer than you think. 9. The advertisers won't buy it That old print model of creating a product, getting a niche demographic audience and selling it on to advertisers is not going to be enough to make you money. The vast majority of online advertising goes to a small number of huge sites, rates are falling and, as a result, few venture capitalists will now fund a project which relies entirely on advertising. 10. You've just let all the above reasons put you off Get a grip. If you give up that easily, you'll never get anywhere. Simon Waldman is the head of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Carlton investigates Cook Report 'set ups'
fields.trailText: Carlton Television's investigative series, The Cook Report, last night was the subject of two internal inquiries after allegations were made against its veracity.
fields.body:
Carlton Television's investigative series, The Cook Report, last night was the subject of two internal inquiries after allegations were made against its veracity.

The News of the World claimed that in four editions of the ITV series, presented by the reporter Roger Cook, crimes were set up for him to solve. Carlton said it was taking the allegations seriously.

Meanwhile, the programme's editor, Mike Morley, is still suspended from work pending the completion, expected imminently, of an inquiry into several allegations by a producer on the show about his handling of a programme on Yardie crime gangs, which has yet to be broadcast.

In allegations which Carlton said were unrelated to Mr Morley's suspension, two former employees of The Cook Report, David Llewelyn and Kevin Bray, spoke to the News of the World claiming that they encouraged and assisted a boy of 15 to steal a computer from a primary school for an edition about fencing stolen goods.

The pair also admitted supplying the boy, now aged 20, with a torch and gloves to steal from the school, and to giving him cannabis and alcohol while setting up the sting operation.

Mr Llewelyn and Mr Bray were described by the newspaper as researchers on the programme, broadcast in 1994, but a Carlton spokesman denied that Mr Llewelyn was a researcher and described him as "an unreliable witness".

In another edition of The Cook Report, about professional gunmen, Mr Llewelyn claimed that researchers paid £2,500 to a pub bouncer from south London to pose as a hitman, and he alleged that the entire production had been "a farce".

Two more recent editions, both dating from 1998, were alleged to have involved cooperation between criminals and members of the production team. However, in both editions, one about antiques theft and the other, The Dodgy Motor Show, about car thieves who steal to order, viewers were told that the crimes had been set up to expose the criminals.

A Carlton source said yesterday that senior executives were convinced that viewers had not been misled by either of the editions from 1998.

Both of the earlier programmes have been investigated by the company but will now be re-examined following Mr Llewelyn's allegations. Carlton is consulting its solicitors over his story.

A spokesman said: "The story is based on the evidence of one person, who was not a researcher on the programmes. His version of events is different from that of the programme makers".

The spokesman added that none of the programme makers who had worked on the hitman or fencing editions still worked for the company.

Last year Carlton was fined a record £2m for a 1996 documentary, The Connection, which was found by the Guardian to have seriously misled viewers. It included faked scenes and false revelations about the Colombian drugs trade.

fields.headline: Home at last
fields.standfirst: A warm welcome awaited the dozens of hostages who returned to Afghanistan today following their week-long ordeal on board the hijacked Boeing 727
fields.trailText: More than 70 hostages from the hijacked Afghan airliner today returned to a warm welcome in Kandahar while the 19 alleged hijackers wait to be dealt with by the English courts. Thirteen of them were due to appear before Southend magistrates' court, Essex, today.
fields.body:
More than 70 hostages from the hijacked Afghan airliner today returned to a warm welcome in Kandahar while the 19 alleged hijackers wait to be dealt with by the English courts. Thirteen of them were due to appear before Southend magistrates' court, Essex, today.

Meanwhile 74 passengers who have claimed political asylum are being interviewed by immigration officials. A foreign office spokesman said they could be dispersed to the United States, India and Pakistan under a new plan being drafted by Britain.

The 60 homecoming adults - including the 10 crew members of the hijacked aircraft - along with 13 children were showered with rose petals as they stepped off their flight. For the men, there were embraces and gifts from the ruling Taliban's foreign minister Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil. In keeping with the Taliban's strict interpretation of Islam, there was no contact with the women disembarking from the aircraft.

One of those to arrive back in Afghanistan, Juma Khan, stepped off the plane and kissed the ground. "This is my home. I love it very much," he said.

Referring to the controversy sparked by the asylum seekers, another homecomer, Abdul Farid, wiped tears from his face as he disembarked, saying: "Why wouldn't I come home? This is my country, this is where my family is, my heart."

The passengers who returned said they had no desire to stay in Britain because it is an "infidel country". "It is not a Moslem country, how could we stay? And the weather was depressing and the food was awful," said one passenger.

Also on the tarmac at Kandahar airport was Tine Staermose, a representative of the Geneva-based International Organisation for Migration, which chartered the flight from Britain. She was there to assist the former hostages in returning to their home villages. "All of them are coming back voluntarily to Afghanistan. Now we have to get them home," she said.

After it was seized on an internal flight from Kabul, the Ariana Airlines Boeing 727 was diverted out of Afghan airspace, making a series of stops on a journey that traversed Central Asia and Russia before landing at Stansted a week ago. British police negotiated an end to the hijack on Thursday and everyone on board was allowed to leave the aircraft.

Mr Muttawakil urged Britain to reject the requests of the 74 asylum seekers for refuge, saying it would encourage hijacking. He said the asylum seekers were economic refugees not political ones. He also promised that they would not be punished if they returned home to Afghanistan, a country ravaged by 20 years of war.

The Taliban, however, want the hijackers prosecuted and punished, but have not demanded their return to Afghanistan. It is not clear what punishment would be applied to the hijackers if they were sent back but Mr Muttawakil has said that the death penalty would be unlikely because no one had been killed.

fields.headline: The moderate and the mediocre
fields.trailText: As the one-day series began, we laid out 10 commandments for England - 10 goals they could reasonably hope to achieve. Did they achieve them all? Of course not. This is England we're talking about. Even realistic targets are sometimes out of reach. But they didn't do too badly either. Here's the full balance sheet:
fields.body:
As the one-day series began, we laid out 10 commandments for England - 10 goals they could reasonably hope to achieve. Did they achieve them all? Of course not. This is England we're talking about. Even realistic targets are sometimes out of reach. But they didn't do too badly either. Here's the full balance sheet:

1. Reach the final

They did it. With a little help from the rain. And the run-rate. But there was rough justice in that, because it was on run-rate that Zimbabwe squeezed England out of the World Cup. "England's last one-day outing in South Africa," we pointed out, "was a 6-1 drubbing. So mere respectability would be a major advance. It's too much to ask that they beat South Africa, who are the world's most effective one-day team outside of major tournaments." And so it proved. What we hadn't bargained for was that South Africa would be a shadow of their normal selves, with no Cullinan, no Donald, no Kirsten, and - for once - no sense of a settled side. They did all they could to lose the tournament, and still ended up winning it comfortably, because England, though only awful on one occasion, were often ordinary. Still, second place is second place, and at least they competed.

Result: a qualified YES

2. Bed in a new opening pair

Nasser Hussain and Nick Knight had never opened together in a major match, because Hussain became an opener only when - in a dreadful, panicky piece of selection - Knight was dropped on the eve of the World Cup. "They have all the balance you could ask for," we argued - "left- and right-hander, blaster and barnacle. But does Hussain have any runs left in him at the end of a long tour, and will he manage to refrain from running Knight out?" The answers to those questions were "yes" and "yes, just". The new opening pair were England's best batsmen. In fact most days they were our only batsmen. And they should never have been opening in the final. That was a pitch on which any team was going to lose early wickets. South Africa had taken the precaution of bringing a middle order with them. England hadn't. Knight should have opened with a pinch-hitter, White or Ealham or Read, in the hope of at least dispersing the slips and getting the target down below 120. Hussain should have held himself back to No 5 or 6 to play a captain's innings like Cronje.

Result: another YES with reservations

3. Field as well asÉ

"I was going to say the South Africans, but some observers, amazingly, felt that England had the edge in this department as the Test series went on." And they kept it up, on the whole, in the one-dayers, rising to the occasion in the final with a series of scintillating catches. This has been the best thing about the Duncan Fletcher regime.

Result: a triumphant YES

4. Get runs out of Chris Read

"He should get the run in the side that he has been denied at Test level," we said. "And Duncan Fletcher has got to find a way of squeezing some runs out of him É Needs to improvise like his glove-mentors, Alan Knott and Jack Russell, and be good for a bustling 20." He did it once, in style, reducing Shaun Pollock to stunned silence with a glorious six in the penultimate over at Cape Town. And he did get a settled place in the side, once the horrible idea of giving the gloves to Mark Alleyne had been shelved. But his batting was all icing and no cake. In the final, admittedly when all was lost, he stayed in for longer than anyone else (70 minutes) but made only nine runs, and farmed the strike so ineffectually that Alan Mullally faced more balls than he did, in less time. In Zimbabwe, Read must add the string to his bow that most keepers can offer with their eyes shut: the nudge and nurdle that keeps the scoreboard ticking.

Result: Half a YES

5. Set attacking fields

"The one disappointment of Nasser Hussain's captaincy in the Tests was a tendency to go on the defensive," quoth we. "When in Rome, behave in a way the Roman isn't used to. Keep a slip in throughout a one-day innings É" Hmmmm. If Nasser had done that in the final, England might have won. In Sunday's Wisden Verdict, Simon Briggs rightly said that Nasser's decision to take Gough off was fatal. But even when he came back on, he didn't have a slip. Cronje, at times, posted three slips for Pollock, and he is not one of nature's buccaneers.

Result: a disappointing NO

6. Get Gough's reverse-swing going again

He was a different man once he pulled on the naff blue shirt. He took as many wickets as Shaun Pollock (14), at a marginally better average (14 not 15).

Result: a resounding YES

7. Name a vice-captain

"President Nasser has a poor record in this area," we said, "having already shared the job out between Graham Thorpe, Mark Butcher and Alec Stewart in the space of nine Tests, as well as giving Graeme Hick a go É" Who the vice-captain was, we never did discover. Come on Nass. Even Tony Blair has an official No 2.

Result: a resounding NO

8. Add two players to the core of the team

"I'm very pleased with the progress our side is making," Hussain said after the final. "There are definite areas we've got to improve, but we've got some good young lads coming through." Excuse me, but who are they? I can only think of one: Chris Read (qv). Vikram Solanki is good, but showed no real sign of coming through. Same with Darren Maddy. Mark Alleyne did a job, as the pros say, now and again, but he is hardly young (31). Mark Ealham had one fine day but he too is past the big three-O. Caddick came through too, once he had got used to the colour scheme: such are the vagaries of our selection system that he had only played nine ODIs in six and a half years before this tournament. Hussain is a clear thinker on the field; why can't he be one off it as well?

Result: a worrying NO

9. Get a run, a wicket or a catch out of Gavin Hamilton

The Forgotten Scotsman is thought to have been injured some of the time, but he can't have been too bad, or he would have been the Flying Home Scotsman. Of all England's squad members, he had the best World Cup. So it might have been an idea to give him a game. Hussain keeps saying that England now know more about their young players. It can't be Hamilton he's thinking of.

Result: a dismal NO

10. Have meaningful numbers

"One of England's many crimes in the World Cup," we said, "was to do their numbering alphabetically, so that the number was meaningless. This was bovine in itself, and plain rude to the spectator, who is entitled to think that if a man has No.6 on his shirt, then there is at least some chance that he will come in to bat after No.5." In the Test at Centurion, Hussain showed a revolutionary ability to see the game from the spectator's point of view. Not here.

Result: a small but telling NO

Overall score: Four and a half out of 10. Somewhere between moderate and mediocre.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Mandelson: 'I hope that the suspension will be short'

fields.headline: Mandelson: 'I hope that the suspension will be short'
fields.standfirst:
Speech To British Irish Inter-Parliamentary Body by the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland,
Peter Mandelson MP
fields.trailText:
I first want to wish the BIIPB a happy 10th birthday. I am only sorry that it takes place in something some way short of
a party atmosphere, despite all that we have to celebrate ten years on from your founding.
fields.body:
I first want to wish the BIIPB a happy 10th birthday. I am only sorry that it takes place in something some way short of a party atmosphere, despite all that we have to celebrate ten years on from your founding.

During this time, the island of Ireland has become a safer, more harmonious and prosperous place. Ireland in the North has a transformed security situation. Ireland in the South has acquired a modern economic brand image. The potential for both is huge and I have a deep sense of personal commitment to entrenching Ireland's security and prosperity, North and South.

We owe nothing less to the people we represent and serve.

It was, therefore, with a heavy heart that on Friday I took a step I had hoped would not prove to be necessary and suspended temporarily the institutions set up under the Good Friday Agreement.

I hope that the suspension will be short. I intend it to be. But it was, even so, a move that the British and Irish Governments, in constant touch with the political parties, pulled out all the stops to avert.

If we had found any way of securing enough confidence for the institutions to continue we would have taken it.

The bedrock of the Good Friday Agreement is cross-community support. Without a consensus across the political spectrum, its institutions cannot be sustained. It is not a matter of taking one side or the other. The only side that I am on is that of the Agreement as a whole and the interests of both traditions invested in it.

Decommissioning is not a unionist or a British fixation.

The statements of John Hume and Seamus Mallon confirm that, as do the calls made by President Clinton and Senator Kennedy.

Nor is it an issue only in the minds of politicians. It has been called for by Protestant and Catholic, from all corners of Ireland, north and south. That it must happen is agreed by leader-writers from the Newsletter to the Irish News to the Boston Globe. And I do not just mean republican decommissioning. The onus is on every paramilitary to dispose of their illegally held arms for politics to work properly.

Such was the overwhelming desire for progress that Bishop Heggarty was prepared to help personally and I commend his bold initiative.

It was, and remains, a crucial part of building consensus, a signal that paramilitaries - from all sides - were committed to playing their part in building a new, peaceful Northern Ireland.

On Friday, there was one very positive development. After I had signed the Order suspending the institutions, we received a report from General John de Chastelain's decommissioning commission.

The Commission reported that the IRA had indicated the context in which they would initiate a comprehensive process to put arms beyond use. In the Commission's view, this held out the real prospect of an agreement which would enable it to fulfil the substance of its mandate.

I do not for a moment underestimate the significance of this. If it means what it appears to mean, it may be the first sign that the IRA are , after all, prepared to give up their arms.

We need to find out what the context is in which the IRA says it will put arms beyond use. Brian Cowen and I intend to follow this up urgently, first by exploring with General de Chastelain what lies behind Friday's report. But, in the situation we faced on Friday, it was too unspecific and it came too late. It provides the basis for answering Seamus Mallon's "whether" question, but not his "when" question or "how".

Had it come earlier, we could have sought, and possibly received, greater clarity. But, as it was, with the institutions on the point of collapse, I had no choice but to act as I did - as I said I would - under the review provisions of the Agreement.

Some have said that I acted in breach of the Good Friday Agreement. On the contrary, I acted to save the Agreement as the two governments said they would in the conclusions of the Mitchell accord. The consensus necessary for the institutions to continue simply did not exist.

Though convinced that this step was the right one, it was with great sadness that I took it.

The institutions set up under the Good Friday Agreement have proved to be the most effective, most democratic form of government that Northern Ireland has ever known. I rejoice in the fact that there are no longer strangers, no more outsiders from Northern Ireland's administration.

Northern Ireland finally had a truly representative Executive, with members drawn from all the major pro-agreement parties and including two of its opponents. It underlines that there are not second class citizens in Northern Ireland any more.

It had local Ministers, with local accents and deep local knowledge. With the power to make decisions that affect the daily lives of local people.

And each and every one of those Ministers, regardless of political affiliation, have fulfilled our highest expectations: that they are the right people to govern Northern Ireland. Government of Northern Ireland from outside Northern Ireland is inferior to inclusive self government of Northern Ireland.

The Good Friday Agreement created a framework of north-south institutions for practical co-operation between Ireland and Northern Ireland. This means greater co-operation and better services not just for Northern Ireland but for the whole island of Ireland.

And East-West arrangements that will broaden and deepen relations between Ireland and the United Kingdom and throughout the United Kingdom.

Sadly these, too, are now on hold. But not indefinitely.

I do not want direct rule to continue for a moment longer than necessary. That's why the talks that Brian Cowen and I are initiating with the parties today are so urgent.

In the last 72 hours, some harsh words have been spoken. That is perhaps not surprising. Huge issues are at stake. And yes, at times, there are differences of emphasis between us.

There is a keen sense of loss, which extends beyond Northern Ireland and beyond these islands, among all those who support the Agreement and want it to succeed.

But this process has worked best when we have all worked together, while honestly recognising the difference between us.

I appeal to all the parties to work with the Irish Government and ourselves, without reservation or precondition, to create the conditions needed to reactivate Northern Ireland's devolved government. To seek the necessary clarity. To move forward together.

Any less wholehearted approach will not be understood or forgiven by the people of Northern Ireland.

They take pride and delight in the huge progress which has been made in recent years.

Ceasefires well established.

A peace which is still not perfect, but is infinitely better than what went before. And I do not underestimate the courage and effort it has taken on all sides for that to be achieved.

A remarkably settled consensus about the constitutional questions that have dogged the last thirty years.

The emergence of new institutions in which both traditions play a full part.

The pursuit of an active agenda on rights and equality.

This is not an agenda of "political correctness". I am no fan of gesture politics. But the generosity of spirit and imagination on all sides that have got us this far must not fail us now.

Taking the necessary final steps - and risks - on the way means each side understanding the mindset of the other.

It means, in particular, republicans understanding better why unionists are reluctant to join in government without more definitive progress on the arms issue. Why the fact that the guns are silent, welcome as it is, is not enough.

And all of us understanding better why arms have the almost totemic significance they have for those who hold them.

Above all, it means the avoidance of any suggestion of surrender or climbdown on either side.

There will be dissidents on both sides who do not want us to succeed. But we should not be afraid of the men and women whose gaze is firmly backwards, whose justification is some eccentric notion that nations can be built on violence and intimidation and cite a spurious analysis of history in support.

Or equally, those who refuse to admit that change is either possible or desirable. Those who prefer the certainties of past conflict to the uncertainties of future reconciliation.

They have not deterred us in the past and they never will.

That's why I am committed, as I was before devolution, to good government in the interests of all the people of Northern Ireland, irrespective of their tradition or political allegiance.

That's why I propose to continue to advance the programmes of positive reform that flow from the Good Friday Agreement.

Because the Good Friday Agreement envisaged not just a new constitution, but fundamental changes to the political and social fabric of Northern Ireland.

The Agreement has given Northern Ireland some of the most sophisticated rights and equality arrangements in the world.

But rights cannot simply be tacked on to the systems and institutions of government - we must actively seek new and imaginative ways to encourage respect for rights and equality in every area of public life. Everywhere from employment to policing and parades - all areas that must advance regardless of the state of political progress.

I have faced calls to suspend the implementation of the Patten report on policing while the institutions are on hold.

This is just not possible. In the words of the Chief Constable 'the vast bulk of the recommendations are simply about good and effective policing'.

Policing is not a partisan issue to be traded as if it were part of some political scoresheet and it must not be used to give comfort to any political party. I have not done that to date and I am not going to start now, however much I respect the right of any politician to express their view on the subject.

I know the passions that reform of the RUC arouses, particularly the prospect of a new name and changed badge. I have heard at first hand, many times, the harrowing stories of how these symbols have come to mean so much to so many people in the RUC family who experienced tragedy.

But a nine to one religious imbalance cannot be allowed to continue. A police service that is not representative of the society it serves cannot hope to be fully effective. It cannot hope to draw support and strength from all parts of the community.

We must not rest until all the pillars of the state command the same respect, inspire the same sense of ownership across the community in Northern Ireland. Until the state and its agencies truly are representative of and responsive to the society it serves.

So much, though, has changed already in a positive direction in Northern Ireland. And you in the BIIPB have seen at close quarters the great advances that the last ten years have brought. From terrible violence, political instability and little hope of anything better.

I am determined to work harder still to build confidence in the Good Friday Agreement and to create the conditions for the swift return of devolved government.

And I will do all I can to encourage the incremental shifts that have brought ceasefires, then the Good Friday Agreement, then devolution.

The shifts that will one day secure truly democratic government and an unbreakable peace in Northern Ireland.

Those are our goals. And we need each other - indeed, unionists need nationalists who need republicans who need unionists - to achieve those goals. That recognition was the mainspring of the Good Friday Agreement. It remains so. It is what will carry us forward.

fields.headline: Fertility laws
fields.trailText:
Why is fertility in the news?
The human fertilisation and embryology authority (HFEA) is bracing itself for legal challenges from single women, older women and gay men who believe existing fertility rules in the UK have denied them the right to have children. Ruth Deech, the head of the HFEA, told the Guardian that European human rights legislationwhich comes into effect in the autumn could lead to test cases over fertility issues.
fields.body:
Why is fertility in the news?
The human fertilisation and embryology authority (HFEA) is bracing itself for legal challenges from single women, older women and gay men who believe existing fertility rules in the UK have denied them the right to have children. Ruth Deech, the head of the HFEA, told the Guardian that European human rights legislationwhich comes into effect in the autumn could lead to test cases over fertility issues.

What is the HFEA?
The HFEA was set up in august 1991 by the human fertilisation and embryology act 1990 (HFE Act). The first statutory body of its type in the world, the HFEA was created to regulate a sensitive area amid public and professional unease about human embryo research and infertility treatments. HFEA members are appointed by the government. The recommendation for such a body had come from the 1984 report of the committee of inquiry into human fertilisation and embryology (the 'Warnock' report). In practical terms, the HFEA ensures that all UK treatment clinics offering in vitro fertilisation (IVF) or donor insemination, or storing eggs, sperm or embryos, conform to high medical and professional standards and are inspected regularly.

What are the HFEA's main rules or recommendations on fertility treatment?
The HFEA produces a code of practice to guide licensed clinics. The code includes a key section on welfare of the child. While the offer of treatment is a decision ultimately for the patient's clinician, the HFE act requires every clinician to make this decision only after "account has been taken of the welfare of any child who may be born as a result of the treatment (including the need of that child for a father), and of any other child who may be affected by the birth". Clinics must bear in mind factors such as the prospective parents' ages and their likely future ability to look after, or provide for, a child's needs, and any risk of harm to the child or children who may be born. Where the child will have no legal father, clinics must pay particular attention to the prospective mother's ability to meet the child's needs throughout its childhood.

So where do the problems come in?
In practice, single women, gay women and older women have little chance of being treated in private clinics on the NHS, where budgets for IVF are tight. NHS clinics usually do not select people who are over 40, or even in their late 30s, and who are not part of a stable heterosexual couple.

Why should this lead to lawsuits?
Ruth Deech believes that European human rights legislation being introduced could open the door for lawsuits in Britain. The human rights legislation was originally a response to Nazi atrocities, to make sure there would never be a repeat of forced sterilisation of men and women. European legislation includes provisions on the right to private and family life and the right to marry and found a family. Those two rights stem from the second world war, when the Nazis banned sexual relations between people of different races. But Ms Deech sees people interpreting the new law as an absolute right to have a child regardless of sexual orientation or age.

For example?
Ms Deech says: "If a single woman were rejected for treatment by a clinic she might say 'I demand my human rights', if a lesbian couple, perhaps, had a baby abroad or were rejected by a clinic here, they would challenge any refusal to treat them like a heterosexual couple, because there is a clause which says the rights and liberties in this act must be extended to people without discrimination or status."

What was a recent controversy involving the HFEA?
The HFEA opposed the decision by Diane Blood to have a child with her dead husband's sperm. But Ms Blood went to court and, after a four-year legal battle, gave birth to her son. Ms Deech remains convinced the HFEA's 21-strong committee made the right decision as "you don't carry out medical procedures on the dying or unconscious".

fields.headline: And the losers are . . .
fields.trailText: By now long accustomed to being described as a "mature" market - magazine-speak for "in decline" - the women's monthly sector saw double-digit year-on-year losses in the July-December 1999
fields.body:
By now long accustomed to being described as a "mature" market - magazine-speak for "in decline" - the women's monthly sector saw double-digit year-on-year losses in the July-December 1999. ABC figures for such titles as Prima (down 17.4%), Company (down 16.6%), Minx (18.2%) and Essentials (11.7%). Apart from the relaunched Woman's Journal, up 20.4%, the only significant gainers were Elle (4.8% up) and Red (4.2%).

Otherwise, changes were modest, although IPC's Marie Claire (up 1.1%) made ground on its long-standing rival, National Magazines' Cosmopolitan (down 1.3%, and now just over 20,000 copies ahead at 470,280). Marie Claire claimed to be out-selling Cosmo in the UK, causing NatMags supremo Terry Mansfield to attack misleading IPC "spin". Tatler lost 0.6% in a period in which the early issues were inherited by new editor Geordie Greig from his predecessor Jane Procter, but saw Harpers & Queen fall further, by 4%.

Women's weeklies were even more depressed, showing an almost uninterrupted pattern of year-on-year slumps. The most spectacular trend-bucker was OK!, continuing a relentless rise with a 37.70% jump to 551,901. This allowed it at last to overtake Hello!, looking jaded in falling 3% to 495,349.

Once able to contrast its huge gains each six months with the dwindling sales of the women's titles, the men's monthly market now looks equally "mature". Although sector-leader FHM's sales figure is still astronomical at 702,514, it fell back year-on-year by 6.5%, losing more sales than there are readers of Arena, down 22.7% at 47,096. Loaded (down 18.8%) and Men's Health (17.5%), star performers in previous seasons, slipped badly, and previously ascendant Maxim came down to earth with a 2.1% drop. While the lad mags were tumbling, the upmarket men's title GQ - now distancing itself from its me-too laddery under James Brown - recovered, up 7.5%.

Perhaps significantly, meaty losses in the once-zippy teenage sector (down as a whole by 9.2%) coincided with further growth in most computer magazine sectors: general computer titles, for example, showed combined growth of 28.4%while 11 internet titles between them more than doubled the previous period's sales, growing 122.5%.

Fans of the riveting BBC series Trouble Between the Covers, about Sally O'Sullivan's start-up magazine group Cabal Communications, will be keen to know how its two titles fared. Not bad, it turns out, with both Real Homes Magazine (131,189) and the lad mag Front (141,742) achieving slim increases. Front editor Piers Hernu will be cock-a-hoop.

fields.headline: Chic and cheerful
fields.standfirst: As ever, claim and counter-claim greeted last week's magazine circulation figures. But one continues its serene upward course - Vogue.  Imogen O'Rorke  talks to the style-bible's editor, Alexandra Shulman
fields.trailText: As ever, claim and counter-claim greeted last week's magazine circulation figures. But one continues its serene upward course - Vogue. Imogen O'Rorke talks to the style-bible's editor, Alexandra Shulman.
fields.body:
The battle for editors of women's glossies now will not be how to put on new readers, but how to maintain existing ones. While last week's circulation figures revealed the significant fact that OK! has finally overtaken its arch rival Hello! with a quite remarkable year-on-year increase in sales of 37.7% (what are they doing right?), the trend for the traditional titles in the past 10 years has been a downhill one. The overall loss of readers since 1987 is well over a million readers.

This fact has not passed without the requisite amount of paranoia behind closed doors, reflected by the redistribution of human resources - or large number of sackings - in major publishing houses. In news-papers, the perennial debate about the state of women's magazines has reached fever pitch in the past two years: from the Daily Mail to the Guardian, they have been denounced as "an insult to womanhood", "sex-crazed and salacious", or just boring and old hat.

Are they really that bad, or are there just too many out there? In an over-saturated, oxygen-depleted marketplace, even the more illustrious titles such as Elle have been forced out on to the sawdust of the market floor to scrap for readers: fighting mere "sex" coverlines with "bigger, bolder sex" and resorting to plastering free goods all over the front of the magazine.

Reader loyalty seems to be a luxury of the past - according to some estimates it is down 30% compared to five years ago. As for advertising loyalty - was it ever there in the first place? With women readers accounting for 30% of the sales of men's magazines, a market growing ever stronger (a growth rate of 674% between 1993 and 1998) and more pornographic, the women's sector looks like a universe in decline.

There have been some launches since 1996: Frank, which settled at around 40,000 and was effectively folded by Wagadon; and Red and B, launched with the full muscle of Emap and Attic Futura respectively behind them. But more newcomers have arrived over the same period in the healthier men's market, which has supported the launch of Maxim, Bizarre, Front and several health titles.

Sally O'Sullivan, ex-editor of Good Housekeeping and chief executive of Cabal - the star of the BBC2 series Trouble Between the Covers - believes that ever-fewer women's magazines reflect the life, aspirations and emotions of the readers: "Eventually the gap between the lifestyle of the readers and the static nature of the current brands will show - unless they can move fast enough. The magazines with longevity are the ones that have grown with society - evolution is what it's all about."

Amidst all the Ab Fab-style panic and the desperate sales-boosting tactics, one title stands out. Vogue's sales figures are more robust than ever at 202,668, with 25,000 more readers put on since editor Alexandra Shulman came on board, and it has so far resisted the fads and faux pas of the marketplace. Its millennium issue was a sell-out.

While others fought for celebrities on their covers, Vogue left its own blank, using self-reflective mirrored silver. The fashion journal which launched in 1916, monitored hemline movements through two world wars, and met the challenge of women's lib, effortlessly claimed "A Century of Style" as its own. It confidently straddled the millennium with one Blahnik heel resting in the 20th century and the other lodged firmly in the future.

Although its rival Elle sells more copies (210,076), it is not Elle that fashion devotees turn to to find out what's in. Only Vogue has the gravitas to sweep the board clean and start a new look. Just as we've spent our wages in haberdashery trying to get "the shamanic look", the February issue heralds "The New Chic", a return to 70s smart.

It's enough to make other editors sick. "There's Vogue on this one level and then there's all the rest," says Andrew Wiles, head of advertising at Harrods, which sponsored the February catwalk guide. "Vogue has the authority in terms of fashion positioning - it's stuck to its identity." Advertisers use it as the trade showcase for repositioning brands.

What is it about Vogue? "I thought it had become a little irrelevant - showing gorgeous models and nothing else." Society has also changed. Vogue once appealed to a narrow echelon of British society. Now we are all supposed to be middle class.

"Vogue is classless. It's not about class, it's about style. When I took over, England was in the midst of a recession - the fallout from the good-time 80s. Fashion literacy has improved enormously since then. "Now women want to buy into the whole thing - if they can't get the clothes, they'll buy the handbag."

Such moments might include the Kate Moss-in-tiny-knickers shock, followed by a shoot with a size 16 model, or more recently an article about "bi-try", inspired by the rumours of threesomes among the glamorous London set.

fields.headline: Defence of the title
fields.standfirst: The New Yorker is 75 - and as ever no one can quite agree how good it is.  Edward Helmore  hears editor David Remnick hit back at the latest criticism of an American institution
fields.trailText: The New Yorker is 75 - and as ever no one can quite agree how good it is. Edward Helmore hears editor David Remnick hit back at the latest criticism of an American institution.
fields.body:
This week, the New Yorker celebrates its 75th anniversary with a 300-page bumper edition that finds many of its past contributors tempted back into the flattering typeface of the fabled publication.

Likely as not, the week will also see additions to that vast file of articles about the title - one that still counts to most as the finest execution of magazine publishing - that will complement some 22 books that have been written about it.

Of those books, seven are being published on this anniversary. Among them are Letters from the Editor, a collection of the words of founder Harold Ross, About Town: The New Yorker and the World it Made by Ben Yagoda, John Seabrook's Nobrow, a deconstruction of the Tina Brown era during which, he argues, the New Yorker's identity was lost in the blurring of high- and low-brow culture, and the American publication of Alexander Chancellor's memoir of being an employee under Brown.

In addition, the current editor of the magazine, David Remnick, has edited two compilations of New Yorker writing over the years, Wonderful Town: New York Stories from The New Yorker and Life Stories: Profiles from the New Yorker. They effectively substantiate the magazine's reputation as a home to some of America's best writing.

But no good birthday passes without a good fight. And Renata Adler, a contributor to the magazine from 1963 to 1979, has stirred up a literary squall with her book Gone: The Last Days of the New Yorker in which she argues that what made the magazine great has long since departed. "As I write this, The New Yorker is dead. It still comes out week after week, or almost every week . . . Otherwise, not a single defining element of the magazine remains," is Adler's opening attack on the first page.

Her definition of the elements that combined to produce what she calls the golden age [roughly 1946 to 1980] include "the look, the format, the content, the humour, the level of seriousness; the ambition at the top; the standards in the middle; the limits below which it would not sink."

Though the specifics will not mean much to British readers, Adler goes on to eviscerate editors William Shawn and Robert Gottlieb current owner SI Newhouse, settle old scores with fellow writers, and generally depict the institution as a vipers' nest of poisonous flatterers and charlatans.

Reaction to Adler's tirade was largely one of surprise, both for its force and for its reading of history. "Part wacky, part unpleasant," noted Gottlieb, as the American press ran a series of gleefully critical pieces about the magazine.

Adler's attack fits nicely into the long tradition of writers assaulting each other with bitterness and has given commentators a chance to reach for their best prose and weigh in on the New Yorker's past and present merits and wonder who or what killed it if it is dead.

After reading more than 3,500 issues in preparation of the anthologies, Remnick must have a better understanding than almost anyone of how the magazine came to occupy such a high place in American culture, and of its progression since it began life as a humour magazine in 1925 and then broadened and deepened - the term "profile" was a creation of the magazine.

Sitting in the conference room adjoining his office on the 20th floor of Condé Nast's sleek new headquarters in Times Square after a late night closing the issue, he is careful not be drawn deeply into the debate. "In so far that the mystique is a sustained compliment to the magazine, I welcome it. But in so far that it regards the magazine as some sort of religion, I find it uninteresting," he says.

Indeed, he finds the elitist fascination that propels the debate largely tiresome. "I have a hard time believing that beyond the media bubble of certain precincts of Manhattan it matters to anyone. It's just gossip . . . it's the magazine equivalent of caring more about TS Eliot's marriages than his work. What matters to readers is the issue they get in the mail."

Remnick, a former sports writer, Moscow correspondent of the Washington Post and author of the well-received Muhammad Ali biography, King of the World, has now been in the editor's chair for 19 months. The erruptions that greeted Brown were absent and his succession was a popular choice amongst the New Yorker staff. He is, after all, a known and respected quantity.

As a keen student of its history and able to pinpoint which famous writers were published and when, he's also acutely aware of the New Yorker's lapses. "The New Yorker's achievements are many. However, it pub lished Bernard Malamud, Saul Bellow and Philip Roth rather lightly," he says revealing an earnestness. "Indeed, one of the things I did in my first week was to take out the fiction we had and publish a portion of Roth's book I Married a Communist."

Many say that the publication was placed in his hands after its proprietor, SI Newhouse, grew tired of the constant criticism that the magazine had dumbed down and, by default, that he was responsible for the ruination of an American institution. To add insult to injury it was also losing him millions of dollars.

It would be wrong to regard Remnick as a kind of custodian charged with returning a greater sense of sobriety and measure to the weekly. It does lean toward being less frenetic and noisy than it was under his predecessor and it's a good deal less Anglo-centric.

For any New Yorker editor, criticism comes with the territory. Some say its more dull, that you need a bit of trashiness to keep things buoyant; others that it's been enriched by Remnick's beefed-up arts and cultural criticism and returned somewhat to the principle of attraction rather than promotion.

The feature stories and special issues tend to be less of the moment for the moment's sake (no fashion issues in fashion week, for instance) and more interested in the world beyond that which can be spied from the high floors of a Manhattan skyscraper.

The anthology of profiles Remnick prepared for the anniversary makes clear that some of the best writing in the magazine during the so-called golden age that critics love to exult was often about the emergent figures of the day.

"Kenneth Tynan wrote a series of profiles which are among the best ever written in the New Yorker. They were not about medieval scholars or Gregorian chants. They were about Johnny Carson, Mel Brooks, John Gielgud. Was that noisy? I don't know. Certainly they tell me a lot about that world. It's become harder and harder to write about certain kinds of public figures, athletes, actors, directors, all the people that have press agents," he points out. "They're much more on their guard, they parcel out their time just enough to get the requisite publicity. If there's somebody we're interested in and all we're going to get is 45 minutes in a hotel room with a publicist having her own tape-recorder rolling then to hell with it."

Remnick's appointment came just as Condé Nast folded the backroom affairs of the New Yorker into that of its other, glossier titles. Many feared that in an effort to stem mounting losses its independence would somehow be compromised.

But Remnick says there have been no creeping efforts to tailor editorial to the interest of advertisers ("Not only would it be wrong, it would be dumb"), no dramatic budget cutting, nor any proprietorial nudging. "There's been no instruction. No 'you must publish so-and-so because I met them at a cocktail party'. No wink-wink, 'I have a special interest in such-and-such'. Nothing. Zero. The degree to which it's given to you to make of it what you will is really quite breathtaking."

Though advertising is up, the New Yorker is not profitable nor, he says, is it prudent to suggest when it will become so. "I have every reason to believe the magazine will become economically healthy, but we have a way to go. The one thing that's close to perfect is the circulation [around 800,000] and the subscription renewal rate is the highest it's ever been at 75-80%. Evidently, once you're hooked, your hooked."

Under Remnick, the New Yorker looks set to remain an idiosyncratic publication. To this day it does not have a masthead, a hangover from the years when it displayed neither a table of contents nor displayed the names of its writers prominently.

The anniversary issue out this week promises to be a tour-de-force: Joan Didion on Martha Stewart, Janet Malcolm on Chekhov, Wendy Wasserstein on getting pregnant at 49, a reporting piece from Cuba by John Lee Anderson, Woody Allen's first piece in 20 years and fiction by Alison Munro, Steve Martin and John Lahr.

It won't satisfy everyone and the argument over the New Yorker in another 75 years will probably still be as intractable as it is today. It is, in effect, a special kind of Manhattan sport. Yet Remnick does not appear encumbered by the weight of its history, or distracted by the clutter and noise of the media below. "I will not rest easy until I know all aspects of the New Yorker are in place," he assures.
