fields.headline: I wrote that
fields.standfirst: A (very) occasional series in praise of the sub-editors' craft
fields.trailText: A (very) occasional series in praise of the sub-editors' craft
fields.body:
Sub: Paul Hickson.

Publication: The Sun, Wednesday, February 9.

Occasion: Celtic suffer most embarrassing defeat, losing third-round cup tie 3-1 to First Division Inverness Caledonian Thistle, just five years out of the Highland League.

Headline: Super Caley Go Ballistic, Celtic Are Atrocious

"The headline came long before the final whistle. Caley were 2-1 up. It had looked like a straightforward evening. We expected Celtic to win, but it soon became obvious something big was happening. Celtic losing to a team nobody had heard of - or could even spell - that was the story.

The Scottish sports editor, Steve Wolstonencroft, mentioned the 60s headline used when Liverpool striker Ian Callaghan scored three goals against QPR. It went some thing like: 'Super Calli Scores a Hat Trick, QPR Atrocious.' I didn't know it. I hit back with 'Super Caley Go Ballistic, Celtic Are Atrocious'.

It had looked like a normal evening. We expected Celtic to win, but it soon became obvious something big was happening. Celtic losing to a team nobody had heard of - or could even spell - that was the story.

My job is chief sports sub-editor, my speciality writing headlines. I've been doing it since 1991. The best headlines come like this. Most have been used in one form or other. There are very few really original ones. It's good, but I don't think it's that good - a nice pun. I like to think I do good headlines every week.

The sports editor rang me up the next day. 'The whole country's talking about you,' he said. 'Oh dear,' I replied, 'What have I done?'"
fields.bodyText: Sub: Paul Hickson. Publication: The Sun, Wednesday, February 9. Occasion: Celtic suffer most embarrassing defeat, losing third-round cup tie 3-1 to First Division Inverness Caledonian Thistle, just five years out of the Highland League. Headline: Super Caley Go Ballistic, Celtic Are Atrocious "The headline came long before the final whistle. Caley were 2-1 up. It had looked like a straightforward evening. We expected Celtic to win, but it soon became obvious something big was happening. Celtic losing to a team nobody had heard of - or could even spell - that was the story. The Scottish sports editor, Steve Wolstonencroft, mentioned the 60s headline used when Liverpool striker Ian Callaghan scored three goals against QPR. It went some thing like: 'Super Calli Scores a Hat Trick, QPR Atrocious.' I didn't know it. I hit back with 'Super Caley Go Ballistic, Celtic Are Atrocious'. It had looked like a normal evening. We expected Celtic to win, but it soon became obvious something big was happening. Celtic losing to a team nobody had heard of - or could even spell - that was the story. My job is chief sports sub-editor, my speciality writing headlines. I've been doing it since 1991. The best headlines come like this. Most have been used in one form or other. There are very few really original ones. It's good, but I don't think it's that good - a nice pun. I like to think I do good headlines every week. The sports editor rang me up the next day. 'The whole country's talking about you,' he said. 'Oh dear,' I replied, 'What have I done?'"

webTitle: It's going to be a month of Sundays

fields.headline: It's going to be a month of Sundays
fields.standfirst: The papers have had a good start to the year, with upturns in circulation. Now let the battles commence, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: The papers have had a good start to the year, with upturns in circulation. Now let the battles commence.
fields.body:
There are few better guides to the state of the national press than the January sales figures. Newspapers are expected to emerge from the December doldrums with boosted circulations, engendered by the positive feelings readers are supposed to enjoy when entering a new year. Expensive TV promotions also help, and some £6m has been spent already this year.

As our chart shows, most titles did indeed bounce back. Only four papers lost copies month on month: the Financial Times, the Independent, the Daily Star and the Sunday Telegraph. The FT's loss is unimportant because, apart from its global sale fluctuating more than any other, it had a record-breaking December and is selling 13% more copies than a year ago.

The Independent's failure to improve on December, and its continuing reliance on 25,000 bulk sales, is certainly alarming. Although it is doing just a little better than a year ago, it appears to be marooned on a circulation plateau. But it has yet to spend any of its promotion budget.

The Daily Star's position is much worse. Its British sale is barely 500,000 and, despite the enthusiasm and professionalism of its small editorial squad, its long-term future is obviously desperate. Until the mooted merger between its owner, United News & Media, and Carlton, is settled one way or the other, it will struggle on with limited resources and the sad knowledge that it exists merely to utilise machine capacity. Papers are supposed to be about more than corporate commercial necessity, aren't they?

The Sunday Telegraph's down-turn is, I am assured, a technical blip to do with the fact that ABC recorded its unusually bumper January 2 sale in the December returns. This left it with a healthy December and a sickly January. It is expected to recover this month.

These four cases apart, the sales stories elsewhere confirm a number of trends that are best explained by comparing last month's figures with those from January 1999. For example, the Sun sold 3,557,336 this January but 3,772,416 last time, a fall of 5.7% which, significantly, is exactly the same decline suffered by the Daily Star. The Mirror's loss in the same period was less than 1% - a measure of the way the paper's fortunes have turned around and the reason why it and the Sun fight so fiercely.

One of the main battle areas is Scotland, where the Sun has a massive lead because, throughout past decades, the Mirror refused to sell north of the border in order not to compete with its successful stablemate, the Daily Record. Now the three titles are in hand-to-hand combat.

The Sun is reaching towards a Scottish sale of 400,000, the Mirror has about 50,000 and the Record, once the proud claimant of 750,000 regular buyers, is down to 626,000. In one year, it has lost 8% of its sale.

The daily middle market trend has remained unchanged for many years: the Daily Mail rises and the Daily Express falls. Compared with a year ago, the former is up 3.6% and the latter is down 4.8%. Their Sunday titles show a similar divergence: the Mail on Sunday is up 1.4% while the Sunday Express is down 3.5%.

Sunday provides the most intriguing sets of struggles, firstly among the broadsheets. The Sunday Times remains apparently invulnerable, but the jockeying for position among its competitors, where the hidden factors of subscription and bulk sales play a large role, is fascinating.

In second place is the Sunday Telegraph which relies on 285,000 cheap subscription sales along with a further 176,000 discounted sales and 31,000 giveaways to boost its headline figure.

This means that its full-rate sale is less than that of the third-placed Observer, which rival editors regularly tell me has become, under Roger Alton, "a proper paper once again". Since it is owned by Guardian Media Group, this sounds like bias, but it is not.

Alton's professionalism has eliminated the negative gossip about the paper that was so harmful. Any week now though he will face, at last, the challenge from the fourth-placed Independent on Sunday. After more than six months in the chair, editor Janet Street-Porter's substantial revamp of her title is being tested in the crucible of market research.Current readers and would-be readers are being grilled about her changes, which include a new magazine entitled Reality.

Its launch will be backed by a substantial promotion spend and a lot hangs on the outcome. Despite Street-Porter's boasts about rising sales, the Independent on Sunday sold only 97,000 at its full cover price in January and gave away more than 29,000 copies. Even with all that massaging, its overall figure was down 4,000 on a year ago.

The other surprising turn of events is among the red-tops where the Sunday Mirror appears to have got to grips with its decline. Now its ailing stablemate, the Sunday People, is in sore need of a similar uplift.

fields.headline: Drawing fire
fields.standfirst: Aaron McGruder is young, black and talented. His cartoon strip is carried by 250 US newspapers. And then readers started accusing him of being racist.  Duncan Campbell  reports on a row that has split America's liberal classes
fields.trailText: Aaron McGruder is young, black and talented. His cartoon strip is carried by 250 US newspapers. And then readers started accusing him of being racist. Duncan Campbell reports on a row that has split America's liberal classes.
fields.body:
The newspaper cartoon strip is part of the American way of life in a way that it never really has been - pace If . . . , Andy Capp, the Broons, Fred Bassett and the Gambols - in Britain. Many US papers run a couple of dozen every morning and when Charles Schulz announced that Peanuts was about to end after nearly 50 years because his cancer made it impossible for him to continue, a nation mourned as though a real death had occurred.

Some of the cartoons date back decades, from Rex Morgan MD to the Wizard of Id, from Blondie to the Amazing Spider-Man, and are as much a part of the country's shared cultural history as television quiz shows, Dear Abby and baseball caps. As Guardian readers might expect, Garry Trudeau's Doonesbury is an essential daily starting point for liberal America.

But rarely do the cartoons make their presence felt on other pages of the newspaper. Until, that was, the arrival of the Boondocks, a strip that has created a stir sufficient enough to make it the subject of intense debate in news and letter pages across the US. It has provoked both a fierce loyalty from its admirers and an angry reaction from its detractors, leading to a debate between readers and their papers about the role of the cartoon. The key questions are to do with race, humour and the American condition.

The creation of a young artist called Aaron McGruder, the Boondocks began its life four years ago as an online strip on a small website. At the time McGruder, now 25, was studying African-American history and computer graphics at the University of Maryland and the strip duly graduated to his campus newspaper, the Diamondbacker, and from there to the music paper, the Source.

After completing his degree, McGruder sent his work off to the main syndicates that control most of the cartoons in America's newspa pers. A stack of rejection slips returned but just over two years ago he went to the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention where an executive from one of the main syndicates, Universal Press, spotted the strip's potential. Last year it was launched nationally and it now appears in more than 250 daily papers in the US, others in the Caribbean and South Africa and has earned McGruder a contract worth six figures over five years.

The central character is a scornful and hard-to-please black schoolboy called Huey Freeman, named after the Black Panther, Huey P Newton. His family has just moved from the inner city of Chicago to a white suburb and Huey is on the lookout for racism, whether overt or covert. His fellow protagonists include his best friend, the outgoing Caesar, from Brooklyn; Jazmine DuBois, a sweet and rather confused bi-racial girl - her hair is "frizzy", she says, not an Afro; and Huey's full-on little brother, Riley, who has bought into the gangsta culture. Cindy is the white girl thrilled at the street-cred rap 'n' basketball possibilities of her new neighbours and who offends Huey by doing Puff Daddy imitations. Adults feature mainly as creatures unable to understand the complexities of life and music.

While most strips meander gently through life's little complexities, as seen perhaps through the eyes of a dog or a cat, the Boondocks cheerfully deals with some of the most delicate issues in America today: race, drugs, violence, education. Only last week, the strip was cut from a Georgia newspaper unhappy with episodes about the singer Whitney Houston and the alleged seizure from her in a Hawaii airport of a bag of marijuana. Papers in South Carolina and Ohio have dropped the strip after complaints from readers but others have hailed it as a breath of fresh air on the sometimes rather predictably humdrum "funnies" page.

When the Los Angeles Times, which carries 27 strips a day, first ran it last year more than 100 letters of complaint flooded in. "This is a depiction of angry black children bent on killing," wrote one university sociology researcher who threatened to cancel her subscription if the cartoon continued.

The Times has backed McGruder but other papers have been challenged by readers who claim that they would not run anything as strong from a white cartoonist. Complaints have predictably come from people who do not want to share their morning Corn Pops with a stroppy, young black kid but also from readers who say that they feel it presents a negative image of black people.

The Boondocks is certainly different from most strips, with the obvious exception of Doonesbury, in that it deals with the kind of issues that are normally left for the op-ed pages: the Ku Klux Klan, black history, tokenism. But McGruder deals with them without preaching, often gently mocking the lines Huey draws between right-on and wrong. Many of the issues are from McGruder's own background: like Huey, he was born in Chicago before moving to the white suburbs, initially in Champaign, Illinois, then Louisville, Kentucky before settling in Columbia, Maryland, in 1980. He, too, was used to being one of the few black faces in a classroom of white ones. His frames of reference are wide, from veteran black activist and academic Angela Davis to the Backstreet Boys.

"People are amazed that I say the things I say to mainstream America," says McGruder, who now lives in Los Feliz, one of the more interesting districts of Los Angeles. "But really it shouldn't be that big a deal. The problem is that information is so controlled and limited in this country that other perspectives are quickly seen as offensive or subversive. I'm coming from a hip-hop foundation which is about honest, creative expression that isn't watered down or scared. I'm coming from the perspective that if you have something to say you should say it without fear or hesitation but with great thought and preparation."

Has he been surprised by the reaction to the Boondocks? "America is very immature on race - we haven't really grown up," says McGruder. Having studied African-American history for so many years, he says he is used to having casual conversations about colonialism, different philosophies of black activism and self-identity, and had not realised how puzzling or threatening this might be to some readers.

McGruder, who takes his artistic inspiration from Japanese animators, accepts that the Boondocks will be subject to much more scrutiny than the more conventional new arrivals on the scene and that it will be viewed through the nation's racial prism. He is one of only five syndicated black artists among hundreds of white cartoonists. "I have a responsibility to the black community to represent us accurately and depict us in both writing and art in a way which black people will be proud of and allow their children to read. It has been really important to me to try and show the beauty of black children artistically, show the intelligence and sophistication of young black kids today. Black people are going to be watching very closely to see if you misrepresent something - and for good reason: they've been horribly misrepresented in the past."

He feels that the overwhelming response to his creation has been good. "I would say it's an indicator that while America has a long way to go before it tackles its racial issues, people from all walks of life are ready to start talking about things openly and addressing these taboo issues with candour and honesty." He feels the strip has many "curious onlookers" who are not quite sure how to take what the characters say.

Some of the criticisms, he says, have come from "whites who simply cannot stand the thought of dealing with black people on our own terms. When we demonstrate true independence of thought and action we are accused of widening the racial gap. It's as if the 'acceptance' of black equality is conditional to our behaving and speaking as much like white people as possible."

It is the cartoon strip that has brought McGruder recognition - although his website (boondocks.net) claims that he still has "no BMW, no Benz, not a single item of clothing from Versace" - but he says he is not wedded to it as a form. A book of the strip will be out later this year and an animated version is already underway and will hit television screens in 2001. But he likes the simplicity and directness of the daily strip. "It's a great medium because there's so little standing in between myself and the readers." And when some papers decide to censor an episode or two, his website provides the missing links for deprived readers and his growing army of fans.

The cartoon strip can have a wonderfully subversive effect as followers of underground comic artists such as Robert Crumb and Gilbert Shelton, the creators of Mr Natural and the Furry Freak Brothers, discovered in the 60s and 70s. They and others helped to spawn a new generation of cartoonists both in the United States and Europe who saw the form as a simple way of reaching readers who were resistant to worthy editorialising but responsive to seeing what they could identify with - drugs, sloth, trouble with the law - being reflected on the printed page.

McGruder is also reaching an audience that previously may have felt that the funnies were for their parents rather than them and his success has already prompted other young artists to see if they can enter the hallowed gates where BC and Dilbert, Garfield and Citizen Dog roam free.

It can still, of course, be a delicate business tiptoeing through the minefields on an unmarked path between what offends and what stimulates. Last year Rutgers university in New Jersey found itself attacked after the campus newspaper had run a strip about a fictional town called Hicksville. One girl in the strip suggests that black people got "a free ride" to which another character replies: "on a slave ship". The editors, one black, one white, apologised for causing offence.

McGruder, whose guiding light is Yoda from Star Wars, is anxious to continue to try and push the boundaries of the form. The rather sterile presidential race currently under way offers plenty of ammunition. Over the past week, the ever-critical Huey has been watching television and discovering that Beavis and Butthead can sometimes provide rather more mature intellectual debate than Gore and Bradley, Bush and McCain.

Perhaps, in a small way, nothing better signifies the way the United States may change in the new century than the passing of the comforting beagle and his chums and the arrival of the uncompromising Huey and his.

fields.headline: Why fcuk spells success
fields.trailText: Once again, "shock advertising" is a hot topic of debate in the industry. We are confronted with the faces of death row prisoners by Benetton, a heroin-injecting baby by Barnardo's, and the F-word, or a version of it, by French Connection. Are these all similar examples or are there important differences between them?
fields.body:
Once again, "shock advertising" is a hot topic of debate in the industry. We are confronted with the faces of death row prisoners by Benetton, a heroin-injecting baby by Barnardo's, and the F-word, or a version of it, by French Connection. Are these all similar examples or are there important differences between them?

I remember when I first saw that great white billboard with those four letters, fcuk, in the middle. There were a few complaints and an Advertising Standards Authority investigation and it is heartily disliked by some older advertising luminaries. But what matters to me is that my eight-year-old daughter doesn't understand it because she doesn't think in anagrams. She knows the word, but she doesn't "see" the word on those posters. People who have expressed outrage and who think that this advertising pollutes the nation's morals clearly spend too much of their time doing crosswords.

I believe fcuk is a stunning piece of brand communication. French Connection's Stephen Marks has attributed the bulk of his 84% increase in profits in the first half of last year to the fcuk advertising campaign. Consumers voted by buying 120,000 T-shirts bearing the slogan. French Connection has been transformed from a run-of-the-mill name to being a youth icon right up there with Sony, Nike and Tango. It deserved its accolade as Campaign of the Year.

Benetton is a different matter. People who call for a ban on its ads play right into their hands by ensuring acres of coverage. You'd think it was spending £50m when in reality it is not a major advertiser.

I was a great supporter of Benetton's original campaigns, but I think they're unpopular with most people in the advertising industry now. This may be because they don't use an advertising agency, relying instead on the photographer, Oliviero Toscani.

The first United Colours campaign was a brilliant portrayal of Benetton's brand proposition - that it is the leading provider of the key colours for each fashion season. But Benetton was also an early proponent of the view (which I share) that advertising has a role to play in social awareness. As consumers become more sophisti cated, they look behind the products, first of all for signs of the company's reliability, then deeper to establish its ethics and behaviour. But with Benetton this appears to have got out of hand.

My experience has proved to me that if you give complete freedom to a film director or a photographer you're in danger of losing the commercial imperative. fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: The media diary is delighted to announce that our favourite author, David "blood and guts" Docherty, has secured a SECOND book deal. Rejoice, rejoice for that means that avid readers of his first (the recently published The Spirit Death, exclusively excerpted here) will not have long to wait for more heart-pumping prose.
fields.body:
The media diary is delighted to announce that our favourite author, David "blood and guts" Docherty, has secured a SECOND book deal. Rejoice, rejoice for that means that avid readers of his first (the recently published The Spirit Death, exclusively excerpted here) will not have long to wait for more heart-pumping prose. Apparently David, the BBC's deputy director of television, is planning an eco-thriller set on a beach in Cornwall for his second outing. Obviously our spies are already out, scouring the landcape for a sniff of any proofs of the new tome so that we can once again bring them to the public first. If it's anything like The Spirit Death (you remember, "the hypershock thriller about the most terrifying plague since the black death") then it will certainly be worth the wait.

The row about fur and fashion is reaching such heights that it has even touched the editor of American Vogue, the tremendously icy Anna Wintour. The pressure group, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) which disrupted last week's New York fashion shows, has produced a leaflet showing the editrix clad in a coat of furry carcasses. The front reads "Without my fur . . ." Open it up, and there's Wintour's head on a bikini-clad skeleton emblazoned with the bloody words "I am nothing."

Wintour is hardly the only trendsetter to favour fur. But Peta, which once dropped a dead racoon on her plate at lunch, hates no one more. The group's website www.voguesucks.com features a Wintour lookalike holding a copy of "Morgue" magazine.

Much worried scratching of heads at the BBC as news circulates that the corporation has bought up an option to join Channel 4's new Racing Channel, launching in November. Rum indeed, since the service is aimed at the punter and will be part-financed by the broadcasters taking a cut from bets placed via an interactive service.

Concerned critics point out that encouraging people to gamble is not something obviously compatible with public service broadcasting. Nor is it providing something the market won't - BSkyB was the loser in a bitter bidding war. Even if the deal is handed over to the BBC's commercial partner, Flextech, eyebrows will be raised.

The humbling of Piers Morgan continues apace. As rumours circulate that the Mirror editor is just about for the off, some may not have noticed the paper's launch of the Pride of Britain Awards last Wednesday.

But notice them they should. Last year Morgan was front and centre, proudly leading the judges in praise of those brave Brits whose everyday bravery warms the heart.

This year? Well, it's all a bit different. Although Piers is supposedly still the chairman of the judges there are no pictures of him at this year's launch (apart from one of the back of his head, and even then he is not named). There are not even any quotes from the great man.Piers was brutally cut out of the celebration by execs worried that linking the Morgan brand, so damaged by the share-dealing row, to the awards would only bring hoots of derision from competitors.

Piers has been feeding friends who ask him how he's feeling with the classic George Burns line. Asked how he felt about being 99, Burns said: "Well, given the alternatives, not bad."

fields.headline: Number crunching
fields.standfirst:
As a decision looms over the vexed issue of BBC funding, Janine Gibson reveals that the question of a supplementary fee for digital TV has split the Treasury and Number 10.
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: As a decision looms over the vexed issue of BBC funding, Janine Gibson reveals that the question of a supplementary fee for digital TV has split the Treasury and Number 10.
fields.body:
Back in October, a national newspaper devoted much of its front page to the prediction that the BBC's future funding would be secured by a substantial rise in the licence fee - not a supplement paid by digital subscribers. It claimed that a key trade-off for this would be letting the national audit office in to balance the corporation books.

Four months on, the stories have run through every conceivable option for the future: a digital licence fee of anything between £6 and £24, a licence fee rise of £12 to £15, a combination of the two. Rest assured that, come decision day, someone will be able to trumpet: "Ooh, I said that all along." The excesses of zeal which have characterised the BBC's bid for increased digital funding and the commercial broadcasters' determined opposition have hit peaks of lobbying meriting the question: "Have you no shame?"

The interested parties, sensing now the climax to their battle of over a year, can almost laugh, albeit wrily, in recollection. One senior government source still left with a sense of humour intact remembers the moment last November when the BBC said it needed "£700m a year and not a penny less . . . That was an extreme bit of lobbying." One partic ipant in the bad-tempered meeting at the department of culture, media and sport remembers the BBC executives present "were like kids talking about what they wanted for Christmas".

The source remembers being amazed by how many people at the BBC appeared to be genuinely surprised when it was pointed out to them with some force that they were damaging their case by refusing to quantify their demands. Others remember a crunch meeting between the DCMS and some commercial broadcasters when, poised for their killer argument, they announced that the introduction of a digital licence fee would prove "the end of digital television". "No one," they declared, "is going to switch over. It'll put the switch off back at least five years."

It would also, said Sky breathlessly, irrevocably damage Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, smugly convinced they had frightened Chris Smith, the secretary of state, off such a foolhardy plan. According to sources, all Smith was moved to think was: "Oh, be a bit more rational, please."

Gavyn Davies, the economist who led the panel charged with determining the best way forward last spring, published his report in August. He delivered a near-unanimous verdict (there was one prescient doubter) that a sliding digital licence fee was the way forward, presenting a case which admiring government officials termed "intellectually compelling". Until then, the high stakes campaign had been conducted behind closed doors. It was in the following six months that it was blown wide open.

Instantly christened the "digital poll tax" - reputedly by BSkyB's then general on the frontline Tim Allan - the supplement has since proved the main focus for the warring factions. Far from being all done and dusted by Christmas, or even by John Birt's departure last month - and great efforts were made to present the departing director-general with a conclusion as a leaving gift - the question of the BBC's funding is far from answered, despite the best efforts of some News International newspapers to settle the matter by devoting three inch headlines to a possible solution.

Trouble is no one can agree what the solution is. The talk now is that rifts between Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, Gordon Brown's Treasury, Tony Blair's number 10 advisers and Smith himself have caused the delay. Smith and Number 10 are pro digital licence fee, say those who spend a Gormenghast budget to know these things; while Byers and Brown say over their dead bodies. Or it might be the other way round, they concede. Whitehall sources would have it that the manifold distractions of daily government have necessarily taken prominence. At least one broadcasting source last week ventured the opinion that there could be no answer on this question until the troubles in Northern Ireland have been sorted, an awe-inspiring thought, but no one denies that it would have been preferable to get an answer out before Christmas as originally promised.

Davies' other, less controversial, conclusions have been quietly accepted, while the spin and counter-spin have been played out. His arguments that BBC Resources and Worldwide should be sold off are now seen as not practicable, but nevertheless valuable pointers to the corporation that it should get its act together. His half-price licence fee for the blind has been all but rubber-stamped. Crucially, his recommendations regarding external regulation of the BBC via the national audit office and the consequent removal of ultimate power from the governors is seen as one of the main planks of the government's trade-off with the corporation. You will get more money; you will have to demonstrate better how you spend it. It is the key area on which all agree.

The BBC has done itself no favours in its handling of the economics. Given that, in the perception of most, Smith's opening statement in the whole affair seemed to presuppose that the corporation needed more money, the BBC, in the words of one government source, "has been fantastically unclear on how they justify their figures". Others point out that the convoluted handover between Birt and Greg Dyke has prolonged the process and emphasise that the new director-general is far more keen to be open about accounts. Many describe the "arrogance" of the BBC's senior executives who regarded the intrusion into their plans as unwarranted. Senior government figures are still angry that they were forced to send a set of external consultants into the corporation before Christmas to analyse the BBC's finances and cost assumptions for new services. That report will be published with the decision.

"They have been very passionate that the BBC is an organisation which governments ought not to be quizzing on a business plan basis," says one. More than one player describes the corporation's detailed plans for its new digital services as laughable. Some were spectacularly ill thought-out, it is said - in particular, an early plan to provide BBC high street internet outlets, which was quietly dropped near the beginning of the campaign.

Unattributably, senior government sources will now confess that the exercise has at least proved fruitful in ensuring the corporation will now be subject to external checks. In the run-up to full charter renewal in 2006, they assert, this victory over the past must be seen in context and applauded.

The (unholy) alliance of commercial broadcasters has undoubtedly been led by Sky, though Granada, Carlton and their ITV peers have not been far behind. Sky has brought in QCs, invoked European law, refused to hand over its database to enable the digital licence fee to be collected and fought a strange skirmish over News 24 - which, if every major campaign needs a small but significant territory over which to shed blood, has undoubtedly been the Belgium of this war.

Best guesses this week suggest an answer - probably the simplest of all the convoluted options put forward - this week. Or next. It is not over yet, said the key players last week as one commercial broadcaster summed up the strength of feeling: "I will die in a ditch saying the BBC could better allocate its resources," he pledged. Goodness. It's only television.

webTitle: Police given tough targets to cut crime

fields.headline: Police given tough targets to cut crime
fields.trailText:
Police forces in England and Wales were today set targets to cut crime by up to 64% over the next five years.
 
The targets, published by the home office, have been set to narrow the gap between the best-performing forces and those with a poorer record on fighting crime.
fields.body:
Police forces in England and Wales were today set targets to cut crime by up to 64% over the next five years. The targets, published by the home office, have been set to narrow the gap between the best-performing forces and those with a poorer record on fighting crime.

During a visit to a crime-fighting initiative in east London, the prime minister said: "This more rigorous inspection regime, with the crime reduction targets all forces have signed up to, will give the police and those who are policed, a better picture of what is going on in their own neighbourhoods."

Home office minister Charles Clarke admitted there would be no automatic sanctions for forces that failed to meet the targets, but denied that the exercise was "meaningless".

Mr Blair and home secretary Jack Straw were visiting Newham council where innovative use of close-circuit TV cameras has helped drive down crimes such as shoplifting, mugging and vandalism.

The ministers welcomed the council's use of hi-tech cameras which are able to recognise the faces of known criminals as they walk through the borough's shopping centres.

Across the country the home office hopes to see vehicle crime fall by 30% over five years from 1998/99 figures. Domestic burglaries are hoped to fall by 26%.

The five forces with the highest robbery rates have been told to reduce them by 10% in Greater Manchester and Merseyside, 15% in the Metropolitan Police area, 34% in West Midlands and 22% in West Yorkshire.

Launching the initiative, home secretary Jack Straw compared the setting of targets and publishing of new league tables for police performance with league tables published by schools which had helped local people monitor the performance of their public services.

Targets for individual forces range from 10% to 64%.

He said: "For the first time there will be a meaningful target regime which police forces themselves will own, driving up morale and performance. "And for the first time people will be able to measure the success of the fight against crime in their own back yard."

Inner city police forces have also been set targets to reduce the number of muggings by up to 34% within the next five years.

The targets published today were drawn up in consultation with police forces which will be able to amend them before they are finalised at the end of next month.

Sir John Evans, president of the association of chief police officers, said forces had drawn up their targets on the basis that they would receive enough money and officers to fund their operations properly.

He warned that the enormous over-application for funds freed up by the home office to recruit 5,000 new officers could cause difficulties in meeting the targets for forces which were relying on extra manpower.

He also warned that fighting crime was a partnership and that other agencies, such as local authorities, should be accountable for meeting the targets.

fields.headline: Nats sell-off hits more turbulence
fields.trailText: The government may be powerless to prevent a takeover by France or Germany of Britain's £1bn air traffic control service if it proceeds with its controversial plans to sell off the business, treasury sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
The government may be powerless to prevent a takeover by France or Germany of Britain's £1bn air traffic control service if it proceeds with its controversial plans to sell off the business, treasury sources confirmed last night.

The treasury's view is that ministers would not be able to place a protective cocoon around air traffic control (Nats) and allow a British company to take a majority share holding in the business.

The sale is planned later this year on the back of legislation going through parliament, against mounting opposition from Labour backbenchers, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats.

Whitehall sources say that the sell-off is affected by European law, and that companies like the French multinational Thomson CSF, which the French government owns a large stake, and US group Lockheed Martin would not be prevented from bidding for Nats.

The treasury's view is at odds with those of Nats officials who, taking the lead from their chairman Sir Roy McNulty, a successful businessman brought in by the government to speed up the process, have argued that they would ensure that a British company retained the major shareholding.

This privatisation will be unique. Under the sale the government would keep 49% of the shares, with 5% going to staff and 46% to the private sector. But ministers are now taking steps to retain just 25% of the shareholding at a later date. Concerns over national security will ensure that the British government retains a sizeable stake.

Paul Noon, leader of the air controllers' union (IPMS), has written to Brussels asking for immediate clarification on the issue. In a letter to Alexander Schaub, director general of the EU's competition division, Mr Noon has asked for a view "whether the proposed Nats' legislation complies with EU law".

The letter says: "It is crucially important that the EU's position is made clear soon, as it will affect the legal basis of the new agreement. It cannot enhance the standing of the EU for the UK government so openly to flout a legal opinion which could still lead to proceedings in the EU court."

Government sources last night stressed that while Nats was advising on the sell-off, the final decision about who it would be sold to rested with the government. Ministers may try to argue that the sale is so unusual, with 5% of the staff being allowed a stake, that it does not contravene European law and should be allowed to go ahead.

Ministers will this week suffer a setback to their privatisation plans with the publication of a hostile report into the plan from the commons transport select committee, chaired by Gwyneth Dunwoody, Labour MP for Crewe and Nantwich.

The committee is likely to oppose the plan on safety grounds. It will say that a private company should not be given the responsibility of controlling the movement of civilian and military aircraft and that such a move will create a dangerous precedent.

The plan will be brought back to the commons in May for a third reading, the moment when backbenchers have decided to apply maximum pressure on ministers to drop the privatisation. Mr Noon said last night: "We want to know from the EU what procedure we can follow if the government's plans do not conform with EU law."

Another offer which the controllers will exploit is the 5% shareholding on offer to employees. A senior traffic controller said yesterday that the share offer was extremely limited and that staff would have to wait some time before they could make any profit.

Mr Noon is also asking Brussels whether the government's plan to retain a "golden" share in the business is in breach of European law.

The share is designed to help the government to veto any organisation from taking over Nats, if it disliked the organisation, but the share may be worthless.

Nats facts

The service employs 5,200 people and has an annual turnover in excess of £500m; 85% of income derives from providing air traffic control services from RAF West Drayton, the control centre at Manchester Airport, and a facility at Prestwick.

Since the 1991 Gulf war, there has been a sustained increase in traffic levels, typically more than 5% a year.

Nats wants eventually to operate only two centres, a new one at Swanwick and one at Prestwick.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Leonardo DiCaprio at the Berlin Film Festival, Kira Muratova wins Andrzej Wajda Freedom Prize, more tribulations for Lord of the Rings, Jennifer Aniston tipped to play Mary Jane, and no shenanigans for Spacey
fields.body:
 Just to increase the teen frenzy that has greeted Leonardo DiCaprio ever since he arrived for Berlin Film Festival on Friday, BZ - a German tabloid newspaper - has offered a thousand marks (just over £300) to the first Berlin girl who delivers photographic evidence of her kissing the baby-faced star. The news should please the star: at every press conference for The Beach he has lamented that he has no control over his image.

 Kira Muratova has won the first ever Andrzej Wajda Freedom Prize at the Berlin Film Festival. The director himself presented the $10,000 prize to the Russian producer for her work and her "commitment to truth" during the Soviet era. Many of her films were banned by the Soviet Union, and some were not shown for up to 17 years. Muratova, winner of Berlin's Golden Bear film award in 1990, said the award would be a useful injection of funds for her film business. A Letter to America, her 20-minute short designed as an ironic message from suffering intellectuals in Odessa to their friends who have managed to emigrate to the United States, is being screened at this year's festival.

 What with losing his New Zealand army cavaliers to East Timor, seeing his set being swept away during freak floods, and having to give lead actor Stuart Townsend the big heave-ho, things haven't been going all that smoothly for Lord of the Rings director, Peter Jackson. The next upset according to TheOneRing.Net is that Uma Thurman will not be cast as the female warrior, Eowyn, in the first instalment of the trilogy. There is no word yet as to why she left the part, or who her replacement will be.

 Jennifer Aniston is the favourite to play Spiderman's gal pal, Mary Jane, in the forthcoming Spiderman film, according to SpidermanHype.Com. The producers are said to be attracted to Brad Pitt's squeeze because she's a household name, but is cheaper to hire than a number of other actresses and, most importantly for any superhero, she's quite short.

 Don't expect any under-age shenanigans with high school cheerleaders from Kevin Spacey's new film, Pay it Forward. Governors has just given permission for the film, about a 12-year-old boy's desire to make the world a better place, to be shot at an LA school on one condition: that the film is rated lower than an R.

Casting couch

 Director Jon Amiel is to take Thomas Hardy's Far From The Madding Crowd and turn it into a western called North of Cheyenne. Set in Wyoming, not Wessex, the film will focus on a headstrong woman who is loved by a number of men. No cast is attached as yet, and Amiel's commitment would be subject to his approval of the casting.

 Girl, Interrupted scribe James Mangold is to write and co-direct a biopic about the tumultuous life of singer Johnny Cash.

fields.headline: Lucasfilm dismiss 'rainbow Star Wars' rumour
fields.trailText: Lucasfilm has quickly stamped on reports that the next Star Wars film is about to have a multi-racial cast
fields.body:
Lucasfilm has quickly stamped on reports that the next Star Wars film is about to have a multi-racial cast. On the official Star Wars website, company spokeswoman Lynne Hale has refuted Wednesday's story about the types of parts to be cast in Star Wars: Episode 2.

Dismissing the rumour as totally "false", she says that George Lucas is still working on the script and that the casting director Robin Gurland is currently concentrating on casting Anakin. She will not begin to cast other parts until she gets a character breakdown from Lucas and, in any case, the descriptions that Variety quoted would not be appropriate for a Star Wars film.

"The diversity of actors who have appeared in Star Wars such as Pernilla August (Anakin's mother), Hugh Quarshie (Captain Panaka), Dhruv Chanchani (Kitster), and Kristina DaSilva (Rabe) were chosen for the talent they brought to their roles - not because they were Swedish, Ghanaian, Indian, or Brazilian," says a frustrated Hale, adding, "The Star Wars movies have always been populated with a rich cast of characters that make up this fantasy world."

webTitle: American Psycho faces legal action over rating

fields.headline: American Psycho faces legal action over rating
fields.trailText: An American lawyer, who represents three of the students who were murdered in the high school shooting in Kentucky, has threatened to sue the makers of American Psycho if the film does not get a NC-17 and an under 17-year-old commits a copy-cat crime after seeing it
fields.body:
An American lawyer, who represents three of the students who were murdered in the high school shooting in Kentucky, has threatened to sue the makers of American Psycho if the film does not get a NC-17 and an under 17-year-old commits a copy-cat crime after seeing it.

Jack Thompson, a Florida lawyer, who has already filed a lawsuit against the makers of The Basketball Diaries - the Leonardo DiCaprio film whose school shooting scene was said to have inspired the rampage at the high school in Columbine last year - says that he will sue Lions Gate, the producer, and even the American censors, the MPAA, if the certification is not given.

The fact that Thompson has not seen the film or read the script does not give much weight to his case and both Mark Urman the Lions Gate co-president and the MPPA chairman do not seem particularly worried about the threat. Urman says, "The film's treatment of violence is highly tasteful and oblique and, by today's standards, tame", while MPAA chairman Jack Valenti has dismissed the case, saying, "I think the court will probably throw it out. We've been sued before and we've never lost."

The MPPA's concerns have always centred around the sex scenes rather than the violence; it wants the scene where Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) has anal sex with two women whilst watching himself in a mirror to be cut. However, it appears that Canadians, who had thought the film would be subject in Canada to the same ratings code that control American films, will be able to see the movie intact with an R-18 rating. Lions Gate Films told the Toronto Star that despite early word that the R-rated version would be the only cut of the film available in North America, the company has changed its mind and will release the uncut version in Canada in April.

webTitle: Miller gets the nod for selector's job

fields.headline: Miller gets the nod for selector's job
fields.trailText: After keeping faith with standard practice by throwing away yet another one-day tournament, England are poised to turn tradition on its head and appoint Geoff Miller - the uncharismatic former off-spinner-cum-after-dinner speaker - as their fourth selector.
fields.body:
After keeping faith with standard practice by throwing away yet another one-day tournament, England are poised to turn tradition on its head and appoint Geoff Miller - the uncharismatic former off-spinner-cum-after-dinner speaker - as their fourth selector.

Miller, whose appointment is expected to be announced on Wednesday, is a surprise choice ahead of the former Test captains Ian Botham and Ray Illingworth.

The 47-year-old is believed to have won the job ahead of another unexpected candidate, his old off-spinning colleague Vic Marks. His primary role will be to identify new talent on the county scene.

The choice of Miller - who will join the captain Nasser Hussain, coach Duncan Fletcher and chairman of selectors David Graveney on the panel - is a bold departure from recent tradition. His predecessors Graham Gooch and Mike Gatting, who were dumped during last summer's disastrous home series against New Zealand, were outstanding cricketers who captained England with distinction.

By contrast, Miller was an unspectacular all-rounder who batted with little flair and spun the ball only marginally in his 34 Tests. Despite taking 60 wickets and averaging over 25 with the bat, he is best known for mopping up the rebound catch initially spilled by Chris Tavare which gave England a famous three-run victory over Australia in Melbourne in 1982.

He has since done some coaching work with England youth teams, but it is on the after-dinner circuit with his humourous cricketing anecdotes that Miller has become a real success story. Indeed it was his career flexibility which apparently gave him the edge.

"Mine's a very flexible lifestyle," Miller said, "and I'm prepared to work around the work I have."

 The banned fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar may play in this month's Test series against Sri Lanka after all, according to the Pakistan Cricket Board chairman Tauqir Zia. "He has been cleared by the International Cricket Council and now it's entirely up to the board to decide if we want to play him," Zia said yesterday.

Pakistan lost the opening one-dayer at Karachi by 29 runs, Marvan Atapattu hitting an unbeaten 119 for Sri Lanka.

webTitle: From the Hindu Kush to the Cotswolds

fields.headline: From the Hindu Kush to the Cotswolds
fields.trailText: It's difficult to imagine any place less like Kabul than Moreton-in-Marsh. The 70-odd asylum seekers now cooped up in the Fire Service College on the outskirts of the little Cotswolds town might catch a whiff of the bazaar in the regular Tuesday street market (there is an excellent spice stall), and, being from a culture steeped in superstition, they would no doubt be intrigued by the rich local lore of ghosts. Otherwise, they might be on a different planet.
fields.body:
It's difficult to imagine any place less like Kabul than Moreton-in-Marsh. The 70-odd asylum seekers now cooped up in the Fire Service College on the outskirts of the little Cotswolds town might catch a whiff of the bazaar in the regular Tuesday street market (there is an excellent spice stall), and, being from a culture steeped in superstition, they would no doubt be intrigued by the rich local lore of ghosts. Otherwise, they might be on a different planet.

At least it is a comfortable new world. The would-be refugees are being put up in three accommodation blocks in sprawling College grounds. They are penned in by a hastily built wire fence, and guarded by several dozen Group Four security men, but the views are pretty and the immediate surroundings are fraught with interest.

The College campus - a former RAF base - covers 550 acres. Some 6000 fire officers, from all over Britain and abroad, pass through its handsome gates each year, to learn the latest in firefighting lore.

To help them there is a firmly landlocked full size ship, an oil rig, and even a section of motorway. Off-duty facilities are also lavish: there is a swimming pool, gymnasium, sports complex, library and social club.

The College employs some 250 instructors and other staff, costs around £16m a year to run, and like all government agencies it is expected to pay its way with fees and other income. There was a detailed Home Office review of its finances last year and too the consternation of local folk, there have been ugly rumours of its imminent closure.

The sports and social facilities at the College are popular with local residents, who can join by subscription. That part of the campus is apparently still open to club members, though the press is being told, very firmly, to stay away.

All inquiries to the College are being redirected to the Home Office, which is similarly discouraging. "This is a very sensitive matter and we cannot allow any interference with the asylum procedures", said a spokeswoman for the immigration desk.

Oddly enough, the entire telephone system at the Home Office crashed shortly afterwards.

fields.headline: Netta Rheinberg's selection
fields.trailText: 1 Sir Donald Bradman
fields.body:
1 Sir Donald Bradman

He started to make headlines when very young. His batting dominated the world of cricket. He showed excellent leadership and had a strong grasp of the game as a whole. He went into administration later on, and proved a great influence.

2 Sir Garry Sobers

A skilful and intelligent bowler and a player able to cope with all the facets of batting. His mere presence in a team daunted opponents. He was a fine character, unselfish and a true sportsman.

3 Viv Richards

A fearless, dominating cricketer - certainly on a footing with Bradman and Sobers. He was always able to make the runs when needed, and did things his way. He displayed the same qualities as a captain and rejected the wearing of helmets.

4 Ian Botham

He was always daring and aggressive and was the leading allrounder of his time. He was able to win a game for his team and attracted spectators wherever he played.

5 Denis Compton

First and foremost a great entertaining cricketer. A genius with the bat and a natural, he too was a great crowd-puller, and loved any challenge. Despite deterioration in his later years, he remained much loved.

Molly Hide was the greatest female cricketer of the century. I managed her first tour, and her knowledge and flair, and inspired leadership, made her unique. She led England in 11 Tests, winning four, and was regarded as the finest allrounder in the country. She was also a selector for Surrey and England. Not enough was made of her achievements when she died in 1995.

Netta Rheinberg has been active in the Women's Cricket Association for half a century, and is now a member of MCC.

This item appears in the March 2000 edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly, now on sale in the UK

fields.headline: Looking after the lost children
fields.standfirst: In the light of a worrying report on school exclusions, Martin Wainwright examines one city's solution to the problem
fields.trailText: In the light of a worrying report on school exclusions, Martin Wainwright examines one city's solution to the problem
fields.body:
One of the general rules about children which unites almost every expert - however much they bicker about everything else - is that they like to know where they are.

It makes it all the more alarming that today's report on school exclusions finds that two thirds of secondary pupils, and a third of primary ones, never return to mainstream schools once they have been officially told to leave the classrooms.

They are the lost boys and girls, who will soon cost the country millions in the underworld of drugs and crime and their concomitants, the courts and prisons. The majority have no stable refuge at home when school rejects them; indeed their problems are often created by what passes for their family life. School is the first clear framework they have known.

Exclusion is exclusion, however, and it cannot work if children know that the penalty is false and that all will be rapidly forgiven without any reform on their part. Allowing them back into class to disrupt the schooling of other pupils is not kind to anyone; it saps teachers' energy, creates misery for other children and blurs the very framework which, above all else, the troubled pupils need.

In such dilemmas, with several hundred local education authorities and a history of reluctant schoolboys, we should hardly be short of solutions. Fortunately, we are not. The charity Include, which produced today's report, should buy itself a day return to Leeds to check out one of the most successful ways of dealing with the challenge.

Exclusions in the city, which has plenty of hardcore deprivation alongside the glitz of Harvey Nichols and all-night clubbing, stood at 315 in the school year 1994/5. By last year they had dropped to 155, or 0.1 percent of the school population. In the current year, only three pupils had been excluded by November and the tally has only recently reached double figures.

There has been no magic involved, but a well thought-out strategy of 'positive behaviour strategies' in each school, encouraging the devolution of power from town hall to the head's study which tends to make for quick and effective decisions based on personal knowledge. Every school has set itself targets and has chosen from a range of treatments, including old-fashioned fixed-term, temporary exclusions (with rigorous visits and monitoring) and novel ones like 'time-out' rooms and 'buddy rooms.'

The first provides a space - still within the mainstream school - for tempers to cool and reflection to take place. The second, at which Leeds is particularly good, offers one-to-one help from teachers or volunteer mentors.

Funding has been helped by a successful bid to the government's 'Excellence in Cities' pot of extra money for schools; but the strategy is not expensive. Ofsted's report on Leeds earlier this month found that the city's spending on excluded pupils is among the lowest of all England's metropolitan councils. The key is exclusion from normal school life but not from the school itself; an acknowledgement of a problem rather than outright rejection. Significantly, too, the philosophy has spread to Leeds' four pupil referral units, which take the most disruptive pupils when all other measures fail. All but a handful are back in mainstream education after six months.

In for a pleasant spell

It hardly ranks with exclusion, but the national loss of spelling ability has increasingly worried authorities in government departments, classrooms and above all, saloon bars. Historically the Guardian has not, perhaps, been best-placed to comment on this, with an exotic history of typographical glitches including, allegedly, the masthead once appearing as 'Grauniad'.

But help for the pedants among us has now arrived, courtesy of the net. It's perfectly true, as cheeky sixth-formers tell you, that Shakespeare couldn't spell and that it didn't really matter or affect his wonderful writing. But Shakespeare didn't have to do web searches or send email.

He would have sorted things out after a few server failures to locate Annhathaway.com or failed attempts to email Frances.Bacon@virgin.net. Good spelling needs a good reason; and, unlike all those doomed Monday morning school tests, clarity in the world of electronic communications is a very good one.

webTitle: IRA move 'unspecific and too late', says Mandelson

fields.headline: IRA move 'unspecific and too late', says Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, this morning hailed the IRA's latest message on putting arms beyond use as encouraging but said it was ''too unspecific and came too late'' to prevent suspension of the power-sharing executive.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, this morning hailed the IRA's latest message on putting arms beyond use as encouraging but said it was ''too unspecific and came too late'' to prevent suspension of the power-sharing executive.

In a speech aimed at reviving the faltering peace process he told the British-Irish inter-parliamentary body meeting at the House of Commons that the Patten reforms of the police would not be halted and suspension would last no longer than necessary. He is due to meet the Irish foreign minister Brian Cowen in Belfast today to discuss the approach of the two governments to the Good Friday agreement and the intractable issue of decommissioning.

The IRA's last-minute approach, made on Friday to General John de Chastelain's commission on arms, should not be underestimated, said Mr Mandelson. "If it means what it appears to mean it would be the first sign that the IRA are after all prepared to give up their arms once and for all.'' But the initiative was too unspecific and, with power-sharing institutions on the point of collapse, there had been no time to clarify it.

Mr Mandelson said the 72-day experiment in devolution had proved the most effective and democratic form of government Northern Ireland had ever had and the politicians involved had fulfilled the highest expectations.

He assured republicans and nationalists that reforms of the Royal Ulster Constabulary would continue despite the resumption of direct rule from London. While he understood the passionate attachment to the name, especially on the part of people who had suffered in the Troubles, a nine to one religious imbalance could not be allowed to continue if the police were to be fully effective. But he warned republicans they must understand why unionists were reluctant to join in government without decommissioning.

webTitle: Smith's striking path to the ultimate honour

fields.headline: Smith's striking path to the ultimate honour
fields.trailText: If Britain and America are two countries divided by a common language, it can surely never be more evident than in football - sorry, soccer. It is enough to have to unravel the complex league structures across the Atlantic (are there any?), and trying to decipher the lexicon (Ryan Giggs, I guess, would be wide offense) only serves to accelerate the confusion. When it relates to the hitherto simple art of scoring, the divide could not be wider.
fields.body:
If Britain and America are two countries divided by a common language, it can surely never be more evident than in football - sorry, soccer. It is enough to have to unravel the complex league structures across the Atlantic (are there any?), and trying to decipher the lexicon (Ryan Giggs, I guess, would be wide offense) only serves to accelerate the confusion. When it relates to the hitherto simple art of scoring, the divide could not be wider.

Americans insist on giving credit for assists, which means the final pass to the scorer (however distant from goal) is awarded a single point. The goal itself, being naturally more important, gets two points. The points are then added together and divided by the number of games to provide the statistics.

Perhaps this is why Kelly Smith, from Garston in Hertfordshire, is still an anonymous figure to most of her compatriots. No one this side of the pond has been able to work it out: just how good is her 176 points in 51 matches for a 3.45 points-per-game average.

The answer is very good. If you listen to the Americans, they will crank it up a notch or two. "She is one of the greatest players in the world," says Marie Wozniak, who runs public relations for Seton Hall University, Smith's New Jersey home for the past three years. When you do decipher the statistics, you get confirmation. Smith's points-per-game average is a college all-time record, as is her goals-per-game average of 1.49. The rate is not far off Dixie Dean's English record of 60 goals in 39 matches (1.53), far and away above anything anyone has ever achieved in the Premiership.

On February 1 Seton Hall paid her their highest possible compliment by retiring her number, six. The Oilers did it for Gretzky, the Bulls for Jordan, Seton Hall for Smith. The ceremony took place at half-time in a college basketball match, with the giant screen showing video replays of her goals. No other non-basketball player has ever been so honoured in Seton Hall's history.

"It was immense," Smith says. "In front of 9,000 people they presented me with my shirt. My mum and dad were crying, they had flown them over for the occasion."

Smith was encouraged to play from her infant days by her father Bernard, but as a nine-year-old was dropped by two boys' teams because their opponents refused to play against her. At 10, with no other options on offer, she joined the grown-ups, playing for Watford Ladies.

"They seemed so huge. It was kind of frightening. Being so young, with all those women closing in on the ball and pushing me off the ball, I think that's where I got my strength."

Smith continued to bridge the age gap, moving into senior football with Arsenal and earning her first international cap at only 16. The goals were soon forthcoming for England: Smith scored four times in the European championship qualifying matches in 1995 and 1996, but the goals were to no avail. England did not qualify for the finals - a familiar story.

Smith's next season in English football would be her last for a while. She was talent spotted at the Watford football festival.

"This guy was recruiting for American Universities and thought I was a really good player. My dad gave him our phone number and I got calls within a week or so. They wanted me to drop everything," she recalls.

Seton Hall offered her a degree course in sports science and physical education and, one would hope, the talent scout got a raise. For in her first year in New Jersey Smith not only broke all the college records but became the first player ever to win the regional (Big East) honours as rookie and senior offensive player of the year at the same time.

The awards and the goals kept coming. This winter Smith was third in the most prestigious of them all, the Hermann Trophy, even though her college did not progress beyond the regional semi-finals; Smith was injured for the crucial match.

She will graduate in May and hopes the explosion of interest in North America will fuel a professional league, the launch of which is planned for 2001.

The end of college football has resolved one problem. Seton Hall invested heavily in their soccer star, paying for her tuition, her lodgings and a car, so Smith knew where her loyalties had to lie. Since August 1998 she has not been available for England. The Football Association even approached Fifa when Smith was not released for the European championship qualifier against Switzerland in October last year. One can imagine the American response. Fifa who?

But on Sunday the 21-year-old striker lines up against Portugal at Barnsley in the second qualifier. If she finds it strange back among English team-mates, she will find it curiouser in the echoing galleries of Oakwell, having sat in on the World Cup opening ceremony in the US last summer when 78,000 fans turned out. Such a celebration is beyond the British game.

Smith would love the progress in England to mirror that of America but the game we invented has been re-invented with a new shape and a new language. Smith could help us catch up but, if it does not happen soon, we too could end up calling it women's soccer.

webTitle: London Fashion Week gets under way

fields.headline: London Fashion Week gets under way
fields.trailText: London Fashion Week, which began yesterday, will not only showcase Britain's brightest Fashion talents. The world's fashion press and buyers will also be treated to a tour of some of the capital's recent architectural achievements.
fields.body:
London Fashion Week, which began yesterday, will not only showcase Britain's brightest Fashion talents. The world's fashion press and buyers will also be treated to a tour of some of the capital's recent architectural achievements.

Yesterday's highlight show by Elspeth Gibson was staged in the Floral Hall of the Royal Opera House, while Julien MacDonald, who holds the prestigious final slot on Thursday evening, will set up his catwalk in the Millennium Dome.

Gibson, 34, is one of Britain's most successful young designers. Winner of the 1998 new generation designer of the year award for her women's wear, she has a toiletries line and designs a children's wear collection for Debenhams.

She makes clothes that are feminine without being simpering or twee. As she once said: "My customer wants to wear her beaded dress while dodging traffic in Oxford Street, not sitting on a swing in an orchard."

Last night Gibson included some stronger, more directional clothes, including ballroom-style full-circle embroidered skirts with black net underskirts, cuffed knickerbockers and a hipster pleated skirt worn with a cropped blouson jacket.

Some of these looked a little clumsy, however, and the collection was far stronger where she stuck to what she does best: simple, sexy clothes.

The rock'n'roll velvet hipsters in purple and burgundy looked like hits, but it was the evening dresses that stole the show. The feather-trimmed black angora dresses, one with a plunging v-neck, the other with one shoulder bare, were irresistibly feline.

As for accessories, you don't get much sexier than glitter mules and boots with precipitous cigarette heels.

The most hotly awaited shows of the week include those of rising stars such as Matthew Williamson and Julien MacDonald, avant garde talents such as Boudicca and Shelley Fox, and Alexander McQueen.

fields.headline: Fools for love
fields.standfirst: Everybody wants it, even those who claim to have given up hope. But unless we drop our romantic illusions, most of us will go to our graves with no experience of true love. bell hooks on why Valentine's-style sentimentality is the enemy of intimacy
fields.trailText: Everybody wants it, even those who claim to have given up hope. But unless we drop our romantic illusions, most of us will go to our graves with no experience of true love.
fields.body:
In her first book, The Bluest Eye, novelist Toni Morrison identifies the idea of romantic love as one "of the most destructive ideas in the history of human thought". Its destructiveness resides in the notion that we come to love with no will and no capacity to choose. This illusion, perpetuated by so much romantic lore, stands in the way of our learning how to love. To sustain our fantasy, we substitute romance for love.

When romance is depicted as a project, or so the mass media would have us believe, women are the architects and the planners. Everyone likes to imagine that women are romantics, sentimental about love, that men follow where women lead. Even in non-heterosexual relationships, the paradigms of leader and follower often prevail, with one person assuming the role deemed feminine and another the designated masculine role.

No doubt it was someone playing the role of leader who conjured up the notion that we "fall in love", that we lack choice and decision when choosing a partner because when the chemistry is present, when the click is there, it just happens - it overwhelms - it takes control. This way of thinking about love seems to be especially useful for men who are socialised to be out of touch with what they feel.

In the essay Love and Need, Thomas Merton contends: "The expression to 'fall in love' reflects a peculiar attitude towards love and life itself - a mixture of fear, awe, fascination and confusion. It implies suspicion, doubt, hesitation in the presence of something unavoidable, yet not fully reliable." If you do not know what you feel, then it is difficult to choose love; it is better to fail. Then you do not have to be responsible for your actions.

Erotic attraction often serves as the catalyst for an intimate connection between two people, but it is not a sign of love. Exciting, pleasurable sex can take place between two people who do not even know each other. Yet the vast majority of males in our society are convinced that their erotic longing indicates who they should, and can, love. Seduced by erotic desire, they often end up in relationships with partners with whom they share no common interests or values.

Women rarely choose men solely on the basis of erotic connection. While most females acknowledge the importance of sexual pleasure, they recognise that it is not the only ingredient needed to build strong relationships. The sexism of stereotyping women as care-givers did make it acceptable for women to articulate emotional needs. Women who have only named their erotic hunger in the wake of the permission given by the feminist movement have always been able to speak their hunger for love.

But this does not mean that we find the love we long for. Shared sexual passion can be a sustaining and binding force in a troubled relationship, but it is not the proving ground for love.

Even though sex matters, most of us are no more able to articulate sexual needs and longing than we are able to speak our desire for love. Ironically, the presence of life-threatening sexually transmitted diseases has become the reason more couples communicate with each other about erotic behaviour. Where once knowing nothing was the basis for excitement and erotic intensity, knowing more is now the basis.

Cultural acceptance of this shift shows that we are all capable of changing our attitudes about "falling in love". We can acknowledge the "click" we feel when we meet someone new as just that - a mysterious sense of connection that may or may not have anything to do with love. How different things might be if, rather than saying "I am in love" we said "I am loving" or "I will love". Our patterns around romantic love are unlikely to change if we do not change our language.

I have learned over the years that we may meet a true love and that our lives may be transformed by such an encounter even when it does not lead to sexual pleasure, committed bonding or even sustained contact. The myth of true love - that fairytale vision of two souls who meet, join and live happily thereafter - is the stuff of childhood fantasy. True love does not always lead to happily ever after and even when it does, sustaining love still takes work.

Usually we imagine that true love will be intensely pleasurable and romantic, full of love and light. In fact, true love is all about work. The poet Rainer Maria Rilke wisely observed: "Like so much else, people have also misunderstood the place of love in life, they have made it into play and pleasure because they thought that play and pleasure was more blissful than work; but there is nothing happier than work, and love, just because it is the extreme happiness, can be nothing else but work."

The essence of true love is mutual recognition - two individuals seeing each other as they really are. We all know that the usual approach is to meet someone we like and put our best self forward, or even at times a false self, one we believe will be more appealing to the person we want to attract. When our real self appears in its entirety, when the good behaviour becomes too much to maintain or the masks are taken away, disappointment comes. All too often, individuals feel, after the fact - when feelings are hurt and hearts are broken - that it was a case of mistaken identity, that the loved one is a stranger. They saw what they wanted to see rather than what was really there.

True love is a different story. When it happens, individuals usually feel in touch with each other's core identity. Embarking on such a relationship is frightening precisely because we feel there is no place to hide. We are known.

The heartbeat of true love is the willingness to reflect on one's actions and to process and communicate this reflection with the loved one. Honesty and openness is always the foundation of insightful dialogue. Most of us have not been raised in homes where we have seen two deeply loving grown folks talking together. We do not see this on television or at the movies. And how can any of us communicate with men who have been told all their lives that they should not express what they feel? Men who want to love and do not know how must first learn to let their hearts speak. Choosing to be fully honest, to reveal ourselves, is risky. The experience of true love gives us the courage to risk.

As long as we are afraid to risk, we cannot know love. Hence the truism: "Love is letting go of fear." Our hearts connect with lots of folks in a lifetime but most of us will go to our graves with no experience of true love. This is in no way tragic, as most of us run the other way when true love comes near. Since true love sheds light on those aspects of ourselves we may wish to deny or hide, enabling us to see ourselves clearly and without shame, it is not surprising that so many individuals who say they want to know love turn away when such love beckons.

No matter how often we turn our minds and hearts away - or how stubbornly we refuse to believe in its magic - true love exists. Everyone wants it, even those who claim to have given up hope. But not everyone is ready. True love appears only when our hearts are ready.

Not everyone can bear the weight of true love. Wounded hearts turn away from love because they do not want to do the work of healing necessary to sustain and nurture love.

When one knows a true love, the transformative force of that love lasts even when we no longer have the company of that person with whom we experienced profound mutual care and growth. Thomas Merton writes: "We discover our true selves in love." Many of us are not ready to accept and embrace our true selves, particularly when living with integrity alienates us from our familiar worlds. Often, when we undergo a process of self-recovery, for a time we may find ourselves more alone. Writing about choosing solitude over company that does not nurture one's soul, Maya Angelou reminds us: "It is never lonesome in Babylon." Fear of facing true love may actually lead some individuals to remain in situations of lack and unfulfilment. There they are not alone, they are not at risk.

It transforms our entire life. Genuine love is a personal revolution. Love takes your ideas, your desires and your actions, and welds them together in one experience and one living reality which is a new you."

Without "falling in love", we can recognise that moment of mysterious connection between our soul and that of another person as love's attempt to call us back to our true selves.

Intensely connecting with another soul, we are made bold and courageous. Using that fearless will to bond and connect as a catalyst for choosing and committing ourselves to love, we are able to love ruly and deeply, to give and receive a love that lasts, a love that is "stronger than death".
