Its destructiveness resides in the notion that we come to love with no will and no capacity to choose. This illusion, perpetuated by so much romantic lore, stands in the way of our learning how to love. To sustain our fantasy, we substitute romance for love. When romance is depicted as a project, or so the mass media would have us believe, women are the architects and the planners. Everyone likes to imagine that women are romantics, sentimental about love, that men follow where women lead. Even in non-heterosexual relationships, the paradigms of leader and follower often prevail, with one person assuming the role deemed feminine and another the designated masculine role. The essence of true love is mutual recognition - two individuals seeing each other as they really are. We all know that the usual approach is to meet someone we like and put our best self forward, or even at times a false self, one we believe will be more appealing to the person we want to attract. When our real self appears in its entirety, when the good behaviour becomes too much to maintain or the masks are taken away, disappointment comes. All too often, individuals feel, after the fact - when feelings are hurt and hearts are broken - that it was a case of mistaken identity, that the loved one is a stranger. They saw what they wanted to see rather than what was really there. True love is a different story. When it happens, individuals usually feel in touch with each other's core identity. Embarking on such a relationship is frightening precisely because we feel there is no place to hide. We are known. Honesty and openness is always the foundation of insightful dialogue. Most of us have not been raised in homes where we have seen two deeply loving grown folks talking together. No matter how often we turn our minds and hearts away - or how stubbornly we refuse to believe in its magic - true love exists. Everyone wants it, even those who claim to have given up hope. fields.headline: Under pressure
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we ask a county cricketer what he's been up to in the close season. This week we talk to Worcestershire wicketkeeper Steven Rhodes
fields.trailText: Steven Rhodes, 35, the Worcestershire wicketkeeper, played for England in 11 Tests , taking 46 catches and three stumpings. He also played in nine one-day internationals (9 ct, 2 st). He was a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1995.
fields.body:
Steven Rhodes, 35, the Worcestershire wicketkeeper, played for England in 11 Tests , taking 46 catches and three stumpings. He also played in nine one-day internationals (9 ct, 2 st). He was a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1995.

"I've been working on the commercial side for Worcestershire, answering questions from journalists and helping to promote the club. It is something which I would consider going into after my career as a cricketer ends.

I have also been coaching a lot, including the cricket team at Bradford University. After the season ended in September, I went on a cricket tour to Barbados, which was brilliant. The previous month I'd taken my wife and three kids to Disney World in Florida. It was amazing. I needed to relax after the season.

I started training for next season as soon as the last one ended. I've had a few niggling injuries but nothing too serious. Officially, Worcestershire do not start training until March 25, although we did have a session in the nets last Monday, so I'll be fit and raring to go by next season.

I haven't seen any of the Worcestershire guys over the break. I do see them socially during the season but from the end of March to the end of September you live in each other's pockets, so it is nice to have a break. The winter is when most cricketers want to spend time with their families, and that is just what I did.

I had a very family-orientated Christmas and New Year. For the millennium, we went out with five other families and started with a good pub lunch, you know, the full works - starter, main course and pudding. We then all came back to my house to see in Year 2000.

I've been watching England in South Africa too. I listen to it on the radio mostly. It's a shame they haven't got the desired results. On a positive note, England have seen the emergence of Michael Vaughan. The selectors have made the right choices for their wicketkeepers too. Alec Stewart is our best keeper and also a terrific batsman. He thoroughly deserved his place on the tour. Chris Read has gained valuable experience, which shows that England are thinking about the future.

My goals for this year are for Worcestershire to gain promotion into the first division. We did well in the National League last season, so we need to get ourselves into a good position this year and hopefully go on to win it.

I've been roped into taking my son George to see Toy Story 2 next week, so I've got that to look forward to! Make sure you put that I am being pressurised into going. Apart from screaming at my teenage daughter Holly to turn her music down, I'll be concentrating on the start of the season."

Steven Rhodes was talking to Jackie Burke.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
Bob Greene, www.chicagotribune.com

Some people are cancelling their subscriptions. There's no getting around it. Perhaps the most dismaying thing I have found in readers' emails can be summed up in sentences like these:

"I've been reading [your column] for about two years now online. I even cancelled my subscription. Why should I pay for a paper every morning when I can read just what I want for free, without getting my fingers dirty?"

The most difficult part of all this to understand, for those of us who write the stories, take the photos and lay out the pages that appear in daily newspapers, is that readers are not acting in defiance of what the newspaper companies are offering to them- they're gladly taking the publishers up on their offer. The publishing executives of newspaper corporations have decided to make one version of their product free on computer screens, and have asked people to click on.

Those of us who love newspapers - the real ones, the ones you hold in your hands - are trusting that our corporate bosses know what they're doing, that they are laying the groundwork for the future of our business. But every time I read an "I've-cancelled-my-subscription-because-the-computer-version-is-so-great" letter, I become extremely nervous. This is our lives here; for all of us - publishers, editors, reporters, photographers - this is what we have devoted our working lives to.

Steve Outing, www.mediainfo.com

It wasn't that long ago that the typical newspaper was filled with content from a few predictable sources - staff writers, assorted freelancers, The Associated Press, Reuters and columnists and comic strips. One newspaper in one part of the US carried pretty much the same content as another 1,000 miles away.

The growth of internet-originated content is starting to change that. Increasingly, content from online sources is showing up in print editions of newspapers. Where once print editors distrusted content from online content companies, now there is much more acceptance that online content can be every bit as good, if not better, than content from traditional media sources. And, best yet, online content creators are producing new types of content that wasn't available before.

A prime example is New York City-based web content company APBNews.com. Its website is a crime buff's ultimate news, information, and entertainment source. It covers not only breaking crime news, but offers up assorted crime-related content - such as book and movie reviews, crime databases, crime mystery games, and live police scanner webcasts from various cities.

fields.headline: The future of learning
fields.standfirst: "The education system is a curious hybrid of factory, sanctuary, library and  prison. Too much schooling kills off the desire to learn."
fields.trailText: Demand for knowledge is rising from corporations and individuals. Our investment in knowledge creation and learning has to rise. To encourage this, education needs to leave behind organisational models inherited from the nineteenth century. The main response to demand for more investment in education has been to expand the role of schools and universities, extending the time students spend in these institutions and introducing performance targets to drive the system to higher levels of productivity.
fields.body:
Demand for knowledge is rising from corporations and individuals. Our investment in knowledge creation and learning has to rise. To encourage this, education needs to leave behind organisational models inherited from the nineteenth century. The main response to demand for more investment in education has been to expand the role of schools and universities, extending the time students spend in these institutions and introducing performance targets to drive the system to higher levels of productivity.

This process of modernisation through institutional reform started in 1902 with the Balfour Act, which consolidated a national education system in England and Wales. The Butler Act in 1944 enforced participation in secondary education to the age of 14. The Robbins Report in 1963 and subsequent reforms in the 1980s opened higher education beyond an lite. Reforms in the 1990s drew three- and four-year-olds into the net of formal education. As educational institutions have extended their scope, central government has extended its power to set a core curriculum, accompanied by a panoply of targets, tests, restrictions and regulations.

This approach to modernisation also reinforces a deeply conservative approach to education, as a body of knowledge imparted by organisations with strong hierarchies and demarcated professional disciplines. As Tom Bentley points out in Learning Beyond the Classroom, two traditions are reflected in this culture: the monasteries, which were closed repositories for knowledge in the form of precious manuscripts, and Taylor's factory, which encouraged standardized, easily replicated knowledge.

The result is a system that is a curious hybrid of factory, sanctuary, library and prison. Educational institutions inherited from the industrial age provide a safe and supportive environment for children, but they also seek to control and contain children and standardise the knowledge they acquire. The reforms of the last two decades have intensified these tensions, rather than resolved them or created an education revival in the UK led by the creation of new kinds of learning institutions, tailored for their times.

A new educational system is slowly developing, in parallel and outside the traditional state and private school system. This evolving system operates with a different definition of learning and education. It delivers education through quite different mechanisms and funds it from private and public sources. Elements of this system include: the Open University; public investments in the National Grid for Learning and the University for Industry; home schooling, which involves 50,000 children in the UK and many more in the US; a plethora of corporate universities and a burgeoning self-help market involving books, digital television channels and interactive learning programmes. These new educational institutions are demand-led, use information technology as much as libraries and classrooms, and tailor learning to individual needs. They are frequently financed by shared investments between pupils, employers and the state.

How can the old and the new educational systems evolve together to mutual benefit? The starting point must be a redefinition of the purpose of education. We must move away from a view of education as a rite of passage involving the acquisition of enough knowledge and qualifications to acquire an adult station in life. The point of education should not be to inculcate a body of knowledge, but to develop capabilities: the basic ones of literacy and numeracy as well as the capability to act responsibly towards others, to take initiative and to work creatively and collaboratively.

The most important capability, and one which traditional education is worst at creating, is the ability and yearning to carry on learning. Too much schooling kills off a desire to learn. The traditional institutions of education may be well suited to delivering basic core competencies, such as literacy and numeracy, but they fall down on many other counts: many people are turned off learning because they find school constraining, frustrating and patronizing. The new networked education system is more in tune with these modern goals, but it is designed for people with initiative who can afford to invest in their own learning. It is far from a national, inclusive system.

We need hybrid public and private institutions and funding structures. Schools and universities should become more like hubs of learning, within the community, capable of extending into the community. New primary schools, for example, should be set up as family learning centres, catering for adults and children. As far as secondary schools are concerned, we should follow Ivan Illich's inspirational advice thirty years ago to partially de-school society. More learning should be done at home, in offices and kitchens, in the contexts where knowledge is deployed to solve problems and add value to people's lives.

With this must go changes in accreditation, to move away from a sole reliance on traditional entry qualifications, such as GCSEs. Instead we should provide people with a portfolio of continuous assessment and records of achievement. British universities have been able to survive in the middle ground between the old and the new economies. They do not fit neatly into either. In some respects universities are models for the new economy, particularly the way they encourage research, experimentation and knowledge-creation by autonomous, self-managing researchers and knowledge workers. Yet universities are hardly freewheeling, entrepreneurial places and academic communities are riven by professional, doctrinal and disciplinary disputes and demarcation lines which few outsiders can understand. Moreover, universities have their own protocols, hierarchies and procedures - especially the older universities - which make them slow-moving and resistant to change.

In short, universities have cultures which seem to borrow from the library, the monastery, the gentleman's club and the laboratory but not the factory. British universities were able to survive as mutant-hybrids only so long as there was a social contract supporting them. For most of this century they have served only a niche market: the elite 5 per cent of the population. That meant that universities could be funded by taxation, which in turn meant that academics did not face rigorous market pressures to improve their performance. The academic community had its own social contract. High-flyers did not mind the poor pay and teaching load as long as they had the freedom to get on with their research. They did not worry that the poor performers among their colleagues were holding them back.

That social contract and everything that goes with it is falling apart. The proportion of the population going through universities has gone up to 35 per cent - one of the main achievements of Thatcherism was to drive the expansion of higher-education - and almost certainly will touch 50 per cent in the next two decades. Demand for expansion, combined with growing state regulation to improve performance, is driving many universities to become mass-production degree machines. Meanwhile, elite institutions with international brand names are pulling away from the mass-production university designed to churn out the basic, commodity first degree.

The same process of fragmentation is at work within the academic workforce. Top researchers and academic superstars are increasingly in an international market for their talent; academic scientists can often work in the private sector. These superstar academics can bid up their salaries, terms and conditions. They operate in a quite different world from the mainstream, middle-ranking workforce, which is employed to do the basic teaching. And the top and the middle are far less tolerant of the underperformance of the worst academics who pull down the institution's rankings in research and teaching assessments.

Add to all this the growth of new technologies to deliver learning and corporate universities, which will soon take students from outside their own companies, and it is easy to see why the cosy old order is falling apart. Universities and academics will become increasingly segmented. The elite will be involved in the 'knowledge-creation' business of research and experimentation; the mass will be involved in the 'knowledge-management' business of delivering degree modules. This segmentation means that the funding, organisation; ownership, management and pay systems of universities will all become far more diverse.

It is not hard to set how far and how quickly this could go. Imagine that Rupert Murdoch were to set up the News International University, serving initially only his employees. After a while he might open up entry to the university to readers of his newspapers and viewers of his television programmes. News International University might grow very fast as one of the world's first truly global learning institutions. Armed with Murdoch's money, the university would acquire some star names as teachers. After ten years of development Murdoch might then decide the time was ripe to add some brand quality to his commodity business: he might bid for Oxford, or the London School of Economics.

By that stage, of course, public funding for universities would be tightly constrained, tuition fees would be a fact of life and universities would be familiar with competing in a market. In those circumstances a lucrative offer from Murdoch will seem quite attractive. He might offer to pump billions of dollars into research and development, recruiting top stars from around the world. How many billion pounds would an international brand name like Oxford University or the London School of Economics be worth? Who would own the brand: the taxpayer, the academics? The accountants working for the vice-chancellors had better get cracking. Expanding university education should not be the Holy Grail. Bill Gates was a college drop-out. As the supply of graduates expands, the value of a college degree, on its own, will decline.

In some respects universities are models for the new economy, particularly the way they encourage research, experimentation and knowledge-creation by autonomous, self-managing researchers and knowledge workers. Yet universities are hardly freewheeling, entrepreneurial places and academic communities are riven by professional, doctrinal and disciplinary disputes and demarcation lines which few outsiders can understand. Moreover, universities have their own protocols, hierarchies and procedures - especially the older universities - which make them slow-moving and resistant to change. In short, universities have cultures which seem to borrow from the library, the monastery, the gentleman's club and the laboratory but not the factory. British universities were able to survive as mutant-hybrids only so long as there was a social contract supporting them. For most of this century they have served only a niche market: the elite 5 per cent of the population. That meant that universities could be funded by taxation, which in turn meant that academics did not face rigorous market pressures to improve their performance. The academic community had its own social contract. High-flyers did not mind the poor pay and teaching load as long as they had the freedom to get on with their research. They did not worry that the poor performers among their colleagues were holding them back. That social contract and everything that goes with it is falling apart. The proportion of the population going through universities has gone up to 35 per cent - one of the main achievements of Thatcherism was to drive the expansion of higher-education - and almost certainly will touch 50 per cent in the next two decades. Demand for expansion, combined with growing state regulation to improve performance, is driving many universities to become mass-production degree machines. Meanwhile, elite institutions with international brand names are pulling away from the mass-production university designed to churn out the basic, commodity first degree. The same process of fragmentation is at work within the academic workforce. Top researchers and academic superstars are increasingly in an international market for their talent; academic scientists can often work in the private sector. These superstar academics can bid up their salaries, terms and conditions. They operate in a quite different world from the mainstream, middle-ranking workforce, which is employed to do the basic teaching. And the top and the middle are far less tolerant of the underperformance of the worst academics who pull down the institution's rankings in research and teaching assessments. Add to all this the growth of new technologies to deliver learning and corporate universities, which will soon take students from outside their own companies, and it is easy to see why the cosy old order is falling apart. Universities and academics will become increasingly segmented. The elite will be involved in the 'knowledge-creation' business of research and experimentation; the mass will be involved in the 'knowledge-management' business of delivering degree modules. This segmentation means that the funding, organisation; ownership, management and pay systems of universities will all become far more diverse. It is not hard to set how far and how quickly this could go. Imagine that Rupert Murdoch were to set up the News International University, serving initially only his employees. After a while he might open up entry to the university to readers of his newspapers and viewers of his television programmes. News International University might grow very fast as one of the world's first truly global learning institutions. Armed with Murdoch's money, the university would acquire some star names as teachers. After ten years of development Murdoch might then decide the time was ripe to add some brand quality to his commodity business: he might bid for Oxford, or the London School of Economics. By that stage, of course, public funding for universities would be tightly constrained, tuition fees would be a fact of life and universities would be familiar with competing in a market. In those circumstances a lucrative offer from Murdoch will seem quite attractive. He might offer to pump billions of dollars into research and development, recruiting top stars from around the world. How many billion pounds would an international brand name like Oxford University or the London School of Economics be worth? Who would own the brand: the taxpayer, the academics? The accountants working for the vice-chancellors had better get cracking. Expanding university education should not be the Holy Grail. Bill Gates was a college drop-out. As the supply of graduates expands, the value of a college degree, on its own, will decline. Copyright © Charles Leadbeater, 1999, 2000

webTitle: For the love of the game

fields.headline: For the love of the game
fields.trailText: "You must be mad to follow cricket", say my friends. But what they fail to understand is that all of us who love cricket are maniacs. We are fanatical about the game, forever fascinated by its unpredictability and the twists and turns that only it can produce. This was confirmed as I sat in a state of nervous collapse after Chris Read's heroic efforts against South Africa the other week - a game England had all but won, then all but lost and came agonisingly close to winning before finally losing. And people say cricket is boring.
fields.body:
"You must be mad to follow cricket", say my friends. But what they fail to understand is that all of us who love cricket are maniacs. We are fanatical about the game, forever fascinated by its unpredictability and the twists and turns that only it can produce. This was confirmed as I sat in a state of nervous collapse after Chris Read's heroic efforts against South Africa the other week - a game England had all but won, then all but lost and came agonisingly close to winning before finally losing. And people say cricket is boring.

The passion cricket-lovers have for the game is legendary. I was in Barbados when West Indies were in the process of losing 5-0 in South Africa. Driving through a rural part of the island, we stopped for a drink at a roadside bar. From inside came such shouting and general mayhem that you'd have thought war had broken out. We asked a guy sitting outside what it was all about. He grinned and said, "Cricket".

Inside, a tiny man in a bright-red shirt was leaping up and down screaming "Lara never makes any runs! Hooper never makes any runs! West Indies are finished!" Everyone else was trying to shout him down and, on the verge of spontaneous combustion, he left, still yelling. <P

"It's always the same," the barman said , "win, lose or draw - he goes crazy." But that's what cricket does to you.

During the Ashes tour last winter my flatmate, getting up to go to work, would find me, half-crazy from lack of sleep, staring intently at the TV and muttering a mixture of curses and encouragement at 11 men on the other side of the world. I become absurdly superstitious, believing that if I go and make a cup of tea then a wicket will fall - although usually by the time the milk is in and I've sat down again, Steve Waugh has calmly moved on to another century.

But this eternal optimism is a vital part of the game, because, as we all know, in cricket anything is possible. I sat transfixed by that amazing Test match in Barbados where, with Australia apparently in complete control, Brian Lara defied his critics and played one of the innings of his life to give his team an astonishing victory. That game encapsulated the beauty of cricket. Not just because of the enormous turnaround in fortunes but because of the adrenalin-charged confrontation between Lara and Glenn McGrath.

These individual duels between players are part of the fabric of the game, whether it's Lara v McGrath, Mike Atherton v Allan Donald or Sachin Tendulkar v Shane Warne. It's not just about the result - we're intrigued by players' personal strengths and weaknesses. At The Oval last summer Phil Tufnell got a huge cheer from the crowd when he came to field on the boundary - even though he'd been clattered all around the ground by Chris Cairns - because he's just one of those players supporters love, flaws and all, in the same way we love Darren Gough's ebullience and Atherton's gritty determination.

It's as if cricket is one giant soap opera and we're all waiting for the next episode. When will the brash, tough, all-conquering Australians cease to be all-conquering? Will the mercurial West Indies rise again? Why do the oh-so-efficient South Africans suddenly fall to pieces out of nowhere? And what about England? Eternally unpredictable England, who can veer between brilliance and incompetence, sometimes in one afternoon.

However, one thing is certain - next summer, when Curtly and Courtney are charging in at Athers and his opening partner, I shall be there, fingers crossed, wanting England to win. And anyone who's driving past that bar in Barbados will probably see a little man in a red shirt leaping up and down, simply because like me and so many others he's mad about cricket.

fields.headline: Pay as you go
fields.standfirst: It will be like the gas meter. Want to watch EastEnders? That'll be 50p. Mike Young on how smartcards will change the way we watch TV
fields.trailText: It will be like the gas meter. Want to watch EastEnders? That'll be 50p. Mike Young on how smartcards will change the way we watch TV
fields.body:
The digital wave is only just beginning to hit the beach that is the TV industry. But the tide is coming in fast, and when the water recedes what will have been washed away and what will have been dumped on the new shoreline? Will viewers flock to see it or will they complain bitterly that the golden age of television is long gone?

Digital is unifying the way we use equipment to get information, process it and be entertained. It's a bit like our political landscape - New Labour adopts Conservative policies, the Conservatives adopt New Labour policies and they both end up talking the same language.

Computers are getting more like televisions by bringing us audio and video content. Televisions are getting more like computers by bringing us e-mail and the internet. However, the look and feel of TV and computers is very different, reflecting the needs of desktop versus lounge, lean-forward technology (computer) versus lean-back (television).

Open, the interactive TV service that comes with Sky Digital, brings us home shopping, e-mail and some simple games. But, interestingly, there appears to be a brick wall built between Sky's programming and Open's content. So, thus far, I have not found any interactive adverts on Sky prompting me to buy something from one of Open's retailers.

So we may have the new technology, but the broadcasters are far from sure what to do with it. In fact some of them find it positively scary, and probably with good reason as they see the balance of power shifting away from the likes of the BBC and Carlton.

Smaller, more nimble companies can overturn the traditional model of broadcasting. Take FutureTV, a company we (Mondex International) have just done a smartcard deal with. Viewers using FutureTV technology can now choose what programmes they want to watch and when they want to watch them. Using a smartcard with e-cash, such as Mondex, you pay solely for the programmes you watch - 50p here, click, 50p there, click. And just as Amazon knows what you like to read and listen to, your television knows what you like to watch, and can suggest programmes you might want to see.

So broadcasters are faced with two terrible challenges: the "unbundling" of content (in fact the death of television channels like Channel 4 or BBC1, which schedule the programmes they think you might like to see) and the growth of "pay-as-you-go".

Why are these terrible? Simply because they threaten the power and the revenue patterns that broadcasters have grown used to. To date, the power of the broadcasters has been based on ownership and control of content, and ownership of the audience.

But, of course, unbundling and pay-as-you-go are both inevitable - inevitable because they have a powerful appeal to consumers. Today, more mobile phones are sold on a pay-as-you-go basis than on subscription. Recent research by NOP shows that 57% of people would prefer to pay for TV on a pay-as-you-use basis. And look at how the music industry is being turned upside down by our ability to go to a website and download MP3 music tracks or get custom CDs made. All of these things are surely strong pointers to the future of television content.

However, amid all this fear, there is a massive opportunity. In the long run, there is no point trying to fight the consumer, and if a company does not give its consumers what they really want, a competitor or a new entrant will. Addressing fundamental consumer needs is the fastest route to greater market share and increased capitalisation, and as the tie up of AOL with Time Warner and EMI shows, some will "get it" and some won't.

New ways of accessing and paying for TV programming is only the start of the revolution. The nature of programming will change and, equally important, we will also have the opportunity to interact far more with our TV. Audience participation could mean playing the quiz show at home or voting on the plot direction of your favourite soap, although in experiments many viewers considered the latter just too wacky. Sky Digital already gives the viewer a chance to choose a particular camera angle when watching football, a concept capable of extension to other formats. It could certainly heighten the drama in programmes such as Casualty - just click here for more blood. More likely we will watch the news headlines and then choose which new items to view rather than following the running order of the news programme. So if you are fed up with watching depressing news, simply go for a diet of feel-good stories.

TV news will therefore become much more like internet news, where news is packaged by a whole new breed of "aggregators". Football news, company news, currency news, celebrity news, shopping news, technology news, in fact an explosion of news for special interest groups.

Viewers will have access to far more news items and more targeted, in-depth coverage, if they want it. The BBC and CNN will no doubt struggle to maintain their position against the new entrants in this new world.

Advertising will also have to move on. Broadcast advertising is pretty much a scatter-gun approach. By linking adverts to channels and programmes, you can point the gun in the right direction, but nobody knows what will actually get hit.

In the future we will be able to target adverts to individuals and, by giving the viewer a chance to respond instantly, the effectiveness of the advert can be assessed more accurately.

Although this sounds like good news for the advertisers, the bad news is that they will need to be more clever in order to persuade us to watch the advert in the first place.

One way will be to embody advertising directly within programmes, rather than between programmes. In the US, Princetown Video works with broadcasters to "paint in" sponsors' logos and messages within programming as it is delivered. These are not simple captions overlaid on the screen - in football, for example, the messages appear to be painted on the grass of the field. The advantage of doing this digitally is that messages can be tailored to particular viewer segments. Of course, to move "in programme" advertising beyond sport will mean pushing the boundaries of the regulatory envelope.

Will all this mean that Big Brother will now be sitting in our once friendly television set, building up a precise picture of who we are and everything we do? I think not. In fact, I believe that corporate owners of personal data are in for a big shock because power is going to be placed in the consumer's hands.

The security built in to smartcard technology will enable consumers to protect their own personal data. I will be able to build my own personal database of my purchases, my shopping behaviour and preferences. This will be a much more complete and accurate database than any that could be built by a single retailer that I interact with, and therefore it will be more valuable. Then, I could choose whether or not to reveal my data to a company that wants my business, either anonymously or using my true identity. I could be rewarded for this behaviour either with better service or simply by getting paid.

Already some ISPs and net retailers offer free services or lower prices if you are happy to accept a greater level of advertising. For example, you can earn "Beenz" web currency by completing surveys or filling in forms with your personal details. If this kind of technology and marketing was confined to computers on the net, it would undoubtedly have the potential to be socially divisive, whereas the great advantage of TV is its potential for universal access. And getting paid cash for genuine interaction with TV adverts and learning about new products sounds to me like a more equitable deal.

Maybe, in a few years' time, you will only be able to tell the difference between programmes and adverts by the fact that you pay for watching the programmes and get paid for interacting with the adverts.

Will you and I like all this new TV stuff? Bits of it, yes. We will like the feeling of control brought by being able to select the time at which we view a programme. We will be intrigued and excited by some of the interactivity. We may value the additional convenience of armchair shopping. But as the sheer volume of content grows and audiences fragment, one thing we may lose is that shared emotional experience on a Monday morning when we discuss the best programme of the weekend with our friends and colleagues.

Whatever happens, Coronation Street and EastEnders will be with us for many years to come.

Mike Young is head of e-commerce at Mondex International mike.young@mondex.com

fields.headline: Surprise as 72 hostages fly out
fields.trailText:
Seventy-two former hostages from the Stansted hijack
were this morning on their way back to Afghanistan,
while the British government began negotiations with
Pakistan over the price to be paid for providing a home
for the remaining passengers seeking asylum.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Lucy Ward and Paul Kelso
fields.body:
Seventy-two former hostages from the Stansted hijack were this morning on their way back to Afghanistan, while the British government began negotiations with Pakistan over the price to be paid for providing a home for the remaining passengers seeking asylum.

A Kampuchean Air Tristar bound for Kandahar, chartered by the International Organisation for Migration, departed from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire, where it has been on standby since Friday morning, at 12.50am today.

The number of Afghanis flying home was much higher than had been expected. But home office officials stressed that the process was "fluid", with hostages changing their minds about staying when they realised the implications of applying for asylum.

As they prepared for departure, a foreign office spokesman said talks had been held about the future of the 73 other passengers, all of whom are expected to apply formally for asylum today.

"We are in touch with a number of countries, Pakistan and others, in case passengers show an interest in going there." Among factors to be taken into consideration would be whether they had relatives in those other countries.

Nineteen men are expected to appear before magistrates at Southend today charged with offences under the prevention of terrorism act and international hijack law. Yesterday three men arrested at the end of the hijack last Thursday were released without charge.

The foreign office spokesman stressed that, contrary to reports yesterday, there were no ministerial-level negotiations with Pakistan. But a Whitehall source confirmed that though ministers were not involved, discussions were taking place between diplomats.

Neither the foreign office nor home office ruled out the possibility of expenses being paid to countries prepared to take the Afghans, but a home office source said talks were at too early a stage to have reached detailed negotiations.

"The issue of money would be subject to discussions with third countries that might be willing to take people," the source said.

The foreign office was last night trying to establish which of the asylum seekers would be willing to go to third countries.

In addition to Pakistan, Britain was in contact with Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, India, Russia and the US.

Ministers believe that those Afghan passengers who do claim asylum in the UK have little chance of having their application accepted.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, made it clear yesterday that he is to press for international reform of the rules under which the Afghan hostages have claimed refuge in Britain.

He will urge ministers from other countries to redefine the 1951 convention, arguing that the law was never designed to cope with the various types of refugee seeking shelter in Britain and Europe.

Speaking on BBC1's On the Record yesterday, Mr Straw denied he had spoiled any chance the Afghans had of getting a fair hearing when he said last week he wanted as many as possible removed from Britain.

"We have a great sympathy with those who have a genuine and well founded fear of persecution," he said. "On the other hand we cannot possibly be in a circumstance where it appears we are encouraging international terrorist crime."

The remaining hostages spent a second night at the fire service college in Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, following interviews by immigration officials. The four crew members who escaped from the plane are understood to be staying elsewhere in the area.

fields.headline: Rising wages
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The traditional wish for a prosperous new year has had some substance to it for a change. Figures for January released by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation last week show wages rising on the back of a strong demand for staff.
fields.body:
The traditional wish for a prosperous new year has had some substance to it for a change. Figures for January released by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation last week show wages rising on the back of a strong demand for staff.

Employers are still cautious about taking on people. Growth faltered over the new year, partly because, hype or no hype, the millennium boosted seasonal employment, and partly because the ruthless productivity drive continues.

Nevertheless, pay rises showed their biggest jump since August 1998. And by the laws of supply and demand, rising wages should indicate, crudely, that there are more jobs than people available to fill them, or at any rate that the ratio is improving.

There is other evidence to support this. According to REC figures, both recruitment advertising in the press and vacancies notified to jobcentres showed healthy growth in January. The expansion is certainly far more inclusive than the boom of the late 1980s. Back then the ratio of unemployed people to unfilled vacancies was eight to one; these days it is nearer three and a half to one.

Yet it is skill shortages that are having the most leverage on wages. Even with more people in the labour market than was once thought possible, the recruitment industry is still struggling to find the right people to match certain jobs. The well trained are most likely to benefit from these conditions.

Figures for January released by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation last week show wages rising on the back of a strong demand for staff. Employers are still cautious about taking on people. Growth faltered over the new year, partly because, hype or no hype, the millennium boosted seasonal employment, and partly because the ruthless productivity drive continues. webTitle: Risks of speed that give rallying its appeal

fields.headline: Risks of speed that give rallying its appeal
fields.trailText: To competitors and spectators alike, part of rallying's appeal is cars being driven on any kind of road in any kind of conditions.
fields.body:
To competitors and spectators alike, part of rallying's appeal is cars being driven on any kind of road in any kind of conditions.

Yesterday's accident has underlined the sport's dangers.

Rallies can cover hundreds of miles in remote countryside, and it can be difficult to maintain close crowd control. While even minor rallies are required to have doctors and ambulances in attendance, it can take time to get emergency assistance to the scene of an accident.

National-level rallies attract nothing like the crowds who flock to the Rally of Great Britain every November.

But national rally organisers do not have anything like the same manpower at their disposal, and amateur drivers are more likely to crash than professionals.

The Cheviot Rally has a reputation for good organisation, however, and as it takes place largely on military land at Otterburn, close to the Scottish border, spectators are rarely numerous.

But roads are fast and the area is renowned for bad weather.

Spectators need reminding that no driver is infallible. But freak accidents - even on a race track - will remain difficult to prevent.

fields.headline: Hallmark cards
fields.trailText: Hallmark cards
fields.body:
Founded: 1910, in Kansas City, by a man named Joyce C Hall.

I'm sensing he was a man with a vision. Boy oh boy, you know how to understate. "His inventory of postcards fit into a couple of shoeboxes, but his dreams couldn't be contained," intones the company website, in the beautiful prose-style for which it is famed.

And what, pray, was Hall's dream? To help people share their feelings, of course, via the medium of tightly written greeting-card ditties.

Which brings us rather neatly to Valentine's Day . . . It's the third-biggest card-sending occasion in the calendar - 20m cards were sent in 1998. (If you're interested, the people most likely to send cards to themselves are from the West Midlands.)

Can we expect anything different from Hallmark this year? Sure can. After holding extensive focus groups, its US arm has extended the range to include 237 new card designs, reflecting "more blended and non-traditional family situations".

Like, cool, the greeting card as social barometer. What have they got? There's an inflatable woman on the front of one of the e-cards on its website.

Sounds good. What else? A moose kissing a baby and a cow bearing a bunch of flowers.

Wow, they really are pushing the boundaries. In life, as in art - its employees lead by example. In October, you might remember, David Machin, Hallmark's UK group logistics manager, eschewed traditional family values and was caught in a rather blended situation with a woman on a flight from Dallas to Manchester.

Doing his bit for the new product line. Yup, and that's not all. Hallmark urges us to send cards not only to our lovers, but to friends and peripheral relations, "regardless of the level of emotion or intimacy". I can see it now: "Roses are red, violets are blue, just for the record, I never liked you."

Do say: What a beautifully written sentiment, thank you darling.

Don't say: You couldn't just phone?

Not to be confused with: Shakespeare.

fields.headline: Charles Schulz
fields.standfirst:
Cartoonist whose comic strip Peanuts, featuring good ol' Charlie Brown and Snoopy, brought pleasure to 90 million readers worldwide
Farewell to Peanuts and Schulz
fields.trailText: The world's richest cartoonist; the world's most popular cartoonist: which rates first? To Charles Schulz, who has died of cancer aged 77, it was definitely the second.
fields.body:
The world's richest cartoonist; the world's most popular cartoonist: which rates first? To Charles Schulz, who has died of cancer aged 77, it was definitely the second. His comic strip creation, Peanuts, a catch-all title for a group of knee-high kids in a world no taller than their heads (one of the secrets of the strip's success was that adults were only apparent in the odd off-panel speech balloon), never changed beyond a certain shakiness of line, after it made its debut in American newspapers on October 2, 1950.

Although only eight mid-western newspapers printed the strip, today over 90m people read Peanuts world-wide. Originally, Schulz was paid $3 for each daily strip he drew; a recent estimate paid him $1m a month. And then there was the merchandising.

Charles Monroe Schulz was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota. His father was a small-time barber. Two days after the boy's birth he nicknamed him Sparky, after Sparkplug, the hapless horse owned by Barney Google, the popular comic strip hero drawn by Billy de Beck. It seems like a twist on an old fairy story, for the baby would be involved with comics for the rest of his life.

On his first day at kindergarten, the teacher gave the class sheets of white paper and big crayons, and told them to draw anything they liked. Young Charlie drew a snow scene, then added a palm tree in the background: an unlikely combination, commented on by the teacher, which made the picture stick in the boy's memory, an early illustration of the humorous way his creativity would grow.

When he was 11, the first comic books began publication in the US. Already a devotee of the coloured comic supplements to his father's newspapers, Sparky (as he was now signing all his sketches), began to buy and study each new issue. As with most other beginners in the comic strip trade, he learned to cartoon by copying other cartoonists, filling his drawing books with careful versions of every character he enjoyed, from Popeye the Sailor to Buck Rogers.

Schulz published his first drawing when he was 14. His pet dog Spike, a mongrel with a touch of hunting hound, had a predilection for eating certain unlikely objects, such as pins and razor blades. He sketched Spike and sent the results to the world-famous Robert Ripley, whose Believe It Or Not panels had world circulation. The picture was signed "Sparky" and Ripley reproduced it. The spotted dog bears a certain resemblance to a beagle called Snoopy, co-star of the Peanuts strip.

Schulz's first publication seemed likely to become his only one. At high school he was asked to contribute caricatures to his senior year book. He drew them eagerly but the editor refused to publish them. Meanwhile his father paid for a course in cartooning by correspondence with the Art Instruction School of Minneapolis. It cost him $170 in subscriptions, but was ultimately worthwhile. Schulz would eventually join the staff, but not until after his war service.

Called into the US Army in February 1943, Schulz would be discharged in the rank of staff sergeant. Although he spent most of his service time in Kentucky guarding trucks, he was sent to France two years later, where he drew his everyday adventures in a pocket sketchbook. Returning home, he joined Art Instruction, correcting the homework sent in by students.

He worked under Frank Wing, a perfectionist who was the first man to spot the potential in the cartoons Schulz sketched in his spare moments. Wing persuaded Schulz to submit them to the local newspaper, the Saint Paul Pioneer Press. Although they may not have been aware of it, since the series was called Li'l Folks, local readers were the first to see Peanuts in print. For a while Schulz was delighted enough just to see his drawings appearing regularly, but when the time came for him to ask for an increase in recompense, the editor promptly dropped the feature.

Schulz, however, continued to make up his income by let tering the pages of strips in a locally published series of Catholic comic books, Timeless Topix. He also submitted cartoons to the national weekly, Saturday Evening Post, which bought 15 of them before cancelling out. All the cartoons pointed to the shape of strips to come: they all featured little kids with big rounded heads, and not a grown-up in sight.

It was 1950 when at last fortune smiled in the shape of the United Feature Syndicate. Schulz had sent them a batch of sample strips. They signed him and sent them out to their worldwide customer list. Eight papers responded; all small circulation, but it was a start. A year later Schulz married Joyce Halverson; they divorced in 1972.

From the very first strip Charlie Brown - the champion chump, the favourite fall-guy, the (if-you-like) typical real-life American hero - was the star, and the first character to be named. Then one by one came Linus van Pelt, the first kid to own a security blanket (Schulz's own term, now in Webster's Dictionary); his sister Lucy, the sneery little brat; Schroeder who plays perfect Beethoven on his toy piano; scruffy Peppermint Patty; grubby Pigpen and, of course, Snoopy, the dog given to daydreaming he is a first world war flying ace, and his friend, the yellow bouncing bird, Woodstock. Together they were Peanuts, the only thing Schulz disliked about his strip. He'd gone on calling it Li'l Folks, but the syndicate changed it.

Schulz's first acknowledgement came from his fellow newspaper cartoonists: they gave him their Reuben Award in 1955, the first of many honours including, in 1978, being voted by his peers across the world of cartoonists as international cartoonist of the year. Peanuts made the cover of Time Magazine in 1965. The first Peanuts book was published in 1952 (20 years later there were 190 of them); the first of 16 television cartoons was made in 1965; the play You're A Good Man Charlie Brown opened on Broadway in 1967; and the first feature film cartoon was produced in 1969, the year that Charlie Brown and Snoopy went truly out of this world - as mascots of the Command Capsule and Lunar Module of NASA's Apollo 10.

Schulz spent much of his time at the Redwood Empire Ice Arena in Santa Rosa, where he played hockey or had coffee at the appropriately named Warm Puppy snack bar. Frequently asked the secret of his characters' appeal, Sparky Schulz would reply: "If you read the strip regularly you know everything there is about me." And as he once confided to the Washington Post: "My whole life as been one of rejection. Women. Dogs. Comic strips." As Charlie Brown was wont to remark: "Good grief!"

Charles Schulz leaves a wife, Jeannie Forsyth, a daughter and a son.

fields.headline: Farewell to Peanuts and Schulz
fields.standfirst:
Cartoon's creator dies on eve of final strip's publication
Obituary
fields.trailText: Just as millions of admirers around the world were reading the farewell Peanuts cartoon strip yesterday, it was announced that Charles Schulz, its creator, had died in his sleep. Schulz, 77, passed away at home in Santa Rosa, California, on Saturday from colon cancer.
fields.body:
Just as millions of admirers around the world were reading the farewell Peanuts cartoon strip yesterday, it was announced that Charles Schulz, its creator, had died in his sleep. Schulz, 77, passed away at home in Santa Rosa, California, on Saturday from colon cancer.

"Dear friends", he told his readers in 68 countries, "I have been fortunate to draw Charlie Brown and his friends for almost 50 years. It has been a fulfilment of my childhood ambition. Charlie Brown, Snoopy, Linus, Lucy - how can I ever forget them." Schulz always said his characters had "a little bit of me in them".

He had said last November that because of his illness February 13 would be the strip's final day.

Since it first appeared in October 1950, the strip has been syndicated in 2,800 newspapers around the world and spawned an industry that made its creator a multi-millionaire. He and his family had agreed that it would be wrong for anyone else to take over the strip, which will therefore die with him, although many papers will still run Peanuts "classics".

Schulz drew 18,000 strips in his career and saw them translated into 21 languages, an animated cartoon and into countless artefacts, from lunchboxes to baseball caps.

fields.headline: Why Tunbridge Wells matters
fields.standfirst: Net talk is all about building global communities. But what about the small specialist groups that are often the web's lifeblood?  Patrick Barkham  on the need for national newspapers and broadcasters to listen to the locals.
fields.trailText: Net talk is all about building global communities. But what about the small specialist groups that are often the web's lifeblood? Patrick Barkham on the need for national newspapers and broadcasters to listen to the locals.
fields.body:
In the heated debate about whether newspapers - either the actual product or their staff or their strategies - will ever make it on the net, a new set of questions is now being asked. At their simplest they focus on one subject: niche versus generalist.

Whereas internet has proved the perfect harbinger of niche interests, serving individuals' peculiar tastes and diverse geographical demands, newspapers and national broadcasters are traditionally great generalists. They often seem ill-at-ease on the internet: able to provide a breadth of information but unwilling to dig down to meet the diverse and specialist demands of their users.

As successful online newspapers in the US reach less than 25% of their local internet users, some have tried to add an interest-based niche to their regional focus. The San Jose Mercury is currently devoting much online energy to SiliconValley.com, a specialist site for technology news. They hope to create a vibrant community of loyal users by meeting specialist demands with detailed information.

In the UK, OneWorld is one such community. Launched in 1995 to bring international human rights and sustainable development issues to a mass audience, its network of more than 700 partner organisations now gets 2m hits, or page impressions, each month.

The site is founded on a different model, using partnerships with experts in non-governmental organisations to provide many of its stories. It has 20 UK employees, staff in seven other countries, and is devolving work to new centres across four continents.

"News sites that used to do their own content are now simply bringing in news from Reuters and PR," says OneWorld UK editor Mark Linus. "I think they have to listen to the concerns of audiences and try and do something different. People are looking round for information that they can believe in."

"We do not treat our audience as passive," adds OneWorld's publicity manager, Glen Tarman. "If they want to take action on issues relating to a piece of news we give them avenues to find out more."

But many other non-commercial UK internet projects have conspicuously failed to create active online citizens or establish the necessary critical mass to become a successful niche news site. While American city sites prosper, the internet offerings based on community projects - such as Brixton Online - slumber, going quietly out-of-date. The talk boards on Islington.org, surely the site of choice for every self-respecting member of the chattering classes, are deafeningly silent.

One avowedly commercial site, Fish4, backed by local newspaper publishers in the UK, including Newsquest, Northcliffe, Associated, Trinity and the Manchester Evening News (owned by Guardian Media Group, owners of the Guardian), claims that it has the necessary mass of information to make a niche product. As sales and marketing director Jonathan Lines says: "Our shareholders own over 800 local and regional newspapers between them. We've got in the region of 200,000 cars, 100,000 homes and 30,000 jobs on our website. We have critical mass."

It means that the classified information on the site meets people's specific demands, while users can also get niche news from the 103 local news websites linked through the Fish4 network. With 20m page impressions across the network last month and a £20m advertising campaign budget this year, Fish4 hopes to become "the intuitive place for users to go if they want to find anything in the UK," says Lines.

BBC News Online is one place where the battle between general and niche is at its most acute. It has a huge breadth of content, both broad-brush and localised. The way it is used demonstrates the diversity of users and their demands. During just one day last week people looked at 98,450 different stories, amounting to a staggering 20% of all the stories the site has ever produced.

"What the user now has is the ability to get more information than ever before and to get it on more platforms than ever before and to get a lower level of detail than ever before," says BBC News Online's project manager, Bob Eggington.

A news site as big as the BBC can turn itself into a niche site simply with the judicious use of personalisation. Eggington believes that personalisation is a way of shifting the balance of power "away from the provider and towards the consumer, which from the consumer's point of view must be a good thing".

BBC News Online and the Fish4 network boast a breadth of information. Both recognise the importance of adding depth to this, but neither has yet managed to start serving the diverse niche interests that form at the grassroots.

'Rolling out to the lowest level of granularity that resources will permit is clearly a very desirable strategic objective," says Eggington. Last October, the BBC launched sections for Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales, but plans for 10 further regional niches have been postponed while resources are invested in building a sports site. Eggington hopes to develop the regional news niches "towards the end of this year . . . We have got local content and we should get it out there."

By the time the BBC unveils its regional niches, others will be well established. Newsquest has ambitious plans for its 18 local news websites, which are accessible through the Fish4 network.

Simon Gray, deputy managing director of Newsquest digital media, says forthcoming new designs will offer "functionality and lots of very granular community information, real parish pump stuff, from local round table meetings to the local Sunday football league tables". As well as using local paper copy, Newsquest will also offer new self-build pages for societies, groups and geographical communities to create and edit their own niches within the local news sites.

"The BBC will provide regional news services on the web and they'll do a brilliant job," adds Fish4's Jonathan Lines. "If you watch Newsroom South East you'll get half a dozen stories about the south east. What you won't get is half a dozen stories about Tunbridge Wells. Now we can deliver that. The BBC aren't going to want to provide that, nor are they equipped to do so, but the regional press is."

By creating such a large aggregate of classified and news information, Fish4 and its subsidiary news websites hope to protect themselves from specialist sites such as Football365, Autotrader or Totaljobs, which will attempt to claim the lion's share of valuable niche advertising revenues.

Eggington accepts other sites can beat the BBC on specifics ("It seems to me likely that CricInfo will always go down to deeper levels of granularity than the BBC sports site") but says his experience at BBC News Online suggests "people who have a specialist interest don't take exception to our general site. There is clearly a tension between being general and being specialised," he says. "Our aim is to provide a site that is generally accessible while also being of interest and credible to the specialist."

The first stage for many news sites in Britain is over. They have ceased to be defensive operations, fearful of cannibalising their offline profits. Through partnerships and expansion of content many have acquired a decent breadth to their news and information online. The next challenge is to seek depth and better satisfy specialist concerns. The niche market is, after all, the mass market.

For

 Bob Greene, <A HREF="http://www.chicagotribune.com"

" TARGET="_NEW">www.chicagotribune.com

Some people are cancelling their subscriptions. There's no getting around it. Perhaps the most dismaying thing I have found in readers' emails can be summed up in sentences like these:

"I've been reading [your column] for about two years now online. I even cancelled my subscription. Why should I pay for a paper every morning when I can read just what I want for free, without getting my fingers dirty?"

The most difficult part of all this to understand, for those of us who write the stories, take the photos and lay out the pages that appear in daily newspapers, is that readers are not acting in defiance of what the newspaper companies are offering to them - they're gladly taking the publishers up on their offer. The publishing executives of newspaper corporations have decided to make one version of their product free on computer screens, and have asked people to click on.

Those of us who love newspapers - the real ones, the ones you hold in your hands - are trusting that our corporate bosses know what they're doing, that they are laying the groundwork for the future of our business. But every time I read an "I've-cancelled-my-subscription-because-the-computer-version-is-so-great" letter, I become extremely nervous. This is our lives here; for all of us - publishers, editors, reporters, photographers - this is what we have devoted our working lives to.

Against

Steve Outing <A HREF="http://www.mediainfo.com"

" TARGET="_NEW">www.mediainfo.com

It wasn't that long ago that the typical newspaper was filled with content from a few predictable sources - staff writers, assorted freelancers, The Associated Press, Reuters and columnists and comic strips. One newspaper in one part of the US carried pretty much the same content as another 1,000 miles away.

The growth of internet-originated content is starting to change that. Increasingly, content from online sources is showing up in print editions of newspapers. Where once print editors distrusted content from online content companies, now there is much more acceptance that online content can be every bit as good, if not better, than content from traditional media sources. And, best yet, online content creators are producing new types of content that wasn't available before.

A prime example is New York City-based web content company APBNews.com. Its website is a crime buff's ultimate news, information, and entertainment source. It covers not only breaking crime news, but offers up assorted crime-related content - such as book and movie reviews, crime databases, crime mystery games, and live police scanner webcasts from various cities.
fields.bodyText: In the heated debate about whether newspapers - either the actual product or their staff or their strategies - will ever make it on the net, a new set of questions is now being asked. At their simplest they focus on one subject: niche versus generalist. Whereas internet has proved the perfect harbinger of niche interests, serving individuals' peculiar tastes and diverse geographical demands, newspapers and national broadcasters are traditionally great generalists. They often seem ill-at-ease on the internet: able to provide a breadth of information but unwilling to dig down to meet the diverse and specialist demands of their users. As successful online newspapers in the US reach less than 25% of their local internet users, some have tried to add an interest-based niche to their regional focus. The San Jose Mercury is currently devoting much online energy to SiliconValley.com, a specialist site for technology news. They hope to create a vibrant community of loyal users by meeting specialist demands with detailed information. In the UK, OneWorld is one such community. Launched in 1995 to bring international human rights and sustainable development issues to a mass audience, its network of more than 700 partner organisations now gets 2m hits, or page impressions, each month. The site is founded on a different model, using partnerships with experts in non-governmental organisations to provide many of its stories. It has 20 UK employees, staff in seven other countries, and is devolving work to new centres across four continents. "News sites that used to do their own content are now simply bringing in news from Reuters and PR," says OneWorld UK editor Mark Linus. "I think they have to listen to the concerns of audiences and try and do something different. People are looking round for information that they can believe in." "We do not treat our audience as passive," adds OneWorld's publicity manager, Glen Tarman. "If they want to take action on issues relating to a piece of news we give them avenues to find out more." But many other non-commercial UK internet projects have conspicuously failed to create active online citizens or establish the necessary critical mass to become a successful niche news site. While American city sites prosper, the internet offerings based on community projects - such as Brixton Online - slumber, going quietly out-of-date. The talk boards on Islington.org, surely the site of choice for every self-respecting member of the chattering classes, are deafeningly silent. One avowedly commercial site, Fish4, backed by local newspaper publishers in the UK, including Newsquest, Northcliffe, Associated, Trinity and the Manchester Evening News (owned by Guardian Media Group, owners of the Guardian), claims that it has the necessary mass of information to make a niche product. As sales and marketing director Jonathan Lines says: "Our shareholders own over 800 local and regional newspapers between them. We've got in the region of 200,000 cars, 100,000 homes and 30,000 jobs on our website. We have critical mass." It means that the classified information on the site meets people's specific demands, while users can also get niche news from the 103 local news websites linked through the Fish4 network. With 20m page impressions across the network last month and a £20m advertising campaign budget this year, Fish4 hopes to become "the intuitive place for users to go if they want to find anything in the UK," says Lines. BBC News Online is one place where the battle between general and niche is at its most acute. It has a huge breadth of content, both broad-brush and localised. The way it is used demonstrates the diversity of users and their demands. During just one day last week people looked at 98,450 different stories, amounting to a staggering 20% of all the stories the site has ever produced. "What the user now has is the ability to get more information than ever before and to get it on more platforms than ever before and to get a lower level of detail than ever before," says BBC News Online's project manager, Bob Eggington. A news site as big as the BBC can turn itself into a niche site simply with the judicious use of personalisation. Eggington believes that personalisation is a way of shifting the balance of power "away from the provider and towards the consumer, which from the consumer's point of view must be a good thing". BBC News Online and the Fish4 network boast a breadth of information. Both recognise the importance of adding depth to this, but neither has yet managed to start serving the diverse niche interests that form at the grassroots. 'Rolling out to the lowest level of granularity that resources will permit is clearly a very desirable strategic objective," says Eggington. Last October, the BBC launched sections for Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales, but plans for 10 further regional niches have been postponed while resources are invested in building a sports site. Eggington hopes to develop the regional news niches "towards the end of this year . . . We have got local content and we should get it out there." By the time the BBC unveils its regional niches, others will be well established. Newsquest has ambitious plans for its 18 local news websites, which are accessible through the Fish4 network. Simon Gray, deputy managing director of Newsquest digital media, says forthcoming new designs will offer "functionality and lots of very granular community information, real parish pump stuff, from local round table meetings to the local Sunday football league tables". As well as using local paper copy, Newsquest will also offer new self-build pages for societies, groups and geographical communities to create and edit their own niches within the local news sites. "The BBC will provide regional news services on the web and they'll do a brilliant job," adds Fish4's Jonathan Lines. "If you watch Newsroom South East you'll get half a dozen stories about the south east. What you won't get is half a dozen stories about Tunbridge Wells. Now we can deliver that. The BBC aren't going to want to provide that, nor are they equipped to do so, but the regional press is." By creating such a large aggregate of classified and news information, Fish4 and its subsidiary news websites hope to protect themselves from specialist sites such as Football365, Autotrader or Totaljobs, which will attempt to claim the lion's share of valuable niche advertising revenues. Eggington accepts other sites can beat the BBC on specifics ("It seems to me likely that CricInfo will always go down to deeper levels of granularity than the BBC sports site") but says his experience at BBC News Online suggests "people who have a specialist interest don't take exception to our general site. There is clearly a tension between being general and being specialised," he says. "Our aim is to provide a site that is generally accessible while also being of interest and credible to the specialist." The first stage for many news sites in Britain is over. They have ceased to be defensive operations, fearful of cannibalising their offline profits. Through partnerships and expansion of content many have acquired a decent breadth to their news and information online. The next challenge is to seek depth and better satisfy specialist concerns. The niche market is, after all, the mass market. For  Bob Greene, www.chicagotribune.com Some people are cancelling their subscriptions. There's no getting around it. Perhaps the most dismaying thing I have found in readers' emails can be summed up in sentences like these: "I've been reading [your column] for about two years now online. I even cancelled my subscription. Why should I pay for a paper every morning when I can read just what I want for free, without getting my fingers dirty?" The most difficult part of all this to understand, for those of us who write the stories, take the photos and lay out the pages that appear in daily newspapers, is that readers are not acting in defiance of what the newspaper companies are offering to them - they're gladly taking the publishers up on their offer. The publishing executives of newspaper corporations have decided to make one version of their product free on computer screens, and have asked people to click on. Those of us who love newspapers - the real ones, the ones you hold in your hands - are trusting that our corporate bosses know what they're doing, that they are laying the groundwork for the future of our business. But every time I read an "I've-cancelled-my-subscription-because-the-computer-version-is-so-great" letter, I become extremely nervous. This is our lives here; for all of us - publishers, editors, reporters, photographers - this is what we have devoted our working lives to. fields.headline: UK negotiates hostage price
fields.standfirst: Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: The government was negotiating with Pakistan yesterday over the price to be paid for providing a home for the Afghan passengers seeking asylum after last week's hijack.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Lucy Ward  and Paul Kelso
fields.body:
The government was negotiating with Pakistan yesterday over the price to be paid for providing a home for the Afghan passengers seeking asylum after last week's hijack.

As 72 former hostages prepared to return to Afghanistan early today, a foreign office spokesman said talks were taking place about the future of the other passengers.

The spokesman said: "We are in touch with a number of countries, Pakistan and others, in case passengers show an interest in going there." Among factors to be taken into consideration would be whether they had relatives in those other countries.

Essex police are today expected to charge 19 passengers arrested after the hijack with offences under the prevention of terrorism act and international hijack law. Yesterday three men arrested at the end of the hijack last Thursday were released without charge.

The foreign office spokesman stressed that, contrary to reports yesterday, there were no ministerial-level negotiations between Britain and Pakistan about the asylum seekers. But a Whitehall source confirmed discussions were taking place between diplomats.

Neither the foreign office nor home office ruled out the possibility of expenses being paid to countries prepared to take the Afghans, but a home office source said talks were at too early a stage to have reached detailed negotiations on terms.

"The issue of money would be subject to discussions with third countries that might be willing to take take people," the source said.

The foreign office was last night trying to establish which of the asylum seekers would be willing to go to third countries.

In addition to Pakistan, Britain was in contact with Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, India, Russia and the US.

Ministers believe that those Afghan passengers who do claim asylum in the UK have little chance of having their application accepted.

The home secretary Jack Straw, made it clear yesterday that he is to press for international reform of the rules under which the Afghan hostages have claimed refuge in Britain.

He will urge ministers from other countries to redefine the 1951 convention, arguing that the law was never designed to cope with the numbers of types of refugee seeking shelter in the UK and Europe.

Speaking on BBC1's On the Record yesterday, Mr Straw denied he had spoiled any chance the Afghans had of getting a fair hearing when he said last week that he wanted as many as possible removed from Britain.

"We have a great sympathy with those who have a genuine and well founded fear of persecution," he said. "On the other hand we cannot possibly be in a circumstance where it appears we are encouraging international terrorist crime."

A Kampuchean airline jet was set to leave RAF Brize Norton early today bound for Kandahar in southern Afghanistan with 72 of the former hostages on board.

A home office spokesman said the number expected to leave was greater than had been thought, but that the situation was still "fluid".

Some 100 of the remaining hostages spent their second evening at the fire service college in Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, following a fourth day of interviews by immigration officials.

The former hostages are being housed in three accommodation blocks at the college, surrounded by a hastily erected 6ft 5in wire mesh fence, and guarded by around 60 Group Four security guards.

The four crew members who escaped from the plane are understood to be staying elsewhere in the area.
