fields.headline: Workplace bullying
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you have been bullied at work, you are not alone. According to new research from Good Housekeeping magazine, one in four women have been the victims of workplace bullying.
fields.body:
If you have been bullied at work, you are not alone. According to new research from Good Housekeeping magazine, one in four women have been the victims of workplace bullying. The magazine also reports that 60% of those polled admit to suffering from work-related stress, while 30% had been victims of sexism. But the overall result was more optimistic - three-quarters of readers are happy in their current job.

New job blues

You can't remember anyone's name, the software on the PC is defeating you, and you have yet to transfer a phone call successfully. Sound familiar? Starting a new job is extremely stressful, says recruitment agency Adecco, and a significant proportion of people quit within the first few weeks. Researching the company, asking for a tour of the premises, and getting properly briefed on your job description will all help to make you feel more positive on the day. Finally, smile and appear confident - you might even convince yourself!

Waterworks

Looking for something different for your firm's event this year? How about dragon boat racing? According to Peterborough-based Gable Events, teams of ten people furiously paddling a 30ft boat to the beat of a drum is one of the fastest growing team building activities in the country. The company has launched new, shorter boats to make the sport accessible to smaller firms. This month saw the start of the Chinese Year of the Dragon - what better reason to do a spot of paddling? Call Gable Events on 01780 470718 for more details.

Travel in comfort

Does your boss dread the next business trip? A new book may offer some comfort. The Survivor's Guide to Business Travel by Roger Collis gives an insider's tips on beating the system. Taken from his International Herald Tribune column, the book explains how to get upgrades, beat jet lag, save money, and keep fit while circumnavigating the globe. It costs £12.99 from Kogan Page, tel 01903 828503.

Government homework

Continuing its bid to improve our work-home balance, the government has set up a committee to advise it on the issues involved. Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities, aims to bring together the needs of bosses and workers, improving profitability while helping staff to enjoy more flexible working. The committee will examine, among other things, the UK's long hours culture as it prepares a new work-home campaign to be launched in the near future.

 Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: Sleepless in cyberspace
fields.standfirst:
Like many PAs, Julie Robinson has to arrange a lot of meetings. The difference with hers is that they often lead to romance. Ann Bird found out why
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Like many PAs, Julie Robinson has to arrange a lot of meetings. The difference with hers is that they often lead to romance. Ann Bird found out why.
fields.body:
You may love your job, but not many PAs or secretaries spend every working day bringing love to others. As a PA at introduction agency Club Sirius, Julie Robinson plays an essential role in helping its 10,000 members find the perfect match, whether through the events and holidays it organises or through its website.

"Anyone interested in signing up can now visit the site, tap in their postcode, state their preferences and preview a selection of potential matches," says Robinson, 37, who has worked at the company for five years. It certainly worked for one woman, who liked the profile of a particular man so much - you don't see photographs initially - she promptly joined so she could meet him, and they've recently announced that they're getting married.

But it's not all about walking down the aisle. Club Sirius, which is based in Northwich, Cheshire, says it is more a lifestyle club than a dating agency obsessed with arranging cosy dinners for two. It claims to be the largest club in the country specifically for "single, well-educated and articulate people", with members all over the country, but mainly in urban centres. "I think, in terms of numbers, Devon is probably our worst area," says Robinson. "We have lots in London, Manchester and Edinburgh."

Much of her time is spent arranging venues for the company's events programme, such as bowling evenings, go-karting and Spanish dinners, where a big group of members can get together. If they feel more adventurous, they can even go on group holidays skiing. Each can bring a single friend for reassurance, too.

When the office is busy - and the start of the year is always the most frantic time - Robinson will help out on the phones, liaising with members. A typical day can involve anything from checking the managing director Conrad Morris's appointments, to updating the members' newsletter, to helping write scripts for the events hotline.

"With the new millennium, there's a greater feeling of 'turning over a new leaf' and people always look for romance in the run up to Valentine's Day," she says. And she can easily get caught up in the wooing herself: "It's always nice when a man rings up and asks me to send some flowers to his date from the night before to say how much he enjoyed the evening - that's one of the best bits about the job.

"Often members who don't have access to the internet ring me, so I go online to do a search for them before making a printout of suitable candidates, which I send them. I think also they like the personal touch - after all, if you married as a teenager and suddenly find yourself widowed in middle age, the thought of going dating again can be very daunting."

Love, it seems, is a growth industry. The website already has around 100,000 hits a week, with a million visitors in its first six months last year. The company was founded in 1992 and claims to have doubled in size every year since. Club Sirius now employs about 100 people, 40 of whom are computer analysts, as well as numerous part-timers - everyone from lawyers to psychologists to teachers - who interview all the prospective members in their own homes.

But Robinson, who is married with three children, must be utterly dis creet, ensuring members' details are kept confidential. "We have several very famous people on our books - politicians, sportsmen - but I couldn't possibly tell you who they are! We use aliases for them." Seeking love is by no means the pursuit of the young. "Our oldest member is about 80 and we have quite a few in their 70s."

But not everything is rosy in the world of moonlight and roses. Telling people at parties what she does for a living, says Robinson, can mean she's quizzed for hours. And although it's a very social job, she keeps work and play separate and doesn't attend club events. "I might if my husband let me," she jokes. "And no, we didn't meet through the club."

fields.headline: Float planned for web video service
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Investors including Cliff Stanford, the founder of Demon internet, are likely to float Britain's first "video on demand" business on London markets later this year.
fields.body:
Investors including Cliff Stanford, the founder of Demon internet, are likely to float Britain's first "video on demand" business on London markets later this year.

The Redbus Film Group, which is part-owned by former investment banker Simon Franks, is considering raising money on the markets for additional funding for the fast-growing web-based film enterprise.

The group, which intends to start a video-on-demand service on the internet later this year, secured rights via its distribution arm for the new Antonio Banderas and Woody Harrelson film Play it to the Bone.

Other films in the deal announced yesterday include Gun Shy, which stars Liam Neeson and Sandra Bullock, as well as Sam Raimi's The Gift, in which Keanu Reaves, Cate Blanchett and Hilary Swank playing leading roles.

Mr Franks, the chief executive who set up the business two years ago, said the group was already able to offer its video-on-demand service through the internet but was waiting to launch it until high-speed internet access was more widely available.

He owns part of the business in which Mr Stanford, who made £30m when he sold his Demon internet business to Scottish Telecom last year, also has a stake. Mr Stanford is chairman of the film group and has other business interests through his venture capital company.

Mr Franks said Redbus Film Group was considering ways to raise fresh investment. "There are lots of ways we can go but the IPO [initial public offering, or flotation] is the route we are advised most often [by the firms's bankers]."

Earlier this month he hired nine senior staff from Polygram, responsible for releasing blockbusters such as Four Weddings and a Funeral, and expects to secure more than 25 films a year for cinema distribution as well as over 2,000 for the video service.

fields.headline: The pursuit of paranoia
fields.standfirst:
On US 'cyberterrorists'
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Computers crash every day. Servers go down. Bandwiths get congested and networks clog. The IT world is as prone to breakdown and gridlock as our transport systems. But something unusual is happening.
fields.body:
Computers crash every day. Servers go down. Bandwiths get congested and networks clog. The IT world is as prone to breakdown and gridlock as our transport systems. But something unusual is happening. Since early February there have been a series of strikes on high-profile e-commerce and e-news targets:Yahoo!, Amazon,Buy.com, Ebay, CNN.

The assaults have all followed a pattern - floods of data released by implanted saboteur programs in remote sites. The result, for a few hours, is overload and "denial of service": a jam. The raiders were initially assumed to be hackers; pointy-headed kids playing computer games in grown-up places. The authorities were not amused. After the third wave of assaults the raiders were relabelled "cyber- terrorists"; up there with Osama Bin Laden.

The Justice Department warned of grim penalties: five years and $250,000 for a first offence; 10 years for a second. Attorney general Janet Reno declared: "We are committed in every way possible to tracking those who are responsible". Not since the Unabomber have the G-Men seemed so determined to get their man.

Who are they? "Pranksters", cyberloonies, or a new underground army linked with the anarchists who pissed so spectacularly on the WTO party in Seattle?

In a thoughtful editorial on February 10, the Guardian proclaimed itself alarmed but also "puzzled". Alarm is understandable. The US economy is booming on the strength of its grotesquely overvalued high-technology stocks. Amazon.com, whose shares have gone up tenfold in four years, has yet to return a cent's profit. No one is quite sure whether this is the Calgary stampede, the 1849 gold rush or Tulipmania. For two years Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has been trying, vainly, to take the heat out of hi-tech stocks. There's a terrifying risk, if e-commerce proves vulnerable to any computer-literate vandal, that investors will pull out their money and put it somewhere safer. If Wall Street catches a cold, we get pneumonia. What if Wall Street gets pneumonia? Puzzling aspects to this scare remain. How did the crackers suddenly get so smart, so organised, and why are they so hostile to cyber-heroes like Jeff Bezos? Nerds hangouts are buzzing with poisonous suspicion. The US government, they believe, is confecting an electronic Gulf-of-Tonkin pretext for going to war against them. The case is put by "jim the paranoic" [sic] on slashdot.org ("News for Nerds. Stuff that Matters"). Jim's scenario runs thus: on January 27, Clinton announced in his State of the Union address that "electronic law enforcement" would be a high priority. Three days later, the National Security Agency announced that its mainframe had crashed from January 24 to 28.

It boggles the imagination that this could happen and that the secretive NSA would embarrass itself by voluntarily making its incompetence public. They instinctively cover their "asses", they don't bare them to the world's press. A week later, Clinton's budget allocated $240m to expand, massively, the government's wire-tapping facilities ("wire" means world wide web; the FBI will be listening to you, Guardian- reader). Then began the February cyber-assaults on the electronic shopping malls and news services of America.

What got less headline attention was that on February 8 the phone systems in Missouri and Oklahoma crashed. Why should those backwoods states be targeted by the new raiders of the net? As Jim darkly speculates: "It illustrated the horrors of vile cyber-terrorists, but without bothering 'important' people in Washington or on the east and west coasts. What better way to 'prove' the need for massively expanded surveillance, and create a frenzy of support for it?!"

It may be that when the FBI crawls back through the net they will find some 15-year-old kid at his keyboard having fun. Nonetheless, two new and frightening entities emerge out of the panic.

After this month, the FBI's National Infrastructure Protection Centre is going to be a main player. And behind it is something eerily reminiscent of the old military-industrial complex. Only this time it's e-commerce and government. It's enough to make anyone paranoic [sic].

fields.headline: World Bank in e-loans link-up
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
World Bank
Softbank
fields.trailText: The World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the Japanese internet investor, Softbank will launch a $500m fund today to invest in the digital economies of 100 developing nations.
fields.body:
The World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the Japanese internet investor, Softbank will launch a $500m fund today to invest in the digital economies of 100 developing nations.

According to the two partners, it is the most significant initiative yet to narrow the global digital divide between technologically advanced nations and poorer countries which are losing out in the internet revolution.

The president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, will formally announce the plan in Tokyo with Masayoshi Son, president of Softbank and the world's biggest "e-investor".

Named Softbank Emerging Markets and headquartered in California, the new venture will provide seed money and technological, legal and management support for internet-related businesses.

Under the plans, the company will also promote free or subsidised internet services to schools and other educational institutions in poor nations.

"The digital divide is one of the greatest impediments to development and it is growing exponentially," Mr Wolfensohn said.

"This investment will accelerate the inclusion of the developing countries in the information revolution."

IFC, a division of the World Bank which promotes private-sector investment in poorer countries, will contribute 25% of the initial capital of $200m.

fields.headline: Mind your languages
fields.standfirst:
Becoming bilingual can double your options, says Helene Mulholland
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Becoming bilingual can double your options, says Helene Mulholland
fields.body:
The day you first heard those immortal words "Liselotte ist krank," it was always going to go one of two ways. Either you would love learning German, or you were going to spend the next couple of years doing some serious doodling.

But when the UK subsidiary of an international property company needs to liaise with its foreign clients, or the architectural partnership you work for is bidding for a project in Europe, you'll be glad you listened. For those with both sharp secretarial skills and the ability to speak in a foreign tongue, bilingual secretarial work is the natural and rewarding career option. Many London agencies will have language desks, but there are also several recruitment agencies that specialise in languages.

Cathy Fawcett is a consultant at Language Recruitment Services, which specialises in language-based positions across the career board. Business is brisk at the moment, with the heaviest demand for bilingual secretaries coming from the corporate world of finance, law, and architecture. The ability required, she says, will depend on the contract: "We have positions requiring advanced bilingual skills, while other companies want a spectrum of languages to a working level."

An increasing number of applicants are graduates, many of whom will have studied languages at university and are keen to find a job where they can use them. Candidates must have good typing speed, proficiency with Word, and ideally be familiar with Excel and Powerpoint. And the biggest reward will show up in the bank balance. "Languages are definitely an advantage and attract greater remuneration," says Fawcett.

As for glamour, overseas postings do arise; Christine Proctor, director of recruitment agency Language Matters, currently has vacancies in Paris, Amsterdam and Frankfurt. But for those wanting to stay in Britain, the capital calls. "There is a much more focused need for languages in London than anywhere else," she says.

Anita Bucknall came to London to find work as a bilingual secretary after failing to find suitable positions in the north west. Once in the city, she was offered three jobs in a single week and accepted a post with prospects in a foreign bank.

Bucknall did a degree in French and German, followed by a course in international business administration. "I had no additional skills to fall back on so secretarial studies was the way to go." She then worked as a bilingual secretary in Switzerland, where she picked up Italian as a fourth language. With her current employers she has progressed from bilingual secretary to administration officer, and is currently being trained as a credit analyst.

For those feeling defeated by the level of competition Bucknall presents, don't fear. Some companies request only a working knowledge of a language, enough to make a foreign contact feel welcomed. And more often than not, they will be only too happy to practise their English on you.

Alternatively, the RSA offers a certificate in either business language competence, or administrative and secretarial procedures with a language option. Failing that, try language course packs from your local library. This will also allow you to find out if Liselotte ever made it out of her sick bed.

fields.headline: Take the corpse road
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: You can't park your car beyond the entrance to the quiet, secluded valley of Swindale nowadays. If you're lucky enough to spot the Riggindale golden eagles, you can watch them undisturbed by traffic. There were two of them the other day, slowly soaring above the road that drops down into the valley from Mardale. I hear, however, that no eggs have been laid this season.
fields.body:
You can't park your car beyond the entrance to the quiet, secluded valley of Swindale nowadays. If you're lucky enough to spot the Riggindale golden eagles, you can watch them undisturbed by traffic. There were two of them the other day, slowly soaring above the road that drops down into the valley from Mardale. I hear, however, that no eggs have been laid this season.

A century or two ago Swindale was a scholarly sort of place, with a grammar school, where the farmers, it was said, could sow in Latin and read in Greek. Now there are just three lonely farms, scattered woodlands, a lovely, meandering beck, some steep crags where I used to climb in the 50s and, in the middle of the dale, a modest weir perhaps 10 feet high. If the water engineers had not changed their minds, there would have been a 100 foot high dam, the farms would have been swept away and the valley flooded like Mardale just over the steeply wooded fells to the west.

Indeed, the old church was demolished, years earlier, in readiness for the drowning of the dale. About 50 years ago I found the tiny schoolroom that had served as a temporary church - five dusty pews, the parson's lectern and, in the corner, the little organ, perhaps three feet long, on which, by furious pedalling, I managed to produce a few lugubrious notes in the bass. Clearly, the sheep had taken over the ruin and, a few years later, the last stones had disappeared and I could find no trace of the place.

Having escaped being turned into a reservoir Swindale, which once turned out bishops, seems still a sad dale, full of memories but also much quiet beauty. Leave your car before the first farm, walk along the dale and climb steeply up to the corpse road (along which Mardale's dead were taken, by horseback, for burial at Shap). Bear left at a cairn for Selside Pike, the highest hill around here, strike east across the moor and return to the dale down the side of an impressive cataract of waterfalls. A delightful track underneath the crags brings you back to the car. The chances are you won't see a soul all day.

webTitle: How do I love thee? Let me count the gays

fields.headline: How do I love thee? Let me count the gays
fields.standfirst:
The dome is a dull, heterosexual thing that doesn't fire my passion

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The dome is a dull, heterosexual thing that doesn't fire my passion.
fields.body:
I do believe that some inanimate objects have an inherent sexuality. For example: a friend recently moved into a new flat which is, if not gay, then certainly camp. It took her two hours to remove the statue of David fridge-magnet that was clamped to the Smeg she inherited. With a chisel. And when she tried to paint the living room a gentle shade of light grey, it became an unequivocal lilac.

So there you go. Things can boast sexual leanings. Given which, I hardly think the Millennium Dome was a screamingly appropriate venue for a "gay day".

Few things are as heterosexual as the Millennium Dome. I mean heterosexual in the most leaden, uninspiring way. It is this dull, pedestrian heterosexuality that is much of the dome's problem, I'd say. Heterosexual in the Ian Beale, Ken Barlow sense of the word - all hetero and very little sexual. It's as camp as, well, a tent, which, if you think about it, is not actually camp in the least.

Nonetheless, the weekend did, indeed, see gay day at the dome. Now, when the event was first announced, it was easy to imagine what the dome had to gain by association with gay culture - a public perception that is a little sparklier, a little more lithe around the hips. You never know. Maybe gay day could render the dome a bit less tent, and a bit more marquee.

It was not so easy, however, to imagine what gay culture had to gain by association with the dome. It is hardly Canal Street at dusk.

Yet people were encouraged to express their gayness by wearing rainbow clothes, and one particular group were rumoured to have printed a load of T-shirts which read: I'm a domosexual.

Inevitably, the people who get cross about such things, did so. Realising that a) gay was catching, and knowing their luck, their year 10 group would contract the permanent Mandelson gay variant, as opposed to the passing-fad type that Michael Portillo was briefly struck down with; that b) their spotty, graceless, monosyllabic adolescent charges were bound to be the prime cruising targets; and that c) there would be no end to the cottaging going on in the body zone, school trips were cancelled.

Fewer kids equals less queues, so I thought I'd pop along. Generally, if enough people declare something crap, my expectations are lowered sufficiently, and I'll enjoy it. But on this occasion, no dice. Gay day or not, the dome is one tedious pile of canvas.

It took me a while to see between the buggy-wielding couples, the nylon wearing Americans, the over hair-sprayed, Tommy Hilfiger wearing teens, through to the sporadic gay group. Absolutely no sign of the domosexual T-shirts, but still, your average gay punter does seem exotic against the structure's backdrop of absolute banality. I stalk a gay threesome round some zones, and note that one security guard tuts none too subtly at a gay group leader's Burberry check kilt.

I begin a gay count, thinking I might be able to conclude something. Life's too short to wait for the body zone, so I count gays in the queue instead: zero.

The play zone (rules of the play zone: do not run in the play zone, play fair in the play zone. Very Fight Club); gay count: three, all observing rather than participating.

McDonald's: zero, though the staff are much nicer here than in Oxford Street. Aroma Café; gay count: through the roof.

Queue for the rainbow tunnel of the rest zone; gay count: zero. The mind zone; gay count: two in the first hall, watching robots shift rubber balls around, three by the heat-sensitive camera, two taking photos of the monster crouching boy, none by the ant colony, eight in the electrical impulses-as-music room. The work zone; gay count: two. The faith zone; gay count: zero.

I conclude: gay people don't queue. And no one, regardless of sexual orientation, likes the faith zone.

At 3.45, the London Gay Male Voice Choir strike up in the main arena. A sizeable crowd, half gay, half straight, assembles. The choir sing a Welsh folk song; Seasons of Love; Aqua's Barbie Girl (dedicated to all the school trips that were allowed to come); Bananarama's Nana Nana Hey Hey (Goodbye) and I Could Have Danced All Night.

Apart from one minor slip, when the conductor adopts domespeak and says: "It's not about who you sleep with, it's about who you love" (rather too reminiscent of the ghastly soundbites about working together that cover all available dome wall space), it is by far the best thing on offer. But then it's over, and there is nothing for it but to plough on.

After three hours, I feel the exact opposite of gay, in any sense of the word.

It must be an incredible time to be gay: things to be rallied against, things to be celebrated. Surely there are better places to do it?

fields.headline: GP faces drug death inquiry
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Harold Shipman trial has triggered a second police inquiry into a GP over the deaths of two women after they were injected with large doses of diamorphine, the drug used by the Manchester doctor to murder at least 15 patients.
fields.body:
The Harold Shipman trial has triggered a second police inquiry into a GP over the deaths of two women after they were injected with large doses of diamorphine, the drug used by the Manchester doctor to murder at least 15 patients.

Police were contacted after a call to Granada TV's This Morning programme in the middle of a studio debate and phone-in about the Shipman case two days after the guilty verdicts at Preston crown court.

Detectives in South Yorkshire confirmed yesterday that a detective chief superintendent is heading initial checks on material in the call, which is understood to have come from the GP's wife. They refused to name the doctor and stressed that patients in the county should continue to see their GPs as normal and that "there is no reason for any member of the public to be afraid".

The deaths of the women within hours of receiving 15 and 20mg shots of diamorphine, a painkiller more often given in recommended doses of up to 10mg, have already been investigated by the General Medical Council after complaints from relatives. More than 350 other patients signed a petition of support for the GP, but some members of the families of the two women were resentful and unconvinced after the GMC heard the case without local witnesses.

Det Chief Supt Mick Burdis of South Yorkshire police yesterday acknowledged claims of alleged malpractices. "It is early days regarding any inquiry. We have not received any formal allegations. Information has been passed and we need to examine this in detail to determine whether there is any truth in what has been said."

Police said that no further information would be released until today, and others involved in the initial call have been asked to keep details to a minimum.

A Granada spokeswoman said: "The phone call came in while This Morning was in the middle of the phone-in on Wednesday morning, February 2. It was not broadcast but staff felt that it was genuine and that the police should be informed."

Relatives of the patients only learned of the police inquiry this weekend, after detectives had made initial contact with local health authorities to check the GP's background. The doctor, who denied wrongdoing at the GMC inquiry, has not yet been questioned by police.

The deaths of the women within hours of receiving 15 and 20mg shots of diamorphine, a painkiller more often given in recommended doses of up to 10mg, have already been investigated by the General Medical Council after complaints from relatives. More than 350 other patients signed a petition of support for the GP, but some members of the families of the two women were resentful and unconvinced after the GMC heard the case without local witnesses. Det Chief Supt Mick Burdis of South Yorkshire police yesterday acknowledged claims of alleged malpractices. "It is early days regarding any inquiry. We have not received any formal allegations. Information has been passed and we need to examine this in detail to determine whether there is any truth in what has been said." Police said that no further information would be released until today, and others involved in the initial call have been asked to keep details to a minimum. A Granada spokeswoman said: "The phone call came in while This Morning was in the middle of the phone-in on Wednesday morning, February 2. It was not broadcast but staff felt that it was genuine and that the police should be informed." Relatives of the patients only learned of the police inquiry this weekend, after detectives had made initial contact with local health authorities to check the GP's background. The doctor, who denied wrongdoing at the GMC inquiry, has not yet been questioned by police.

webTitle: A real will for peace would put millions on the streets

fields.headline: A real will for peace would put millions on the streets
fields.standfirst: The people of Northern Ireland must grasp the initiative at last Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Nobody, of course, can go back to the beginning. That is an Irish legend lost among the bogs and mists of futility. But, as the chimera called "peace" slips and slides again, it is at least worth going back to the beginning of these Troubles (more modern than ancient). What did the British government think then?
fields.body:
Nobody, of course, can go back to the beginning. That is an Irish legend lost among the bogs and mists of futility. But, as the chimera called "peace" slips and slides again, it is at least worth going back to the beginning of these Troubles (more modern than ancient). What did the British government think then? We know, because the 30-year rule opens the closed cabinet doors of 1969.

Home secretary James Callaghan told his colleagues that: "There is a good deal of corroboration for the view that the Catholics have acted in self-defence, and little evidence to support the view of the Northern Irish government that the IRA are mainly responsible." Big Jim's officials reported widespread unionist gerrymandering, favouritism and seedy control over local authority housing. "There are legitimate grievances and it is entirely legitimate that they should be ventilated by demonstration."

Callaghan himself told the new Northern Irish prime minister that "he must not rely on British military support in maintaining repressive policies". Harold Wilson's private secretary reported bleakly that "our main trouble is from the Protestants". Defence secretary Healey blamed the RUC for the "indiscriminate use of firearms, tear gas etc" and the head of the British army described a police force "which is behind the times, poorly led and administered, with a sadly inefficient special branch."

In sum, as it seemed to the men and women gathered around the long table in Downing Street, this was a no-win game which the unionists, the triumphalists of the Orange Order, had started by their mindless choice of sectarian repression over liberal democracy. And now, yet again, the poor old mainland Brits were being summoned to sort things out in blood, sweat and tears.

You don't need to agree in detail with those ministers and witnesses of 30 years ago to see the point. Agreement about anything in Northern Ireland's past is probably an unattainable golal. But the cabinet minutes do paint a grisly picture of frustration and helpessness. They tell us, as troubled times returned, where an impotent government far away laid the (mostly private, teeth-grinding) blame. British imperialism? Wilson's team, even then, wished Belfast could be deemed independent and told to push off.

For once, too, the recent past has relevance to the present. It reminds us, as the IRA hangs on to its guns and another "process" of reconciliation threatens to go belly up - perhaps for many years - that it takes two to make a peace. It reminds us that nothing can really begin afresh without continuing compromise, exercised day after day until it becomes normality.

A few weeks ago one truce ended. Eta, the zealots of Basque nationalism, returned to blowing up cars in crowded streets and killing people. And some thing else returned to Spain, the squares of Madrid and Pamplona. Crowds a million-strong walked arm in arm, expressing their disgust, horror and defiance. The Spanish people made their voices heard and, in so doing, immediately isolated the tiny straggle of terrorists. It won't end their campaign, to be sure: but it does create a political context which puts the greatest pressure on them. The people, massed, have that power.

I wonder, though, where the people of Northern Ireland have gone through these few glum weeks of slithering failure. I wonder (extrapolating) what the rest of the people of Britain think, if they care. For it is the people who have gone missing again, ruled themselves out of this eqation.

They were there once, with their candlelit vigils and their funeral marches as the killings echoed on. Many gallant individuals began movements then and still persevere. But where is the great shout of anger? Where are streets filled end to end with crowds who put peace first? Where is the pressure, the blessed pressure, for change?

Gerry Adams was talking the other day about "the undefeated army" of the IRA. It wasn't a popular line, one promptly rubbished by all the usual suspects. But it is also a clinically accurate description. The IRA was not defeated, any more than the British army and the RUC were defeated. Neither side was winning or losing: the struggle was just going on, for decade after decade, without point or possible outcome. If it is now renewed, as it may well eventually be, the years ahead will only be filled with more pointless violence. The IRA cannot win; but nor - as those who confront them admit under their breath - can the security forces. There is no easy fix of internment. There is no possibility of totally isolating the terrorists where a sectarian divide still yawns. No solution: just more of the same. You might as well say the Russian army has settled the Chechen problem by flattening Grozny. Dream on!

So where are the people in their own hour of need? There is no doubt how they feel or what they want, passively. They continue, for the most part, to vote along traditional lines. They haven't transplanted the old heart of Northern Irish politics.

They have accepted the reluctances of the Aremy Council with resignation and more depressingly, done little to disrupt activist distrust of the unionist Council which now, apparently, will circumscribe David Trimble's room for manoeuvre still more chokingly. They have, in sum, left hope to others they decline to influence directly. Too harsh? Certainly in individual terms (see the tortured exhaustion of Seamus Mallon) but a collective judgment remains more problematical. If both Councils now feel the wind of outrage at their backs, then anything yet remains possible. But if there is no such manifest fury, then that in itself will deliver an awful truth.

Exit Mo, enter Mandy; exit, one day, Tony, enter who-can-say? The heirs of Wilson and Callaghan over the water will keep toiling on, biting their lips, hiding their real feelings because words out of place invoke inevitable furies. But peace, real peace, has to be craved for on the ground, sought as the highest prize. Peace isn't about symbols - a few machine guns or tons of Semtex given up in a hollow show of "disarmament" in Kosovo mode. New guns can always be bought, new obstacles found among the fudged clauses of diplomacy. Peace is determination to live together come what may. Peace isn't a minefield of ifs and buts - and sitting back while the vested interests carry on conniving. Peace has to be worked for.

A million Spaniards realise that. They walk for a purpose. It is a bleak thing to say, but there will be no lasting peace for Ireland until more millions throng the streets of Belfast and Dublin (and yes, Manchester and Birmingham too). This, 30 years on with nothing to show, is our challenge and our responsibility. And one day we shall have to acknowledge that by taking the prize for ourselves.

fields.headline: Child abusers need help
fields.trailText: When working with the serious issue of abusive behaviour by children, the NSPCC's response is informed by our understanding of child development (The end of innocence, February 12). In doing so we address these serious concerns without confusing them with normal, healthy child development.
fields.body:
When working with the serious issue of abusive behaviour by children, the NSPCC's response is informed by our understanding of child development (The end of innocence, February 12). In doing so we address these serious concerns without confusing them with normal, healthy child development.

In relation to children who abuse, the behaviour we are dealing with includes harmful and deliberate acts involving the use of force. Many of the children, both victims and abusers, with whom we work have extremely serious behavioural difficulties which in many cases are likely to become more serious without professional help. They are referred to us by other agencies or services that frequently have nowhere else to turn for specialised help.

Children involved in "horseplay" or "kiss chase" or normal playground behaviour are not referred to us. Natural sexual curiosity and experimentation is a healthy part of growing up. In attempting to link this unrelated subject with serious sexual abuse by children, the article denigrates a very real problem.

It has taken a long time for all of us to grasp that sexual abuse of children does happen. Now we need to grasp that sometimes children do this to children. We need to do this so that we help not only the child victim but also the child who harms, and in doing so harms not only others but their own healthy development into adulthood.

Phillip Noyes
Director, public policy NSPCC
pnoyes@nspcc.org.uk

fields.headline: Intolerance by any name
fields.trailText: Why, why, why do you still give space to Melanie Phillips (They call me a moral authoritarian, February 11)?
fields.body:
Why, why, why do you still give space to Melanie Phillips (They call me a moral authoritarian, February 11)?

So now it is genuine progressive liberalism and tolerance to oppose equal rights for gay and straight people? It is compassion to support section 28 which prevents teachers from encouraging tolerance towards those whose sexuality is different to your own? And equality means treating all gay people as if they were paedophiles while supporting gay rights is a militant campaign which may do harm to your children?

The values Melanie Phillips preaches are indeed universal, they are the values of bigotry and hypocrisy.

Dr Tim Matschak
London
T.Matschak@iop.kcl.ac.uk

 If, as Melanie Phillips asserts, "it is perfectly possible to be tolerant and compassionate to gay people while opposing a militant campaign which may do harm to children", why do I see and hear from all the people that have spoken against the repeal of section 28 (from Baroness Young to Cardinal Winning) the cold glitter of prejudice, and sometimes hatred in their eyes or words? Is this coincidence? Just remind me, Melanie, who is subjecting people to "hate campaigns of rare viciousness"?

Andrew Hibbert
Nottingham
trentvoyager@diamond.co.uk

 We all know that Melanie Phillips has gone a bit peculiar since her days as a regular columnist on the Guardian, but she really cannot be allowed to get away with the statement that the gay rights lobby "subjects its opponents to hate campaigns of rare viciousness".

To deny equality to gay men and lesbians on the grounds of wholly irrational fears and scare stories is homophobic. And it should be quite clear to anyone who has listened to the recent parliamentary debates which side in the current argument is fomenting hatred.

Nick Billingham
London

Melanie Phillips is far too modest. Surely, with her unerring ability to judge the proper outcome of every divorce case heard in the past 40 years and her omniscient knowledge of precisely what has gone wrong in society and how to put it right, she should be called neither a moral authoritarian or a progressive who believes in simple liberalism but, quite simply, God.

Pam Holden Smith BR> Coventry

 Jörg Haider believes in freedom and Melanie Phillips is a progressive. And I'm Chairman Mao.

David Rosenberg
London
david@bardrose.dircon.co.uk

 Bravo Melanie Phillips. She admirably stands up for traditional moral values and underlines their importance for the health of society. For too long, it seems, the strident voices of the cynical "anything goes" minority have scarcely been challenged.

Frank Murphy
Sheffield

OK, Melanie Phillips may be amalgamating ideas that do not deserve to be bedfellows - I would not have thought, for instance, that supporters of section 28 receive as much moral obloquy as runaway parents. But her central point, that liberals who blindly pursue personal satisfactions are as bad as rightwing globalisers, and for the same reason, is superbly persuasive.

Ian Wood
Ashbourne, Derbyshire

Melanie Phillips "intimidated into silence" via the pages of a national newspaper!

Martin Dearden
Liverpool

fields.headline: Outing the facts
fields.trailText: May I correct a few myths before people assume they are facts (Outraged of Lambeth, February 12).
fields.body:
May I correct a few myths before people assume they are facts (Outraged of Lambeth, February 12).

It not not true that I "refused to discuss" my homosexuality during the Bermondsey byelection. Under pressure from the Labour party, I did not talk to the press about my private life. That was a mistake, and I apologise. But I was totally open about my gayness when canvassing on the doorsteps, which is why there was such a homophobic campaign against me.

I do not support outing gays who have "denied, or kept secret" their sexuality - only those who are hypocritical and homophobic, and who condemn and harm the gay community. Queer Remembrance Day at the Cenotaph was not intended to "cause offence". Most of the public who witnessed it were not offended; they applauded.

If I am so "unforgiving", why did I send Michael Portillo a letter thanking him for voting for an equal age of consent? I do not "refuse" to consider criticism from other gays. I take it very seriously and often feel great self-doubt. As to the charge of "extremism": my methods are much less extreme than those of the now near-universally admired suffragettes.

Far from being obsessed with gay issues, I oppose special gay rights laws, and support universal legislation to protect everyone against discrimination - not just gays, but senior citizens, religious minorities and others.

Peter Tatchell
OutRage! London
peter@tatchell.freeserve.co.uk

 Roy Hattersley has allowed Peter Tatchell to rewrite history. The controversy over Tatchell's selection as Labour candidate in Bermondsey in 1982 had little to do with him being gay, and almost everything to do with it not being a fair fight. The secretary of the local party, far from being impartial in the selection process, was Tatchell himself.

Chris Jones
Luton

The dome is a microcosm of the society in which we live - which substitutes image for substance, style for design, and presentation for value. A candidate from never-never land is just the man. Bon chance monsieur.

Sible Hedingham, Essex

fields.headline: It's a hamster
fields.trailText: Edward Hardy (Letters, February 12) is incorrect. A man who claims to be an expert should have no problem identifying that the hamster illustrated clearly has a small tail whereas guinea pigs have no tails at all. We can safely say that the creature shown is a hamster. Mice, hamsters, and guinea pigs all make up part of the rodent family, so the hamster quite obviously would be a "mouse-like thing".

webTitle: Thirst for power vies with communal hate as Kosovo's deadly sin

fields.headline: Thirst for power vies with communal hate as Kosovo's deadly sin
fields.standfirst:
Bank official's murder fuels fears over power vacuum in the province
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The middle-aged Albanian was lying on the pavement outside the bank he ran in the main street, bleeding heavily from his gunshot wounds.
fields.body:
The middle-aged Albanian was lying on the pavement outside the bank he ran in the main street, bleeding heavily from his gunshot wounds.

From their headquarters little more than 100 yards away, American peacekeepers raced to help. The man was taken by helicopter to the military hospital in Camp Bondsteel, the huge American base in this south-eastern corner of Kosovo, but died on the way.

Though his killer or killers quickly disappeared, Danush Januzi's circumstances suggest he was not a victim of Serb anger, but of something which moderate Kosovan Albanians fear is the new danger facing the territory. A struggle for power and money is pitting Albanian leaders against each other in the vacuum left by Serb officials when they withdrew last summer.

"Mr Januzi had been the manager of the bank long before the international community arrived in Kosovo," said Gilles Dubuc, the foreign official who was appointed as Vitina's mayor by the United Nations mission in Kosovo.

"The local political party replaced him, but he stayed in his job and when I got here in early November I was confronted with two individuals fighting over it. I decided to give Mr Januzi his old job back. I told the other man not to show up any more but promised to find him a job somewhere else. Whether there's any connection with the killing, I don't know," Mr Dubuc said. Asked which party the other man belonged to, he said: "The PPDK."

The problem facing Mr Dubuc when he took up his duties several months after the Serbs' withdrawal has been repeated in scores of town halls across Kosovo. The PPDK, the Kosovo democratic progressive party, is the new incarnation of the Kosovo liberation army, whose guerrilla forces fought for independence against the Serbs.

The KLA was required to disarm in September, three months after the agreement which ended Nato's bombing campaign in the province. But long before the deadline expired, it used its power and wartime popularity to appoint local mayors and other officials in towns and villages with an Albanian majority after the Serb withdrawal.

One aim was to provide much-needed services, but the KLA also wanted to present the United Nations, which has a mandate to run Kosovo, with a fait accompli when international officials arrived.

Some new UN administrators accepted the KLA appointees as advisers, though they lost the official mayoral title. Others found replacements. Mr Dubuc chose a compromise. He dismissed Daut Shemali, a KLA man who became a local hero after spending two years as a political prisoner under the Serbs, but allowed him to stay temporarily in the office he occupied. In the meantime, Mr Dubuc started negotiations with other parties in Vitina to share out town hall departments.

The position of bank manager was a much-coveted post, since its responsibilities included handling the wages of teachers and all other local employees. But if jealousy over this access to power and cash was one possible motive for Januzi's death, there was another.

"Everyone who collaborated with the Serbs ought to be killed. Presumably that's why he died," snapped Bedre Peposhi, a history teacher, as he stood outside the town hall after Januzi's murder this week.

Vitina's population of Serbs has halved since Serb forces abandoned Kosovo to K-For, the international peacekeeping force, in June. Serb teenagers go to secondary school in the Serb enclave of Vrbovac, five miles away.

As Serb children yesterday piled into a bus with armoured American Humvee vehicles acting as escorts for the journey home, Aca Nikolic, the headteacher, recalled Januzi: "He stayed in Kosovo throughout the war. He was the best Albanian in Vitina. I knew him because we got our salaries from the Yugoslav state bank he managed."

Veton Surroi, the publisher of Kosovo's best-known newspaper, Koha Ditore, sparked controversy last year when he condemned the revenge killing of Serb civilians by Albanians.

If public opinion did not move to stop such murders and prevent the growth of a climate of impunity, the next targets of Albanian killers would be other Albanians, he warned. Januzi's death this week seemed to bear out those forebodings.

The former banking official's white Mercedes was parked close to the bloodstains on the pavement where he was shot. Its special four-digit licence plate showed that he had been employed in a high position by the Serbian state. But whether he died because of envy, competition for power, or revenge, may never be known.

fields.headline: Our schemes are working
fields.trailText: Your article relating to the preliminary OECD report about the transition from education to working life (UK fails to provide path from school to work, February 11) has the merit of acknowledging that it referred to the period before the election of this government.
fields.body:
Your article relating to the preliminary OECD report about the transition from education to working life (UK fails to provide path from school to work, February 11) has the merit of acknowledging that it referred to the period before the election of this government.

It is odd, however, to go on to claim that the "government spin machine" was silent about the conference when the report was first presented to ministers. Not only did Tessa Jowell and I issue press releases, but I chaired the conference. Our press releases outlined some of the many things this government has done to bridge the gap between school and work - most notably mentors for all 13 to 19-year-olds under the Connections initiative and increased basic skills support under the New Deal for those who suffered from the educational legacy of the past.

All 14 to 16-year-olds are provided with at least two weeks' work experience. The department gave half a million pounds last year to the National Mentoring Network to enrich the experience of young people in relation to the world of business. We have put £5m into New Start to tackle disaffection and re-engage back into learning those who have dropped out from education and £20m a year into the neighbourhood renewal fund specifically geared to this group.

The preliminary OECD report incidentally, is not "confidential". It is available on their website.

David Blunkett
Secretary of state for education and employment

webTitle: Snipers shoot Nato troops in Kosovo's divided city

fields.headline: Snipers shoot Nato troops in Kosovo's divided city
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Snipers hiding in high-rise flats wounded two French soldiers in the divided Kosovan city of Mitrovice yesterday in defiance of a security clampdown by K-For, the Nato-led peace force. The ominous appearance of snipers and the targeting of K-For sent tension soaring in a city symbolising ethnic polarisation.
fields.body:
Snipers hiding in high-rise flats wounded two French soldiers in the divided Kosovan city of Mitrovice yesterday in defiance of a security clampdown by K-For, the Nato-led peace force. The ominous appearance of snipers and the targeting of K-For sent tension soaring in a city symbolising ethnic polarisation.

British troops were rushed to Mitrovice last week to beef up French contingents which had been accused of allowing Serbs to launch a pogrom a few nights earlier against the few Albanians left in the north of the city.

Ten people died and more than 20 were wounded as the gangs smashed the doors of flats throwing in grenades and shooting.

Yesterday's violence began with a grenade attack on an Albanian house at about 8am, which wounded six people. Gunfire rang out later and a French officer said five snipers were seen in a tower block on the north side of the Ibar river.

K-For troops fired back, killing one sniper and capturing two - Albanian men who had crossed the river from the southern side.

Lieutenant Colonel Patrique Chanliau said a French soldier was shot in the stomach while on patrol in the Serb part of the city. A second peacekeeper was shot in the arm after Nato troops launched a counter-attack on the snipers.

Before the Serb expulsion of most Albanians from Kosovo last year, the Albanians were a majority in Mitrovice, on both sides of the river. But the Serbs made a special effort to clear the northern side and rehouse Serbs in empty Albanian flats.

When K-for occupied the province last June, the city was put into the French sector. French peacekeepers erected barricades on the three bridges across the Ibar and stopped many Albanians from returning to their homes on the northern side. Meanwhile, Serb homes on the southern side were looted and burned by Albanians, leaving the Serbs no choice but to live in the north or leave Kosovo.

Although the Albanians held regular protests against the French policy, the de facto partition of Mitrovice appears to have emboldened the Serbs to try to evict the remaining Albanians from the north of the city.

Serb leaders there are in constant touch with Slobodan Milosevic's regime in Belgrade and there are unconfirmed reports of special police and paramilitaries in plainclothes moving back to Mitrovice.

After the pogrom 10 days ago, General Klaus Reinhardt, the K-For commander, sent more troops to the city, including British, German, Belgian and Italian contingents. Controls on the border with Serbia proper were tightened and troops began patrolling on foot through the city to deter the Serb gangs.

The French policy had been to rely mainly on guards at a few key points.

fields.headline: Labour's valentine
fields.standfirst:
Unloved but more popular than the rest
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: This may be St Valentine's Day, but the great love-in is over. Last Friday's Gallup Poll in the Daily Telegraph made Tony Blair's Labour look, more than ever before, like a government in the customary throes of mid-term.
fields.body:
This may be St Valentine's Day, but the great love-in is over. Last Friday's Gallup Poll in the Daily Telegraph made Tony Blair's Labour look, more than ever before, like a government in the customary throes of mid-term.

More than six in 10 of us are no longer convinced that Labour is fulfilling its promise to be tough on crime and the cause of crime. More than seven in 10 decline to believe that the NHS is improving. Around the same numbers make the same judgment of public transport. Even on education, education, education, only 48% are happy with this government's performance against 44% who are not. The economy too - Gordon Brown's miracle - turns out to lack universal acclaim with respondents agreeing by a margin of 43% to 40% that the old stop-go cycle has yet to be conquered. And Mr Blair's familiar appeal to "trust me" no longer gets the response that it did - almost half of us no longer accept that this government has on balance been honest and trustworthy.

Some of these condemnations are just, others less so. Discontent with the NHS, which did so much to erode Labour's standing at the turn of the year, reflects the decision, taken in the hope of stamping this government at the outset with the hallmark of extreme economic rectitude, to stick with Conservative spending plans (plans which Ken Clarke, who devised them, would plainly have abandoned with his usual insouciance had circumstances demanded it). The early stages of devolution may be souring things too. That the Northern Ireland assembly folded so soon is unlikely to be scored against Labour, but the headlines on recent events in Scotland and Wales in newspapers hostile to devolution create the impression of a writhing, wrangling mess. That is unjust. Much of what has happened in Edinburgh and Cardiff is part of the growing-up process which all such institutions have to go through. The toppling of Alun Michael, especially, happened because Wales demanded real devolution, and not just cosmetic version. It was Downing Street's reluctance to let go of the leading strings, here as with the London mayoralty, which fomented the trouble.

There are other disappointments too: the retreat from past aspirations on freedom of information, the pathetic farce of the Wakeham "reform" of the Lords, the shelving of the commitment to a referendum on changing the electoral system. But these are the preoccupations of the political class. What is more unnerving for Labour is that people should doubt on the scale that Gallup suggests Labour's management of the economy. The Telegraph thinks the finding that the "stop-go" cycle has yet to be conquered is "puzzling". Not outside the south-east it isn't. There, as across much of manufacturing industry, the relentless rise of the pound, fuelled by a succession of interest rate rises, has old economics written all over it. We cannot run the economy in the interest of a single region, the governor of the Bank, Eddie George, insists on his travels to Scotland and the north-east or wherever the natives are turbulent. But that is just how it looks as you travel away from London. The overwhelming objective of the policy is to stifle a boom which has hardly been felt in large swathes of the country. Of course there is boom and bust: but it's the south-east's boom, and their bust.

And yet this unpopular government is not an unpopular government. Some 49% would vote for it in a general election tomorrow - a phenomenal figure for any government in mid-term. The explanation is plain. The electorate this St Valentine's Day may be cooling in its ardour for Labour but it is certainly not succumbing to the suitor next door. People may be less than content with Labour's economic management, but Labour still has a 23-point lead as the party best equipped to handle economic difficulties. The nation's esteem for Tony Blair may be edging downwards, but he is still streets ahead of his rivals; 54% rate him the best of the bunch against 14% for William Hague and 11% for Charles Kennedy. As the Telegraph's Gallup analyst, Professor Tony King, unchallengeably concludes: "a well-respected opposition party would probably be making sweeping gains at Labour's expense."

There is a further factor at work which no examination of the state of our politics can now afford to exclude. The fastest growing group in the British electorate over the past three decades has been the non-voters. In 1997, just 31% of the qualified electorate gave Labour its triumph; almost 29% did not vote at all. Just 22% backed the Tories. Parliamentary byelections and last year's Euro-elections have told a similar story. This year's local elections could see very low turn-outs, with Labour, if its supporters have the least motivation, losing many seats by default. Like Conservative councillors dumped in the Thatcher years, many Labour stalwarts will feel their careers have been terminated more because of the national leadership than because of themselves.

Mr Blair needs to take all this seriously, for two reasons. First, because he still needs his party, even though on this St Valentine's Day it feels gravely unloved by him, and in turn loves him less than it loved some past leaders who steered it far less successfully. Second, and still more important, because a society switched off from politics, increasingly of the view that politics is a minority sport which makes little difference to people's everyday lives, is an ailing, alienated society, and one which a Labour prime minister especially should feel anxious to plug back in before the malaise goes deeper.

fields.headline: Other men's shoes
fields.standfirst:
A peace process which needs Sinn Fein
North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Suppose that it had not been David Trimble's political future at stake at the weekend, but Gerry Adams? Suppose that Mr Adams and Martin McGuinness felt they no longer had the support of the communities they were supposed to represent and stepped down. What then?
fields.body:
Suppose that it had not been David Trimble's political future at stake at the weekend, but Gerry Adams? Suppose that Mr Adams and Martin McGuinness felt they no longer had the support of the communities they were supposed to represent and stepped down. What then?

The champagne might have been uncorked in the offices of the Daily Telegraph, which delights in printing the words "peace process" in inverted commas lest its readers misunderstand the editor's fastidious disbelief in the concept. But there would have been precious little celebration elsewhere. Not in the office of David Trimble, certainly. Not in Stormont, Dublin, Westminster or Washington. For without Messrs Adams and McGuinness there is no effective leadership capable of coaxing the wilder outreaches of Irish republicanism into the democratic fold. Without Messrs Adams and McGuinness it is difficult to see how there could be a peace process, inverted commas or no inverted commas. So it was alarming last week to witness the exhaustion in Mr Adams's voice as he wondered how long he could go on being the "messenger who continually gets shot". There may, to be sure, have been an element of calculation in his timing. But long-standing observers of the Sinn Fein leader could not remember him previously admitting his vulnerability so publicly.

His frustration needs to be understood. The "message" for which he continually gets shot is that it is not within his power to deliver decommissioning to a timetable which - in republican eyes - is designed to bolster David Trimble's standing (or, at times, survival) within the Ulster Unionist Party. In this view Sinn Fein has stuck by the letter of the Good Friday agreement and considers May, not mid-February, to be the relevant date for demonstrating a credible and concrete commitment to decommission.

Mr Mandelson must now show an equal understanding of the difficulties the Sinn Fein leader will now have in advocating a political path where "normal" politics has been suspended.

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Gardener is in love with his new computer. He is in thrall to its fractals. For hours on end he glares at the swirling screen. Day turns into night, still he stares on. In the early hours he staggers to bed, rising red-eyed soon after dawn to return to the beloved machine and discover more of its charms.
fields.body:
Fractal friction

Gardener is in love with his new computer. He is in thrall to its fractals. For hours on end he glares at the swirling screen. Day turns into night, still he stares on. In the early hours he staggers to bed, rising red-eyed soon after dawn to return to the beloved machine and discover more of its charms.

"Come and look!" he used to cry. "You must look at this one." But after the millionth wibbly pattern, interest waned and the rest of the household grew sullen. Now only the dog sometimes sidles into Gardener's room, to chew up the odd pencil or long-forgotten snack. Gardener doesn't notice. He cannot hear the bumbling, crunching dog. He has his earphones on and is safely insulated, jerking about in his seat and calling out bits of song to himself. And now he has a new crush - random dot stereograms of fractal images. He is in heaven. He prints them out on his fabulous new colour printer and runs down to the normal world in the kitchen, waving sheets of pattern.

"Look, look!", he cries, full of hope again. "Just stare at that point and that point and bring them together!" But no one wants to. "So passé," says Daughter, gliding out of the room, but Gardener is not crushed. All around him people are gritting their teeth, sticking their noses in the air, running away or screaming, but he seems not to notice. He is in another world of swirling patterns, where there is no bedtime or dull routine, or life as we know it.

The trouble is that as Gardener stumbles about in the night, he often wakes the dog, who wants to play, and pounces about the bedroom savaging its chewy, which wakes me up, which makes me want to smash Gardener's new computer to pulp and long for the return of his old Amstrad that only did words.

Sometimes there is a tiny gap in the fractal life and Gardener comes down to the kitchen for an odd meal of unrelated bits - bananas and herring, or a complex chocolate sauce - and talks like he used to do.

"I wonder where you buy nice kitchen worktops," I say. Gardener's eyes glint, he springs up, "I'll look it up on the internet," says he, quick as a flash. "NO, NO!" Too late. Lost again.

fields.headline: Britain's guilt on Iraq bombing
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The Bishop of Coventry yesterday said that Britain had to accept responsibility for the death and deformity of children in Iraq as a result of allied bombing during and since the Gulf war.
fields.body:
The Bishop of Coventry yesterday said that Britain had to accept responsibility for the death and deformity of children in Iraq as a result of allied bombing during and since the Gulf war.

Preaching a sermon in German in Dresden at a ceremony to mark the 55th anniversary of the bombing of the city in the second world war, the Right Rev Colin Bennetts spoke of Britain's collective sorrow for the attack.

The commemoration, televised live in Germany, was attended by the Duke of Kent, by a delegation from Coventry, heavily bombed in 1940, and by senior German government figures.

It culminated in the presentation of a large gilt cross and orb for the pinnacle of the city's baroque Frauenkirche which was badly damaged in the raid.

While criticising Saddam Hussein for doing "evil things" to his people, the bishop, who led a delegation to Iraq last year, attacked allied raids on the country. "It is the memory of some of the children that remains with me. These children were conceived and born around the time of the Gulf war.

"They were born with hideous physical deformities. Many are also suffering from infantile leukaemia. There is very strong evidence to suggest that all this was caused by the depleted uranium in our weapons."

fields.headline: Excluded pupils 'never return'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than a third of children excluded from primary schools and two thirds expelled from secondaries never return to mainstream education, according to research published today by Include, a charity campaigning for reintegration of excluded children.
fields.body:
More than a third of children excluded from primary schools and two thirds expelled from secondaries never return to mainstream education, according to research published today by Include, a charity campaigning for reintegration of excluded children.

The charity is concerned about the future of such children, who spend most of the rest of their education either in special schools or dedicated units, or being taught at home. It is calling on the government to collect detailed data on what happens to excluded children, and for there to be closer working relationships between schools and social services.

Carl Parsons, of Canterbury Christ Church university college, has analysed official statistics for the 1997-98 academic year, when 12,298 pupils were permanently excluded - some 1,500 being primary school pupils, of whom 400 were under seven. In primary schools 62% of those permanently excluded from a school later found their way back to mainstream education, and in secondary schools it was 31%.

Of those who did return, 51% aged under seven were out for more than one term while a new school was found to take them, and 20% missed more than two terms. The findings also show a disproportionate number of excluded children had special educational needs, and also relatively high numbers of black and ethnic minority children.

In a parallel move today, the government will announce the first funding for ethnic minority pupils attending community "supplementary schools". The schools minister, Jacqui Smith, will detail a £1m package to link these schools to mainstream education.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Man held over hospital killing
A 33-year-old male nurse was last night being questioned by detectives after a health worker was stabbed to death in front of patients on a hospital ward.
fields.body:
Man held over hospital killing
A 33-year-old male nurse was last night being questioned by detectives after a health worker was stabbed to death in front of patients on a hospital ward.

Lee Field, a 34-year-old care assistant of Mottingham, south-east London, died after being attacked on the orthopaedic ward of Bromley hospital in Kent.

Drama boss dies at 74
Actor Bernard Price, one of London's leading drama school administrators, has died of cancer, aged 74.

Price, who was a straight man for comedians such as Tony Hancock and Tommy Trinder, died at St Thomas' hospital, London, on Friday. He converted the New Era Academy of Drama and Music into one of the country's most prestigious drama schools.

Price doubts halt car sales
More than two in three car buyers are holding off from buying a new vehicle as they expect prices to drop significantly, according to an insurance company survey. More than half (58%) believe prices will fall, while 54% think they could save up to £3,000 on their next model.

Millennium bug failures The millennium bug caused reports of 100 "significant" systems failures across the world in January, research showed yesterday. Problems ranged from failures in nuclear power plants and the US nuclear arsenal to glitches making it difficult to download music over the Internet. Most incidents were dealt with quickly.

Georgie Fame charged
Sixties singing star Georgie Fame has been arrested and charged with drink-driving, police said yesterday. The 56-year-old musician, who lives in Wincanton, Somerset, failed a breath test after being stopped by officers in Carmarthen, south Wales, on Saturday night. He was bailed to appear in court on February 24.

Eight win lottery Eight ticket holders shared last night's £6,073,920 National Lottery jackpot, each winning £759,240, Camelot said. The winning numbers were 4, 6, 12, 17, 18, and 19, bonus 37.

Six tickets each won last night's £250,000 top Thunderball prize. Numbers were 7, 11, 18, 25, and 33; Thunderball was 3.

webTitle: Terrace clue to Arthur's round table

fields.headline: Terrace clue to Arthur's round table
fields.trailText: King Arthur's round table is not to be found in a West Country castle but behind a terraced house in Scotland, a historical researcher said yesterday.
fields.body:
King Arthur's round table is not to be found in a West Country castle but behind a terraced house in Scotland, a historical researcher said yesterday.

The meeting place of knights may be buried in a back garden in Adam Crescent, Stenhousemuir, Stirlingshire, according to Archie McKerracher, a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland.

Mr McKerracher said Arthur's meeting place was a round hut in one of the furthest-flung points of his ancient kingdom. And the round table may not have been a table at all - but a beehive-shaped stone hut.

It was believed to occupy a site now marked on an Ordnance Survey map as being in the back garden of the house in Adam Crescent.

webTitle: 750,000 homes lie empty as prices soar

fields.headline: 750,000 homes lie empty as prices soar
fields.standfirst: Blame put on private sector cashing in on property boom
fields.trailText: Charities for the homeless yesterday called for stronger government measures to deal with the growing number of empty houses in England, after figures showed that more than 750,000 properties were unoccupied.
fields.body:
Charities for the homeless yesterday called for stronger government measures to deal with the growing number of empty houses in England, after figures showed that more than 750,000 properties were unoccupied.

Returns by councils to the department of the environment show a rise of 11,500 in a year, the first increase since the recession of the early 1990s, with vacant private houses giving greatest cause for concern.

The returns demolish the misconception that the main cause of vacant property is council houses on bleak northern estates, abandoned as people move south in search of work.

The rising number of empty private homes, now 637,000, ranges from old Lancastrian terraces, and newer semis near problem estates, to boarded up, structurally sound properties in London. Councils and housing associations have 112,000 empty homes, with government departments such as the ministry of defence - accounting for the remainder of the 750,000.

The Empty Homes Agency, a charity partly funded by the department of the environment, yesterday accused the government of complacency. "It has a responsibility to take action and introduce tough policies to help councils, and others, tackle this blight," said its chief executive, Ashley Horsey. "Questions have to be asked why, at a time of housing boom, the number of private homes standing empty has increased."

The agency wanted ministers to give councils discretionary powers to charge owners of long-term empty properties the full rate of council tax - a recommendation made by the government's own urban task force, chaired by the architect, Lord Rogers of Riverside.

The agency believed that the threat to end the current 50% discount would persuade many to either sell or refurbish vacant houses so they were fit to let. If owners failed to co-operate, the agency believed that stiffer penalties should be introduced, such as a "premium"' council tax rate.

London councils, and the agency, also believe that speculators are taking advantage of the capital's property boom by sitting on empty houses in the hope of making a killing in a rising market. Around a third of London's 113,000 empty homes have been vacant more than a year, and the number is steadily rising. Significantly, the capital has a record 40,000 homeless families in temporary accommodation. "Investors seem to be looking at capital appreciation and hanging on to empty houses until they judge the market to be right so they can dispose of them - making a big profit without the need for either improving or renting," said John Bownas, empty property officer for the south London borough of Croydon, which is taking a particularly tough line against some property companies.

Croydon recently imposed a compulsory purchase order on a company that owned seven houses in one street in South Norwood, each of which had been empty for up to seven years. The council planned to sell the houses to people willing to do them up. In the end, Mr Bownas said, the council contacted shareholders and forced a change in the management of the company, the Investors Property Corporation. As a result, the homes were being modernised.

Michael Blacker, a structural engineer who now helps run the company, accepted that the houses were in a terrible state. "One had a tree growing through the roof. I could not believe how many had gone to rack and ruin." He said many Victorian houses in London were in poor repair. "When owners look at the cost of putting things right, they shy away and wait until someone offers a good deal."

Away from London, the Empty Homes Agency said that 500,000 abandoned, private houses were an eyesore in many cities and towns, but pointed out that there were just as many redundant commercial buildings that could be converted into good homes.

In Kings Lynn, Norfolk, the council has taken out a special planning enforcement order against the owner of a four-storey hotel, opposite the station and in a conservation area, to make it improve a property empty for eight years by converting the Victorian building into flats. Other councils, however, were accused by the agency of ignoring problems on their doorstep. It argued that the government should force all town halls to have an empty property strategy, which would set targets for bringing vacant homes back into use.
