webTitle: Straw tops inquiry list as leaks mount

fields.headline: Straw tops inquiry list as leaks mount
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has ordered more leak inquiries than any other minister, according to figures released by Whitehall at the end of last year.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has ordered more leak inquiries than any other minister, according to figures released by Whitehall at the end of last year.

The figures suggest that either the home secretary is more keen than any other minister to hold inquiries into leaked information or he is presiding over the most leaky ministry in Whitehall.

The list - released after a request by the Guardian under John Major's "open government" code - shows that Labour has had almost as many serious leaks from Whitehall as the last two years of the Tory government.

So far there have been 60 leak investigations compared to 70 in the last two years of John Major's administration.

Jack Straw tops the list with nine investigations. These include an inconclusive inquiry into the premature disclosure of the findings of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry to the Sunday Telegraph, and the Guardian's disclosure of Mr Straw's minute to the cabinet detailing his climbdown over some of the more draconian proposals in the freedom of information bill.

The health department and Northern Ireland office are joint runners-up with leaks. Successive health secretaries, Frank Dobson as well as Alan Milburn, had seven leak investigations since 1997.

These include inquiries into leaked information from the NHS executive. The Northern Ireland leaks, under Mo Mowlam and Peter Mandelson, concerned peace keeping and security.

The department of social security and the ministry of defence hold third place - with five inquiries each.

The department of environment, transport and the regions and the cabinet office have had four leak inquiries each - suggesting that the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is either very relaxed or has his giant ministry sown up. One of the cabinet office's leaks involved the disclosure of David Clark's first-class air trip to Australia and New Zealand as part of fact finding tour into freedom of information legislation.

The ministries with the smallest number of leaks are the foreign office, the Scottish office, the office of fair trading and the department of education and employment, which have one leak inquiry each.

The most leak-free is the Welsh office which either has no worthwhile secrets or has had no need to order any inquiries since Tony Blair came to power.

The government refuses to comment on the subject or outcome of leak inquiries - and would not even release this information to MPs.

At the time of complying with the Guardian request Tony Blair released the same information to Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes. Downing Street said this was a coincidence.

The league of leaks - leak inquiries since May 1997 for government departments

Home office 9

Health 7

Northern Ireland 7

Social security 5

Defence 5

Cabinet office 4

Transport, environment and the regions 4

Trade and industry 3

Crown prosecution service 3

Customs and excise 3

Maff 2

Directorate of civil nuclear security 2

Lord chancellor's dept 2

Office of fair trading 1

Foreign office 1

Education and employment 1

Scottish office 1

fields.headline: Scots rights move for gays
fields.trailText: Homosexual relationships could be given the same legal status as marriage in Scotland under legislation which is already being condemned by family values campaigners.
fields.body:
Homosexual relationships could be given the same legal status as marriage in Scotland under legislation which is already being condemned by family values campaigners.

Scottish ministers are coming under pressure from a parliamentary committee to amend forthcoming legislation with a clause which would, for the first time in Britain, enshrine the equal status of same-sex relationships on statute.

The issue has arisen from the incapable adults bill, which grants rights to the nearest relatives of someone who becomes incapable of making significant decisions for themselves. Currently, the law overlooks same sex partners in favour of parents or brothers and sisters.

Jim Wallace, the justice minister, said last year that he intended to end this type of discrimination.

Yesterday the Conservatives said they would not support Mr Wallace if the bill made same-sex relationships equal to marriage.

The party's home affairs spokesman, Phil Gallie, said: "Marriage is a contract between two people, drawn up to offer security and also to protect children, and, on that basis, gay relationships can never be seen to be on an equal footing."

Officials and ministers initially drew up a definition which would give same-sex couples who had been living together for at least six months the same status as unmarried heterosexual couples.

But MSPs said that was unfair towards same-sex couples, and the parliament's equal opportunities committee has made it clear that it will not allow the legislation to be discriminatory.

Officials will this week attempt to come up with a new definition which will meet the concerns of the committee. If it does not, the committee intends to make sure that the issue goes before the full parliament for debate.

webTitle: Oasis stand on top of charts again

fields.headline: Oasis stand on top of charts again
fields.trailText: Oasis bounced back after a two-year break by claiming their fifth number one hit single yesterday. Fans flocked into stores throughout the week helping Go Let It Out, the first taste of their fourth album, Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants, to oust Gabrielle.
fields.body:
Oasis bounced back after a two-year break by claiming their fifth number one hit single yesterday. Fans flocked into stores throughout the week helping Go Let It Out, the first taste of their fourth album, Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants, to oust Gabrielle.

But the guitarist and mastermind behind the band, Noel Gallagher, was indifferent to the success. "I've never really bothered about chart positions, we've had a few number twos as well. It's never really mattered in the first place. What matters is that we're happy with the songs and they get through to people."

The track sold well from the moment it hit the record racks last Monday. Many stores opened early to cope with the expected clamour of fans.

One, the HMV shop in Dundee, had not even planned its 8am start, but the crowd queuing outside prompted staff to open the doors anyway.

By midweek Oasis had sold 114,000 copies, compared with Gabrielle's Rise which had achieved sales of just 34,000. In fact, Oasis had sold almost as many copies as the rest of the top eight put together. The band was last at number one with All Around The World in January 1998, before taking a break from recording.

webTitle: Gift protest over Briton in Burma jail

fields.headline: Gift protest over Briton in Burma jail
fields.trailText: The parents of a British pro-democracy activist sentenced to 17 years in a Burmese prison will today mark his 27th birthday by delivering a gift-wrapped bamboo cage and a letter of protest to the Burmese embassy in London.
fields.body:
The parents of a British pro-democracy activist sentenced to 17 years in a Burmese prison will today mark his 27th birthday by delivering a gift-wrapped bamboo cage and a letter of protest to the Burmese embassy in London.

James Mawdsley was arrested last August for distributing anti-government literature and entering Burma illegally. He has been kept in solitary confinement in Kengtung prison, 400 miles north-east of the capital, Rangoon.

The cage, with a banner calling for an end to the genocide against ethnic minorities by the Burmese junta, will be presented to the embassy by David and Diana Mawdsley, who will also hand in a letter calling for the Burmese government to respect human rights.

The letter, signed by Lord Alton, David Amess, Tory MP for Southend West, and the Bishop of Liverpool, the Right Rev James Jones, calls for the international community to act to end the "barbaric" genocide of the junta, believed to have murdered more than 30,000 Karen people.

The Jubilee Campaign, the Christian pressure group which is backing the Mawdsleys, has also sent 5,000 alternative Valentine's Day cards to, among others, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, to alert them to the fate of ethnic minorities in Burma.

webTitle: Body parts thief displays his art

fields.headline: Body parts thief displays his art
fields.standfirst: Cast of human head used for London show
fields.trailText: A sculptor who was jailed for stealing body parts is now exhibiting some of his controversial works that were seized by police.
fields.body:
A sculptor who was jailed for stealing body parts is now exhibiting some of his controversial works that were seized by police.

Anthony-Noel Kelly, 43, from south London, was jailed in 1998 after he was convicted of stealing human body parts, which he used to make moulds for his sculptures.

A legal technicality enabled him to reclaim the confiscated items from the police, including a bronze cast of a human head and a large photograph of 36 human teeth, which are now on display at a gallery in the capital. They form part of an exhibition at the Anne Faggionato gallery in central London, entitled Psycho/Art and Anatomy.

"The head and the teeth were returned to me on a legal technicality after the police basically raped my studio," Kelly said. "I had to go up to Scotland Yard to collect them. I am delighted to have them back."

Kelly, a former butcher and abattoir worker who is a cousin of the Duke of Norfolk, described his work as being very optimistic.

He added: "Dead things are not morbid to my mind because they become something that is quite abstract.

"But I realise that it is only my opinion and other people can be upset by them. If you open up a red pepper you can get similar colour schemes to the human body."

He said the aim of the exhibition was to look at anatomy in a historical context. Before his arrest, his detractors described his work as abhorrent.

The thefts began after Kelly received permission to sketch dismembered body parts held at the Royal College of Surgeons in London. Kelly paid Niel Lindsay, a trainee lab technician whom he befriended, to smuggle body parts out of the college in plastic bin bags. Kelly later buried some of the remains in the grounds of his ancestral home near Ashford, Kent.

Police discovered a human torso, two severed heads and various limbs when they dug up the area in Kent. Various other body parts were discovered in the basement of a flat belonging to an unsuspecting friend of Kelly.

fields.headline: 200ft crane fall kills student
fields.trailText: An Oxford university student plunged 200 feet to his death after climbing to the top of a crane in the city centre.
fields.body:
An Oxford university student plunged 200 feet to his death after climbing to the top of a crane in the city centre.

The man, aged 22, had managed to inch his way to the end of the jib before falling.

Police were called 15 hours before the body was found, after a passer-by heard someone shouting from the top of the crane just after midnight on Saturday morning.

Officers could not hear or see anybody on the crane and went away - unaware that the young man was lying dead just yards from them.

The alarm was raised on Saturday afternoon, when a resident spotted the body in a garden in Rectory Road.

Detective Chief Inspector George Turner said that the death appeared to be an accident.

"It appears that the young man had fallen from the end of the crane jib, which was about 200ft high and overhanging the neighbouring gardens.

"The man had suffered multiple injuries despite his fall being broken by a tree."

It appeared that he had been out drinking on Friday night with a group of other students. He had climbed over a fence on to a building site.

"He climbed the crane and was shouting from the top. At that stage it appears, his friends left him." His body was identified by a fellow student. He has not yet been named but his parents live in the west country.

"We are fairly sure that this man's death was an accident. It is too early to speculate on what led to him climb the crane."

fields.headline: Romance in brief
fields.body:
 A Chelsea fan making his first visit to the team's London ground was proposed to yesterday in front of a crowd of 30,000. Amanda Kirk, 22, popped the question on Stamford Bridge's giant scoreboard.

"I just could not believe it," said Michael Evans, 30. "I had no idea I was coming to the game until we arrived in London from South Wales. Then when the announcement came at half time, I was just amazed. Of course I said yes." Miss Kirk said she had used her prerogative of proposing in a leap year .

 While the sexual revolution may have made us explicit, lovers today use names of characters from children's books and TV as endearments. Julie Cole man, of Leicester university's English department, says we prefer to use words that disguise our emotions.

Her study, Love, Sex and Marriage, A Historical Thesaurus, found a changing use of different terms with different connotations.

"The 20th century emphases the link between sex and procreation, while the 19th century produces a limited selection of terms indicating sex is pleasurable. Terms implying sex represents joining or commitment are characteristic of the Anglo-Saxon period."

The day for choosing a sweetheart is said to date from 1381 and was believed to be the day on which birds chose their mates for the year, although the term Valentine card was first recorded in 1959.

 Almost a 10th of under-25s had negative feelings towards Valentine's Day in a survey, the Samaritans said yesterday when launching a campaign to help young people be more open about their feelings. It is being supported by Emmerdale star Adele Silva, whose character, Kelly, attempted suicide.

The charity said: "We urge people not to bottle up relationship problems on Valentine's Day but talk to a friend or perhaps a Samaritan if they're in crisis."

 Some 250,000 men and women used their local paper to send Valentine's Day messages, according to the Newspaper Society.

Almost 500,000 have placed or responded to a personal ad in their local paper this year, and more than 155,000 confessed to browsing the dating pages every time they read their local paper.

 Only 40 couples turned up yesterday for an attempt, cheered on by TV star Anthea Turner, to beat the world record for the most people kissing in the same place at the same time. The Variety Club event in London was 1,504 couples short.

A club spokesman said: "Okay, we didn't beat the record - but that didn't stop everyone having a jolly good snog."

webTitle: Police given five-year target to cut burglaries, car thefts

fields.headline: Police given five-year target to cut burglaries, car thefts
fields.trailText: Police forces around the country will today be set individual five-year targets to slash burglary and car crime under a government drive to bring down wide regional variations in crime levels.
fields.body:
Police forces around the country will today be set individual five-year targets to slash burglary and car crime under a government drive to bring down wide regional variations in crime levels.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, will announce that, if targets are met, domestic burglary will fall by a quarter by 2005 while car crime will drop by 30%.

The new goals, which also include a 17% cut in robberies, follow last month's figures showing that crime is rising for the first time since 1992.

This is the first time individual forces, and even their component command units, have been given goals reflecting their performance, rather being asked to work towards a national average crime reduction.

Ministers are anxious to put an end to wide variations in crime levels within and between regions when other circumstances such as population and poverty levels are comparable.

The new effort to make those forces with the worst track records work hardest to do better is based on a similar approach used in school improvement.

There, schools are matched against those in similar catchment areas to identify good and bad performance.

A Downing Street source said last night: "What we can't understand is why there are such variations between units in virtually identical areas. The aim is to get the standard equal to the best in the country."

Details of the new targets will be given by Mr Straw during a visit with the prime minister to Newham, east London, where they will view a new closed circuit television system.

The home secretary will say that the latest crime figures revealed "patchy" performances between and within forces.

He will add: "We can and must do better. These targets are ambitious but achievable - they will give a real focus to our fight against crime.

"The criminal justice system has a way to go to match the strides that have been taken in other public services like health and education in monitoring and improving performance." Domestic burglary and car crime have been chosen as the headline target areas because they are the crimes which, according to surveys, most concern the public.

Individual police authorities have been asked to propose their own targets - to be published as provisional goals today - but these then go to the home secretary for review and can be raised if considered insufficiently ambitious.

Final fixed targets will be published in April with the toughest expected to be for forces in the cities, where 70% of crimes occur.

Five forces in big metropolitan areas have been told to produce targets to cut robberies. Seventy per cent of robberies take place in London, West Yorkshire, Merseyside, the West Midlands and Greater Manchester.

Last year there were 1,720,241 car thefts, 74,843 robberies or muggings and 935,423 burglaries.

webTitle: Boy, 11, killed as rally car hits spectators

fields.headline: Boy, 11, killed as rally car hits spectators
fields.trailText: A boy aged 11 was killed and his young cousin critically injured yesterday when a rally car driven by a novice skidded off a country lane and somersaulted into spectators.
fields.body:
A boy aged 11 was killed and his young cousin critically injured yesterday when a rally car driven by a novice skidded off a country lane and somersaulted into spectators.

The father and grandfather of one of the boys were also seriously hurt when the family group took the impact on a right-angle bend in the cross-country course at Otterburn army ranges in Northumberland.

The surviving child, seven, was taken to Newcastle upon Tyne general infirmary unconscious with head injuries and a fractured femur, while paramedics tried vainly to revive his cousin.

Three other spectators, among only a handful on the verge of the narrow road as rally cars sped by, are in hospital with less serious injuries and shock.

The victims were hit by a Vauxhall Nova, driven by one of the last of 69 amateur competitors in Wickham motorclub's annual Apex Cheviot event. It veered into gravel at about 50mph, took off and landed on the group.

The driver, a Tyneside man in his 20s who had never competed in a rally before, was discharged from Hexham general hospital last night with his navigator after both had been treated for minor injuries and severe shock.

Both the children had to be cut free from the wreckage.

One of the two older family victims, unconscious with severe head injuries and breathing difficulties, was flown to Newcastle by an RAF helicopter. The other, with a ruptured spleen, was taken to the city by ambulance.

The accident was at Bennets Field, on the army's tank and self-propelled gun ranges north-west of Newcastle. The rally has long been a highlight of the northern motorsport calendar.

A witness said: "The driver just lost it; the car spun out of control, shot up in the air and landed on the two young lads."

Another driver, Ashley Reid, 34, from Aberdeen, who had dropped out of the tarmac stage of the rally to fetch spares from Otterburn, said: "It was an appalling, unbelievably tragic freak accident.

"In these things no one is really to blame. I can only guess how [the driver] must be feeling now."

The tragedy was made worse by the fact that spectators were thin on the ground on the moorland stretch of the rally, where Cheviot competitors can reach 80 or even 100mph on straights but have to brake suddenly for sharp bends and hidden hill crests. The victims were standing in a knot exactly where the white Nova lost control and flew off the road.

Along with the nearby Kielder forest, which is used for rallies and husky sledge-driving races, Otterburn is one of England's largest wildernesses and is a favourite with extreme sports enthusiasts.

Mr Reid said: "It's a bleak, unforgiving place where you can make no mistakes. The roads are narrow, the bends are tight and you have to watch for the crests. One unlucky bounce and you have a real problem."

Colin Wilson, spokesman for UK rallying's governing body, the Motor Sports Association, said last night that "every stringent measure that can be taken is taken" to keep spectators away from competitors.

"If a marshal spots people who are in a dangerous position, he asks them to move. If they refuse, then the stage will simply not be run. Similarly, if the course car spots people in danger, the race is also stopped."

fields.headline: Thinktank calls for £1,000 baby gifts
fields.standfirst:
Cash pot from government could be spent on education

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Every child should be given £1,000 at birth by the government to set up an investment pot to draw on in later life, a leading Blairite thinktank suggests today.
fields.body:
Every child should be given £1,000 at birth by the government to set up an investment pot to draw on in later life, a leading Blairite thinktank suggests today.

The "baby bond", which could be spent on education, training, starting a business or buying a house, would be designed to counter growing inequality in asset ownership.

But the idea put forward by the institute for public policy research, which is regarded as close to the government, is likely to alarm Labour traditionalists seeking higher spending on public services and social security benefits.

There will be further concern at the institute's admission that it wants to see the centre-left create "a new politics of private ownership".

In a report, Ownership for All, researchers say: "Progressive politics needs to become less preoccupied with the structure of ownership of organisations and more concerned about the opportunities that individuals have to own assets."

Inequality of asset ownership has not been identified by the government as an indicator of social exclusion, although ministers are committed to raising the proportion of the working population contributing to a non-state pension.

The report says too few people have assets, defined as savings accounts, a mortgage, shares or investments.

Between 1979 and 1996, the proportion of people without any assets doubled from 5% to 10% among the whole population and from 10% to 20% among young adults. Half the population has less than £500 savings.

Studies in the US have suggested that asset ownership is linked to better health and education, greater entrepeneurship and stronger marriage.

The report, by senior research fellow Gavin Kelly and researcher Rachel Lissauer, says Britain should build on the idea of "individual development accounts", being piloted in the US, whereby the state matches what an individual pays into a savings fund for a, socially useful purpose.

"Opportunity funds" could go one step further. The government would set up a fund for each child with a lump sum, starting at £1,000, and would then match any further, private investment in the fund according to a means-tested sliding scale.

For a family on very low income, the government would contribute a further £3 for every £1 invested from other sources. This ratio would taper down to a point where the level of income would disqualify the child from any matched investment.

To prevent abuse, payments from the fund - at age 18 or above - could be made direct to mortgage companies or universities, or made in the form of vouchers, or closely monitored in cases where the cash was being used for a business start-up.

A sum of £1,000 invested on behalf of a baby in 1981 would have been worth £3,500 to an 18-year-old last year, the report says.

The scheme would cost some £720m a year for the initial bonds, on present birth rates, plus whatever matched funding was triggered.

Mr Kelly said: "Opportunity funds have the potential to become one of those rare creatures in British public life - a policy which is both highly progressive and intrinsically populist."

webTitle: Nasa craft's close encounter with Eros

fields.headline: Nasa craft's close encounter with Eros
fields.trailText: The four-year Erotic obsession of a team of space scientists culminates in a Valentine's Day encounter on the approaches to Mars today with deep implications for the future of life on earth.
fields.body:
The four-year Erotic obsession of a team of space scientists culminates in a Valentine's Day encounter on the approaches to Mars today with deep implications for the future of life on earth.

If all goes to plan, a Nasa spacecraft will go into orbit around Eros, a shoe-shaped rock the size of Manchester - the first time a space probe will have orbited an asteroid.

Although Eros poses no threat to our planet now, it is typical of hundreds of near earth asteroids (NEAs) which, if they struck, would threaten the survival of civilization. The impact of an asteroid or comet half the size of Eros 65m years ago is thought to have wiped out the dinosaurs.

The information gleaned by Nasa's mission to Eros will be critical to possible preventive measures if one day astronomers calculate that an NEA is about to collide with the earth.

Since March 23 1989, when earth and a quarter-mile-wide asteroid missed a messy encounter by six hours, there have been regular scares. "It certainly is a concern," said Helen Worth of John Hopkins university's applied physics laboratory, which is running the project.

"When the mission was approved it wasn't that we were going to do it so that tomorrow we'd be able to deflect an asteroid. But the possibility of a major impact is one reason."

The Eros mission, known as Near, faced disaster in 1998 when the unmanned spacecraft's first attempt to go into Erotic orbit failed. It accelerated too fast, shot past the asteroid and for a nail-biting day went mute. Ingenious work by earthbound navigators put it back on course for a new rendezvous this month.

Eros is a curved, elongated chip of matter, airless and waterless, with a huge bite out of it on one side and a crater on the other. Its gravity is feeble. The Near spacecraft will orbit it for a year, surveying its physical and geological properties. Towards the end it will swoop to within a mile of the surface for close-up views.

Erotic gravity may be weak, but it is capricious, and the orbiter will have its work cut out to avoid crashing or being flung out of orbit as its begins its slow dance towards the asteroid.

"Monday's manoeuvre isn't terribly tricky, because it's going into orbit quite far out and going in at a very slow speed, of 22mph," said Ms Worth. "When it gets tricky is when it gets closer and closer."

Nasa's unmanned space exploration programme is in disarray and badly needs a morale boost. In three months three Mars missions have failed: the climate orbiter, the polar lander and Deep Space 2.

On Friday the US Planetary Society is host to an anguished forum, open to Internet participants, asking where space exploration goes now. By then the fate of the NEAR orbiter's first wooing of Eros will be known. "We're hoping to redeem the name of space science," said Ms Worth.

fields.headline: Police warn harasser of Beckhams
fields.trailText: A woman obsessed with David and Victoria Beckham has received a formal police warning after the couple lodged a complaint about her behaviour.
fields.body:
A woman obsessed with David and Victoria Beckham has received a formal police warning after the couple lodged a complaint about her behaviour.

Cheshire police have confirmed that a woman was spoken to after the Manchester United footballer and the Spice Girls singer reported they were being harassed.

It is alleged that she had been plaguing the Beckhams for several weeks, leaving letters and gifts outside their home in Alderley Edge, Cheshire.

A Cheshire police spokesperson said: "The police at Wilmslow are investigating an allegation of harassment made by David Beckham at his Alderley Edge home address. The police have spoken to and formally warned a 36-year-old woman in relation to this allegation."

Although inquiries were said to be ongoing, the nature of the allegation remains unclear. The woman has not been arrested or charged.

Beckham's agents, SFX Sports Group, last night refused to comment on the matter.

The warning to the woman follows two incidents within three months. In January it was claimed Scotland Yard had prevented an alleged £1m plot to kidnap Mrs Beckham, and her son, Brooklyn. Last December while shopping in central London, Mrs Beckham knocked a man to the ground when he tried to grab hold of her son.

fields.headline: Cracking fertility's ethics code
fields.standfirst: Embryology expert talks of her concerns about 'procreative tourism' and changes in law
fields.trailText: Britain's careful regulation of fertility treatment is the envy of the world, but "procreative tourism" is challenging the UK's autonomy even before human rights legislation comes into force in October, according to Ruth Deech, head of the human fertilisation and embryology authority.
fields.body:
Britain's careful regulation of fertility treatment is the envy of the world, but "procreative tourism" is challenging the UK's autonomy even before human rights legislation comes into force in October, according to Ruth Deech, head of the human fertilisation and embryology authority.

Under European law, Britons are entitled to seek medical treatment anywhere in Europe if they cannot get it in their own country. People cannot necessarily get it on the NHS, but nor can they be prevented from having it by any ethical scruples of the public or the government.

So although the human fertilisation and embryology authority refused Diane Blood permission to be inseminated with her husband's sperm because it was obtained without his consent when he was unconscious, once she won her court battle to take his sperm abroad she was able to get the IVF treatment she craved in Belgium. Swedes travel abroad to obtain anonymous donor sperm, which is not permitted in their own country.

Differences

Mrs Deech points out that all the European countries have cultural and religious differences, "so if you can't get what you want in one country you can get it in another. And that attitude is feeding itself into the human rights law in the sense that we begin to feel that, if something is possible anywhere, you're being deprived of your human rights if you can't get it here," she said. Another Diane Blood would be able to argue her case for the use of her husband's sperm in Britain under the forthcoming human rights legislation.

Mrs Deech acknowledges that the Blood case was a difficult time for her. Public feeling, stoked by publicity from Max Clifford, was strongly behind Mrs Blood's desperate desire to have her dead husband's child. But she is convinced her 21-strong committee made the right decision.

"The question was not whether he consented - he never even knew it was being done to him. It's an absolutely basic principle of British law, European law, international law, human rights law - you don't carry out medical procedures on the dying or unconscious," she said.

"There is a grave danger that men's bodies are not treated with the same respect as women's. The danger is not just with the Blood case but with some other modern developments that men are treated simply as a bundle of useful tissues.

"I think we have a problem now not so much with respect for women's bodies - that particular aim I think has been won - but with respect to men's bodies - men's necessity. The danger for women is that they are treated only as beings who want babies at all costs. The danger for men is they are treated just as the source of the gamete and no more."

Cloning, to which Mrs Deech is firmly opposed, would take this further if it were permitted. Women could have babies without men. "Sperm is not necessary. It is the ultimate dispensibility of men," she said.

She cannot see it being allowed in the foreseeable future. It is unnecessary in her view and there is a danger cloned children would be regarded as freaks. Although there might be an argument under human rights legislation that a woman was entitled to produce a child in any way that she chose, the welfare of the child must also be considered.

To order

"What will happen to love if the child is produced to order in a particular way? Supposing it isn't quite right? Will you not love it because you intended it to have brown eyes and a musical disposition and in fact its music isn't up to scratch. It becomes a commodity, I suppose," she said.

Mrs Deech has both a child and a career. She is now principal of St Anne's college, Oxford. She is very conscious that her good fortune must not blind her to the distress of women who find they are infertile, but at the same time she worries that too many people assume that anybody can have a baby.

"While I understand that women get terribly unhappy if they are infertile, I think at the same time you have to try and say with empathy that every woman is a perfectly worthwhile whole person in her own right." She worries that women feel they must go on trying, distressing them selves with one IVF failure after another and spending many thousands of pounds when their chances of success are slim. "She must not have presented to her this notion that around the corner lies the miracle baby - and it's her fault that she has not taken the extra step.

"I suppose if someone had told you 50 years ago you couldn't have a baby you may have wept but you then had to get on with your life and it may be now that women are misled by stories into thinking that they must go on even though it's upsetting."

webTitle: Human rights test for fertility rules

fields.headline: Human rights test for fertility rules
fields.trailText: Human rights legislation which comes into force this autumn will lead to a spate of legal challenges by single women, older women, gay men and others who believe existing fertility rules have denied them the right to have a family, the chair of the human fertilisation and embryology authority has predicted.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, Lucy Ward  and Julia Hartley Brewer
fields.body:
Human rights legislation which comes into force this autumn will lead to a spate of legal challenges by single women, older women, gay men and others who believe existing fertility rules have denied them the right to have a family, the chair of the human fertilisation and embryology authority has predicted.

Home office sources last night acknowledged that the new human rights act could lead to string of test cases over fertility issues, as individuals opt to challenge the current rules in the courts.

In an interview with the Guardian, Ruth Deech, who has worked as an international lawyer, said: "I suspect that from October we're going to have a lot of interesting questions being raised about whether treatment can be refused to single women, to women of 60, to lesbian and gay couples, to widows, and whether sex selection for social reasons can be denied."

The human rights legislation which is being introduced from Europe was originally a response to the atrocities committed in Nazi Germany. "To make sure there was never again the forced sterilisation of men and women, it has got provisions like the right to private and family life; the right to marry and found a family. Those two rights are rooted in the horrors of the second world war - the prohibition of sexual relations between people of different races," Ms Deech said.

In modern Britain, however, those phrases are open to another interpretation - that no one who wants a child should be denied the chance to have one, regardless of sexual orientation, age or anything else.

"I think people will come forward and say, 'I want this; I have a right to private and family life, I have a right to marry and found a family.' The courts may reject the more far-fetched claims, but they may have to consider them," Ms Deech said.

"If a single woman were rejected for treatment by a clinic, she might say, 'I demand my human rights'. If a lesbian couple, perhaps, had a baby abroad or were rejected by a clinic here, they would challenge any refusal to treat them like a heterosexual couple, because there is a clause which says the rights and liberties in this act must be extended to people without discrimination as to status. I'm not saying that all the careful protection we have will crumble, but it seems to be likely that some very deep questions will be posed to the courts."

The human rights legislation is not supposed to override British statute but it will be for the courts to try to strike a balance. One of the conditions of a licence granted by the HFEA to a clinic to practise in vitro fertilisation is that "a woman shall not be provided with treatment unless account has been taken of the welfare of any child who may be born as a result (including the need of that child for a father), and of any other child who may be affected by the birth". But the meaning of that phrase is "terribly unclear," said Ms Deech

No category of woman is specifically excluded from treatment by the regulations, so in principle a single woman, older woman or lesbian couple can be treated. But the HFEA lays down specific factors to be considered by the doctor, including "their ability to provide a stable and supportive environment for any child produced as a result of treatment", and "their ages and likely future ability to provide for a child's needs".

Private clinics are just as bound as NHS clinics to take all these factors into consideration. But while some single women, gay women and older women have been treated in private clinics, such people have very little chance on the NHS, where budgets for IVF are tight. NHS clinics usually do not select people who are over 40, or even in their late 30s, and who are not part of a stable heterosexual couple.

A source close to Jack Straw, the home secretary, said that ministers had always anticipated that the new act would have implications for all departments, and stressed that all new policy was "tested" to ensure that it was consistent with the European convention on human rights. However, he said it would be up to the courts to decide on cases in which new rights established under the human rights act appeared to clash with UK rules on fertility. "The act will obviously result in a lot of test cases," he said, but "the nature and the beauty of the convention is that it is about balancing rights".

Baroness Warnock, who chaired the 1984 committee of inquiry into human fertilisation and embryology, and is an adviser on medical ethics to the archbishop of Canterbury, described the law as "a real can of worms".

"It never seemed to me the right to a family enshrined in European law had any reference to single people, post-menopausal women or homosexual couples," she said. "It seems to me to be very risky to interpret the law in that way."

Diane Blood, who won the right to be artificially inseminated with her dead husband's sperm, and gave birth to her son in December 1998 after a four year legal battle, said: "As far as my understanding of the law goes, people already have those rights but they have to go to Strasbourg to get them enforced. This is just bringing the right within the domestic law, instead of them having to fight an expensive legal battle."

Peter Tatchell, of the gay rights campaign group Outrage!, said: "All the unjustified restrictions will have to be abolished. It's good that these previously overlooked issues are now to be acknowledged by European jurisprudence."

webTitle: How true love has survived - for more than 500 years

fields.headline: How true love has survived - for more than 500 years
fields.trailText: Some things never change. In 1477 Medieval Man was just as slippery as today's New Man, particularly when it came to the c-word - commitment.
fields.body:
Some things never change. In 1477 Medieval Man was just as slippery as today's New Man, particularly when it came to the c-word - commitment.

So on February 14, 523 years ago, when Margery Brews, a forthright lady of the Fens, wrote the oldest surviving valentine in the world, she used the full range of womanly wiles. First she flattered her true love, then she appealed to his chivalry. Then, with his guard lowered, she followed through with good old fashioned emotional blackmail.

John Paston, you see, was a mite reluctant. And his father, a goodly Norfolk squire, was not overly impressed with the size of her dowry.

"But if you love me," implored Margery, "as I trust verily that you do, you will not leave me therefore. For even if you had not half the livelihood that you have, for to do the greatest labour that any woman alive might, I would not forsake you. "

The message was clear: marry me, you cad.

Keen to cover herself, if the valentine should fail, Margery signed off: "And I beseech you that this bill be not seen by any non earthly creature, save only yourself."

John kept the note, showed it to his folks, and it will be on display at the British Library next month in an exhibition called Chapter & Verse.

Margery eventually got her man, said the curator, Chris Fletcher. "They even had two sons. It's a fascinating story, a marvellous insight into the way love and marriage was contracted in the Middle Ages."

For not only was John's father a bit snooty about Margery, his big brother (also called John) tried to put a spanner in the works. "He was jealous, infuriated in fact, that his mother had given a manor house to his brother to make him a more attractive prospect to Margery," said Mr Fletcher.

The older John died horribly the following year of plague - a salutary warning to anyone who might interfere in the course of true love.

A reluctant bridegroom he might have been, but John Paston could not have been all that choosy. He tried to get hitched to 10 different women in the year before he met Margery, and wrote despairingly to his brother: "I pray, get us a wife somewhere."

Contrary to perfidious foreign - mostly French - propaganda that Anglo-Saxons are a cold and unromantic race, it was the English who invented the valentine. The tradition really got going only in the 16th century, though the origins are older, said Mr Fletcher. "Paper valentines started the greeting card business as we know it. They had nothing really to do with the various St Valentines [obscure Roman and Byzantine martyrs] and more to do with the time of year."

As Chaucer wrote in Parliament of Foules:

For this was sent on Seynt Valentyne's day Whan every foul cometh ther to choose his mate.

It was a simple case of when the sap rose, and the birds began to pair, men and women's thoughts also turned to their loins and love.

"Margery Brews comes over as a subtle, literate, intelligent woman, someone who knew how to manipulate," said Mr Fletcher. "She was very similar to another remarkable Norfolk woman of the time, Margery Kemp, who wrote the first autobiography we know of."

The men may have held the power and the purse, but it was the women who pulled the strings, he said. "Margery and John's mothers really made the match. The men were the reluctant ones. Nothing changes, does it?"

fields.headline: Talks to save Ulster peace
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson to meet Irish minister as Sinn Fein and Unionists revert to war of words
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson is expected to meet Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign minister, in Belfast today to repair relations damaged by the Northern Ireland secretary's decision to suspend the fledgling power-sharing executive after just 72 days.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson is expected to meet Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign minister, in Belfast today to repair relations damaged by the Northern Ireland secretary's decision to suspend the fledgling power-sharing executive after just 72 days.

They will aim to thrash out an approach to the forthcoming second review of the Good Friday agreement, once more stalled after an IRA initiative on arms came too late and offered too little to persuade Mr Mandelson to hold back on restoring direct rule.

Sinn Fein and Ulster Unionists are blaming each other for the collapse of the institutions, and the governments will allow a short breathing space before the review starts. They believe that the current atmosphere would hamper attempts at finding a breakthrough on terrorist decommissioning.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, agreed at a meeting of his party's ruling council on Saturday to form a steering committee made up of delegates to discuss what other issues they would like discussed in the review. The governments will insist the review is focused solely on arms.

Mr Trimble now has to take any deal struck in the review back to council delegates, which is seen as a serious setback to the prospects of re-establishing the executive.

A Sinn Fein spokesman said: "The Ulster Unionists have once again raised the bar. We are in real crisis, much more serious than anything before. None of us can see how it will be resolved. We will have to consider what our approach will be to another review."

There were reports yesterday that the IRA army council, far from countenancing decommissioning, was on stand by to resume a campaign of violence. But security, republican and government sources rejected suggestions of an imminent breakdown in the IRA's 20-month ceasefire.

A British army source said: "The IRA's capability is higher now than it was two years ago. They have used the time well, regrouping, recruiting, retraining and retargeting."

One republican suggested that the IRA might withdraw its interlocutor from General John de Chastelain's International Commission on Decommissioning. The source said that the IRA's participation depended on all the institutions of the agreement being in place.

Mr Mandelson and Mr Cowen must today also attempt to avert a fresh row over the six cross-border implementation bodies, which remain in place despite the suspension order.

Mr Cowen, who wanted Mr Mandelson to delay suspension on Friday night pending clarification of the IRA's latest initiative, is understood to be reluctant to halt the work of the six bodies. But the Northern Ireland office is adamant they must be put on ice.

The governments were also unable on Friday to agree a positive, joint statement welcoming the IRA move. It is the first fall-out since long before the agreement 22 months ago.

Gen de Chastelain late on Friday issued a positive report after at least two meetings during the day with Brian Keenan, the IRA figure who acts as its interlocutor.

In contrast to his downbeat assessment of January 31, Gen de Chastelain on Friday said the IRA's offer could allow him to oversee the completion of decommissioning by May 22.

fields.headline: Bowie to be dad at 53
fields.trailText: Rock star David Bowie announced yesterday that he is to become a father again at the age of 53. Bowie and his wife, the model Iman, 44, were married in 1992. Both have children from their previous marriages which ended in divorce.
fields.body:
Rock star David Bowie announced yesterday that he is to become a father again at the age of 53. Bowie and his wife, the model Iman, 44, were married in 1992. Both have children from their previous marriages which ended in divorce.

Both plan to reduce their work schedules to make more time for the child, which is due in August.

In a statement Mr Bowie, estimated to be worth more than £500m, said: "It's been a long and patient wait for our baby but both Iman and I wanted the circumstances to be absolutely right and didn't want to find ourselves working flat out during the first couple of years of the baby's life."

Bowie has a son, now 28, from his 1970 marriage to Angie, who changed his name from Zowie to Joe. The couple were divorced in 1980. Iman has a daughter, Zulekha, from a marriage to a basketball star.

webTitle: Clash with Lords may delay mayor poll

fields.headline: Clash with Lords may delay mayor poll
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour is heading for a full-scale confrontation with the Lords over the election for mayor of London which could lead to legal challenges to contest rules or even the postponement of the poll, set for May 4, government sources warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour is heading for a full-scale confrontation with the Lords over the election for mayor of London which could lead to legal challenges to contest rules or even the postponement of the poll, set for May 4, government sources warned yesterday.

The prospect of a head-to-head clash with the opposition parties, centred on the government's refusal to agree to free postal delivery for mayoral candidates, comes as Labour's battle over its own candidate nears its climax.

Voting for the candidate ends at 5pm on Wednesday, with the result expected next weekend.

Two of Labour's three nominees, Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson, are piling on complaints about a process they regard as rigged against them.

But the possibility of the election itself being in question has become more serious as Labour has dug in its heels over the polling rules and the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, who are expected to command a Lords majority, prepare to vote down the government's plans.

"Positions have hardened in recent days, and we're now on a confrontation course," one minister involved in the negotiations said last night.

The government's regulations for the mayoral poll - which fix deposits and spending limits - are due to be debated in the Lords tonight, but the crunch is expected next week when they are expected to be defeated unless Labour concedes a freepost mailing for all candidates.

Ministers say that could mean that the poll would have to be held under ordinary local election rules, without any deposit requirement and "severe" limitations on spending.

But others, including home office officials and the Electoral Reform Society, believe that may be challengeable in law and that, if the government's regulations are rejected, the election will have to be postponed.

The government argues that freepost delivery of election addresses - as allowed in elections to Westminster, the European parliament and the devolved Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly - would be too expensive and would give free rein to fringe and "unscrupulous" candidates.

The opposition parties believe the government line is partly motivated by fear that Mr Livingstone might still run as an independent - and benefit from a free mailshot - if he is defeated in Labour's electoral college.

Mr Livingstone said yesterday that the three-day gap between the close of voting in Labour's ballot on Wednesday and the counting of postal votes was an "open invitation to fraud", and demanded the right to have his own scrutineers.

Both he and Ms Jackson's campaign team said Labour's decision to give a vote to Pauline Green, who retired as a London MEP in December, was in breach of the party's rules, which require all MPs and MEPs to be "in receipt of the Labour whip" to qualify to vote.

A Labour spokesman countered that the three-day gap was to allow challenges and appeals and that Ms Green was able to vote because she was an MEP on the qualifying date last September.

Ms Jackson's spokesman also branded as "Bulgarian-style democracy" a decision by the Co-operative party in south London on Friday to cast its 50,000 votes in Labour's electoral college for the third nominee, the former health secretary Frank Dobson - as expected - without a ballot.

fields.headline: Ministers' chauffeur perk extended
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has quietly extended one of the most exclusive political tax perks - the right to have a chauffeur driven car from home to work - estimated to be worth more than £5,000.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has quietly extended one of the most exclusive political tax perks - the right to have a chauffeur driven car from home to work - estimated to be worth more than £5,000.

The perk, introduced by Kenneth Clarke, the Tory chancellor in 1996, followed the disclosure by the Guardian that ministers were illegally not paying tax on their chauffeur-driven government car from home to work.

It was officially clarified by changing the law in the 1996 budget.

This allowed the prime minister, the speaker, all cabinet ministers and ministers who were assigned their own government drivers to be the only people in Britain given the right to be exempt from company car tax.

The tax perk was also extended to cover the leader of the opposition and the opposition chief whip who also get chauffeur-driven cars.

Now Mr Brown has gone one stage better and extended the tax perk to ministers in the Scottish parliament, Welsh assembly and the suspended Northern Ireland assembly.

The deal also covers Lord Steel, the presiding officer of the Scottish parliament, Lord Elis-Thomas, the presiding officer of the Welsh assembly and Lord Alderdice, the presiding officer of the Northern Ireland assembly.

The inland revenue confirmed yesterday that the change in the law had been made in a clause in last year's budget. It coincided with a hike in company car tax as part of an attack to curb business users.

The change in the law was made before the establishment of the new devolved parliaments and increased the number of people exempt from company car tax from about 100 ministers to nearly 150.

Maurice Fitzpatrick, head of corporate tax at accountants, Chantrey Vellacott DFK, estimates that the perk is worth £5,414 a year for most cabinet ministers.

This is based on a the fact they are using a £20,000 car and have to pay standard fuel charges, tax on part of the chauffeur's salary and a £798 national insurance bill.

fields.headline: Activists tell Brown: reform tax
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour activists have urged their leadership to place redistribution, including commitments to end child and pensioner poverty and to restore full employment, at the heart of the party's manifesto for the next election.
fields.body:
Labour activists have urged their leadership to place redistribution, including commitments to end child and pensioner poverty and to restore full employment, at the heart of the party's manifesto for the next election.

Consultation of the grassroots found that local parties wanted Labour to move further towards a "redistributive tax system" as part of "building fairness" in a second term in office.

The recommendation is contained in a consultation document on economic policy which will feed into the manifesto under Labour's newly established policy development process. Although Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has no obligation to take every proposal on board, he could not ignore the conclusions of a process the party frequently bills as democratic.

The proposals will be widely interpreted as a sign of grassroots frustration at Labour's wooing of middle England at the expense of its core voters, though party insiders last night insisted the references to redistribution indicated a new willingness to drop the self-imposed doctrine of always "acting left, talking right".

The document is one of six second phase policy papers being sent out to constituency parties as pressures grow on the leadership to beware of growing disaffection in Labour's heartlands.

Peter Kilfoyle, whose resignation as defence minister threw a spotlight on mounting concern among MPs and activists that the party is failing to address the issues that matter to its core voters, yesterday warned that voters regarded New Labour as merely "a conspiracy to defraud them".

The Liverpool Walton MP called for increased spending to be put ahead of tax cuts to reflect the heavy reliance of the poor on state services.

Meanwhile, the government faces more accusations of neglecting its core constituency with the expected announcement this week that there will be no rise in the £3.60 minimum hourly wage until April next year. Backbenchers are threatening an unprecedented vote against the freeze at this Wednesday's meeting of the parliamentary party.

In response to an initial policy document published a year ago, party members have called for a rewrite to focus on achieving Labour's open-ended commitment to full employment and on child poverty, which the party has pledged to eradicate within 20 years.

A report on the first phase of consultation included in the new document also raises the possibility of achieving full employment within 10 years. It says: "In the next decade, if we stay the course of reform, it can be one of our country's proudest achievements".

The results of consultation on the document will be fed into a draft final document for submission to Labour's national policy forum in July, from where an agreed paper will go on to party conference in October for approval.

fields.headline: It'll all end in tears
fields.trailText: The early end of Saturday evening always has a slight feeling of forced jollity about it. With memories of Noel's House Party still fresh and sore in the public consciousness, it takes courage to launch new formats into the 6.15pm slot - but launch they must, or everyone might decide to go out and not watch TV at all.
fields.body:
The early end of Saturday evening always has a slight feeling of forced jollity about it. With memories of Noel's House Party still fresh and sore in the public consciousness, it takes courage to launch new formats into the 6.15pm slot - but launch they must, or everyone might decide to go out and not watch TV at all.

BBC1 put up two plucky contenders on Saturday, battling against scarred old ITV veterans You've Been Framed and Blind Date. Friends Like These is a good old-fashioned game show hosted by Ant McPartlin and Declan Donnelly, for whom three hours of ITV's Saturday morning schedule is clearly not enough. The format is simple, a hybrid of The Crystal Maze and Mr And Mrs, with two teams (five Geordie lasses, five Essex lads) competing in tests of dexterity for the holiday of a lifetime. All ten contestants were good-looking and well dressed, in co-ordinated outfits almost certainly provided by a BBC stylist. The girls hugged a lot and cried real tears when they lost a round; the boys preferred manly back-slapping and those strange victory celebrations that simulate coitus.

The Essex boys won through to the final, thanks to some fancy business on a bowling alley, and then had to prove just how well they knew each other by answering intimate questions. "In which Chelmsford bar did David meet his girlfriend?" was easy enough (Yates's), but "What is Alex's favourite pizza topping?" was a stumbling block. "The answer is tomato and sweetcorn", said Dec; "we've got cheese over here", moaned Ant, as if the bottom had just fallen out of his world. So little did the boys know about each other's taste in vegetables that only one of them ended up with a ticket to Malaysia, but happily for all concerned he gambled his holiday and won a reprieve for all his mates, who knew, collectively, that David's least favourite drink is Bovril.

Next up was When Changing Rooms Met Ground Force , a dream come true for those of us who fantasise about characters from TV programmes "accidentally" strolling into other shows. Until Hayley out of Coronation Street sets up a trannie bar in Walford, this will have to do. In a wheeze that must have taken mere moments to dream up, Ground Force's Charlie Dimmock and Tommy Walsh were kept indoors to decorate a bedroom, while Changing Rooms' Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen and Handy Andy got to grips with the garden. "I'm going to be Carol Smillie", chirped Alan Titchmarsh, who focused his energies on creating a strange light fitting for the boudoir. Llewelyn-Bowen experienced a rush of testosterone and decided that the butch outdoors life was just the thing for him, even though it ruined his leather trousers.

When Changing Rooms Met Ground Force was a one-off, but we can only hope the concept lives on: When Children's Hospital Met Animal Hospital, perhaps, with vets having a crack at paediatrics?

The weekend was rounded off in style by Gimme Some Truth (Sunday, BBC2), the premiere of Andrew Solt and Yoko Ono's film chronicling the making of John Lennon's Imagine album. Lennon, Ono and "a few friends" (Phil Spector, George Harrison) got together at the Ono-Lennon Ascot mansion in May, 1971, to knock out a few songs, and a camera crew captured every last detail. What could easily have descended into sub-Spinal Tap rockumentary (Ono is, at times, perilously close to Spinal Tap wife Janine bleating about "Dobbly") was actually a moving portrait of Lennon at his casual best, chain smoking, drinking beer, swearing like a trooper and every so often laying down some of his best-ever performances. Things didn't always go smoothly: Lennon got fractious during the recording of Oh Yoko!, and occasionally harangued his troops in tones that sounded like Lily Savage.

Most revealing of all was an awkward little scene when a stoned fan stumbled up to the door and claimed that Lennon had been writing all his songs about him. "I'm singing about me and my life, and if it's relevant to other people's lives that's all right. Are you hungry?" asked Lennon, and invited the lost soul into the kitchen for some soup. For a second, the shadow of Mark Chapman fell across the Lennons' Berkshire idyll.
fields.bodyText: The early end of Saturday evening always has a slight feeling of forced jollity about it. With memories of Noel's House Party still fresh and sore in the public consciousness, it takes courage to launch new formats into the 6.15pm slot - but launch they must, or everyone might decide to go out and not watch TV at all. BBC1 put up two plucky contenders on Saturday, battling against scarred old ITV veterans You've Been Framed and Blind Date. Friends Like These is a good old-fashioned game show hosted by Ant McPartlin and Declan Donnelly, for whom three hours of ITV's Saturday morning schedule is clearly not enough. The format is simple, a hybrid of The Crystal Maze and Mr And Mrs, with two teams (five Geordie lasses, five Essex lads) competing in tests of dexterity for the holiday of a lifetime. All ten contestants were good-looking and well dressed, in co-ordinated outfits almost certainly provided by a BBC stylist. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Mark Coles's week-long series about his Meetings With Remarkable Men (3.45pm, Radio 4).
fields.body:
Mark Coles's week-long series about his Meetings With Remarkable Men (3.45pm, Radio 4) doesn't get off to much of a start. He phones, he writes, but his quarry remains elusive. Not to worry: a fellow philosopher reassures Coles that Jacques Derrida's deconstructionist theories are "absolute tosh". Then comes a message from the great man, who turns out to be quite charming and largely comprehensible.

The environmental movement is not all organic food and squatting in trees. In tonight's Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4) Julian Pettifer describes projects which have barely attracted the limelight in spite of their clearly beneficial impact. Some of the participants have worked to save Himalayan medicinal plants, others in the post-war reconstruction of Croatia. Now their efforts are being formally recognised when the Princess Royal gives them Whitley Awards for International Nature Conservation.

fields.headline: Farce in a flowerpot
fields.trailText: The insufferable Flowerpot Men are currently in high level negotiations with the BBC to make a comeback. The one proposed change will be to transform Weed from a limp growth behind the potting shed into an exotic plant from foreign climes, bullying Bill & Ben to experiment with organic fertilisers.
fields.body:
The insufferable Flowerpot Men are currently in high level negotiations with the BBC to make a comeback. The one proposed change will be to transform Weed from a limp growth behind the potting shed into an exotic plant from foreign climes, bullying Bill & Ben to experiment with organic fertilisers.

Who is to blame for this sacrilage? Feminism of course - that bugbear of the 1980s Daily Mail (whom I seem to remember mounting a fierce defence of gollywogs). If critics of politically correct Kids TV had their way, the last word in pre-school education would come not from educationalists or feminists, but from a vicar writing about steam trains in the 1930s.

In spite of 20 years of PC Kids TV: Mary, Mungo and Midge in their towerblock (now probably a loft apartment); Playaway's makeover into the urban, street-tough Playdays; and the bovver-booted Bella and Judy in The Tweenies, positive female role-models remain as stereotypical as their sexist counterparts.

There are exceptions, of course. Postman Pat has Granny Dryden and Mrs Goggins, both of whom are strong career women - Granny Dryden, in particular, a triumph of post-retirement multi-skilling, holding down a job at the Post Office while still coordinating the annual Greendale Fete.

The one unreconstructed sexist series on childrens TV is Bob The Builder (pictured), which coincidentally happens to be the most popular with kids. Bob's "secretary" Wendy, not only spends her entire life organising and humouring the oafish Bob (voiced, unsurprisingly, by Neil Morrissey), but waiting for him to propose marriage.

Bob The Builder is as popular with girls as boys. Why? Because contrary to what liberal educationalists and Daily Mail traditionalists might think, children are not stupid. Girls play at Wendy, but identify with Bob, just as they can own a Barbie, and end up Nicola Horlick. At the end of the day, everyone wants to drive the truck.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.standfirst: Wuthering Heights. A wild romance concocted by scriptwriters Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur from Emily Brontë's classic novel, and a must on St Valentine's.
fields.trailText: Wuthering Heights
fields.body:
Wuthering Heights

(William Wyler, 1939)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

A wild romance concocted by scriptwriters Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur from Emily Brontë's classic novel, and a must on St Valentine's. Once he'd stopped sulking over not getting Vivian Leigh as co-star, Laurence Olivier made a tormented but heroic Heathcliff, and Merle Oberon was a touching Cathy.

Cyrano De Bergerac

(Jean-Paul Rappenau, 1991)

8pm, FilmFour

Another great lover: Gérard Depardieu's Cyrano has the heart of a lion and the soul of a poet, but, cursed with an unfeasibly large nose, is too shy to declare his love for his beautiful cousin Roxane (Anne Brochet). Instead, the 17th century swordsman with the rapier wit woos her on behalf of handsome but dim comrade-in-arms Vincent Perez. Rappeneau directs on the heroic scale, with huge battles and a fine eye for lush settings and costume, and Anthony Burgess's subtitles, in Rostand's Alexandrine verse, are an additional pleasure.

Get Carter

(Mike Hodges, 1971)

9.15pm TCM

More lovey-dovey Valentine's stuff. OK, we all know Michael Caine's amoral Carter is a very 'eavy London 'ood returning to his native Newcastle to sort out his brother's killers: "You're a big man, but you're out of shape..." etc, but he also simultaneously seduces girlfriend Britt Ekland (by phone) and the landlady-with-the-purple-underwear: a little warmth at the heart of Hodges's stark thriller.

Hamam: The Turkish Bath

(Ferzen Ozpetek, 1997)

12.25am, FilmFour

First-timer Ozpetek draws on his Italian-Turkish roots for this dreamy, steamy tale of a cool Italian man's thawing out under the exotic influence of Istanbul. Having inherited a run-down Turkish bath there from his aunt, he visits with the intention of a quick sale and a respite from his frosty wife, but is soon drawn in by tales of aunty's bohemian past, the friendly neighbours, and the intoxicating (homo)eroticism of the bath experience. Opulent colours and frenzied percussion only enhance the sensual spell.

fields.headline: Kes 2: The Revenge
fields.standfirst: A new serial, Nature Boy, continues television's current obsession with society's dispossessed. Why do the prosperous middle classes suddenly want to watch drama about poor people?
fields.trailText: A new serial, Nature Boy, continues television's current obsession with society's dispossessed. Why do the prosperous middle classes suddenly want to watch drama about poor people?
fields.body:
The opening episode of Nature Boy (tonight, 9pm, BBC2) ends with the assertion that "No animals were harmed in the making of this programme." Having just witnessed a deer having its throat cut; a parrot having its neck broken; and a flock of seagulls forced to re-enact the attack scene from The Birds by pecking a man to death on a beach, I find this a remarkable achievement.

Nature Boy owes something to The Birds, but far more to Kes. Writer Bryan Elsley, who adapted the Iain Banks novel, The Crow Road, has created an ambitious four-part drama that operates as a kind of Kes 2: The Revenge. David, a 16-year-old foster lad brought up on the industrial wastelands of Barrow-in-Furness, finds escape from domestic cruelty and social deprivation in caring for his stepfather's caged birds.

However, unlike Loach's anti-hero, who shares the same hobby and predicament, David is motivated to leave his dead-end home town, following the violent death of a young foster-girl he's befriended. Elsley's drama picks up where Loach left off, taking David on a picaresque journey across every social and geographical divide in Britain, in order to find his real father.

The cod symbolism of the "caged bird" aside (avoided in Kes because the main character didn't have lines like "he's pulling his feathers out, he needs to be free!"), episode one of Nature Boy is a startling piece of drama. The director, the relatively unknown Joe Wright, makes the bleak council estates and sand dunes of the North West Coast look beautiful. The performances by 16-year-old Lee Ingleby and 17-year-old Anne Marie Cooper are flawless.

In fact, the whole thing is so flawless, it raises worrying questions about the idea of poverty as entertainment. Nature Boy walks an ambiguous line between empathy and voyeurism. The photography and styling are remarkably similar to that of fashion shoots in the mid-90s: teenage girl in tracksuit snorting speed in her bedroom. Beth Orton and Pulp feature obtrusively on the soundtrack, the latter as a particularly ill-judged accompaniment to a single mum shooting up heroin.

The programme makers argue that this reflects the reality of teen Britain, and that they're working in the tradition of social realist TV drama. "At the moment, TV runs the risk of being too glossy," says Joe Wright, "so we intended to make something as brutal as the kind of thing Alan Clarke [director of Scum and The Firm] did. I think there's a heritage that sometimes gets forgotten."

But TV doesn't forget, it revives - and at present, the working class are in vogue again. On BBC1, as Neighbours At War. On BBC2, helping Modern Times to remould itself as hard-hitting documentary, dropping the comedy of middle-class manners for dog-kicking council estates.

Nature Boy, like the recent one-off Storm Damage, and BBC1's more sensationalist The Lakes, is part of a cross-channel revival of gritty drama about disenfranchised youth. Programme makers go through the motions of saying they want to raise awareness and create a debate (one that C4 would have Jon Snow chair ing), but the truth is that they're exploiting an increasing appetite for social deprivation as glamorous tableaux. Poverty porn, if you like.

One uncharitable explanation for this is that the middle class love to watch poor people when they're feeling prosperous, but stop when there's a hint of recession. As interest rates go up, so the argument goes, dramas like Nature Boy will be replaced with Inspector Morse/Darling Buds Of May escapism - both series that were first popular during the long nights of late-80s recession.

Intentionally or not, it's true that dramatists are conspiring to create a fictional rock'n'roll underclass - more Larry Clark than Alan Clarke - in order to make compelling believable drama. But it's not true that this so-called poverty porn is less powerful for being sensationalist, or having a moral ambiguity towards it subject.

Forty years ago, Cathy Come Home jammed the BBC switchboard with callers incredulous that such a thing as forced adoption could happen in Britain. Today, a drama will only jam the switchboard if viewers see something that goes outside the ambit of acceptable voyeurism. Viewers are no longer ignorant of what happens in Britain, but confused by their inability to deal with the extremity of it.

This confusion is shared with dramatists, who can't decide whether they're repelled or infatuated with social deprivation. Unsurprisingly, a recurrent theme of Nature Boy, as with The Lakes, is drowning, a symbol of the oblique and half-grasped. Bryan Elsley does nothing to unmuddy the waters, but communicates an overwhelming sense of one thing, and one thing alone. That we have deeply and profoundly failed our children - but don't know how to go about changing that.

Unfortunately, Nature Boy undermines the power of this point with too much ambition. One can just see the editorial meeting in which they decided to shoe-horn in pollution and GM food, oh, and New Labour and a tunnel-digging Swampy element (the doppler-shift time-lag of the commissioning process: Corrie dropped their Swampy character a year ago). Pared down to the simplicity of the first episode, Nature Boy would have been a more shocking, and truthful drama.
