fields.headline: Robert Gosling
fields.standfirst: Psychiatrists' psychiatrist who headed the Tavistock Clinic
fields.trailText: The psychiatrist and psychoanalyst Dr Robert (Bob) Gosling, who has died aged 79, led the Tavistock Clinic from 1968 to 1979. Already a centre of excellence in the field of psychotherapy, under his guidance it became an international model for such training institutions.
fields.body:
The psychiatrist and psychoanalyst Dr Robert (Bob) Gosling, who has died aged 79, led the Tavistock Clinic from 1968 to 1979. Already a centre of excellence in the field of psychotherapy, under his guidance it became an international model for such training institutions. Gosling was the first chairman of its professional committee to be elected by his peers, and made significant contributions to group therapy and training.

Born in Birmingham, Gosling became a medical student there and obtained a BSc in physiology. He then gained a Rockefeller scholarship to do his clinical training in the US, at Cornell. However, after six months he developed tuberculosis, from which he suffered for four years.

He noted that whether patients got better or worse depended to a significant extent on their emotions. This observation, coupled with meeting a psycho- analyst, led to him settling on psychoanalysis as a career - a perceptive choice, as he was closely in touch with his own deeper feelings.

After obtaining his MD at Cornell, and qualifying on his return to the UK, he worked as a locum GP before starting his psychiatric training at the Maudsley Hospital as registrar to professor Sir Aubrey Lewis. Serious illness struck again: poliomyelitis kept him off work for 18 months, and he had to spend several weeks in an iron lung.

He later described, with tolerant good humour, how his medical registrar colleagues, wanting to cheer him up, would keep telling him how lucky he was that the illness had not spread to certain muscles around his thighs, so that he would be able to walk again. Trapped in the iron lung, he did not feel in any way lucky, and desperately wished that they could have tolerated him describing how he really felt.

Eventually he completed his psychiatric training at the Maudsley, and became a senior registrar in the adult department of the Tavistock Clinic, acting for several years as assistant to the psychoanalyst Michael Balint, who was pioneering training for general practitioners. Gosling qualified as a member of the British Psychoanalytic Society in 1958, and became a consultant at the Tavistock Clinic.

Gosling's leadership style at the clinic was primarily that of a facilitator, helping staff of different disciplines to work together, and giving full weight to their shared beliefs in the importance of the insights of psychoanalysis. He enabled them to exercise their particular skills in innovating and developing training programmes. In addition, he encouraged work in schools, residential homes for the mentally sick, and health centres, in order to help staff in their own settings to cope more effectively with the psychological problems they encountered.

A sensitive and insightful clinician, Gosling was often in demand as the "psychiatrist's psychiatrist". The development of the Tavistock tradition of group therapy owed much to him: it aimed at assisting internal changes in individual patients through their involvement with the dynamics of the group.

He also made a study of training in small groups for general practitioners, probation officers, dentists, teachers and clergymen, with the aim of helping them to identify and cope more effectively with the psychological problems of their daily work.

The dynamics of institutions particularly interested him, and he was a senior staff member of the "Leicester conference" on authority and leadership, run twice yearly by the Tavistock institute of Human Relations, for industrialists, managers and professionals.

For many years he acted as consultant to the Richmond Fellowship; he organised the enormously successful 1964 International Conference in Psychotherapy; and he was deeply involved with the work of the Royal College of Psychiatrists.

Bob was strikingly handsome, and had a quiet sense of humour. He was modest, always calm and unflappable, and had a particularly warm way of engaging with people. At the same time he was introspective and, one sensed, deeply vulnerable. He always brought fresh and original thinking to whatever task he was engaged in.

In later middle age, his hearing began to fail and he found it increasingly difficult to continue clinical work, so he took early retirement, and was awarded the OBE.

He and his wife, the novelist Veronica Henriques, bought a Queen Anne house in Gloucestershire, and he combined his hobby, carpentry, with small-time farming. Knowing of this, his friends and colleagues at the Tavistock gave him a goose and a gander. He named them Tavi and Stock - they mated and, to everyone's delight, produced numerous goslings.

In his retirement, Bob became the patron of the Bridge Foundation, a centre for psychotherapy and the arts in Bristol. He was always supportive, playing an active and committed part in its development and success.

He leaves his wife, four sons and a daughter.

In addition, he encouraged work in schools, residential homes for the mentally sick, and health centres, in order to help staff in their own settings to cope more effectively with the psychological problems they encountered. A sensitive and insightful clinician, Gosling was often in demand as the "psychiatrist's psychiatrist". The development of the Tavistock tradition of group therapy owed much to him: it aimed at assisting internal changes in individual patients through their involvement with the dynamics of the group. He also made a study of training in small groups for general practitioners, probation officers, dentists, teachers and clergymen, with the aim of helping them to identify and cope more effectively with the psychological problems of their daily work. The dynamics of institutions particularly interested him, and he was a senior staff member of the "Leicester conference" on authority and leadership, run twice yearly by the Tavistock institute of Human Relations, for industrialists, managers and professionals. For many years he acted as consultant to the Richmond Fellowship; he organised the enormously successful 1964 International Conference in Psychotherapy; and he was deeply involved with the work of the Royal College of Psychiatrists. Bob was strikingly handsome, and had a quiet sense of humour. He was modest, always calm and unflappable, and had a particularly warm way of engaging with people. At the same time he was introspective and, one sensed, deeply vulnerable. He always brought fresh and original thinking to whatever task he was engaged in. In later middle age, his hearing began to fail and he found it increasingly difficult to continue clinical work, so he took early retirement, and was awarded the OBE. He and his wife, the novelist Veronica Henriques, bought a Queen Anne house in Gloucestershire, and he combined his hobby, carpentry, with small-time farming. Knowing of this, his friends and colleagues at the Tavistock gave him a goose and a gander. He named them Tavi and Stock - they mated and, to everyone's delight, produced numerous goslings. In his retirement, Bob became the patron of the Bridge Foundation, a centre for psychotherapy and the arts in Bristol. He was always supportive, playing an active and committed part in its development and success. He leaves his wife, four sons and a daughter.

webTitle: Cook urged to explain MI6 role in Gadafy plot

fields.headline: Cook urged to explain MI6 role in Gadafy plot
fields.standfirst: Foreign secretary pressed after report on the internet claims secret service was told in advance about plan to overthrow Libyan leader
fields.trailText: Robin Cook was under pressure last night to explain MI6 links to a plot to overthrow Colonel Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader, after a British secret intelligence report containing details of the plan were published on the internet.
fields.body:
Robin Cook was under pressure last night to explain MI6 links to a plot to overthrow Colonel Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader, after a British secret intelligence report containing details of the plan were published on the internet.

The report, headed "UK eyes alpha" said MI6 was told by a "delicate source" about the plot two months before it took place in February 1996.

MI6 involvement in a plot to kill the Libyan leader was first alleged by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, before he was arrested in Paris in August 1998.

The MI6 report, which was distributed to senior officials in the foreign office, the ministry of defence, GCHQ, and MI5, said it was told by the source that the plotters had obtained 250 British pistols. It stressed that the MI6 source - one of the plotters - hoped a new Libyan government could enlist British support had it been successful.

It said: "The coup was scheduled to start at around the time of the next general people's congress on February 14, 1996. Coup will start with unrest in Tripoli, Misratah and Benghazi." It added: "The source said that the plotters would have cars similar to those in Qadhafi's (sic) security entourage with fake security number plates. They would infiltrate themselves in order to kill or arrest Qadhafi."

The plot narrowly failed to assassinate Colonel Gadafy, but killed six innocent by standers, according to reports in the Arab press.

Mr Cook subsequently described reports of the plot as "pure fantasy". He said he had seen nothing "which would suggest SIS [the secret intelligence service, more commonly known as MI6] has any interest, any role, or any experience" in "any such escapade". He added: "There was no government-inspired plan to assassinate Gadafy. There was no SIS proposal to do it and I'm fairly clear there has never been any SIS involvement."

Yesterday, the foreign office said in a statement: "Nothing in the alleged intelligence report posted on the internet invalidates what the foreign secretary said. Nor have we ever denied that we knew of plots against Gaddafi."

Rear admiral Nick Wilkinson, secretary of the D notice committee, which operates a system of self-censorhip asked the media not to publish the whole document or the address of the Yahoo website where it could still be read a day after it the government was first alerted to it.

He said: "I have seen it on the internet. It looks genuine but who knows whether it is or not. I would think the chances are it is, and we have treated it as if it is."

There is no law preventing it from being read or copied. The internet site where it originally appeared was chosen because it allows people to place information anonymously without being identified. Mr Shayler alleged in 1998 that an MI6 agent, code-named PT16B, told him of the plot. Details of the plot were also contained in an MI5 "subject file" he said he saw while he was on the agency's Libyan desk.

He later told Jack Straw and the parliamentary intelligence and security committee about the alleged plot. Speaking from Paris, where is now lives, he said yesterday he had legal advice that he should not comment on how the MI6 report appeared on the internet.

Though the report, coded CX95/53452, was drawn up under the Conservative government when Sir Malcolm Rifkind was foreign secretary, Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, demanded an immediate inquiry into the affair.

"This report raises serious questions over Robin Cook's previous comments on this issue," he said.

"There must now be a thorough and full investigation to establish the facts. I will be tabling questions when parliament returns tomorrow to ask what Mr Cook knew about the role of the British intelligence services on this case, and when."

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman called for an independent investigation by a high court judge.

"Knowing that there were plots against Gadafy is one thing, but being involved in them is something entirely different," he said.

"All of this underlines the argument for greater accountability to the House of Commons in relation to intelligence matters."

The MI6 report makes clear that British intelligence knew details of the plot. What it does not say is what Whitehall did with the information. What is certain is that its placement on the internet will raise Mr Shayler's case and credibility.

Mr Shayler said that he had been told by an MI6 officer that a senior Libyan had walked into a British embassy, asking for funds and in exchange for support would hand over the two Lockerbie bomb suspects when Gadafy was overthrown.

The MI6 source, code-named Tunworth - his real name is blanked out on the internet site - was given money by MI6, according to Mr Shayler.

webTitle: Pinochet may have had CIA go-ahead to kill two Americans, documents show

fields.headline: Pinochet may have had CIA go-ahead to kill two Americans, documents show
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The CIA may have given General Augusto Pinochet's government the go-ahead to murder the young American writer on whom the film Missing was based, according to newly declassified documents. The revelation is likely to weaken Gen Pinochet's case that he was unaware of atrocities committed by his secret police when he was Chile's dictator.
fields.body:
The CIA may have given General Augusto Pinochet's government the go-ahead to murder the young American writer on whom the film Missing was based, according to newly declassified documents. The revelation is likely to weaken Gen Pinochet's case that he was unaware of atrocities committed by his secret police when he was Chile's dictator.

Two US citizens, Charles Horman, 31, and Frank Teruggi, 24, were killed in Chile in 1973 following the military coup that overthrew President Salvador Allende.

Both men had been supporters of Allende and had worked for a newsletter sympathetic to him in the capital, Santiago.

Horman had spotted US warships off the Chilean coast at Valparaiso shortly after the coup and had believed this showed signs of American connivance. Horman was given a lift back to Santiago by a US military captain two days before he disappeared. His story was told in Costa-Gavras's 1982 film Missing, which starred Jack Lemmon.

Teruggi, a friend of Horman's, was arrested by the secret police, held at the National Stadium in Santiago and had his throat slashed.

The US government released papers about the deaths in 1980, apparently exonerating the US of any involvement. But some documents remained classified. Now President Clinton has ordered the declassification of "all documents that shed light on human rights abuses... during and prior to the Pinochet era in Chile."

One declassified document states: "US intelligence may have played a part in Horman's death. At best, it was limited to providing or confirming information that helped motivate his murder by the government of Chile. At worst, US intelligence was aware the government saw Horman in a rather serious light and US officials did nothing to discourage the logical outcome of government of Chile paranoia."

The declassified material giving details of a subsequent inquiry carried out by the American authorities into the deaths states: "[The CIA] may have played an unfortunate part in Horman's death."

The implication is that the CIA indicated to the Chilean military that Horman was a danger who could be eliminated without too much risk of a fuss from the US.

Henry Kissinger, who was secretary of state during the period, told the New York Times, which published the declassified material yesterday, that if he had been made aware of the matter, he "would have done something".

Horman's widow, Joyce, is now pressing the government for a fuller investigation into the links between the US government and Gen Pinochet.

The former army captain, Ray Davis, denies any involvement with the deaths of the men, but told the inquiry that Horman and Teruggi were "part of the problem".

webTitle: Wahid backs down on call for Wiranto to resign

fields.headline: Wahid backs down on call for Wiranto to resign
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday backed down in his confrontation with his security minister, General Wiranto, and said that the former armed forces commander would not have to resign until a formal legal investigation had been completed into last year's atrocities in East Timor.
fields.body:
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday backed down in his confrontation with his security minister, General Wiranto, and said that the former armed forces commander would not have to resign until a formal legal investigation had been completed into last year's atrocities in East Timor.

It is not thought that Mr Wahid will suffer politically as a result - despite some foreign analysts' concerns over the president's credibility following the unexpected development.

Mr Wahid denied that he had buckled under pressure from Gen Wiranto or elements within the armed forces. "I asked him to resign, but he asked to be examined by the law, and I said 'okay'," Mr Wahid said following a three-hour meeting with the general.

"This is not a compromise," he added. "There is no problem. Wiranto and me are good friends [but] the media perceives us to be enemies. I have the right to change my ministers. After he is inspected by law, then I will exercise my prerogative. If the result of the report implicates him, then he must resign."

The attorney-general, Marzuki Darusman, who with the vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, also attended the meeting, is expected to take up to three months to complete his investigation into events in East Timor.

During Mr Wahid's absence there were fears that Gen Wiranto and his loyalists within the military might launch a coup, but few people believe this is likely now.

Gen Wiranto is becoming increasingly isolated. On Friday the military broke its 10-day silence and publicly backed Mr Wahid against the general.

The armed forces commander, Admiral Widodo Adi Sutjipto, told parliament that the military would accept whatever Mr Wahid decided.

Two weeks ago Indonesia's human rights commission implicated Gen Wiranto and 32 others in crimes against humanity during and after the independence referendum in East Timor last August.

A United Nations report says Indonesia's military, led by Gen Wiranto, helped organise and took part in the campaign of murder and destruction.

Within hours of the Indonesian report being published, Mr Wahid, who was on a 16-day overseas tour, said Gen Wiranto should resign. He repeated the demand several times before returning to Indonesia yesterday.

Some foreigners fear that the u-turn will harm Indonesia's transition to democracy.

"It was a test for Wahid and it seems he has failed it," a Singapore-based financial trader said. "It just raises so many worrying questions, about his hold on power, about the way he seems constantly to change his mind, about whether this cabinet can function together."

But Indonesian analysts were less concerned. "It is clear there are still strong forces out there against the president and he has to go carefully," one said. "He is strengthening his position in his own way and the people still trust him."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Nine arrests on polling day
The second and final day of voting in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum was marked by the arrest of the human rights lawyer Tendai Biti and eight others as they campaigned against President Robert Mugabe's draft constitution, writes Andrew Meldrum in Harare.
fields.body:
Nine arrests on polling day
The second and final day of voting in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum was marked by the arrest of the human rights lawyer Tendai Biti and eight others as they campaigned against President Robert Mugabe's draft constitution, writes Andrew Meldrum in Harare.

Opposition groups plan to mount a legal challenge to the referendum result, citing alleged voting irregularities.

UN mines probe at El Alamein
A United Nations delegation headed to El Alamein yesterday to assess Egypt's needs in its efforts to rid the second world war battleground of landmines.

Egypt has an estimated 22m mines buried along its western borders. It argues that since it did not plant the mines, it should not be expected to foot the bill for removing them. [AP, Cairo]

Protests at oil tanker spill
Environmentalists and fishermen took dozens of boats out to sea yesterday to protest against fuel oil allegedly still spilling from a Russian tanker which split in two at the mouth of the Bosporus strait on December 29. [AP, Istanbul]

webTitle: Los Angeles muralists look beyond the brick wall

fields.headline: Los Angeles muralists look beyond the brick wall
fields.standfirst: Digital imaging techniques are among the innovations used by artists to take their message into the public arena
fields.trailText: New techniques are revolutionising the art of creating murals in the world's mural capital, Los Angeles. Now muralists are hoping to persuade city authorities to hand over a percentage of public wall space in a celebration of the art.
fields.body:
New techniques are revolutionising the art of creating murals in the world's mural capital, Los Angeles. Now muralists are hoping to persuade city authorities to hand over a percentage of public wall space in a celebration of the art.

It was in Los Angeles that the leading Mexican muralist David Alvaro Siqueiros created his famous work, Tropical America, in 1932. He proclaimed at the time: "We repudiate so-called easel art and all such art which springs from ultra-intellectual circles, for it is essentially aristocratic. We hail the monumental expression of art because such art is public property."

Now a new generation of muralists is following in his footsteps. In the same way that Siqueiros believed that the arrival of acrylic paints in the thirties gave muralists new power, so too is digital imaging seen as opening up new possiblilies for the genre.

"Digital imaging is going to bring muralism into the 21st century," said Judy Baca, a pioneer of the art form in the United States and the founder of Los Angeles' Social and Public Art Resource Centre (Sparc).

In the seventies Ms Baca was responsible for the Great Wall of Los Angeles, the world's longest mural which traces the history of California from prehistoric times to the 1950s. It was completed over six summers by 400 teenagers and established artists and historians and runs for half a mile through the San Fernando Valley, incorporating among others, Joe McCarthy and farm union organiser Cesar Chavez, black activists who fought for equal housing and Japanese Americans who were imprisoned in California during the second world war.

Ms Baca's latest epic work, which charts Mexican-American history through her own family's experience, will be opened at Denver international airport in March.

There are around 3,000 murals in Los Angeles, ranging from small neighbourhood ones in the Hispanic area of Boyle Heights to majestic ones by the coast. The combination of a climate that allows for year-long painting and the proximity to Mexico has helped to turn the city into the world's mural capital.

New digital imaging techniques allow muralists to work on aluminium, which has a longer life span than the average wall, and to adapt the design to the available space, as well as take advantage of temporary sites in the knowledge that the mural will not be lost forever when the wall is knocked down.

Ms Baca, who is also professor of art at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) says the new methods mean the cost of a mural can be kept low. "We have to advance and adapt and keep evolving," she says.

She and her colleagues at Sparc, who run the first digital mural laboratory in the US, hope to harness the new techniques to the growing interest in murals. They are campaigning to persuade cities to make available empty space for public painting.

"We would be looking for a percentage of public space that could be used," Ms Baca says.

"When you think of all the space that is given over to Gap underwear and other advertising it should be possible to secure some for murals, even if it was only one per cent, which could be used as a space for public dialogue."

But patronage from a city can lead to restrictions on the subjects that are painted. When Siqueiros painted Tropical America and depicted an American eagle hovering over a crucified Indian peon, the offending portion was whitewashed out.

The new Tim Robbins film, Cradle Will Rock, shows Diego Rivera having similar censorship problems with his patron, Nelson Rockefeller. When Sparc worked in 1994/95 on a mural that celebrated the Black Panthers there were problems, too. The muralists received several warnings that their work would provoke a riot. Attempts to water down the content are becoming more common, she said. "We get direct calls from police departments saying 'we don't think this is a very good idea'."

One of the city's most famous murals, The Wall that Cracked Open, was painted in 1972 by Willie Heron as an impassioned response to the near-death of his brother at the hands of a gang.

The artist recently covered the work with plywood because the city has an anti-graffiti policy and someone had sprayed graffiti on the mural. The city's anti-graffiti squad then painted over the graffiti, damaging the mural in the process.

"Public demand has increased but government support has decreased and at the same time they're increasing their control of the imagery," said Debra Padilla, director of Sparc.

She said that muralists often consult local people about the kinds of images they would like to reflect their lives before embarking on a new work, so that "99% of murals are not attacked by graffiti artists".

Ms Baca's latest epic work, which charts Mexican-American history through her own family's experience, will be opened at Denver international airport in March. There are around 3,000 murals in Los Angeles, ranging from small neighbourhood ones in the Hispanic area of Boyle Heights to majestic ones by the coast. The combination of a climate that allows for year-long painting and the proximity to Mexico has helped to turn the city into the world's mural capital. New digital imaging techniques allow muralists to work on aluminium, which has a longer life span than the average wall, and to adapt the design to the available space, as well as take advantage of temporary sites in the knowledge that the mural will not be lost forever when the wall is knocked down. Ms Baca, who is also professor of art at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) says the new methods mean the cost of a mural can be kept low. "We have to advance and adapt and keep evolving," she says. She and her colleagues at Sparc, who run the first digital mural laboratory in the US, hope to harness the new techniques to the growing interest in murals. They are campaigning to persuade cities to make available empty space for public painting. "We would be looking for a percentage of public space that could be used," Ms Baca says. "When you think of all the space that is given over to Gap underwear and other advertising it should be possible to secure some for murals, even if it was only one per cent, which could be used as a space for public dialogue." But patronage from a city can lead to restrictions on the subjects that are painted. When Siqueiros painted Tropical America and depicted an American eagle hovering over a crucified Indian peon, the offending portion was whitewashed out. The new Tim Robbins film, Cradle Will Rock, shows Diego Rivera having similar censorship problems with his patron, Nelson Rockefeller. When Sparc worked in 1994/95 on a mural that celebrated the Black Panthers there were problems, too. The muralists received several warnings that their work would provoke a riot. Attempts to water down the content are becoming more common, she said. "We get direct calls from police departments saying 'we don't think this is a very good idea'." One of the city's most famous murals, The Wall that Cracked Open, was painted in 1972 by Willie Heron as an impassioned response to the near-death of his brother at the hands of a gang. The artist recently covered the work with plywood because the city has an anti-graffiti policy and someone had sprayed graffiti on the mural. The city's anti-graffiti squad then painted over the graffiti, damaging the mural in the process. "Public demand has increased but government support has decreased and at the same time they're increasing their control of the imagery," said Debra Padilla, director of Sparc. She said that muralists often consult local people about the kinds of images they would like to reflect their lives before embarking on a new work, so that "99% of murals are not attacked by graffiti artists".

webTitle: Uneasy truce as Spain reels from racial unrest

fields.headline: Uneasy truce as Spain reels from racial unrest
fields.trailText: After the worst outbreak of racial violence to affect modern Spain, Moroccan immigrants in the south-eastern town of El Ejido yesterday called off a protest strike and announced a 12-day truce while they consider an emergency package promised by the government.
fields.byline: Adela Gooch  in El Ejido, Spain
fields.body:
After the worst outbreak of racial violence to affect modern Spain, Moroccan immigrants in the south-eastern town of El Ejido yesterday called off a protest strike and announced a 12-day truce while they consider an emergency package promised by the government.

But as both local people and migrant workers blame official neglect, rather than each other, for an explosion they say was waiting to happen, some insist it will take more than promises of legalised status and decent housing to achieve full racial integration.

Immigrants from north Africa - around 10% of the 50,000-strong population - began a strike last Monday, demanding better pay and conditions. Their work, in plastic hot-house farms that produce vegetables for most of western Europe, has made El Ejido and the province of Almeria one of the richest areas in Spain.

Yet this prosperity has not prevented racial tensions with the local populace. "You have to live here to know what it's like," said the owner of a restaurant that serves rich farmers. "We're always scared of being raped or robbed - and now even killed."

Three murders in the space of two weeks, apparently all carried out by Moroccans, triggered racist violence that led to 23 arrests and 50 injuries, and has left El Ejido, and the rest of Spain, incredulous, and prompted an official protest from Morocco.

Five hundred riot police now patrol the streets. Two helicopters keep a vigilant eye for trouble. "There are no plans for us to leave," says one of the men drafted in three days after bands of young Ejidans - and outsiders alerted by a neo-Nazi website - went on the rampage.

To the battle cry of "Moors out!" that ran through Spain 500 years ago when all Jews and Arabs were expelled, they stoned immigrants, set fire to their shacks and even urinated on a copy of the Koran.

In a knock-on effect, a butcher's shop owned by Moroccans in the town of Tarrassa, near Barcelona, was set on fire. One of the biggest immigrant centres in Spain, Tarrassa was the scene of violent clashes last summer.

For 24 hours last Monday El Ejido town centre was barricaded against journalists, hand-wringing politicians and even Red Cross workers as the conservative local mayor let the population take matters into their hands.

In a state of abject terror, many north Africans took to the foothills of the nearby sierra for safety. Then they responded in kind, setting fire to some of the smallholdings where they worked, calling a strike and attacking eastern European immigrants waiting to take their place.

Until the 1970s, Almeria remained the "dry, rocky, depressing desert similar to the Sinai" seen by the Bloomsbury group writer Gerald Brenan when he settled in the Sierra Nevada 75 years ago.

Then new farming techniques based on artificial irrigation and solar energy led to an economic boom in El Ejido.

"In England, Holland and Belgium you are eating our tomatoes and peppers," says a farmer. "But two generations ago we were immigrants ourselves seeking work abroad."

Half the Spanish population of El Ejido has not even a basic education and neither the sensitivity nor the understanding to give their workers decent pay and conditions, according to the Moroccan-based Spanish writer Juan Goytisolo. He describes the town as "an el dorado of clandestine work and illegal exploitation".

"The dregs of Africa are allowed to come here," insists a businessman.

"There is no integration without legalisation and papers," argues a Moroccan.

Around half of El Ejido's immigrants are said to have entered Spain illegally, and the violence came soon after parliament passed a law allowing 70,000 illegal immigrants to take up residency. But Spain's centre-right government now plans changes if it wins next month's election.

"We can't assimilate so many immigrants so quickly," says the interior minister, Jaime Mayor Orega. But that will simply mean more illegals, according to critics of the government's stance, who include some cabinet members. "We need people to do the jobs Spaniards no longer want to do," says the employment minister, Manuel Pimentel Siles.

This weekend many immigrants marched through El Ejido carrying banners reading: "We want peace." Local people gradually joined in. "We can't let this go on," said one woman. "It's chaos, war, civil war."

At the head of the demonstration were a number of multiracial families, some of whom now want to leave. "Is this the place to bring up our three children?" asked one Moroccan-Spanish couple whose shop was raided and looted this week. "We thought we could have a decent life here. We're not sure any more."

webTitle: Student rejects blame for website attacks

fields.headline: Student rejects blame for website attacks
fields.standfirst: Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old German high school student yesterday claimed that he was the hacker who developed a computer program which last week shut down several of the world's largest commercial websites.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Berlin and  Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
A 20-year-old German high school student yesterday claimed that he was the hacker who developed a computer program which last week shut down several of the world's largest commercial websites.

But he denied personally carrying out the attacks. "I am not involved in attacks on US websites or in any other form of criminal activity," he told the German news agency DPA in an email message.

The student, who is being sought by the FBI and German and Russian police, appeared on the internet under the pseudonym "Mixter" to declare: "I am in fact the only programmer to have so far published the attack program in question and I stand by it."

Mixter made his statement to DPA after Der Spiegel magazine identified him as a Hanover student preparing for the German equivalent of A-levels.

Der Spiegel said that the hacker was wanted in connection with last week's computer attacks on the internet providers Yahoo!, Buy.com, eBay, Amazon.com and Time Warner which shut down their websites for hours by overloading them with a massive influx of computerised demands.

The magazine said that Mixter had also developed a concept which enabled provider companies to protect themselves against his own attack program. The American website company, Packet Storm, is reported to have paid him $10,000 (£6,250) for his idea.

Mixter said that the program thought to have been used in the attack, nicknamed Stacheldraht (barbed wire), was a development of his own work, conceived by other German hackers who operated under the pseudonym "Randomizer".

He claimed that he had developed the software for a program which was capable of massively overloading websites with so-called "data garbage" until they were paralysed. But he said he had developed the program and published it in "security circles" merely to demonstrate that such attacks could theoretically be carried out.

Insurance companies are reaping the benefits of last week's attacks and now charge around £25,000 annually for £1m worth of cover. Internet companies are being urged to divert some of the billions they currently spend in advertising towards security.

The US attorney general, Janet Reno, is meeting President Clinton and around 20 top internet companies at the White House tomorrow to discuss internet security.

fields.headline: Tribal rivalry sparks killing spree
fields.standfirst: Fresh Congo catastrophe unfolds as 150,000 flee massacres which have claimed 7,000 lives
fields.trailText: A violent ethnic war is raging between two tribes who have lived side-by-side for centuries in the north-east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, regularly practise inter-marriage and speak a common language.
fields.byline: David Gough  in Bunia, Democratic Republic of Congo
fields.body:
A violent ethnic war is raging between two tribes who have lived side-by-side for centuries in the north-east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, regularly practise inter-marriage and speak a common language.

As many as 7,000 people have died and hundreds of thousands more have been displaced from their homes since the conflict - fuelled by the civil war in Congo and the breakdown of law and order - erupted last June between the Hema and Lendu tribes.

"This is just a fraction of what we have removed," said Dr Tshulo Ngandju, as he emerged from his hospital looking tired and began sifting through the pile of arrowheads that he was carrying in a metal surgical tray. He pointed to one that still held pieces of torn flesh and dried blood in its barbs.

What began as a dispute over land has now degenerated into an all-out war that the authorities in this part of Congo seem unable, or unwilling, to stop.

Lendu people, who had been driven off their land by Hema landowners seeking to expand their plantations, took to the bush, formed militias and began raiding Hema villages in retaliation. Attack and reprisal - increasingly barbaric and brutal by turn - have marked the conflict since then. Last month more than 400 Hema were massacred in the market town of Blukwa.

Dr Ngandju was one of the first to reach Blukwa after the killers retreated back into the bush. He recalls countless bodies, many mutilated beyond recognition, and the charred remains of people who had been thrown into burning houses.

Richard Lombu, standing next to a freshly-dug mass grave, also remembers the scene. He was there when the killers streamed down from the surrounding hills, chanting war cries. He said that Lendu women and children were also involved in the massacre, "carrying baskets of arrows to resupply the fighters and burning the houses they over-ran".

But for every Lendu-led massacre there is a tale of Hema-led violence to match. Edward Ngorima, the chief of the Lendu village of Saliboko, said that more than 40 died there during an attack by Hema militias three weeks ago, precipitating the flight of thousands of Lendu into the bush.

This pattern is common and has led the aid organisation, Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), to estimate that there are up to 150,000 people living in desperate conditions in the bush. The humanitarian situation has reached catastrophic proportions. Incidences of cholera and measles are on the rise and there are even cases of bubonic plague. Desperate people have taken refuge wherever they can find it.

At night in the grounds of the Gate to Heaven Catholic Mission in Drodro the air is heavy with the hum of uncertain voices. These people have lost their homes and family members have been killed. Above all they are scared of the militias that come in the night to kill them.

"They cut off genitals or limbs. I've seen lots of bodies like that. They cut out hearts and brains and sometimes they eat the parts they remove," said Mateso Kodjo, who was the headmaster of a village school until it was burned down last July. "We are here because we think it is a safe place. But there is little food and when it rains we have no shelter and we can't build a fire to cook or keep warm at night."

Aid organisations are finding it increasingly difficult to reach these displaced people. MSF pulled out of the region last month after one of its convoys was attacked by a Hema militia, and the few agencies still operating in the area are now mostly restricted to the capital town of Bunia, leaving the displaced without the emergency food and medical supplies they so desperately need.

The Hema and Lendu last clashed in 1975, but that violence was quickly stamped out by the government of the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. But since a rebellion against Mobutu's successor, Laurent Kabila, in 1998, the east of the country has fallen to the rebels and their backers, Uganda and Rwanda, who have seemed more interested in looting the resources of the areas they control than administering them.

Ituri province, where the majority of Hema and Lendu live, is nominally controlled by the RCD-ML rebel group and the Ugandan army that supports it. Jacques Depelchin, a spokesman for RCD-ML, said that everything was being done to find a political solution to the crisis, but that attempts at reconciliation looked increasingly difficult, particularly for those who had lost a family member.

"People of both tribes are under great pressure to follow a tribal line," he said.

webTitle: South African editors face jail threat

fields.headline: South African editors face jail threat
fields.trailText: Two prominent editors have received summonses from the South African human rights commission ordering them to answer accusations of racism or face prison terms.
fields.body:
Two prominent editors have received summonses from the South African human rights commission ordering them to answer accusations of racism or face prison terms.

Critics have said the commission's approach is similar to apartheid-era tactics aimed at silencing coverage critical of the government.

The editors of the Mail and Guardian, in which the Guardian Media Group has a majority share, and the Johannesburg Sunday Times were subpoenaed after a controversial investigation by the commission into racism in the media.

The inquiry was launched after associations representing black lawyers and accountants accused newspapers of "violating the fundamental rights of black people" through "subliminal racism" in stories which exposed corruption. Among its conclusions was a claim that a picture of two birds on a bin was racist because it was meant to represent decay under black rule.

The editors have been told to make themselves available for questioning to "shed light" on how their papers handle "the reporting of, and commenting on, national and international affairs and events which impact on race and racism".

The summonses also require them to provide the minutes of all meetings at their newspapers and any other documentation which might have a bearing on the hearings. If the paperwork is not supplied, the commission has extensive powers of search and seizure.

The editor of the Mail and Guardian, Phillip van Niekerk, said he was "unlikely" to obey the summons. He said the paper had written to the commission trying to clarify the nature of the accusations but had not received an adequate response.

The chairwoman of the South African newspaper editors forum, Lakela Kaunda, acknowledged racism in the media but said summonses and threats of imprisonment were "a contravention of the freedom of the media clauses in the constitution".

fields.headline: Cyanide spill floods into Danube
fields.trailText: A flood of toxic cyanide 40km long washed down the River Tisza in northern Yugoslavia yesterday accompanied by a tide of dead fish, spreading the poison further downstream into the Danube and adding to the toll of environmental destruction across central Europe.
fields.body:
A flood of toxic cyanide 40km long washed down the River Tisza in northern Yugoslavia yesterday accompanied by a tide of dead fish, spreading the poison further downstream into the Danube and adding to the toll of environmental destruction across central Europe.

The spill, which originated in northern Romania, where a dam at the Baia Mare gold mine overflowed last month and caused cyanide to flow into streams, has not been diluted to a safe level despite winter rains.

"If I am pessimistic, I would say that life in the River Tisza will never recover from this," said Elemer Szalma, a hydro-biologist from Szeged in southern Hungary. "If I am optimistic, I would say it will take 10 to 12 years to recover."

On Friday fishermen stretched nets between barges in Szeged, and removed five tonnes of dead fish. So far 300 tonnes have been removed from the Tisza, and from the river that carried the pollution into Hungary, the Szamos.

The concentration of cyanide in the Tisza in Szeged on Friday was 2.4mg per litre, compared with 30mg per litre in the Szamos earlier in the week. Biologists say that any level above 0.02 mg per litre is harmful to life. The spill was moving at about 2.5mph.

In Szeged hundreds of people gathered on bridges to throw flowers into the Tisza, which is much loved in Hungary, where it is regarded as cleaner and more beautiful than the Danube. Its fish are highly prized, and the fish soup from Szeged, spiced with paprika, has until now been a national delicacy.

Nevertheless, some places have escaped the poison tide. Imre Molnar, a waiter at the Gorbe Csarda fish restaurant at Poroszlo, beside the Tisza lake, said it was business as usual. A dam had saved the lake and health and safety inspectors have given its fish a clean bill of health.

Elsewhere, however, there was bad news. "This is not a local problem, this is an international ecological disaster," Attila Juhasz, mayor of Senta in the Yugoslav province of Vojvodina, told the independent Belgrade radio, B2-92 yesterday. He estimated that 80% of the fish in the Tisza where it flows through Senta were dead. By midday yesterday 600kg of dead fish had been removed.

Mr Szalma said: "Even if we reintroduce fish into the river, they will die of starvation because the food chain has been completely broken".

Yugoslav officials added their voices to Hungarian and Romanian demands for compensation from the Australian company, Esmerelda Exploration Ltd, which is based in Perth and owns a controlling share in the gold mine.

But company representatives in Perth have played down the disaster.

"There is no doubt that a significant amount of water overflowed the dam," said Brett Montgomery, chairman of Esmerelda Exploration, "but this is not an ecological catastrophe."

He estimated that 80% of the fish in the Tisza where it flows through Senta were dead. By midday yesterday 600kg of dead fish had been removed. Yugoslav officials added their voices to Hungarian and Romanian demands for compensation from the Australian company, Esmerelda Exploration Ltd, which is based in Perth and owns a controlling share in the gold mine. But company representatives in Perth have played down the disaster. "There is no doubt that a significant amount of water overflowed the dam," said Brett Montgomery, chairman of Esmerelda Exploration, "but this is not an ecological catastrophe."

webTitle: Head to head with Cosa Nostra

fields.headline: Head to head with Cosa Nostra
fields.standfirst: The coppola has been the emblem of the mafiosi and their regime of terror in Sicily for decades. Now the islanders are trying to reclaim it - and with it, their identity.  Rory Carroll  tells why a few determined villagers are risking their lives for the sake of a cloth cap
fields.trailText: The coppola has been the emblem of the mafiosi and their regime of terror in Sicily for decades. Now the islanders are trying to reclaim it - and with it, their identity.  Rory Carroll  tells why a few determined villagers are risking their lives for the sake of a cloth cap.
fields.body:
Halfway up a mountain, the village of San Giuseppe Jato is humming with new sewing machines. Each week a truck delivers rolls of cloth to a group of women in grey smocks. They distribute the rolls and return to their machines. The truck loads up with small cardboard boxes and trundles back into the valley.

It is from this village that mafia slyness, corruption and barbarity seeped across Sicily, and so, as the truck winds towards the coast, it is using the same road as the assassins, past crumbling houses - the legacy of twisted deals - and into Palermo port, from where the boxes are shipped, their task: redemption.

Jobs and rehabilitation, things Sicily craves but has been denied, are at stake this week. Models will strut down a Milan catwalk and into the world's gaze wearing the coppola of San Giuseppe Jato: a fashion-show debut of the cap of the mafia from the town of the mafia, made to defy the mafia.

This is a deadly serious attempt to revive an industry and wage cultural war against Cosa Nostra. Shows in Barcelona, New York, London, Paris and Tokyo will follow, accompanied by an exhibition, a blaze of publicity and, it is hoped, huge sales. Designers, entrepreneurs, politicians and intellectuals have mobilised to turn a cap associated with murder and intimidation into a fashion icon. The mobsters are gobsmacked.

San Giuseppe Jato is to be just the beginning. Another 312 communes have been sounded out as production centres. Such is their confidence - or desperation - they all said yes. An island inured to optimism after half a century of political killings is turning giddy. Can the years of waiting for a breakthrough - a chance to banish the mafia nightmare, rescue the economy and present a new Sicily to the world - be accomplished by something so simple? By a hat?

Historians have tried and failed to pinpoint the origin of the coppola, which appeared two centuries ago in Italy, Spain, France, Britain and Ireland. The brim and shape varied, but not by much. A 1783 Palermo dictionary of Sicilian-Italian-Latin recorded coppola as being connected to "birrittu", or beret. Dimensions were indicated with the variant names cuppulina and cuppuluni.

According to Giuseppe Pitre, a 19th-century chronicler, Sicilian men wore a "beret of brown cloth for the peasants, light blue for the seamen, which, folded, hung upon the right shoulder". Peasants with white coppolas were featured in an 1891 exhibition in Palermo, but most turn-of-the-century cinematographers who strived for pastoral imagery showed peasants bareheaded.

In some parts of Sicily the custom that only landed gentry had the right to wear a hat lasted into the 20th century. Bizarrely, a huge boost to the coppola's popularity was the arrival of the motor car. The peak shielded eyes from sunshine and kept rain from goggles, and the fit was tight enough to keep it on the head. Why carless peasants adopted it remains a mystery, but by the 1920s it was embedded in the language. "Tanto di coppola", hats off, was an expression of respect, and, according to some historians, may have been linked to its evolution as the mafia's headgear.

"As a little girl, I did not understand why sometimes the grown-ups whispered about coppole and coppole storte [twisted cap, a nickname for mafiosi], with oblique glances of fear, respect, reverence. As an adult, I understood," says Maria Maniscalco, mayor of San Giuseppe Jato.

Small, hard men, members of the Cosa Nostra had their own territory, code and hierarchy, a state within a state, so it was only natural they wanted their own uniform. The coppola was enough and it was perfect. Fifty years ago, virtually all Sicilian men had one, but mafia members wore it in a certain way. The peak could be tilted up or down, the brim straight or angled, the eyes revealed or hidden. It all meant something: rank, attitude or intent.

Mafia experts agree that the organisation's triumph was to make itself of Sicily, to manipulate symbols and mould the essence of identity until Cosa Nostra and Sicily became indistinguishable. Writers and film-makers caught on. By the time the aptly named Francis Coppola made The Godfather, in 1972, Robert De Niro and Al Pacino were compelled to wear it.

Friday's debut in Milan will be an attempt to reclaim history. Designers such as Gianfranco Ferré, Krizia and Missoni have spurned payment to come up with a range of styles for children, men and women, using plastic, cotton, iron, felt, lace, denim, tweed and python skin. There is a wedding coppola, a waterproof coppola, a knitted coppola, a spouting volcano coppola, a perfumed coppola, a coppola with zips, a coppola with eyes and a tongue, a coppola with false chocolates.

San Giuseppe Jato is 30km inland from Palermo, the island's capital. The higher the climb, the worse the road gets. Ears pop, the markings vanish, the surface turns gritty. Jato valley's greens and yellows sweep below, the mountain swirls into the clouds above.

A heavy fog veils oncoming traffic, but Guido Agnello, wiry and chainsmoking, is in a hurry. It was his idea six years ago to reclaim the coppola; now it is near fruition, he is a ball of nervous energy. "It must work! It will work!" he says. He is president of the Palazzo Intelligente foundation, which has tapped European Union and United Nations funds for cultural and economic initiatives. For the coppola project, there was only one place to start, the village of tattered, two-storey concrete blocks looming from the mist. Symbolism and economics demanded it.

This is the heartland of Costa Nostra, where 11 May Day picnickers were massacred in 1947, heralding an era of political assassination; where Bernardo Brusca and his son Giovanni masterminded their clan's carving up of contracts and rivals; where Baldassare Di Maggio opened a tomb to hide the two bazookas, two Kalashnikovs and two containers of plastic explosive intended for the mafia's greatest enemies: the judges Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino, and the mayor of Palermo, Leoluca Orlando.

The judges died in 1992, but the wave of revulsion that swept Sicily galvanised the state into doing something it should have done decades before: catch and jail Salvatore Riina, the boss of bosses. Cosa Nostra is not the force it was, but it endures, intimidating and corrupting.

The women receiving the new rolls of cloth know all this, but for them the new coppola factory is about jobs and pay packets where before there were none. There are seven of them working at three tables placed at the end of an 800 sq metre plant. It is their job to train others in the art of cutting, sewing and stitching. "My friends want to work here too," says Giulle Terese, 39.

Another 80 women work from home, each making up to 50 caps and £130 per week. The caps return to the factory for ironing, finishing, boxing and loading. A designer, Lina Giarratana, studies the methods and will return to her town of Ragusa, on the other side of the island, where 100 women are waiting for orders.

This was originally a plastics factory, but the owner, Giuseppe Taormina, gave the space and funding in exchange for 49% of the coppola profits. Sporting a matching mustard coppola and overcoat, he gestures at the empty space. "In the next few months we'll fill the rest of it. That's the plan, anyway."

Market research has been minimal, but Taormina is confident foreign consumers will fork out. Depending on the materials and design, prices will range from £10 to more than £100. And the enterprise is safe from racketeering, because the mafia cannot afford to provoke their own neighbours, according to Taormina. "Really, it's true."

For decades, outside investors have been deterred by sinister requests, backed up by threats, fires and bullets. Unemployment of more than 40% in a town of 8,000 left many young men in want of money and status. So they accepted the embrace of Cosa Nostra, completing a vicious circle.

"The coppolas are our best chance," says Maria Maniscalco. "We need this to work." She has been threatened, her car burned. The name of the town is stitched inside each cap. To become a brand is to be cleansed.

Back in the capital, Leoluca Orlando is holding court in the Santandrea restaurant. It is past midnight and his octopus is growing cold, but Palermo's mayor is warming to his favourite theme, destroying Cosa Nostra. The arms cache in San Giuseppe Jato cemetery never claimed him, but since the mafia sentenced him to death in 1987, he has had to sleep in police barracks and keeps bulletproof jackets in his office. This night there are three armour-plated cars with 10 bodyguards waiting outside.

But he is ebullient. "We've won. The mafia no longer controls the way we think. They still make deals and have money, but we are purging them from our culture and there's nothing they can do about it. Nothing."

He has a favourite simile: "Sicily is like a vintage wine. Rich and good but stuck inside the bottle because of the cork. We have to get rid of the cork, destroy the mafia."

Last week he startled the host of a German television chat show by whipping out a coppola just before the final credits. "It is the most powerful message we can send to the world that Sicily is no longer mafia." Maybe so. Maybe his bodyguards were just impatient to get home, but when he left the restaurant at 2am they looked twitchy and screeched away awfully fast.

No one, not the stitchers in San Giuseppe Jato, not the mayor, finds it odd that a fickle, glitzy audience in Milan should pass judgment on Sicily's dark, bloodsoaked past. If the road to redemption starts from a catwalk then so be it.

Cosa Nostra means our thing. The coppola is just a hat, but for an island of symbols, the moment those models sashay towards the cameras is the moment it announces to the world that it is no longer ashamed. It will be the cue to celebrate. The coppola will have become their thing.

webTitle: Hearts broken as love's martyr spurned

fields.headline: Hearts broken as love's martyr spurned
fields.trailText: The Italian town whose bishop Valentine was martyred in 273AD has discovered that its shrine is no protection from the politics of heartbreak.
fields.body:
The Italian town whose bishop Valentine was martyred in 273AD has discovered that its shrine is no protection from the politics of heartbreak.

Dozens rather than thousands of tourists turned up in Terni for Saturday's official opening of a month of celebrations for the patron saint of lovers. And only a handful of outsiders will join locals in admiring tonight's fireworks.

The town, just north of Rome, had hoped to transcend its industrial past by becoming the world capital of romance. Its basilica had been scrubbed, posters of hearts and cupid's arrows festooned the streets, a wedding exhibition was put on, and honeymoon packages were advertised.

But the hotels and restaurants are deserted.

Years of building up the festival were to have culminated this year with the boost from the Vatican's jubilee, or holy year of 2000, according to Bishop Franco Gualdrini.

Instead the festival has virtually died. This year there are no dancers from Brazil, famous sopranos, or street-size Valentine's day cakes.

However, the basilica's traditions do survive. Yesterday 200 engaged couples received benedictions, and today the basilica will be thronged by tens of thousands of locals celebrating their saint's holiday.

But the dream of making Terni the world capital of love has collapsed. "There was fighting in the council over how to promote it. People could not agree on strategy and ideas, so in the end they didn't have any," said Maria Elisabetta Fontana, president of Umbria's hotel reservation centre. Not one tourist had booked into her four-star 67-room Valentino hotel.

The town needs tourism to survive the eventual winding down of its steel mills and chemical plants. Situated in Umbria's landscape of valleys, snow-capped mountains, olive groves and terraced vineyards, it was hoped that St Valentine could attract some of the tourists who flock to nearby Assisi, Spoleto, Orvieto and Perugia.

Although officially the Vatican does not recognise Terni's St Valentine, nor another 16 Valentines in the encylopedia of saints, the town, and some historians, consider its martyr to be the progenitor of the ro mantic cult - Valentine is said to have assured eternal love to a young couple by giving them a flower from his garden.

The difficulty has been that Terni, uniquely in Umbria, is ugly. Allied bombs destroyed its Roman and medieval heritage, and afterward it was rebuilt with brutalist concrete tower blocks. For years a debate raged over how to harness its patron saint, whose alleged remains are housed in the basilica half a mile outside town. An alliance of politicians, business people and clergy formed the San Valentine Foundation, hotels and shops renamed themselves after the saint, and a trickle of Japanese tourists arrived.

The resignation of the entire city government over a budget dispute stalled momentum last year. Speaking above a jazz band, Enrico Melaseccha, a former mayor, gestured at the near-deserted opening ceremony. "This used to be full of people." And while Terni boasts the 165-metre Marmore waterfall, Europe's biggest, an industrial dispute has closed it to tourists.

Optimism endured however. In the tourist office, Paola Alunno waited patiently. "I'm not worried. There will be visitors today, tomorrow and for the whole month."

Inside the basilica, Paolo Rinelli, the parish priest, was making final preparations. "Love never dies," he smiled.

fields.headline: Once a boy racer...
fields.standfirst: Who are the real monsters of the road? The government thinks 17-year-olds are the problem, so it's proposing to raise the legal driving age. But, says  Laura Spinney, they are not targeting the right people
fields.trailText: Who are the real monsters of the road? The government thinks 17-year-olds are the problem, so it's proposing to raise the legal driving age. But, says  Laura Spinney, they are not targeting the right people.
fields.body:
Ask the average road user what image is conjured up by the phrase "boy racer" and they are likely to describe a strutting adolescent driving an Escort XR3i, with spoilers, yellow foglights and extra bass speakers, who practises handbrake turns in the local car park. That is just the kind of undesireable that the government's transport select committee might wish to eliminate with its new scheme. But evidence presented to the committee last September suggests that, if so, it could be targeting the wrong group. According to the new findings, your worst driving nightmare is more likely to be in his early to mid-20s, earning a good salary and wearing a suit.

In general, drivers in their teens and 20s are twice as likely to be killed or seriously injured as thirtysomethings, and the risk for men is double that for women. If the government's recommendation is made law, the earliest you will be able to drive solo will be 18. With a year's experience under their belts, the thinking goes, young novices will cause less havoc on the roads.

The proposed scheme is arguably unfair to women, who have a better road safety record, and to the less well-off who may be twiddling their thumbs for a year because they don't have access to a family car or long-suffering relative. But more importantly, it might leave untouched the real offenders who give young male drivers such a bad name. According to Dr Steve Stradling of the Transport Research Institute at Napier University in Edinburgh, who carried out the research, "Boy Racer" is something of a misnomer.

He and his colleagues interviewed around 800 drivers and found that of those who had been penalised for speeding in the previous three years, or who admitted to a tendency to speed, most were men aged between 21 and 40. They are more likely to come from households with an annual income in excess of £40,000, and they fall into the top socioeconomic brackets - A, B and C1. They tend to drive newer, more powerful cars (minimum engine size 1.8 litres), to live out of town and to clock up a large mileage - in excess of 20,000 miles a year. And the worst offenders are in the Midlands.

Dr Stradling had expected to find the bulk of the problem in a younger, poorer sector of the population, with the predictable aftershock later on, among older drivers of company cars. But company cars account for only 8% of the British car fleet, and surveys of this kind have generally overlooked those whose work requires them to drive their own cars. Factor that in, he says, and it immediately becomes obvious that driving for work is a large part of the problem. One in three of those who drove every working day and drove more than 14,000 kilometres a year had been penalised for speeding.

Speeding drivers are 50% more likely to have been involved in a crash than those who observe the limits, he says. Newly qualified drivers are undoubtedly a hazard, but the chances are they are driving smaller cars at lower speeds. A few years down the line, it's a different story. "They will be driving a half-way decent motor, and they'll be driving a lot," he says. "But they're still young enough to be suffering the effects of testosterone."

Not everyone agrees. Professor John Groeger, a psychologist at the University of Surrey, is suspicious of any attempt to point the blame at young men, whatever car they drive. Right across the age range, he says, males drive between twice and three times as much as females do. They are inevitably at a higher risk of being involved in an accident. If you take mileage into account, there is actually very little difference in the accident rates between men and women under 20. "I think there's a tendency to stigmatise certain groups," he says. "As far as young men are concerned we're not seeing the whole picture." In terms of accidents, he adds, pen sioners are just as dangerous as young males - per mile covered.

But according to Andrew Howard, its head of road safety, it is concerned about what it sees as an attitude problem among young drivers, particularly young males, who seem to view driving as an expressive activity rather than a practical one. The last study it commissioned in this area was published in 1992, though Howard says its findings are still valid. The two groups were then put through a battery of tests that included asking them to define a good driver. It's worth noting that all the respondents picked from the initial cohort were male because there weren't enough unsafe female drivers to control for gender. And some of their answers were "quite stunning", says Howard. webTitle: 'They wanted to give us a good scrubbing'

fields.headline: 'They wanted to give us a good scrubbing'
fields.standfirst: Susannah and Trinny. They do fashion but not as we knew it. They were born posh but know how to be slutty - and in four years they have made £10m.
fields.trailText: Susannah and Trinny. They do fashion but not as we knew it. They were born posh but know how to be slutty - and in four years they have made £10m.
fields.body:
There are worse jobs in the Metropolitan police force these days than standing on guard outside Peter Mandelson's Notting Hill flat. The secretary of state for Northern Ireland's, as we all know, keeps himself pretty much to himself. But downstairs . . . oh the goings-on. The comings, the goings, the steady stream of brightly dressed young things, sometimes as many as 30 a day, female to the last pashmina. The deliveries, the take-outs, the flash of Polaroid and velvet, the bouquets, the Miu Miu heels. Bet it was never like this round Mo Mowlam's.

Downstairs are the headquarters of "The Girls", as everybody calls them. Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall . . . No, that's not right. Susannah and Trinny . . . No, Suse and Trin . . . No, sorry, S and T. S&T are a couple of crazy happening big business chicks. They won't mind being called chicks. Trinny doesn't mind being called a flat-chested, short-legged craterface either. Susannah begs you to see her as a big-titted sumo arm wrestler. You can talk about their tits as much as you like. They do. And not just Susannah's which are "famous for their firmness", but Trinny's "pancake-flat boobs" too. And their bums. Trinny's is "low-slung", Susannah's is . . . well maybe that's enough for now.

But it's talking about bums and tits which has got them where they are today - at the helm of a multi-media empire, valued in December at £10m and rising. It started four years ago with a page, Ready to Wear, in the Telegraph's Weekend section. It was fashion, but not as we knew it. They were photographed looking gawky and awkward in clothes that didn't suit them ("We Don't Like") and they were photographed looking gawky and awkward in clothes that did. You'd have heard of Constantine from her days dating David Linley (she of the tartan taffeta and velvet headband in Tatler's social pages). And Woodall, with her imperious long face, looked like posh totty too.

But they didn't lord it, they slutted it. They found things to rave about in Oasis and Top Shop, they poured scorn on, say, an ill-fitting Azzedine Alaïa. "We were like oddballs in the big world of fashion," says Trinny. "Pariahs," says Susannah. "They wanted to take us by the neck and give us a good scrubbing."

They got better and better at it. They cut their hair. Susannah learned to pose. Almost naked. Even 10 days after giving birth. "We realised," Woodall says, "that we had found a niche." And so Ready to Wear led to a TV show for GSB, a book, Ready 2 Dress: How to Have Style Without Following Fashion, published today, at the beginning of London Fashion Week, and Ready2Shop, an internet site ('To subscribe," says Trinny, "put the mouse over our bodies and double click"). Ready2Travel, Ready2Marry, and Ready2Divorce will soon follow, other sites dedicated to interiors, kids, entertainment and gardening.

Four years ago they were two posh girls with too much time on their hands. Now they have a staff of 30, an MD, whom they pay more than themselves ("and as we're working all the hours God gave us we're not going to pay ourselves 20 grand"), an ad company, a marketing company. Last week they addressed a group of 300 venture capitalists to raise another £20m. They talk about "brand" now, and "concepts" and "concepts versus reality". They are working within certain "parameters". And at one point Trinny says: "We'll certainly be investigating the possibility of working with interactive TV and mobile phone-based net applications."

Today, though, it is just meetings, meetings, meetings. They whirl in, the girls. We're in Trinny's flat, which is above the office. There are loads of rugs and Indian-ey objects and bookcases. Trinny, who has a strong jaw, is wearing lots of purpley layers. Everything is something-ey with Trinny. "I tell you why I'm dressed as I am," she says at intense high speed. "I plan. But last night I got to bed late and this morning I overslept so I'm actually wearing what I wore last night. I'm wearing a Dries skirt. That's Dries van Noten which I have lived in. I have probably worn this skirt about 50 times. What I love is the luxury of wearing velvet in the daytime. And these shoes from Tod's, they make this daytimey . . ."

She's also wearing a Kookaï jumper and a sleeveless top from Knickerbox: "It's my staple diet. I wear it in summer. Every day I wear one. I've got, like, 10 of them." Susannah is keen to emphasise that she is wearing Warehouse (an embroidered turquoise skirt) and a velvet-trimmed top she found in a little shop in Paris. Her tights are M&S. "You can see the label if you want," she says.

The word they always insist on is opposites. The fat and the thin. The technologically fascinated (T) and the technologically bored (S). The beautiful writer (S) and the bad (T). Susannah thinks Trinny's body is the "aspirational one" and that hers is more "accessible". Trinny says Susannah's "sweet" with the staff - "my girls" as she calls them: the girls' girls - and that she's the one who bawls them out. (Except that yesterday Susannah really lost it. "Somebody didn't ask permission to do something and it screwed up our day basically. It was a very small thing but it fucked me off so much I can't tell you." "But a justifiable fuck-off," says Trinny.) Trinny can be too "controlling", Susannah too "guilt-tripping and manipulative". "She's the initiator," says Susannah. "I'm the full-stop."

Trinny, 36, is also the talker. She has no secrets. She talks about her marriage to Jonny "Too Bad" Elichaoff, and how it was affected by problems she had with her mother. "There was six months when I didn't talk to her because there was a lot of strife in the relationship . . . " The years in which she tried to be like her father, a businessman, by slogging as a secretary in a commodities firm, "but I didn't have the finishing ability"; in which she lived on "bullshit, in a skin that didn't fit". She refers without embarrassment to a sister called Wiggles. She herself has been in therapy, she says, "for, like, years".

Susannah, 37 under those sulky brows, is much more guarded, more vulnerable. She spends a lot of time screwing a tissue into a hard ball. Her father, whose money came from shipping and property and who advised Thatcher, died three years ago; her older sister has been "a mother and best friend" to her. Susannah sobs a bit when she talks about this. A while ago, after a spell in fashion PR, and before she met Trinny (they were introduced by a mutual friend), she wrote a book about present-giving and there was a horrid article, in the Telegraph as it happens, saying she'd never done a day's work in her life. "And, I'm not joking, it made me cry for a year." She says she's found the Linley thing hard to shake off. "There's no doubt that it has helped open doors whatever, but it's still 'ex-girlfriend of . . .' It's, like, come on guys, it's 15 years."

She lives in Battersea and Leicestershire with Sten Bertelsen, who launched Death cigarettes, and he is an "amazing husband" and an "incredible father" to their 14-month-old Joe. But she suffered from post-natal depression after the birth, with terrible panic attacks. "I had only 10 days maternity leave which I would not do again." "For everyone's sake," adds Trinny drily.

Today, Susannah and Trinny, S&T, will be taking their seats, like any other British style guru, at London Fashion Week. They'll have front row for Elspeth Gibson, who designed Trinny's wedding dress last year and who they "lurve". Alexander McQueen they don't reckon they'll even get into. Wherever they are, they'll be sitting together. It's a partnership, a double act, after all. It's the relationship that's the secret of their success. It's the relationship that's the brand. And it's less scary that way. "I speak for both of us," says Susannah wincing, "when I say that those sorts of people absolutely terrify us."

Give or take the odd "Dries" or Joseph jacket, S&T will stick with the high street. Stick with the shops. Stick with what suits. Get them on that and the tips come thick and fast. So, whatever you do, don't buy Tracy Feith florals. "There's no difference and sometimes it is better cut in Warehouse," says Trinny. "If you want to make your legs look a little bit thinner, buy bigger shoes," says Suse. And if you're pear-shaped, they both shriek, Morgan's for you. "Great dresses with a ruffle like that, to the knee, with three-quarter sleeve which are fab," says Trin, who is still purring from a "really weird olivey, sagey-green, chiffony thing" she found in Hennes for 28 quid. And as for those enviable Marion Foale cardigans made for the petite out there, "Burn them, burn them, burn them," says Trinny. "M&S do a copy which is exactly the same. And Marion Foale designs it. Anyway," she adds, sizing me up, "they're too short-waisted for you and too knitty for your tits."

Trinny puts her head on one side. "I don't know," she says. "You see these fashion pictures sometimes and there's a nipple and piece of chiffon and what is it telling you? It's telling you that it's so inaccessible that it's a fucking piece of modern art." And you can't speak much plainer than that.

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: When Julia Moore came back to Leicestershire after living in India, she left her beloved old banger behind. But she's been missing it so much she's going back to get it. And she's going to drive it home - all 10,000 miles.
fields.trailText: Julia Moore
fields.body:
Why are you doing this?

To raise funds for a charity, Anchorage Shelters in Bombay (the UK version is Rescue a Child) which I became very attached to when I lived there. It provides Indian homeless children a home, food and a place to rest.

What's so special about the car?

It's a 1954 Fiat with a 1100 engine. A 50s car for a 50s girl and we're both in the same nick! The parts are Italian made and it was assembled in India. It's a precursor to the Panini taxi. Any car that's been designed to be a taxi has to be durable and reliable. It has a good engine but the bodywork isn't exactly waterproof. The Gujaratees call it a "Dukkar" which means pig.

What memories does it have?

Lots. I've had it for 5 years and couldn't bear to sell it. It would be like selling the pet dog. It's done a 1000 mile trip from Bombay to Bangalore - which are bad roads - and it didn't sneeze once.

Who will be your companion?

My step son Alexander.

What provisions will you take?

Lots of spares, tools, two spare tyres, tow rope, fire extinguisher.

Will you take any entertainment?

No - there's no need. I'll have Alexander to talk to and there'll be so much scenery to look at.

How long will it take you?

Two months. I'm hoping to be back in early May with a daily maximum of 250 miles - about five hours.

What scares you about the trip?

Not much. If I get stuck I have faith that the local people will help me. I believe in the fundamental goodness of man. I'll be very respectful of traditions and dress appropriately.

What routes will you take?

I'll go through Pakistan, Iran - Shiraz, Esfahan, Tabriz - crossing the border into Turkey, across the top of the Black Sea through the Turkish province of Cappadocia through to Troy and Istanbul. Then up the Dalmation coast through the Balkans which will be beautiful scenery, through Albania (although I'm not sure how safe that will be), then Slovenia, Italy, then France and home.

Is there anything you don't like about the car?

I hate the thought of it crumbling away some time. I wish it was new.

What kind of driver are you?

With this car, I'm very aware of its age so I'm gentle. If I was driving something more robust I would be speedy.

Any bad habits when you're driving?

I go for all the gaps.

How will you keep in touch with people back home?

I'll be emailing updates to my husband who can then keep everyone up to date.

What will you do with the car afterwards?

It'll have to have a strict MOT within 24 hours of arriving back in the UK. I'll give all the village school kids a ride - it'll be like a donkey at the village fare.
