The parts are Italian made and it was assembled in India. It's a precursor to the Panini taxi. Any car that's been designed to be a taxi has to be durable and reliable. It has a good engine but the bodywork isn't exactly waterproof. The Gujaratees call it a "Dukkar" which means pig. What memories does it have? Lots. I've had it for 5 years and couldn't bear to sell it. It would be like selling the pet dog. It's done a 1000 mile trip from Bombay to Bangalore - which are bad roads - and it didn't sneeze once. Who will be your companion? My step son Alexander. What provisions will you take? Lots of spares, tools, two spare tyres, tow rope, fire extinguisher. Will you take any entertainment? No - there's no need. I'll have Alexander to talk to and there'll be so much scenery to look at. How long will it take you? Two months. I'm hoping to be back in early May with a daily maximum of 250 miles - about five hours. What scares you about the trip? Not much. If I get stuck I have faith that the local people will help me. I believe in the fundamental goodness of man. I'll be very respectful of traditions and dress appropriately. What routes will you take? I'll go through Pakistan, Iran - Shiraz, Esfahan, Tabriz - crossing the border into Turkey, across the top of the Black Sea through the Turkish province of Cappadocia through to Troy and Istanbul. Then up the Dalmation coast through the Balkans which will be beautiful scenery, through Albania (although I'm not sure how safe that will be), then Slovenia, Italy, then France and home. Is there anything you don't like about the car? I hate the thought of it crumbling away some time. I wish it was new. What kind of driver are you? With this car, I'm very aware of its age so I'm gentle. If I was driving something more robust I would be speedy. Any bad habits when you're driving? I go for all the gaps. How will you keep in touch with people back home? I'll be emailing updates to my husband who can then keep everyone up to date. What will you do with the car afterwards? It'll have to have a strict MOT within 24 hours of arriving back in the UK. I'll give all the village school kids a ride - it'll be like a donkey at the village fare.

fields.headline: Road test
fields.standfirst: Fiat Multipla
fields.trailText: Fiat Multipla
fields.body:
The Fiat Multipla is a creature that had its face set on fire and then hastily put out with a cricket bat; gourdish fruit from the ugly tree that hit every branch on the way down; it's a duck-billed platypus. Its roofline is so square you could fit plaster coving inside, it is to chic design what Tommy Cooper was to ballet. But the Multipla has hidden dynamic potential. Because its rubber is banished to the furthest outposts of its chassis and the vehicle is designed to have a three-three seating configuration (so there's a middle seat in the front and the back) it is broad and grippy.

Sitting in any seat, you soon start to marvel at how much free airspace there is within the cabin. The Multipla is intended to carry six people and all their baggage in less space than it takes to park a Fiat Bravo hatchback. It manages, largely because the windscreen projects forward over the bonnet, allowing the final length of the body to be shunted inwards. The boot has 430 litres of bag-hungry space and the design does tend to make a mockery of some of the more Leviathan people carriers out there, such as the Ford-VW-Seat Galaxy-Sharan-Alhambra buffet car, not to mention Fiat's own Ulysses, known by some as the Fiat Useless.

By contrast, this is the Fiat Useful - which is probably why is just won Top Gear's car of the year award. The middle seats both double up as tables and the front one can be replaced with an optional storage unit that both heats and cools whatever you like to consume en route. Despite all the seating trickery, each seat has a proper three-point belt and - a definite boost for fraught families - panoramic views, the glass-to-metal ratio of the entire car being even-Steven.

The standard kit is all the sort of stuff you'd expect, but highlights include ABS, electrically flap-backable door mirrors and a six-speaker sound system. For power, you can choose between a 44mpg smooth and capable two-litre turbodiesel or a 32mpg 1.6 petrol which is more entertaining. And the good news is that the livelier 1.6 is, in SX spec, priced competitively at £13,380, which, for a car that will turn heads far more effectively than any Porsche, seems entirely generous.

fields.headline: Sympathy for the fantasist
fields.trailText: What was the "public interest" involved in the defamation trial judge's ruling that Lynn Walker could be named? Wasn't the punishment of losing the case, having £400,000 damages awarded against her, and becoming penniless enough?
fields.body:
What was the "public interest" involved in the defamation trial judge's ruling that Lynn Walker could be named? Wasn't the punishment of losing the case, having £400,000 damages awarded against her, and becoming penniless enough? Was it really necessary to make it a complete humiliation by ensuring that this pathetic fantasist would have her whole past and present dug up by the tabloids and will now find it almost impossible to get her life together again?

The arguments against me are that other men must be warned against her (I can see them now, checking yellowing newspaper cuttings to make sure the woman they're talking to isn't Lynn Walker); that all other losers in libel cases - indeed litigants in almost every type of case - have their names exposed, so why should she be an exception (since when has consistency been a hallmark of the law?); and that the anonymity rule for rape complainants is there to help genuine victims, not fake ones.

That last has some validity, but not enough to tip the balance towards disclosure. My point has nothing to do with whether or not her loss of anonymity will lead to fewer women reporting rape. It is that the punishment is disproportionate to the act.

She did a very bad thing and made an innocent man suffer. He's now achieved some satisfaction and recognition of his ordeal. She doesn't deserve complete and devastating ruin.

I do hope, though, that Martin Garfoot's elation at winning the case doesn't turn sour. Yes, he's been publicly cleared of the horrible accusations against him - but he probably won't see a penny of the £400,000. Even if Lynn Walker is worth a few tens of thousands of pounds (there is a house) it will all go to pay Garfoot's lawyers. Defamation so often goes wrong for winners as well as losers. A few years ago Dr Malcolm Smith won £150,000 slander damages from his partner in their medical practice, Dr Alanah Houston, over false allegations of sexual harrassment.

She had no money to pay either the damages (reduced to £50,000 on appeal) or any of his substantial legal costs. But he then didn't have enough to pay his own solicitor, who sued him. As a result, Dr Smith lost all his money, his house and his practice. The direct result of winning his case was financial and emotional destruction.

It is, I know, difficult to believe that the Law Society has managed yet another embarrassing own-foot shooting. I'd thought that an institution whose next president is at this very moment the subject of harrassment complaints and has herself accused the current president of bullying her had reached the depths of the cock-up barrel.

But no. It's now been revealed that it has changed the date of its annual conference. Why? Because it clashed, this year, with the Hindu festival Diwali. And it happens that the next president presumptive is Kamlesh Bahl, a Hindu, who apparently made it clear that she wouldn't be able to attend the Birmingham bash. A presidentless annual conference loomed. A change was privately agreed, but leaked prematurely. The Law Society then claimed it was the local law society in Birmingham that had asked for the change, so Hindu solicitors could attend. A terrible excuse. Anyway, the national society's explanation has been blown for another reason. The Birmingham lot has now made it sniffily clear that the change had nothing to do with them, but had been imposed from London. The saga continues.

A curious change has overcome the BBC in reporting recent developments in the Pinochet case. You'll remember Jack Straw said he was "minded" to send the ex-dictator home to Chile, on medical grounds. About two weeks ago, I noticed that BBC bulletins were no longer saying the home secretary was minded, etc; instead, he was reported as being "inclined" to send Pinochet back.

I've listened carefully since, and, whoever the reporter or newsreader, have heard only "inclined" used. Call me Picky the Pedant (thousands do) but I don't think that "minded to" and "inclined to" are the same. Minded suggests a pretty strong intention, not easily displaced, whereas inclination is a rather weak, vague preference. Putting it in figures, "minded to" is a firm 90% oak of an intention; "inclined to" a 55% sapling, which a slight wind can blow the other way. The change of word changes the state of Straw's mind. Besides, he'd used a perfectly good word; why substitute another?

fields.trailText: In a report headed Connex purges top posts, page 25, February 8, we reported "industry sources" as saying that the company's chief executive Antoine Hurel was being recalled to Paris and that his senior colleague Geoff Harrison-Mee was also to be replaced. Mr Hurel says that this is untrue and that netiher he nor Mr Harrison-Mee are being replaced in their functions with Connex. He adds that, on the contrary, they have the full support of shareholders and remain very much involved in Connex's franchise bid.

Mr Hurel says that this is untrue and that netiher he nor Mr Harrison-Mee are being replaced in their functions with Connex. He adds that, on the contrary, they have the full support of shareholders and remain very much involved in Connex's franchise bid.

Frances Cranbrook, the Bournemouth university research fellow, mentioned in an article headed Rise of the silver surfers, page 8, Online, February 10, is female and not male as our misspelling of her first name as Francis may have suggested. Apologies.

We published a letter on page 23, February 10, from Richard Denton-White, identifying him with the words Electoral Reform Society. We had edited out the words "speaker for the [Electoral Reform Society]", a capacity in which he last performed just before Christmas. The Electoral Reform Society has now asked us to correct any impression we may have given that Mr Denton-White was officially authorised to speak for the society which, it says, is not the case.

In our magazine, The Editor, page 3, February 11, we referred to the Six nations rugby [union] tournament in which we said "Wales thrashed France" - a possibly partisan way of interpreting the actual result: Wales 3, France 36.

fields.headline: The net strikes back
fields.standfirst:
We responded with a perverse sense of joy to the havoc wrought by hackers on the big web corporations

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: We responded with a perverse sense of joy to the havoc wrought by hackers on the big web corporations.
fields.body:
I know it's wrong. But to me, the most sobering aspect of the recent spate of hacker attacks on major American corporate websites is that the offenders and their indirect accomplices appear close to being punished.

Amazingly, at least among my friends and students, our initial reaction to news of the sabotage was one of perverse glee. We just couldn't repress our feelings, however illogical we knew them to be.

Admit it: for one brief moment, the campaign of denial-of-service attacks brought a smile to your face. What could account for such widespread ambivalence about a clearly illegal and destructive campaign? Because it's refreshing, that's why.

Over a few days last week, a rather simple programme temporarily paralysed the most established and profitable websites in the world. The attack programme worked by asking the target website for more information than it is capable of dispensing.

With all its resources tied up, the website is forced to deny service to the millions of users who want access. The site goes down.

This digital Molotov cocktail was distributed widely on hacker bulletin boards, so the perpetrator could be anyone, or even different hackers working independently. First, they incapacitated the most popular website in the world, the Yahoo search engine, which went down for hours as engineers struggled to restore order. Then they hit Amazon, CNN, eBay and buy.com.

These are not randomly chosen websites. The hackers didn't attack schools, charities or communities. They attacked commerce. Why?

Those of us who were enjoying the internet back in the 80s and early 90s remember a time when this technology was about communication. Businesses weren't even allowed on the net.

In those days, the interactive media space felt like a cross between a college campus and the Wild West. It was a level playing field, where the size of your computer and the contents of your wallet meant nothing.

The internet changed the way people thought about media and power. The net didn't seem like a particularly safe place - but since when are revolutions safe?

The introduction of business to the internet changed all that. Corporate behemoths ignored the indigenous net population as they colonised our space.

Companies conducting e-commerce needed to make the online environment more secure - in reality and in appearance. They're asking for our credit card information, after all.

The look and feel of the internet changed as users were converted into consumers. Buy more, talk less. This is not a playground, they meant to say; this is business.

"Technology has changed not only the way people do business; it has changed the way criminals do business too," US Attorney General Janet Reno explained in a press conference last week, contextualising the attacks in the prevailing American parlance of commerce.

Her cause-and-effect analysis is backwards. Business has changed the way people do technology, and now the people are fighting back.

Double-click and other advertisers have no qualms about planting cookies on our hard drives and hacking or tracking us; maybe it's time they learnt what it feels like.

Most well-known hackers have publicly distanced themselves from such denial of service attacks, calling them crude. Time magazine and other conglomerate-related outlets are only too willing to publicise these sentiments. But the fact is, this set of crude electronic pipe-bombs worked.

They may be unsophisticated by hackers' standards, un-American by the FBI's standards, and unsportsmanlike by free-market capitalist standards, but as far as changing public perception about the internet goes they were, at the very least, effective. Don't tell me that these attacks didn't make you give a second thought about the valuation of your Nasdaq portfolio.

This month's attacks prove that the internet is not as impenetrable as the opaque interface of the world wide web might suggest.

It reminds us that the online universe was developed with public funds, and that corporate America has been getting a free ride on a civic highway. They are guests, not landlords.

It's also fascinating to watch how rapidly these Silicon Valley CEOs - outspoken advocates of smaller government and deregulation - run for protection under Janet Reno's skirt now they are under attack.

It will be public funds and resources that keep cyberspace safe for the techno-libertarians.

Don't get me wrong: however much I'd like to, I can't condone cyber-terrorism. In the long run, we all pay for it. But the mere fact that our initial response is not one of fear, but rather of perverse joy, means that on some level we resent the companies that now dominate our information space.

Rather than just looking for ways to shore up their defences, perhaps these companies should consider why they are under attack.

 Douglas Rushkoff is a professor of media theory at New York University. His book, Coercion: Why We Listen to What 'They' Say, will be published by Little Brown in April

webTitle: Good news for jobless people confounds the fashionable forecasters

fields.headline: Good news for jobless people confounds the fashionable forecasters
fields.standfirst: Outdated concept leaves godfather with some explaining to do
fields.trailText: The good news for the government is that unemployment is at its lowest for 20 years. The even better news is that on current trends the number of claimants will be below a million by the time of the next election. The bad news is that the treasury and the Bank of England believe that it is too good to be true.
fields.body:
The good news for the government is that unemployment is at its lowest for 20 years. The even better news is that on current trends the number of claimants will be below a million by the time of the next election. The bad news is that the treasury and the Bank of England believe that it is too good to be true.

This sense of foreboding explains why the Bank's monetary policy committee nudged up rates for the fourth time in six months last week, and it explains why Gordon Brown was standing in the shadows applauding while they did so. Don't get me wrong. There is nothing the chancellor would like more than to have the jobless total down to 500,000, but nagging away at the back of his mind is the fear that if unemployment continues to fall it may only be because the economy is growing excessively fast.

This, of course, is precisely what happened at the end of the 1980s. Unemployment fell impressively between 1986 and early 1990, but the decline was illusory because the Lawson boom was unsustainable. Any fool can bring down unemployment or make the public finances look good when growth is running at 4% or 5% a year, but in the end there is a reckoning. That is what Brown wants to avoid at all costs.

The idea, however, that Britain is in the midst of a second Lawson boom is preposterous. In 1985-1988 the economy grew by 4.4% a year, well in excess of any estimate of its long-term potential. In 1996-1999, it expanded by 2.5% a year, bang in line with the treasury's view of its trend growth rate. Over the same period, the unemployment claimant count has halved to 1.16m and inflation has fallen.

All this is rather baffling to the Bank and the treasury. Taking just one example at random, the Bank's inflation report of August 1998 expressed concern about the growth in earnings which it said suggested "that unemployment is more clearly below its natural rate than was then [three months earlier] thought". With the national minimum wage due to kick in the following spring, the bank said that in the short-term earnings growth would accelerate still further. "But in the medium term, there is likely to be a rise in unemployment, reflecting a period of below-trend output growth, that brings down earnings growth before the two-year forecast horizon."

It is unfair to pick on the Bank alone. One of the more august City firms was forecasting that unemployment would have to rise by 500,000 to keep inflation in check. The treasury's fiscal arithmetic, likewise, is predicated on unemployment some half a million higher than its present level. None of the numbers spewing out of econometric models seems to relate to the real world.

For those of us who believe that the three witches from Macbeth would have a better chance of forecasting the economy correctly than an econometrician, this hardly comes as a surprise. For policymakers in the UK, on the other hand, it is a bit troubling since they all believe in the concept known as the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment, developed in Britain in the 1980s by Richard Layard, Steve Nickell and Richard Jackman.

Central to the idea of Nairu was that demand alone would not cure unemployment, especially long-term unemployment, and that there were supply- side problems - the structure of wage bargaining, the level of benefits - that prevented the attainment of full employment. Any attempt to push unemployment below the Nairu using macro- economic policy would lead to higher inflation. The key was microeconomic measures to deal with structural impediments to job creation.

This seemed to fit neatly with life as it was in the late 1980s, but in Britain and US the theory has been discredited by events of the 1990s. The main problem is that it tends to move all over the place. When unemployment was around 10%, the Nairu was thought to be around 8%; now that unemployment is around 4%, the Nairu is thought to be around 5% to 6%. As unemployment has come down so have the estimates of the Nairu, which makes it useless in the conduct of monetary policy, even as an intermediate target.

In the US, Alan Greenspan has recognised this, and has stopped worrying where the Nairu is or whether it exists at all. He has kept demand robust, constantly but gradually pushing unemployment down and taken a risk that inflation would not start to rise. So far, his approach has been vindicated.

One way for the circle to be squared would be if the Nairu had been lowered by extensive supply-side reforms during the 1990s, but in neither Britain nor the US has this been the case. Most of the micro changes took place in the 1980s but still did not prevent unemployment from rising sharply in the early 1990s. Labour-market rigidities have not diminished in the 1990s; on the contrary, to a modest extent they have increased, especially in the UK, where the introduction of the minimum wage and the legislation making it easier for unions to organise should have theoretically raised the level of the Nairu.

In these circumstances, it is fascinating that Nickell - one of the godfathers of the Nairu - has now been appointed to the MPC. As an acknowledged expert in the workings of the labour market, he is just the man to explain why the Nairu has seemingly gone on the blink.

Less useful

One possible theory is that it was developed for a particular and highly unusual period and is now less useful as a policy tool. Western economies suffered from two severe oil shocks in the 1970s, and the determination to combat inflation resulted in a prolonged period of contractionary economic policies. Unemployment that would have been short-term in more normal circumstances became ingrained.

But if the 1980s were exceptional, policies that were inappropriate then might be perfectly appropriate now. The facts seem to suggest that unemployment can come down quite a long way without reigniting inflation and that the right amount of macroeconomic expansion can create jobs, even for those who were seen as unemployable five or 10 years ago. It is possible that the global economy has reverted to a more normal pattern, with generally low in flation combined with much lower levels of unemployment. Indeed, there may be nothing wrong with the allegedly sclerotic economies of Germany and France that a decade of robust expansion would not put right.

So what are the prospects for a new golden age, for the high and stable level of employment that the chancellor said was his goal on the day he gave the Bank operational independence? Given the right mix of economic policies, not bad. That does not mean abandoning all supply-side reforms in favour of a wild dash for growth, nor that the Bank is always wrong to raise rates, but that structural reforms have to be embedded in the right macroeconomic policies.

Naturally, a more complete understanding of what is happening in the labour market would help deliver this, since it would prevent the MPC from crossing the line between being pre-emptive and trigger happy. By all accounts, the chancellor has taken to holding meetings in Downing Street with the MPC and selected left-leaning academics to discuss Keynes and full employment in the 21st century, a heartening development which suggests that sanity is returning to economic policy after the dark days of monetarism.

The Bank, with its 16 changes in base rates in 33 months, has already indicated a willingness to indulge in what used to be called Keynesian fine-tuning. So how about this nugget from the General Theory for the next get-together? "The remedy for the trade cycle is not to be found in abolishing booms and keeping us permanently in a semi-slump; but in abolishing slumps and keeping us permanently in a quasi-boom." Discuss.

fields.headline: US model may 'bankrupt more firms'
fields.trailText: Key parts of the government's insolvency bill - aimed at bringing Britain closer to the American model of corporate bankruptcy - may increase the number of companies going into receivership, top accountants have warned.
fields.body:
Key parts of the government's insolvency bill - aimed at bringing Britain closer to the American model of corporate bankruptcy - may increase the number of companies going into receivership, top accountants have warned.

By ordering firms to disclose that they are in a "debt moratorium", the government is in danger of ensuring nobody will do business with them, said Grant Thornton .

Under the bill's present draft, troubled companies will be given a 28-day breathing space in which they can reorganise their affairs without the threat of bankers or other creditors plunging them into receivership or liquidation.

But clause 15 of the bill's first schedule requires any firm taking advantage of this moratorium to print the fact on every invoice, order or business letter, even to vans and lorries carrying their names. Failure to do so could result in a fine.

This, said GT partner Martin Ellis, makes it less, not more, likely that the firm's suppliers and other creditors will continue to trade with them.

Mr Ellis added that many firms would find it difficult to trade through the 28-day period, let alone through any subsequent voluntary arrangement with creditors.

The bill results from a pledge given by the then trade and industry secretary Peter Mandelson to the Confederation of British Industry conference in autumn 1998, in which he promised to move Britain's regime for corporate and per sonal bankruptcy closer to US models. This pledge followed a speech earlier in the year to the British-American Chamber of Commerce, in which he said: "I think we need fundamentally to reassess our attitude towards business failure.

"In the US, some investors prefer to back businessmen with failures under their belt because they appreciate the spirit of enterprise and the experience gained. In Britain ... most banks will run a mile from someone who has experienced business failure."

webTitle: Time for Japan to stock up

fields.headline: Time for Japan to stock up
fields.trailText: Japan is once again sliding back into recession yet the Nikkei stock market index is soaring. Either investors in the equity market are blind to the macroeconomic indicators or they know something the rest of us do not. Which is it?
fields.body:
Japan is once again sliding back into recession yet the Nikkei stock market index is soaring. Either investors in the equity market are blind to the macroeconomic indicators or they know something the rest of us do not. Which is it?

In normal circumstances, most sane investors would be running for cover.

Economists at US investment bank Goldman Sachs say that confidence is actually quite buoyant despite widespread job losses. Analysis of Japan's job statistics shows that most of those who are joining the jobless queue are doing so voluntarily.

Encouraged by new opportunities in more profitable sectors of the economy, such as wholesaling and retailing, medical/health care services and corporate services, young people are saying goodbye to manufacturing and in doing so laying the foundations for a sustained upswing in economic growth.

"There are strong similarities between the US 'jobless recovery' of the early 1990s and the current Japanese scenario of intersector migration for jobs and excess employment," says Goldman. "During 1991-1993, employees in US manufacturing and construction declined by 1m and 460,000 respectively. Employment shifted to relatively low-wage retail and rose on the back of outsourcing in corporate services and health care services. Corporate earnings swung around to double-digit growth in manufacturing and construction, the sector that shed excess jobs."

Goldmans is not alone it its optimism about Japan. Giles Ockenden, strategist at Jardine Fleming, predicts a marked acceleration in mergers and acquisitions, driven by financial deregulation, legal reform and foreign competition. As long as the economy keeps ticking over, this will ensure that profitability is restored and that the future for Japan is bright, he implies.

But even Mr Ockenden is not blind to the risks. The rebirth of the Japanese economy remains heavily depedent on a number of lucky breaks.

He said three things kept him awake at night. First, Japanese consumers might stop spending. Second, export demand from the US could dry up. And third, the government might begin to put up taxes and/or reduce public spending.

The latter two risks are by no means negligible. So far the mighty US economy shows scant evidence of slowing down, ensuring that demand for imports from Japan and elsewhere remains buoyant, but the danger of a hard landing remains.

Although fiscal consolidation can be discounted before this year's elections, there is a real possibility that it might begin once they are over. With Japan's debt level soaring, everyone agrees that belt tightening by the government will be needed at some point. Choosing the right time to do it, however, will be crucial for the prospects of sustained economic recovery.

The government got it wrong in 1997, when it began raising taxes before recovery had taken hold. It could make the same mistake again.

webTitle: Formula One chief courts German buyer

fields.headline: Formula One chief courts German buyer
fields.trailText: Bernie Ecclestone, the Formula One boss, is thought to be seeking to offload to a German media firm his $2.7bn (£1.7bn) racing business.
fields.body:
Bernie Ecclestone, the Formula One boss, is thought to be seeking to offload to a German media firm his $2.7bn (£1.7bn) racing business.

Mr Ecclestone, the country's richest person according EuroBusiness, had hoped to sell another 37.5% stake in his Formula One Administration business to Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, the venture capital arm of Deutsche Bank which stumped up $325m (£203.8m) for a 12.5% share last October.

However, the venture capitalists at Morgan Grenfell last week decided not to take up the option Mr Ecclestone granted to them when they made their initial investment. An insider at Morgan Grenfell said last night: "We're happy with that 12.5% stake".

Ecclestone is instead thought to be in talks with EM.TV, a German media company, which might take an even bigger chunk - as much as 75% - in the Formula One business. It is understood that EM.TV wants to buy the stake by using its own equity. This suggests that Mr Ecclestone would have to settle for an equity stake in EM.TV, rather than realise any cash through the sale of his business.

Neither Mr Ecclestone nor EM.TV could be reached for comment last night, but it is no secret that Mr Ecclestone is looking for a way to float his company.

He first tried to float it two years ago, but had to abandon it when details of European Union investigation into television contracts with Formula One was revealed.

Morgan Grenfell Private Equity's acquisition of a 12.5% stake in October was regarded as a step towards that goal. The company is thought to have touted the idea of invest ing in Formula One to other European investors, but decided against increasing its own investment.

Mr Ecclestone had been thought to be hoping to float the business next year and has been reported to be considering "sweeteners" for the Formula One teams who share in the television income if the flotation succeeds.

Sources indicated that it was hardly surprising that Mr Ecclestone was talking to more German backers given that one of his bankers is the German bank WestLB.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

The chairman of Jellyworks, the internet wonder stock, mysteriously walked away from a £20m profit on share options before he abruptly quit last week.

Volkswagen has made an audacious bid to acquire the UK's Rover car and Land Rover businesses from rival German carmaker BMW. However BMW strongly denied it was in talks to run its troubled UK operations in a joint venture with its arch-rival.

Sunday Business

Orange chief executive Hans Snook will pocket around £30m as a result of Vodafone's £113bn takeover of Mannesmann. The deal triggers early payment of the package Snook agreed with Mannesmann when it brought Orange last October.

Around 750 British jobs could be lost if the Government does not award a £300m ministry of defence contract to Racal Electronics. A decision is expected this week.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee runs the risk of becoming a "dumping ground" for the "mediocre and the brain dead", according to Willem Buiter, an outgoing committee member.

Sunday Times

The mystery bidder at Liberty, the upmarket London department store, is Marylebone Warwick Balfour, a fast-growing property group. Liberty, valued at £52m and chaired by Philip Bowman, said on Friday it was in "very preliminary talks" that might lead to a takeover, but it did not reveal the identity of the suitor.

Selfridges is planning a giant, futuristic new 200,000 square feet store for the revamped Bull Ring centre in the heart of Birmingham. Architects behind the new and controversial media centre at Lord's cricket ground, Future Systems, are the front-runners to design the building which is expected to look strikingly modern.

Sunday Telegraph

Singer & Friedlander, one of the City's last independent merchant banks, is in takeover talks with a US financial group in a deal that would value one of the Square Mile's oldest denizens at as much as £500m.

Pringle, the golfers' brand, is set to be sold to Kenneth Fang, the Hong Kong knitting tycoon. The deal, worth an estimated £10m, will be announced early this week by Dawson International, the troubled Scottish clothing manufacturer.

Sunday Express

Standard Life is looking at spinning off its highly successful banking arm for more than £1bn as a possible last-ditch defence against a forced conversion. A sell-off of Standard Life Bank could yield about £500 for each of the Edinburgh-based insurer's 2.3m members.

webTitle: Bangkok trade delegates say no to liberalisation

fields.headline: Bangkok trade delegates say no to liberalisation
fields.trailText: Debate: simplistic theories of the automatic and universal benefits of trade liberalisation have never stood up to scrutiny.
fields.body:
Simplistic theories of the automatic and universal benefits of trade liberalisation have never stood up to scrutiny.

And Michael Moore, the head of the World Trade Organisation, is a worried man. His organisation could soon be sharing the fate of many modern workers - downsizing. As the WTO obviously bit off more than it could chew at the debacle in Seattle, people are searching for a more legitimate body to deal with global economic issues.

Attention has turned to a lesser-known body, Unctad - the United Nations conference on trade and development - meeting now in Bangkok. It has what the WTO lacks: the confidence of developing countries. Given the right power and resources it could help overcome failings in the international system.

The untold story of Seattle is that many members of the establishment knew all along that the protesters on the street were right.

"WTO obligations reflect little concern for development and little appreciation of the capacities the least developed countries have," wrote the World Bank's head of trade policy in a low-profile briefing paper. The bank's then chief economist, Joseph Stiglitz, said that poor countries were being left with "neither trade nor aid". It was "not surprising that critics of liberalisation raise cries of hypocrisy".

Critically, he admitted that less developed countries faced greater economic volatility and that "opening to trade contributes to that volatility".

These revelations are not new. Trade economist Paul Krugman once wrote that there is a "dirty little secret" in the analysis of international trade which hides the fact that the costs of protectionism are not all that large, while the empirical evidence of great benefits from liberalisation is at best fuzzy.

Whereas the WTO has become identified as a tool of the rich and an advocate of unthinking liberalisation, Unctad is a more open, democratic forum and a more cautious critic of globalisation.

Mistrust of transnational corporations - the chief players in the global economy - is at the heart of the WTO's crisis of legitimacy.

Rubens Ricupero, the head of Unctad, argues that the ability of poor countries to negotiate with foreign corporations is often limited.

Weak bargaining, he believes, can result in an "unequal distribution of benefits or abuse of market power" by corporations.

Unctad estimates that poor countries that are told to open their markets lose $700bn (£4.9bn) each year in low-tech industries alone - approximately 14 times total aid-giving - because rich countries will not practise what they preach.

The current system is geared for conventional growth, but economists realise that, beyond a certain point, growth is "ushering in a new era of 'uneconomic growth' that impoverishes rather than enriches".

The challenge is to regulate the global economy to allow development at the local level. Britain has plans to protect and develop its own rundown local economies that are directly equivalent to the differential treatment needed by poor countries but denied by the principles of the WTO.

There is poetic justice in the WTO's public fall from grace. When an international trade organisation was first proposed with a comprehensive remit, significantly, it was the US, in 1950, which failed to ratify its existence. When the WTO attempted the grab the same broad influence 50 years later, the developing countries withdrew their consent. Now there is stalemate.

The WTO should not have authority over everything. It would be like expecting the department of trade and industry to run Britain. But a regulatory vacuum exists at the global level; rules and institutions we take for granted nationally are missing.

To work, the WTO needs to be part of a family of global government. Its rules must be subordinate to internationally agreed targets for social and environmental development. In this new family, Unctad is far better placed to lead discussion on prickly issues, such as the role of multinational companies, investment, tax evasion and the growth of monopolies.

Unctad's head wants it to become "a world parliament on globalisation".

It would be infinitely preferable to the unbalanced, one-legged beast we suffer now. Unctad and the rest of the UN must assert themselves and stop cowering before the jaws of US-dominated institutions.

 Andrew Simms is head of the global economy programme at the New Economics Foundation

It has what the WTO lacks: the confidence of developing countries. Given the right power and resources it could help overcome failings in the international system. The untold story of Seattle is that many members of the establishment knew all along that the protesters on the street were right. "WTO obligations reflect little concern for development and little appreciation of the capacities the least developed countries have," wrote the World Bank's head of trade policy in a low-profile briefing paper. The bank's then chief economist, Joseph Stiglitz, said that poor countries were being left with "neither trade nor aid". It was "not surprising that critics of liberalisation raise cries of hypocrisy". Critically, he admitted that less developed countries faced greater economic volatility and that "opening to trade contributes to that volatility". These revelations are not new. Trade economist Paul Krugman once wrote that there is a "dirty little secret" in the analysis of international trade which hides the fact that the costs of protectionism are not all that large, while the empirical evidence of great benefits from liberalisation is at best fuzzy. Whereas the WTO has become identified as a tool of the rich and an advocate of unthinking liberalisation, Unctad is a more open, democratic forum and a more cautious critic of globalisation. Mistrust of transnational corporations - the chief players in the global economy - is at the heart of the WTO's crisis of legitimacy. Rubens Ricupero, the head of Unctad, argues that the ability of poor countries to negotiate with foreign corporations is often limited. Weak bargaining, he believes, can result in an "unequal distribution of benefits or abuse of market power" by corporations. Unctad estimates that poor countries that are told to open their markets lose $700bn (£4.9bn) each year in low-tech industries alone - approximately 14 times total aid-giving - because rich countries will not practise what they preach. The current system is geared for conventional growth, but economists realise that, beyond a certain point, growth is "ushering in a new era of 'uneconomic growth' that impoverishes rather than enriches". The challenge is to regulate the global economy to allow development at the local level. Britain has plans to protect and develop its own rundown local economies that are directly equivalent to the differential treatment needed by poor countries but denied by the principles of the WTO. There is poetic justice in the WTO's public fall from grace. When an international trade organisation was first proposed with a comprehensive remit, significantly, it was the US, in 1950, which failed to ratify its existence. When the WTO attempted the grab the same broad influence 50 years later, the developing countries withdrew their consent. Now there is stalemate. The WTO should not have authority over everything. It would be like expecting the department of trade and industry to run Britain. But a regulatory vacuum exists at the global level; rules and institutions we take for granted nationally are missing. To work, the WTO needs to be part of a family of global government. Its rules must be subordinate to internationally agreed targets for social and environmental development. In this new family, Unctad is far better placed to lead discussion on prickly issues, such as the role of multinational companies, investment, tax evasion and the growth of monopolies. Unctad's head wants it to become "a world parliament on globalisation". It would be infinitely preferable to the unbalanced, one-legged beast we suffer now. Unctad and the rest of the UN must assert themselves and stop cowering before the jaws of US-dominated institutions.  Andrew Simms is head of the global economy programme at the New Economics Foundation

webTitle: Grade wins place on Camelot board

fields.headline: Grade wins place on Camelot board
fields.trailText: Michael Grade, the former Channel 4 chief executive and Millennium Dome director, will take on Sir Richard Branson in the race to run the national lottery after joining the board of Camelot yesterday.
fields.body:
Michael Grade, the former Channel 4 chief executive and Millennium Dome director, will take on Sir Richard Branson in the race to run the national lottery after joining the board of Camelot yesterday.

With the bid deadline for the lottery licence fast approaching, Camelot and the People's Lottery consortium put together by Sir Richard are cited as the only serious contenders.

Mr Grade will join as a non-executive director at Camelot, which holds the franchise to run the lottery. The company said it believed Mr Grade's media expertise would help its "detailed and innovative" pitch.

The 57-year-old, on holiday in the Maldives yesterday, has spent more than three decades in the media industry and was recently involved in the restructuring of First Leisure.

This weekend he was said to be working on a £50m bid for the Pinewood Studios where hundreds of British films - such as James Bond and the Carry ons - and documentaries have been shot.

The studio is owned by Rank which refused to comment on the sale yesterday while the only statement released by Mr Grade was in regard to his appointment at Camelot.

He highlighted the role he expected interactive television was likely to play in the lottery in the future, a feature which the rival People's Lottery consortium is addressing through a link with Microsoft.

"Interactive media provides us with the opportunity to offer new and entertaining ways to play the national lottery in the future. As with all new technology, it is how we use it that counts, in particular the measures that we are able to put in place to prevent excessive and underage plays," Mr Grade said.

Camelot has been revamping itself ahead of the bidding process, recently naming Diane Thompson as the new chief executive, on a sharply reduced salary to her predecessor.

webTitle: IMF chief says: 'We are best friends of the poor'

fields.headline: IMF chief says: 'We are best friends of the poor'
fields.standfirst: Unctad Camdessus bows out with staunch defence of record in helping developing nations
fields.trailText: The outgoing head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus strongly defended his organisation's role in managing the world's poorest economies - after an anti-globalisation protest threatened to disrupt the United Nations meeting he was addressing.
fields.body:
The outgoing head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus strongly defended his organisation's role in managing the world's poorest economies - after an anti-globalisation protest threatened to disrupt the United Nations meeting he was addressing.

In a feisty farewell speech, Mr Camdessus said poverty was the greatest menace to humanity and insisted that the IMF and the World Bank were "the best friends of the poor". But shortly before he began speaking, the French former central banker became the latest international diplomat to be cream-pied.

As Mr Camdessus prepared to deliver his key-note speech at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad), a man stepped forward from the audience and smeared the official's face with a cake. Mr Camdessus quickly removed the remains of the pie and the protester was speedily removed by security staff.

Mr Camdessus refused to press charges against Richard Reuel Naiman, 34, of Washington D.C., representing a group called Fifty Years Enough - which campaigns for the abolition of the World Bank.

The IMF is an object of hate for many activists who blame its orthodox economic prescriptions - high interest rates and budget belt-tightening for worsening the pain of countries that run into balance of payments problems and seek bailouts. Last week, one development campaigner described Mr Camdessus as a "war criminal".

At his last press conference with the IMF, Mr Camdessus made light of the latest attack, calling it "professional risks, part of my job".

Tight security from police who have closed off most of the area surrounding the conference centre has prevented a repeat of the street protests which disrupted the Seattle world trade talks last November.

Earlier in the day, some of the 300 trade unionists camped on the boundary of the exclusion zone managed to break through the police line.

Mr Camdessus suggested that the protesters outside the centre and those who disrupted the trade talks in Seattle were fundamentally misguided. "Globalisation can now be seen in a positive light, not what some have portrayed it to be - a blind malevolent force that needs to be tamed," he said.

Mr Camdessus also said that, as part of the "new paradigm", an expansion of information technology has given poor nations access to knowledge that was once the preserve of the rich. The 66-year-old suggested that the annual summit of rich nations should address mounting criticism that globalisation was benefiting rich nations at the expense of the poor. In questions after his speech, Mr Camdessus brushed over charges that the fund's handling of the Asian crisis two years ago had deepened poverty unnecessarily. He said that Thailand, the country where the crisis began, had graduated "summa cum laude" from the fund's programme for the affected economy, with industrial output back at pre-crisis levels. He said the rapid recovery in all the Asian economies vindicated the IMF's approach.

"It is very touching that he has discovered human development so late in his career," said Martin Khor, head of the Third World Network, a Malaysian think-tank. "It would be more convincing if he admitted we need this new paradigm because the old paradigm has failed."

Unctad issued a report saying that the number of least developed countries - the world's poorest nations - had risen since 1971 from 25 to 48, with 33 in Africa.

The least developed countries are "becoming increasingly marginalised in the world economy," Unctad secretary-general Carlos Fortin said. "There's no greater challenge facing the international community today than integrating the less-developed countries into the world economy and trading system."

fields.headline: Cable firm offers flat-rate internet
fields.standfirst:
Telewest
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: From today 4.5m homes will have cheaper access to the internet as a result of a move by Telewest to charge a flat £10 monthly fee for dialling up the worldwide web.
fields.body:
From today 4.5m homes will have cheaper access to the internet as a result of a move by Telewest to charge a flat £10 monthly fee for dialling up the worldwide web.

The decision by the second largest cable company, which is merging with rival Flextech, came as a new survey showed that such unmetered access could triple people's use of the internet.

Until now, users of the net have faced not knowing how much their telephone bills will be each time they log on.

The government wants flat-rate charging to become more common as part of its strategy to thrust the country to the front of e-commerce.

Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, said: "I warmly welcome Telewest's new internet offer. We want to see more flat rate internet services on offer."

Telewest's SurfUnlimited will be the first unmetered access to the net in the UK, although British Telecom is planning to introduce its own version of the service.

Telewest said it already had 15,000 of its 1.5m customers pre-registered for the service which it first announced last year. Telewest calculates that people using the net an average of 30 minutes a day could save up to £15 a month.

To register, customers would need to subscribe to a Telewest phone line, at a cost of £9.99, and use the number for £10 worth of conventional calls a month too.

According to research published today by Durlacher, a specialist e-commerce firm, the introduction of such charges would increase the frequency of people's internet access from their homes by 46% and the duration of their sessions by over 100%.

Durlacher's research, based on interviews in 4,000 homes, found that over a third of all adults now use the internet somewhere, either at work, home, university or school, while domestic use has risen to 17% of British homes from 11% last year.

fields.headline: Worries over Versailles loans worries
fields.trailText: Versailles, the collapsed trade finance group at the centre of a Serious Fraud Office enquiry, conducted deals with the son of founder Carl Cushnie totalling nearly half a million pounds, The Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Versailles, the collapsed trade finance group at the centre of a Serious Fraud Office enquiry, conducted deals with the son of founder Carl Cushnie totalling nearly half a million pounds, The Guardian has learned.

These transactions took place through the group's controversial "MP" financing package. Separately, Versailles holding company Marrlist lent more than £250,000 to companies controlled by Carl Cushnie Junior, one of which publishes Pride, a magazine for high-flying black Britons.

These loans troubled auditors to Marrlist who noticed in the 1998 accounts that "(these) companies ... have net liabilities, which therefore create doubt as to the recoverability of these loans".

Interest was charged at the favourable rate of 1% above the base rate of Royal Bank of Scotland, one of Versailles' main bankers.

With receivers crawling through the wreckage of Versailles, it is possible they will end up in effective control of Pride and the other Carl Cushnie Junior company i2i.

It was the latter company that in the financial year 1997/98 conducted "MP" deals with Versailles totalling £495,209. The MP package involved Versailles financing small and medium sized companies through every stage of the manufacturing process. The way it was accounted for may have inflated Versailles' turnover by 30%.

Department of trade and industry investigators voiced concern about MP early last year when they were probing the collapse of an unrelated company with which Versailles had done business. This led to Versailles appointing outside accountants who were unable to give MP a clean bill of health. The company went into receivership earlier this year owing its banks approximately £60m.

Since then, it has emerged that Versailles used a system of parallel financing by a club of wealthy individuals to bankroll its deal.

Attention has also turned to the identity of firms with which Versailles was supposed to be conducting business. It is believed some of these may not have been trading.

In the previous financial year, 1996/97, i2i transacted MP deals worth £389,863 with Versailles. In 1997/98 Marrlist lent i2i £135,928 and lent Pride £114, 621.

Marrlist is the ultimate parent of Versailles, holding Mr Cushnie's majority stake in the group.

In the most recent accounts this was given as 59.29%, but in November last year he sold about 5%, then worth some £29m.

Given that he was aware of the inquiry and the market was not, this sale has attracted a great deal of criticism.

webTitle: 'Being an opera star seems entirely normal. I never felt for one second of my life that I would not be here now'

fields.headline: 'Being an opera star seems entirely normal. I never felt for one second of my life that I would not be here now'
fields.standfirst: The astonishing soprano Angela Gheorgiu talks to  Nicholas Wroe
fields.trailText: It seems an unlikely tale now, but there was a time when the Royal Opera House made headlines for its on-stage events and not just for its seemingly endless roll call of off-stage disasters. The return on Friday to Covent Garden of Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu provides a timely reminder in physical form of the way things used to be - at least occasionally.
fields.body:
It seems an unlikely tale now, but there was a time when the Royal Opera House made headlines for its on-stage events and not just for its seemingly endless roll call of off-stage disasters. The return on Friday to Covent Garden of Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu provides a timely reminder in physical form of the way things used to be - at least occasionally.

Gheorghiu is singing opposite her husband Roberto Alagna, "the fourth tenor", in Gounod's sumptuously romantic reworking of Shakespeare, Roméo et Juliette. The couple's earlier recording of the work has been highly praised and the production has been the quickest sell-out since the opera house reopened in December. But while both public and critical acclaim is widely anticipated, it is safe to say that it will not match the intensity of response afforded a previous Gheorghiu performance on the same stage.

In 1994 the relatively unknown singer was cast as the doomed courtesan Violetta by Sir Georg Solti in Richard Eyre's staging of La Traviata. There was already something of an industry buzz building around the young lyric soprano but even Solti - who admitted to having cried when he first heard her sing - was unprepared for the ultimate impact she would make. Just a few days into rehearsals everything changed. Solti took the virtually unheard of step of abandoning a commitment to record the work six months later with a different cast and persuaded his record company that it should be done there and then with Gheorghiu. He then called the BBC to invite the director general Michael Checkland and the controller of BBC2, Alan Yentob, to the first night. They followed Solti's example and cleared both the BBC2 and Radio 3 schedules. La Traviata was broadcast live the following Saturday evening to an audience of 1.5m. The people's opera indeed.

Jeremy Isaacs was general director of the ROH at the time. "You only get one chance in life to hurtle through barriers and make yourself a star and she seized it so unerringly that one was left gasping in admiration. There are all sorts of moments in the history of the artistic world when you think, 'I wish I had been there when that happened'. That was one of those nights."

But while Gheorghiu's emerging talent had catapulted her out of the narrow focus of the opera world and into the cultural mainstream, it was developments in her private life that pushed her celebrity into a new dimension. It was during the run of La Traviata that she had embarked on an affair with Alagna, who had been widowed a few months earlier aged only 31. Gheorghiu obtained a divorce from her husband in Romania and the couple married in 1996. In what sounds like a scene from a publicist's dream the ceremony was conducted by the mayor of New York while the pair were in the city starring opposite each other as lovers in Puccini's perennial tearjerker La Bohème at the Met.

The Alagnas had become opera's golden couple and seemed determined to take full advantage of it. They switched agent to the same man who represented Charles Aznavour and Liza Minnelli, and engaged the same New York publicist that handled Pavarotti. But in an industry where being difficult is hardly a novelty, their increasingly demanding approach soon became a source of worried comment.

At Covent Garden they were called "the Ceausescus", and Gheorghiu was dubbed "La Petite Draculette" at the Bastille opera in Paris. Jonathan Miller, who worked with them both separately, resisted national stereotyping and settled instead for Bonnie and Clyde - although to be fair, he also said that while he was expecting big trouble from Gheorghiu, he got very little. But while the old joke about the difference between a soprano and a terrorist - you can negotiate with a terrorist - still has a certain chilly comic resonance, recently there has been a drying up of Gheorghiu horror stories.

Whether singing opposite Alagna or on her own, the body of work she has produced is remarkable. Their recording of Puccini's La Rondine was Gramophone magazine's 1997 record of the year, Duets and Arias sold over 200,000 copies, and she recently triumphed in the ambitious role of Charlotte in a new recording of Massenet's Werther. Her steadily growing stage repertoire includes L'Elisir d'Amore, Turandot and L'Amico Fritz.

The conductor Antonio Pappano, the next music director at Covent Garden, has worked with her since 1993 when he took her sight unseen for a production of Carmen. "Then I heard her voice and that was that," he says. "The next thing she was mega. In the recording studio I've never heard a voice so seductive to the microphone. Through very subtle inflection and colour she can convey very complex thoughts and emotions. She is innately musical and that transmits itself in recordings."

It all seems a long way from a childhood in Ceausescu's Romania in the 60s, where she grew up in a family that not only had no musical tradition, but no interest whatsoever in singing. "Not even la la la," she now laughs.

The Burlacu family - Gheorghiu is her first husband's name - lived in the small town of Adjud, 300km from Bucharest in the northern Romanian province of Moldavia. Her father was a train conductor and her mother a housewife. In this unprepossessing environment Angela and her younger sister Elena were from the beginning something of a local phenomenon. "We didn't have normal voices. Before I started school I sang with this voice. It was always sort of operatic."

But while the sisters' talent had come as a surprise to the family, there was never any doubt how it would be utilised. They performed in local concerts singing arias and lieder, and when Angela was 14 she was sent to the Liceu de Arte, a music school in Bucharest. Elena soon followed her.

Gheorghiu says that from the beginning it was clear to her, to her parents and her teachers that both girls' future would be as professional singers. "It was never like a dream for us," she says, "it was just the way it would be. It was so obvious."

But the sudden death in 1996 of her sister Elena in "an accident" when aged only 30 put paid to that dream. Gheorghiu moved on to the senior music academy in Bucharest when she was 18. It was while there that she married André Gheorghiu. She kept his name after they divorced on the advice of her record company. Contrary to the popular myth - that she dumped her plumber husband for Alagna when her career took off - André was in fact an engineer from an important musical family in Romania.

Gheorghiu herself pestered the authorities constantly for permission to travel abroad to enter competitions but without success. "While we were privileged in a way, they never even answered me even to say no. It was awful. But I finished the academy just at the right time. The revolution was in December 1989 and I graduated in 1990."

In fact Gheorghiu was one of the first Romanians to directly benefit from Ceausescu's overthrow. While it was still "boom booming" in Bucharest she took a phone call from a Romanian impresario working out of Frankfurt, who asked her to a recital for Dutch television.

Luisa Petrov had seen a video of Gheorghiu performing in Bucharest and says, "From the first moment it was obvious that she was a big talent. With other young singers you try to get them into small houses, but I sent Angela straight to Covent Garden. I was that convinced."

Following Petrov's prompting, Peter Katona, director of casting at the Royal Opera, invited Gheorghiu for an audition. "She sang three arias and I said, 'That's it, we'll do something'," says Katona. So despite having virtually no stage experience she made her debut at Covent Garden as Zerlina in Don Giovanni in February 1992. Alongside her was another young singer whose career also subsequently took off, Bryn Terfel.

Later that year Katona cast her in a production of La Bohème, where she first met Alagna, and then in Massanet's Cherubin, Carmen and Turandot where, in a piece of information that may come in handy for operatic trivia quizes, she shared the stage with the prime minister's son, Euan Blair, who as a 13 year old was a member of the children's chorus.

Richard Eyre went to Vienna to meet her and remembers her as something of an innocent, in that she had never originated a role in a major opera house. But he was still struck by her strong sense of her own destiny. "She was almost like the Dalai Lama; this girl from a small town in Romania with such a pure instinct for music - it was if she had been selected by fate. She does have a voice that can only be described as God-given. The way she acted and sang that part were indivisible. It wasn't quite artless energy, but there was an unbridled enthusiasm. As an actress she hadn't learnt to dissemble."

Gheorghiu relished the idea of the project being Solti's first Traviata, her first Traviata and Eyre's first opera. The combination produced a superstar. "When I tell people it was entirely normal and expected they don't believe me. But that's how it felt. I never felt for one second of my life that I would not be here now, that I would do something else. Everybody has said all my life that I would be a singer."

Pappano says that she is of course outspoken, "but if you're going to put a stamp on something that's what happens." He remembers an evening with the couple - "watching Jurassic Park in French on Roberto's big-screen TV" - when they laughed at all the names they are called by the press, "all the Ceausescus and Bonnie and Clyde stuff. I thought it was so healthy because you could take that to heart and let it destroy you."

Pappano is convinced there is more to come from Gheorghiu. "When, as in the preparation of an opera, you have a bunch of very competent and confident people in one room, it is rare for there to be one person with the power. She has such innate musicality, a beautiful voice and feel for opera in her bones that you must respect what she contributes. You can't just say, 'That's a bunch of crap'.
