fields.bodyText: It seems an unlikely tale now, but there was a time when the Royal Opera House made headlines for its on-stage events and not just for its seemingly endless roll call of off-stage disasters. The return on Friday to Covent Garden of Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu provides a timely reminder in physical form of the way things used to be - at least occasionally. Gheorghiu is singing opposite her husband Roberto Alagna, "the fourth tenor", in Gounod's sumptuously romantic reworking of Shakespeare, Roméo et Juliette. The couple's earlier recording of the work has been highly praised and the production has been the quickest sell-out since the opera house reopened in December. But while both public and critical acclaim is widely anticipated, it is safe to say that it will not match the intensity of response afforded a previous Gheorghiu performance on the same stage. In 1994 the relatively unknown singer was cast as the doomed courtesan Violetta by Sir Georg Solti in Richard Eyre's staging of La Traviata. There was already something of an industry buzz building around the young lyric soprano but even Solti - who admitted to having cried when he first heard her sing - was unprepared for the ultimate impact she would make. Just a few days into rehearsals everything changed. Solti took the virtually unheard of step of abandoning a commitment to record the work six months later with a different cast and persuaded his record company that it should be done there and then with Gheorghiu. He then called the BBC to invite the director general Michael Checkland and the controller of BBC2, Alan Yentob, to the first night. They followed Solti's example and cleared both the BBC2 and Radio 3 schedules. La Traviata was broadcast live the following Saturday evening to an audience of 1.5m. The people's opera indeed. Jeremy Isaacs was general director of the ROH at the time. "You only get one chance in life to hurtle through barriers and make yourself a star and she seized it so unerringly that one was left gasping in admiration. There are all sorts of moments in the history of the artistic world when you think, 'I wish I had been there when that happened'. That was one of those nights." But while Gheorghiu's emerging talent had catapulted her out of the narrow focus of the opera world and into the cultural mainstream, it was developments in her private life that pushed her celebrity into a new dimension. It was during the run of La Traviata that she had embarked on an affair with Alagna, who had been widowed a few months earlier aged only 31. Gheorghiu obtained a divorce from her husband in Romania and the couple married in 1996. In what sounds like a scene from a publicist's dream the ceremony was conducted by the mayor of New York while the pair were in the city starring opposite each other as lovers in Puccini's perennial tearjerker La Bohème at the Met. The Alagnas had become opera's golden couple and seemed determined to take full advantage of it. They switched agent to the same man who represented Charles Aznavour and Liza Minnelli, and engaged the same New York publicist that handled Pavarotti. But in an industry where being difficult is hardly a novelty, their increasingly demanding approach soon became a source of worried comment. At Covent Garden they were called "the Ceausescus", and Gheorghiu was dubbed "La Petite Draculette" at the Bastille opera in Paris. Jonathan Miller, who worked with them both separately, resisted national stereotyping and settled instead for Bonnie and Clyde - although to be fair, he also said that while he was expecting big trouble from Gheorghiu, he got very little. But while the old joke about the difference between a soprano and a terrorist - you can negotiate with a terrorist - still has a certain chilly comic resonance, recently there has been a drying up of Gheorghiu horror stories. Whether singing opposite Alagna or on her own, the body of work she has produced is remarkable. Their recording of Puccini's La Rondine was Gramophone magazine's 1997 record of the year, Duets and Arias sold over 200,000 copies, and she recently triumphed in the ambitious role of Charlotte in a new recording of Massenet's Werther. Her steadily growing stage repertoire includes L'Elisir d'Amore, Turandot and L'Amico Fritz. The conductor Antonio Pappano, the next music director at Covent Garden, has worked with her since 1993 when he took her sight unseen for a production of Carmen. "Then I heard her voice and that was that," he says. "The next thing she was mega. In the recording studio I've never heard a voice so seductive to the microphone. Through very subtle inflection and colour she can convey very complex thoughts and emotions. She is innately musical and that transmits itself in recordings." It all seems a long way from a childhood in Ceausescu's Romania in the 60s, where she grew up in a family that not only had no musical tradition, but no interest whatsoever in singing. "Not even la la la," she now laughs. The Burlacu family - Gheorghiu is her first husband's name - lived in the small town of Adjud, 300km from Bucharest in the northern Romanian province of Moldavia. Her father was a train conductor and her mother a housewife. In this unprepossessing environment Angela and her younger sister Elena were from the beginning something of a local phenomenon. "We didn't have normal voices. Before I started school I sang with this voice. It was always sort of operatic." But while the sisters' talent had come as a surprise to the family, there was never any doubt how it would be utilised. They performed in local concerts singing arias and lieder, and when Angela was 14 she was sent to the Liceu de Arte, a music school in Bucharest. Elena soon followed her. Gheorghiu says that from the beginning it was clear to her, to her parents and her teachers that both girls' future would be as professional singers. "It was never like a dream for us," she says, "it was just the way it would be. It was so obvious." But the sudden death in 1996 of her sister Elena in "an accident" when aged only 30 put paid to that dream. Gheorghiu moved on to the senior music academy in Bucharest when she was 18. It was while there that she married André Gheorghiu. She kept his name after they divorced on the advice of her record company. Contrary to the popular myth - that she dumped her plumber husband for Alagna when her career took off - André was in fact an engineer from an important musical family in Romania. Gheorghiu herself pestered the authorities constantly for permission to travel abroad to enter competitions but without success. "While we were privileged in a way, they never even answered me even to say no. It was awful. But I finished the academy just at the right time. The revolution was in December 1989 and I graduated in 1990." In fact Gheorghiu was one of the first Romanians to directly benefit from Ceausescu's overthrow. While it was still "boom booming" in Bucharest she took a phone call from a Romanian impresario working out of Frankfurt, who asked her to a recital for Dutch television. Luisa Petrov had seen a video of Gheorghiu performing in Bucharest and says, "From the first moment it was obvious that she was a big talent. With other young singers you try to get them into small houses, but I sent Angela straight to Covent Garden. I was that convinced." Following Petrov's prompting, Peter Katona, director of casting at the Royal Opera, invited Gheorghiu for an audition. "She sang three arias and I said, 'That's it, we'll do something'," says Katona. So despite having virtually no stage experience she made her debut at Covent Garden as Zerlina in Don Giovanni in February 1992. Alongside her was another young singer whose career also subsequently took off, Bryn Terfel. Later that year Katona cast her in a production of La Bohème, where she first met Alagna, and then in Massanet's Cherubin, Carmen and Turandot where, in a piece of information that may come in handy for operatic trivia quizes, she shared the stage with the prime minister's son, Euan Blair, who as a 13 year old was a member of the children's chorus. Richard Eyre went to Vienna to meet her and remembers her as something of an innocent, in that she had never originated a role in a major opera house. But he was still struck by her strong sense of her own destiny. "She was almost like the Dalai Lama; this girl from a small town in Romania with such a pure instinct for music - it was if she had been selected by fate. She does have a voice that can only be described as God-given. The way she acted and sang that part were indivisible. It wasn't quite artless energy, but there was an unbridled enthusiasm. As an actress she hadn't learnt to dissemble." Gheorghiu relished the idea of the project being Solti's first Traviata, her first Traviata and Eyre's first opera. The combination produced a superstar. "When I tell people it was entirely normal and expected they don't believe me. But that's how it felt. I never felt for one second of my life that I would not be here now, that I would do something else. Everybody has said all my life that I would be a singer." Pappano says that she is of course outspoken, "but if you're going to put a stamp on something that's what happens." He remembers an evening with the couple - "watching Jurassic Park in French on Roberto's big-screen TV" - when they laughed at all the names they are called by the press, "all the Ceausescus and Bonnie and Clyde stuff. I thought it was so healthy because you could take that to heart and let it destroy you." Pappano is convinced there is more to come from Gheorghiu. "When, as in the preparation of an opera, you have a bunch of very competent and confident people in one room, it is rare for there to be one person with the power. She has such innate musicality, a beautiful voice and feel for opera in her bones that you must respect what she contributes. You can't just say, 'That's a bunch of crap'. But if you are aware of what she has to offer, and balance that with your ideas, then it works just fine. When it comes together it is worth everything. When everybody puts the best of themselves in to something - my God, it is fantastic. And Angela is not only capable of giving the best of herself, she actually goes out there and does it." Roméo et Juliette, Royal Opera House, London WC2 (0171-304 4000), opens on Friday February 18 at 7pm.

fields.headline: G&S, Mike Leigh and me
fields.standfirst: As a child,  he shared an obsession for Gilbert & Sullivan with the family next door. Here,  Colin Shindler  recalls the subversive world of light opera
fields.trailText: As a child, he shared an obsession for Gilbert & Sullivan with the family next door. Here, Colin Shindler recalls the subversive world of light opera.
fields.body:
One of my earliest memories is of sitting on the floor of Mike Leigh's living room in north Manchester in the days when his family lived above his GP father's surgery. I was one of a group of children watching a puppet show written, produced and directed by Mike Leigh - or, as he would now no doubt phrase it, "devised and directed by Mike Leigh".

Mike's parents had known my parents since their teenage years in the 30s, when they had met in the Jewish youth movement Habonim. Mike and my brother Geoffrey also joined Habonim in due course. I was excused the Zionist propaganda and endless Israeli folk music on the grounds that I supported Manchester City and had therefore suffered enough.

The Leighs and the Shindlers formed part of a tightly knit group of a dozen or so Jewish families who remained loyally close until death eventually reduced their ranks. Today my father and Mike's mother Phyllis are two of the few who remain.

In this community the course of our lives was clearly marked out: primary school, 11 plus, one of the three grammar schools, university (probably Manchester or Leeds). Then into the professions (solicitor - there were few Jewish barristers - doctor, dentist, accountant), marriage, children, grandchildren, a seat in the synagogue by the eastern wall and presumably (though this wasn't emphasised), death.

Mike was the first to make the break for ideological freedom. I remember when the news reached our house that he was leaving Salford grammar school not for university but to study acting at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. A shiver ran down my spine. London, acting, the theatre: the possibilities of romance and glamour were endless.

This departure ended the embryonic artistic partnership of Mike Leigh and Geoffrey Shindler. When not engaged upon Habonim business they wrote articles for Punch, words by Shindler, cartoons by Leigh. They were much influenced by WS Gilbert and his Bab Ballads (his nascent anti-semitism notwithstanding), my brother endeavouring to echo Gilbert's satire, Mike inspired by Gilbert's bold drawings.

To us the Leigh house was a haven of artistic sophistication in the bleak north Manchester of the 50s. Lining the walls were framed cartoons of actors who had appeared at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre in Stratford. But the cement that joined us was Gilbert & Sullivan.

For six weeks every spring the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company took over the Opera House in Manchester and performed, as in a religious ritual, the entire canon of Savoy operas. The annual anticipation never wavered throughout my childhood and the first announcement of the schedule was rapidly devoured. Pirates, Pinafore, Patience, The Mikado, The Gondoliers, Ruddigore, Iolanthe and The Yeomen: the meal never varied and neither did the satisfaction. Princess Ida was the last of the Savoy operas to be revived after the war because the sets and costumes had been destroyed in the Blitz. The Leighs and the Shindlers eagerly seized upon it. Is it pure coincidence that Topsy-Turvy begins with the opening night of Princess Ida?

We believed the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company to be our friends. We knew the apostolic line of succession from George Grossmith to John Reed in order categorical, as the Major General would have said. I remember Mike telling me years later of his pleasure in finally meeting Reed, a quiet, inoffensive Liverpudlian most unlike the boastful cowardly roles we had observed him playing from the upper circle.

They were all our friends. Ann Drummond Grant who played the Katisha and Little Buttercup parts; Darrell Fancourt, the bass baritone who played the Mikado, the inheritor of the parts played by Timothy Spall in Topsy-Turvy; Thomas Round; Alan Styler; Donald Adams and Joyce Wright; even the gleaming bald pate of the conductor Isidore Godfrey: they came every year at the time of Passover and made the same gestures and spoke the same lines. From Seder Night to Titipu the ritual was comforting and unchanging.

By far the most worrying development in the late 50s was the approaching end of D'Oyly Carte's copyright. Gilbert had died in 1911 and 50 years thereafter the copyright on his works was due to expire. In 1962 Sadler's Wells came to Manchester with a new version of Iolanthe. The Lord Chancellor still collapsed at the end of the nightmare patter song and the chorus of Peers still married the chorus of overweight fairies. The world didn't come to an end but for the D'Oyly Carte, which had enshrined Gilbert's 19th century production values in holy writ, life would never be the same again.

For years now it has been a social stigma to hum a few bars of "The flowers that bloom in the spring tra-la", as if it conferred immediate membership of the Conservative party. This would come as a big surprise to my late Uncle Laurence, who presented to me his 1939 edition of the complete Savoy operas just before he stopped speaking to me for ever. Laurence Weidberg was a key figure in the Socialist party of Great Britain and the scourge of the Manchester Guardian for its wishy-washy left of centre political views and its refusal to hire him as their cricket correspondent just because he ran a raincoat factory. Laurence knew every line of every song Gilbert & Sullivan ever wrote. He made me learn phonetically the complete lyrics of "I am the very model of a modern major general" at the age of seven, which did wonders for my appreciation of the English language but very little for my street cred in primary school. Laurence knew that Gilbert was another true subversive. Parliament, the class system, the navy, the law, the monarchy and the artistic pretensions of Victorian society all came in for Gilbert's withering scorn and Laurence's approval. It was only later that I discovered Gilbert was just as much a part of the establishment as the institutions he was satirising.

I think Uncle Laurence would have approved of Topsy-Turvy. It contains the right amount of corrective to the uncritical sanitised versions of the story we have seen and heard in previous years. Jim Broadbent restores Gilbert to the towering and frequently dislikeable figure of historical reality. Gilbert & Sullivan must not be allowed to become the exclusive property of the blue rinse brigade who follow the show with the score on their laps. So give three cheers and one cheer more for Topsy-Turvy as for Pinafore.

Colin Shindler's autobiography Manchester United Ruined My Life is published by Headline at £5.99. Topsy-Turvy is released on Friday.

fields.headline: Royal treatment
fields.standfirst: Four years ago, the Royal Court theatre was hot, uncomfortable, prone to floods - and structurally unsafe. Beautifully renovated, it's a place of dark adventures and real magic.
fields.trailText: Four years ago, the Royal Court theatre was hot, uncomfortable, prone to floods - and structurally unsafe. Beautifully renovated, it's a place of dark adventures and real magic.
fields.body:
Alan Bennett nearly fell to his death from an insecure fourth floor window. Harold Pinter railed against the creaking of seats in an auditorium that tended to flood. Terry Gilliam liked the noisy cascade of water that emanated from the ladies lavatory during soliloquies: it brought a touch of reality, he would say, to the make-believe world of theatre. Five years ago, it was derided by the Times for being so tatty, and celebrated by the New York Times as the finest theatre in the world. Welcome to the Royal Court theatre in London's Sloane Square.

Few audiences or critics have ever doubted that the Royal Court has produced some of the finest new plays of the 20th century; but the building, first opened in 1888, was wobbly from the start. By 1995 it was on the way to being downright dangerous. The health and safety people were on the case.

Enter the lottery and an £18.8m grant via the Arts Council that, along with donations from the Jerwood foundation and private donors, enabled the Royal Court's English Stage Company, under the artistic direction of Stephen Daldry, to rebuild the Victorian theatre from top to toe.

The results are superb. Because the old building was in such a parlous state, Daldry and his architects, Steve Tomkins and Graham Howarth, decided to reconstruct it in an imaginative way, so that it's often hard to tell what's old and what's new. The depth of texture is delicious. The Royal Court has been transformed into a dreamlike world, an architectural magic-lantern show. It's a greasepaint realm of shadows and half-light, a Famous Five experience of secret stairs and narrow passageways, of sudden views of the stage, of unexpected vistas across dressing-room terraces of the rooftops of Kensington and across to the urban theatre of the Palace of Westminster, Westminster cathedral and the London Eye.

As for the auditorium, it has to be one of the best. A tight, high space crowded under a dome that disappears into ethereal darkness, its balconies lit so quietly that we might be back in the world of gaslight, its creak-free seats sheathed in warm leather. The armrests fold up so more people can be crowded in if necessary, or if you want to sit a little more cosily than you do in most theatres.

It's hard not to rave about the Royal Court, especially if you remember coming here on summer evenings and, despite the quality of performances, wishing with the noise, people and heat that you hadn't. The theatre is now air-conditioned, the balcony bar is a treat and, although the building is still squeezed, Jersey Lily style, into its corsetted site next door to Sloane Square tube station, it's a delight to promenade through.

And not just for the audience. Actors will be astonished by the graceful new dressing rooms, rehearsal room, meeting room and distinctive lavatories that are cleverly arranged, Rubik's Cube fashion, in new extensions added by Tomkins and Howarth at the back of the building.

What you get, throughout the old parts of the building, is a Victorian feel without any of the frills of the century-old theatre that has been restored in "authentic period style" to within an inch of its life. The trouble with such restorations is that they are always too squeakily clean, overlit and somehow antiseptic. You rarely get the sensation in restored theatres, nor in over-scaled modern theatres, of the darkness, intimacy, sensuality and even danger that the world of make-believe needs if it's to transport an audience convincingly from the world.

Bennett's near death experience aside, the Royal Court has long courted danger artistically and been faced by danger without asking for it. Opened in 1888, its first heyday began in 1904 when inspired impresarios Harry Granville-Barker and John Vedrenne started to show untried and untested new plays by the likes of Yeats, Ibsen, Galsworthy and Shaw.

Too good to last? Perhaps, for by 1932 the Royal Court was a cinema. In 1940 it was blitzed. The London Theatre Guild pieced it together by 1952, and in 1955 George Devine and Tony Richardson began operating the English Stage Company from this physically uncertain base. The show went on - radical, experimental, a launch-pad for young playwrights, actors and directors - until the beginning of 1996. Which is when Daldry, backed by his trustees, began to rebuild the theatre with the young architects chosen through competition; the work has taken four years.

This might seem a long time, but the site is very difficult to work in. The Royal Court occupies a particularly restricted space, hemmed in by the tube station, Toni & Guy's (the hairdressers), the District and Circle line tracks that slice diagonally through its basement, crawling traffic, and, at the back, by what in the romantic imagination is the River Bourne coursing to the Serpentine, but what is today, more prosaically, one of London's major sewer outlets. This flows through a Roman-style Victorian brick tunnel behind the Royal Court before passing over the tracks and platforms of the station in a giant cast-iron tube.

It might well have been easier to knock the whole thing down and start again. Yet what Daldry and all involved wanted was to keep something of the atmosphere and fabric of the old theatre, to retain and even enhance the warm embrace of its interior. This hasn't meant simply restoring old and battered decoration: they haven't. It's the feeling they've worked on. The truly clever thing about the architects' work is that this feeling pervades the whole theatre, from the front door through to the new extensions at the back.

The basement has been dug out and now reaches to the underused traffic island of Sloane Square itself; this cavernous space is the Royal Court's new cafe and restaurant. It's open to the public, theatre-going or not, 12 hours a day. Like the rest of the theatre it is richly textured. The architects have stripped back the old theatre walls and left ducts and wires, sections of I-beams, iron panels and sockets on view.

Exposed Victorian ironwork combines with semi-dark lighting and secretive passageways to lend the newly remodelled theatre the feel of Captain Nemo's Nautilus. Virtually every detail is special and appropriate. Here's a crank to wind open the untreated steel shutters that protect views in and out of the changing rooms; the device might equally raise or lower a safety curtain. Here's an adjustable reading lamp that would be equally at home in a film set by Caro and Jeunet, creators of Delicatessen and The City of Lost Children.

Hidden away in the roof of the building is another small theatre. This eyrie of an auditorium is to be used, as it was, for new plays by untested playwrights as well as for monologues and performances that benefit from being enacted in an intimate atmosphere. The way up to this attic theatre is special. It's reached by a winding stair with dark-painted tongue-and-groove panelling that makes you feel as if you're on a childhood adventure into the roof of an old house, where aged teddy bears sit forlornly alongside long-forgotten rocking horses and abandoned clockwork train sets. The dressing-up box is somewhere up there; so, perhaps, is Alice's looking glass and even the tall cupboard that leads to Narnia. This atmosphere is achieved entirely by suggestion, prompted by the way space here is theatrically manipulated.

Daldry and the Royal Court team appear to have thrown away the architectural rule-book. The new-look Royal Court is, despite intelligent new interventions by Tomkins and Howarth, as far removed from the run-of-the-mill of lofty, all too airy, multi-purpose lottery cultural venues (and there will be plenty of these yawning our way this spring) as Cathleen ni Houlihan is from Cats. This one will run and run.

It's a greasepaint realm of shadows and half-light, a Famous Five experience of secret stairs and narrow passageways, of sudden views of the stage, of unexpected vistas across dressing-room terraces of the rooftops of Kensington and across to the urban theatre of the Palace of Westminster, Westminster cathedral and the London Eye. As for the auditorium, it has to be one of the best. A tight, high space crowded under a dome that disappears into ethereal darkness, its balconies lit so quietly that we might be back in the world of gaslight, its creak-free seats sheathed in warm leather. The armrests fold up so more people can be crowded in if necessary, or if you want to sit a little more cosily than you do in most theatres. It's hard not to rave about the Royal Court, especially if you remember coming here on summer evenings and, despite the quality of performances, wishing with the noise, people and heat that you hadn't. The theatre is now air-conditioned, the balcony bar is a treat and, although the building is still squeezed, Jersey Lily style, into its corsetted site next door to Sloane Square tube station, it's a delight to promenade through. And not just for the audience. Actors will be astonished by the graceful new dressing rooms, rehearsal room, meeting room and distinctive lavatories that are cleverly arranged, Rubik's Cube fashion, in new extensions added by Tomkins and Howarth at the back of the building. What you get, throughout the old parts of the building, is a Victorian feel without any of the frills of the century-old theatre that has been restored in "authentic period style" to within an inch of its life. The trouble with such restorations is that they are always too squeakily clean, overlit and somehow antiseptic. You rarely get the sensation in restored theatres, nor in over-scaled modern theatres, of the darkness, intimacy, sensuality and even danger that the world of make-believe needs if it's to transport an audience convincingly from the world. Bennett's near death experience aside, the Royal Court has long courted danger artistically and been faced by danger without asking for it. Opened in 1888, its first heyday began in 1904 when inspired impresarios Harry Granville-Barker and John Vedrenne started to show untried and untested new plays by the likes of Yeats, Ibsen, Galsworthy and Shaw. Too good to last? Perhaps, for by 1932 the Royal Court was a cinema. In 1940 it was blitzed. The London Theatre Guild pieced it together by 1952, and in 1955 George Devine and Tony Richardson began operating the English Stage Company from this physically uncertain base. The show went on - radical, experimental, a launch-pad for young playwrights, actors and directors - until the beginning of 1996. Which is when Daldry, backed by his trustees, began to rebuild the theatre with the young architects chosen through competition; the work has taken four years. This might seem a long time, but the site is very difficult to work in. The Royal Court occupies a particularly restricted space, hemmed in by the tube station, Toni & Guy's (the hairdressers), the District and Circle line tracks that slice diagonally through its basement, crawling traffic, and, at the back, by what in the romantic imagination is the River Bourne coursing to the Serpentine, but what is today, more prosaically, one of London's major sewer outlets. This flows through a Roman-style Victorian brick tunnel behind the Royal Court before passing over the tracks and platforms of the station in a giant cast-iron tube. It might well have been easier to knock the whole thing down and start again. Yet what Daldry and all involved wanted was to keep something of the atmosphere and fabric of the old theatre, to retain and even enhance the warm embrace of its interior. This hasn't meant simply restoring old and battered decoration: they haven't. It's the feeling they've worked on. The truly clever thing about the architects' work is that this feeling pervades the whole theatre, from the front door through to the new extensions at the back. The basement has been dug out and now reaches to the underused traffic island of Sloane Square itself; this cavernous space is the Royal Court's new cafe and restaurant. It's open to the public, theatre-going or not, 12 hours a day. Like the rest of the theatre it is richly textured. The architects have stripped back the old theatre walls and left ducts and wires, sections of I-beams, iron panels and sockets on view. Exposed Victorian ironwork combines with semi-dark lighting and secretive passageways to lend the newly remodelled theatre the feel of Captain Nemo's Nautilus. Virtually every detail is special and appropriate. Here's a crank to wind open the untreated steel shutters that protect views in and out of the changing rooms; the device might equally raise or lower a safety curtain. Here's an adjustable reading lamp that would be equally at home in a film set by Caro and Jeunet, creators of Delicatessen and The City of Lost Children. Hidden away in the roof of the building is another small theatre. This eyrie of an auditorium is to be used, as it was, for new plays by untested playwrights as well as for monologues and performances that benefit from being enacted in an intimate atmosphere. The way up to this attic theatre is special. It's reached by a winding stair with dark-painted tongue-and-groove panelling that makes you feel as if you're on a childhood adventure into the roof of an old house, where aged teddy bears sit forlornly alongside long-forgotten rocking horses and abandoned clockwork train sets. The dressing-up box is somewhere up there; so, perhaps, is Alice's looking glass and even the tall cupboard that leads to Narnia. This atmosphere is achieved entirely by suggestion, prompted by the way space here is theatrically manipulated. Daldry and the Royal Court team appear to have thrown away the architectural rule-book. The new-look Royal Court is, despite intelligent new interventions by Tomkins and Howarth, as far removed from the run-of-the-mill of lofty, all too airy, multi-purpose lottery cultural venues (and there will be plenty of these yawning our way this spring) as Cathleen ni Houlihan is from Cats. This one will run and run.

fields.headline: You must be joking
fields.standfirst:
What your office gags say about you

Gag factory
fields.trailText: Was Sophie Windsor having a laugh when she wore that fox fur hat on the slopes last week? There is a years-old office joke about Prince Charles and a fox hat (either you know it or you don't) and it occured to me that Edward's new wife was just doing her own, rather tasteless version.
fields.body:
Was Sophie Windsor having a laugh when she wore that fox fur hat on the slopes last week? There is a years-old office joke about Prince Charles and a fox hat (either you know it or you don't) and it occured to me that Edward's new wife was just doing her own, rather tasteless version.

Jokes are a vital part of British culture - we expect everyone to be funny apart from the queen - but business humour is under threat. The PC police gave it a sideswipe several years ago, pointing out - quite correctly - that the racist and sexist stuff was not appropriate. Now there is the 'serious' business climate most people are forced to work under, where stopping for a laugh can be a punishable offence.

If you work in a firm where laughter is still an option, though, you may like to see what your personal style of humour tells others about you in the office.

The professional gag-meister

You gather colleagues in groups and perform like a professional. Most of your gags are long, requiring lots of mugging and acting en route to the punch-line. You use the word "right" with tedious regularity, as in: "This horse walks into a pub, right?" You will never tell less than three jokes per session and the best ones last more than five minutes, with the build-up always being funnier than the punch line.

Verdict: You are a control-freak and a sadist. You know no-one can leave a group once a joke has started and you like to milk this attention for all it is worth. Your attitude to work is very tribal and you probably enjoy stopping the joke when someone from another department walks in.

You watch your audience trying to snigger, squirm and giggle long past the moment when smile-cramp sets in, knowing they will be forced to howl like hyenas through sheer embarrassment and/or exhaustion when you deliver your very weak punch line.

The wag

You don't tell jokes but you do delivery a barrage of "witty" lines and catch phrases. In fact most of your responses will be in comedic style to provide a shared joke with any colleagues that happen to watch the same programmes. Current chuckle-makers will include phrases like: "Okey-cokey, pig in a pokey", "I'll get me coat", "Suits you, sir" and "Can I phone a friend?".

Verdict: You have an identity problem insofar as you don't have one. Borrowing humour can be fine if the punch lines are current and fresh but their shelf life is limited and you could be showing your age. "I don't be-lieve it!", "Beam me up, Scotty" or "I'm free!" are fine examples of a dated repertoire. If you employ lines from telly ads you are in danger of sounding seriously stale and sad.

Knee trembler

No-one knows why you bother telling jokes - least of all yourself - because you are so appallingly bad at it. You even share this information with your audience prior to the joke-telling, as though confession will somehow make them more forgiving. Halfway through the long, tortuous process of listening to your unfunny story they will suddenly hear you announce that you have forgotten the punch line. This is supposed to be endearing but is, in fact, mind-bogglingly annoying.

Verdict: You are immature and manipulative, expecting colleagues to find you cute and winsome when you are being just plain stupid and annoying. You know you could have learnt the punch line but you chose to fluff it deliberately. Your attitude to work is the same. You dumb-down mercilessly, hoping colleagues will take pity and help you with some of your more tedious jobs.

Wind ups

Your jokes tend to be of the practical variety and you adore working long and hard on some of your better gags. Rude e-mails are one of your favourites and no Xmas office party is complete without your "clingfilm over the toilet pan" trick or the "private parts on the photocopier" routine.

Verdict: You are a bit of a sociopath and employ humour to exact revenge on the rest of the world. It is your way of hurting people but it can be forgivable if your practical jokes are genuinely well thought out and funny. If you are the sort of joker who goes ballistic if anyone cares to reciprocate in kind, though, you have a serious personality disorder.

One-liners

You have a knack for the one word or one line funny, which you will throw in at appropriate moments in the style of a heckler. The intensity of the gag will be increased by the fact that you show no other outward signs of being amusing. It is the speed of delivery and deadpan style that gets the laughs.

Verdict: Your business style is cynical and colleagues bent on new business culture will learn to fear you. There is much to mock in modern industry and being the one to do it will either lead to legendary status as "the one who tells it like it is" or redundancy.

fields.headline: A sublime partnership
fields.standfirst:
Kenny Barron/Regina Carter
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Kenny Barron/Regina Carter
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.body:
The payoffs of shouting for attention have often seemed to be on a hiding to nothing in jazz - a genre that frequently gets results via the understated and the oblique. This was evident in the clamour for encores that met the hypnotically subtle duo of young violin virtuoso Regina Carter and the fluent and experienced pianist Kenny Barron.

Regina Carter, the American jazz violinist, is an irresistible presence in her own right. Slight and undemonstrative, she exhibits a classical player's sense of dynamics and meticulous tone control, and the lower she drops her volume the more compelling she can be.

Barron was the perfect companion. A pianist of flawless technique and immense sophistication he galvanised his partner without crowding her. His own solos were like miniature improvised concertos.

Carter's thoughtfulness lent a muted quality to the music in its opening minutes, but then Barron developed There Is No Greater Love as a relaxed walking bassline with fragmented Thelonious Monk-like arpeggios, and the violin took on a looser playfulness. Billie Holiday's Hush Now, Don't Explain drew on Carter's most classical aspect, and became a tone poem of sighing, barely-released sounds, and softly shifting textures. In jauntier guise she eased Swing Low Sweet Chariot into a freewheeling account of Blue Monk, which Barron then cranked up into a walking boogie. The encores revealed more of Carter's flexibility, bouncing the bow on the strings to echo a Latin-jazz percussion section.

fields.headline: Hang on - that's my job
fields.standfirst: If your company plans to restructure, the chances are that it won't tell the workers. And support staff are the most vulnerable. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.trailText: If your company plans to restructure, the chances are that it won't tell the workers. And support staff are the most vulnerable. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
It came as a shock at Greenwich when the Millennium Dome's chief executive, Jennie Page, was abruptly forced to resign just over a week ago. In part, of course, this was because of the harsh nature of the termination, which is believed to have happened without caution or consultation. But it was also because none of the dome's employees was given any warning.

No doubt the recruitment of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the former Disneyland Paris executive who has taken her place, will bring about restructuring on a significant scale. Yet employees learned of his appointment with precisely the same haste and lack of regard with which Page was informed of her sacking.

If we're honest, the story hit a nerve because it is something many of us fear - and not without reason. The tale of the dome is symptomatic of the woeful state of many employers' internal communications.

"A surprising number of organisations fail to plan how they will tell staff about reorganising," says Angela Baron of the Institute of Personnel and Development. "They don't keep staff informed which inevitably results in rumours - and consequently stress and low morale - becoming rife." Even where there isn't harmful hearsay, she says, sudden news of restructuring, without careful planning about how staff will be told, can leave employees feeling uninvolved and undervalued. This in turn can lead to lack of motivation, anxiety and bitterness. Indeed, Page's departure is reported to have been badly received among the Dome's staff, who were fiercely loyal to her and received similar loyalty in return.

Management consultancy firm Collinson Grant Consultants found that of the companies polled for its latest survey, 82% had restructured during the past five years, and three-quarters admitted to experiencing unrest among staff. Many of the companies reported that it was not unusual for staff to become antagonistic, with worryingly large numbers leaving as a result.

Restructuring is particularly bad news for support staff. As Baron says, "They know all too well that secretaries are usually the first to go when downsizing is on the cards. If that isn't bad enough, they often have to cope with their colleagues' worries. After all, most staff assume that secretaries know everything that is going on because they are most likely to be 'in' on the relevant meetings and have access to the relevant documents. They tend to hassle the secretaries for the lowdown even when the secretaries don't know a thing."

Marilyn Davidson, organisational psychologist at the university of Manchester institute of science and technology (UMIST), adds: "In a climate where job insecurity is high, employees get more frustrated than ever at rumours about downsizing. Since they can't risk venting this in the direction of their superiors, their assistants often appear to be the next best option."

Susan Major, a 35-year-old PA in the City, has experience of the frustrations of uninformed colleagues. "In one case where I honestly did not know any more than the other staff, an employee snapped, 'Are you on their side or ours?' They expect - rightfully - that at the very least, you should be able to point them in the right direction for whatever information is available."

Elaine Carter, a careers adviser, believes that the secretary's first course of action should be to point this out to managers. Even in cases where the rumours turn out to be nothing more than idle gossip invented by bored employees, the importance of communication should not be underestimated. "There is evidence to suggest that the absenteeism and inquisitions resulting from a rumoured, or badly communicated, company reorganisation can increase the PA's workload three fold. Knowing this will almost certainly kickstart bosses into responding."

Of those companies that have recognised the benefits of communication, the most successful have set up a communications planning team, reports Collinson Grant. Invariably, a manager leads the team, and additional members include personnel and support staff. The primary objective is to deal with unhelpful rumours, but other potential problems such as stress-related illness and lower productivity should also be taken into consideration. Collinson Grant found that this can triple employers' chances of achieving all their goals and improve staff commitment by up to a quarter.

At Bass Brewers and Vertex Data Science, two companies that have faced restructuring, an intranet system was set up. Other companies opt for more traditional methods of communication such as weekly - and if necessary, daily - team briefings. But written communication, it seems, is not the best way forward - 40% of employers interviewed by Collinson Grant have a written communications policy, but half think most staff have never read it.

Email and one-to-one meetings in person, according to the communication experts, have become the best ways of imparting information, with most employees claiming they are far superior to a telephone conversation.

"Even if you don't end up having a formal team to discuss the best way of communicating with staff, regular meetings with the manager enable secretaries to go back to the office knowing exactly what they are at liberty to disclose, who they can refer concerned employees to for further information, and when the next public instalment is due," says Carter.

Tales of appalling management are rife. Consider the real-life case of the chief executive who looked for a feel-good way of showing staff they were valued during a period of restructuring. In a flash of inspiration, he organised an office party. "Enjoy yourselves," he told employees during a brief speech at the start of the evening. "And don't worry about the redundancies. We'll let you know about those at the next party." To the chief executive's genuine surprise, his joke was met with silence.

Business psychologist Marie Mosely claims that secretaries who do not work for enlightened organisations should still make it a rule to hang on to their integrity. The fact that the word "secretary" has "secret" in it should serve as a reminder of their need for discretion, she cautions. "Remind your colleagues of this, adding that as soon as you are allowed to pass on any news, you will. It will show them that you are not on anyone's 'side' and that decisions about relaying information are out of your hands."

Ben Williams, a chartered corporate psychologist who specialises in change management, believes it is worth reminding yourself as well as everyone else that restructuring is not always bad news. "It can mean a change of premises, a merger or a reshuffle of roles. It can even mean a promotion."

Time will tell whether Pierre-Yves Gerbeau's new broom at the dome will solve the troubled attraction's difficulties. But Jennie Page for one, not to mention the rest of the company's staff, is likely to feel that the sudden changes in structure might have been better managed.

webTitle: Spray invention to help end tight situation

fields.headline: Spray invention to help end tight situation
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Whether it is the career ladder or the social ladder that you want to climb, there is no defence against the most irritating ladder of all - the ever-growing run in a snagged pair of tights.
fields.body:
Whether it is the career ladder or the social ladder that you want to climb, there is no defence against the most irritating ladder of all - the ever-growing run in a snagged pair of tights.

Liz Chantree, a 27-year-old businesswoman from Rayleigh, Essex, has come up with a simple solution. She has invented a spray which stops little holes in tights and stockings from running into huge ladders.

Runaway, a spray in a case the size of a lipstick, looks set to replace the less than satis factory dollop of nail varnish as the favourite stop-gap measure to save women's nylons.

Mrs Chantree, who first patented the idea eight years ago, decided to put an end to the irritation after she laddered her tights on the way to a business meeting. "You can't understand how annoying this is unless you're a woman."

The spray has aroused the interest of at least one high street chain and she hopes to have it in the shops later this year.

"It's taken eight years of patient research and development to perfect it," Mrs Chantree said. "The spray is clear and almost invisible, non-irritant and doesn't stick to the skin."

fields.headline: Dangerous work
fields.standfirst: When Andrew Pennington was murdered last month, other MPs' assistants were not surprised. Sharon Grant on why parliament should put the job on a professional footing - and fund it accordingly
fields.trailText: When Andrew Pennington was murdered last month, other MPs' assistants were not surprised. Sharon Grant on why parliament should put the job on a professional footing - and fund it accordingly
fields.body:
The Commons has got back to business after last month's murder of Andrew Pennington, assistant to MP Nigel Jones. Among themselves MPs' staff murmured. Though all were appalled, none was surprised. All of us had tales to tell of terrifying confrontations with irate or disturbed constituents. We are buffers between MPs and the public, and Andrew Pennington tragically lost his life doing just what we do every day.

Everyone agreed that it was not so much MPs who need protecting: after all, MPs are in Westminster most of the week, surrounded by policemen and all manner of security systems. We, on the other hand, spend some or all of the week in dingy constituency offices, sitting-ducks for anyone with a grievance, real or imagined, against our bosses. While most MPs return for the weekly surgery, for the rest of the week we cope with the casework and the callers, our phone numbers and location widely advertised.

Most people think either that MPs pen every letter personally, or that our elected members have vast offices with teams of staff. The reality is neither. MPs receive an annual allowance of £46,000 to cover everything, including staff salaries. At most, MPs will have two poorly paid staff, stretched to provide support for their member both in the House and in the constituency.

The constituency office therefore is likely to be a shabby establishment, and there is seldom money to spare for security measures to be installed. To create the impression of accessibility, the office may well be a shop front, open all hours to anyone who wants to call. The vast majority who turn up to our weekly surgery are pleasant, ordinary local residents, and often you can use your MP's authority to resolve their problem by making representations to government departments or agencies.

There is no training for this kind of work, no career progression or security of tenure, and there is no formal legal or parliamentary basis for it. Yet it carries huge responsibilities. You are regularly faced literally with life or death situations - the family facing deportation to almost certain persecution, the patient waiting for life-saving treatment, the battered wife on the doorstep with her children and with nowhere to run. And, yes, the mentally ill, the drug addict, the ex-offender, and the obsessive in various states of distress, often mouthing threats and obscenities. Drama is never in short supply.

The trend to community care, and the closure of other advice services, have meant the path to the MP's door is well worn nowadays by deeply troubled and frustrated people. Similarly, the televising of parliament and saturation coverage of politics in the media has brought an explosion in the personal approaches to MPs in recent years. Whereas they used to be a last resort, MPs are increasingly the first port of call for those at odds with officialdom of any kind.

MPs have become celebrities, but there are few celebrities whom you can see face to face each week, just down the road. The level of professional support that they need to meet rising expectations at a local level, in reasonably secure conditions, cannot be supported by existing funding.

Some argue that MPs should not be glorified social workers, and that this is a distraction from their real job of making laws and running the country. Another view is that intimate contact with constituents keeps MPs in touch with the public, acts as a check on officialdom, and gives meaning to "democracy for ordinary people".

I did not know Andrew Pennington but, from what I read, I am pretty sure he would have taken the latter view. Like all of us who work for MPs, he knew that you really could make a difference to people's lives by taking on the powerful on their behalf.

It would be a fitting memorial to him if parliament were now to take a closer look at our work, to put it on a proper professional footing, and to give it the resources it deserves.

 Sharon Grant has been PA to Bernie Grant MP since 1987

fields.headline: Never mind McLaren
fields.standfirst:
The Filth and The Fury
Berlin film festival
****
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText:
The Filth and The Fury
Berlin film festival
****
fields.body:
"The best thing that could happen to these people is death," says a councillor of the Sex Pistols in Julian Temple's The Filth And The Fury. He is talking on television after the Pistols responded to a particularly daft question with the word "fuck". It is difficult to comprehend the hatred born of terror that Sid Vicious, Johnny Rotten and co gathered round themselves as they laid out the markers for punk back in the 70s. They wanted to get rich, get laid and say something, too: "to force our own working-class opinions into the mainstream, which was unheard of in pop music at the time". They were "arseholes" with attitude.

Those are the words of John Lydon, alias Rotten, and Temple lets him be the chief spokesman for the group in this fascinating documentary. Temple digs up so much old footage that you get a real sense of the time as well as of the band, contradicting Malcolm McLaren, their manager, almost every step of the way. The hypocrisy they faced was, the film suggests, a good deal more wicked than anything the Pistols sang or said. And their tragedy was that the mainstream ate them for breakfast in the end, aided by McLaren's greed and, in Sid's case, by drugs. "We were just too young to deal with it all," Lydon says.

The film would be hilarious if it wasn't also so sad. The bollocks came from both sides, but it is easy to prefer the band's brand to that of those who queried their right to exist. The film's strength is that it lets them tell their own story, and it adds weight to it with images of the Britain they thought had betrayed ordinary young people like themselves. Great research and a good argument.

fields.headline: Racism by another name
fields.standfirst:
New laws are promised, but the onus will be on workers to prove discrimination. As Finola Lynch discovers, many feel this will do little to change things
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: New laws are promised, but the onus will be on workers to prove discrimination. As Finola Lynch discovers, many feel this will do little to change things
fields.body:
Do your colleagues tell tasteless race jokes? Is the dress code at your workplace stopping you from practising your religious beliefs? Have you noticed that, for no obvious reason, colleagues have been promoted before you even though they were recruited after you?

If you are familiar with any of these scenarios it is possible that your workplace is displaying signs of what has come to be described - after the protracted Stephen Lawrence inquiry - as institutional racism. It is not just the Metropolitan police force which is guilty; the culture in many of our offices discriminates against people of ethnic minority origin. But the worrying thing is, companies and staff are often unaware of it.

"Most employers don't understand the current racial discrimination legislation," argues Nicola Dandridge, head of equality for employment law firm Thompsons, "and they certainly don't know how to implement it."

Institutional racism is not just about straightforward, ugly prejudice, such as deciding not to employ or promote somebody because of their skin colour. Indirect discrimination is covert, even unintentional, but it still keeps certain racial groups out of jobs. Workplace and employment policies, codes of conduct and even dress codes can cause indirect discrimination if they impact negatively on somebody from a different racial group. No matter if the discrepancy is cheerfully tolerated. It is still racism, whether or not we admit it.

Most of us need only to look around the office to see what is going on. Legislation on indirect discrimination has been in place since 1976, but the statistics suggest we have a long way to go. Black employees are more likely to have higher level qualifications - more than 20% have degrees compared to 16% of white employees - yet only a quarter are managers compared to around a third of their white counterparts. A fifth of black part-timers are working voluntarily because they can't get a full-time job.

"Some people will argue that the lack of black employees is down to them having fewer qualifications and skills," says Kamaljeet Jandu, policy officer for the TUC's equal rights department. "But try asking another question. Is it because on a subconscious level you can't imagine your manager being black?"

The government's announcement last month that it intends to tighten up the current race relations bill followed a campaign by bodies such as the commission for racial equality (CRE) which argued that the current laws did not go far enough. Until now, legislation on indirect discrimination has covered only employment practices in the public and private sector. The amendment will mean that every aspect of public sector services, from police stop-and-search powers to admissions policies in schools, could in theory be subject to anti-discrimination lawsuits.

The government has also stipulated that public sector bodies now have "a statutory duty to promote equality". It is still unclear how this will work in practice, but it does suggest that every sector will have to look closely at its career structures and workforce and account for the lack of black and Asian faces in senior positions.

So does this mean that positive discrimination is now compulsory in offices where there are few black and brown faces? The TUC thinks not, arguing that "positive action", rather than quota-setting, is the way forward. Jandu says: "You take action which broadens the recruitment base, rather than making sure the next five appointees are black. It's about advertising a job in the black press and within black communities. You ensure people doing the selection process have sufficient training." He argues that ethnic monitoring should be mandatory in every office: "One way you can overcome racism is by literally counting heads, monitoring the workplace and identifying indirect racism as it happens."

But not everyone is convinced. Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors, fears employers will be flooded with spurious claims of racial discrimination. "Using statistics alone is very, very crude, and what does the word 'indirect' actually mean? From the employer's point of view, it's going to be dreadful."

But Dandridge argues that since current race legislation has so far failed to reach its own targets, even the new laws may not go far enough. "In the new legislation there is no obligation on the employer to make sure they don't discriminate. There is only the right for the employee to pursue a claim. We need more pro-active legislation." Putting the onus on the employee to take action against racial discrimination, she argues, will mean few bosses are brought to book.

fields.headline: 'Rip-off' inquiry goes on
fields.standfirst: Minsters pursue supermarket investigation despite study showing shoppers are not being overcharged
fields.trailText: The government yesterday vowed to press on with its drive to investigate "rip-off Britain" despite an official survey concluding that British shoppers are not being overcharged in most cases.
fields.body:
The government yesterday vowed to press on with its drive to investigate "rip-off Britain" despite an official survey concluding that British shoppers are not being overcharged in most cases.

A competition commission inquiry into claims of supermarket price-fixing, due to be completed in the summer, and another into car sales will both continue, despite calls from superstores for the investigation into their business to be brought to an early end.

Ministers were yesterday seeking to play down embar rassment over the government's high profile "rip-off Britain" campaign, following the publication of a study indicating that claims of high street rip-offs are largely unfounded.

The study, commissioned by the department of trade and industry and carried out by independent researchers AC Nielsen, looked at the prices of goods in London and Manchester, Paris and Lyon, Hamburg and Düsseldorf and Atlanta and Chicago.

It found that the majority of prices of everyday goods, including food, clothes and leisure items, are roughly the same as on the continent and in the United States. Britain proved the most expensive for eight out of 56 of the surveyed items, including CDs, Sega Dreamcast game consoles, ground coffee, tinned dog food and toilet roll. It was cheapest for three items: men's shirts, Kellogg's cornflakes and chocolate chip cookies.

Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister who pushed a reluctant DTI to commission the survey, last night insisted that research into price comparisons would continue.

"We have just got to try and produce the figures," he said. "If it looks as if we really are being ripped off in any area then we really have got to do something about it. But if the figures indicate that maybe prices are pretty competitive then we have got to acknowledge that as well."

Ministers privately expect the car price inquiry to reveal big mark-ups for British consumers over their continental counterparts. They point to a recent European commission report highlighting significant price differences between the UK and mainland Europe.

The Nielsen research has been seized on by retailers as evidence that British consumers are not being exploited. The British Retail Consortium called on the government to drop claims of "rip- off Britain" and urged a move from the pricing debate to an examination of the barriers to price convergence.

Sainsbury, pressing for a swift end to the competition commission, said: "We believe it is RIP to rip-off Britain".

Tim Mason, marketing director of Tesco, said: "This survey recognises we are a force for price cutting. In the past three years, food prices have dropped by 8% and we won't stop there."

Dr Howells insisted that he had ordered the price comparisons survey simply in response to an absence of adequate figures, and had not set out to reach specific conclu sions. He admitted he was surprised at Britain relatively strong showing, but added: "There are clearly some discrepancies and now it is a case of ripping apart these figures."

 According to a survey due to published this morning, Tesco is the only British supermarket group to reach the top ten rankings in a European comparision of retailers in terms of their sales.

The research by Retail Intelligence shows that while UK companies fail to make much of an impression in the top 10, they account for more entries than those of any other country - with a total of 64.
